sentences.text: There are three formal levels of discipline: elders are responsible for deciding when a judicial committee is required.
Court action involving proceedings of a secular court is a "separate discussion".

When a baptized Witness is accused of a serious sin–generally, a practice considered disreputable or a brazen disregard for Watch Tower Society moral standards, such as sexual misconduct or apostasy for example by promoting teachings contrary to Jehovah's Witness doctrines–a judicial committee is formed to determine guilt and hand down discipline.

The three primary types of discipline are: Disfellowshipping (shunning) is the most severe form of discipline administered; it is reserved for cases in which a baptized Witness is considered unrepentant.

Disfellowshipped individuals are shunned by members of the organization, with only family members living in the same home and congregation elders meeting potentially to extend an offer for reinstatement speaking with them.
Business and employment relationships with disfellowshipped individuals may be maintained if contractually or financially obliged.

It is believed avoiding social and spiritual fellowship ensures the moral cleanliness of the congregation and may also help the shunned one to come to his senses, recover and take steps to rejoin the congregation, "Jar his memory", hence come back to Jehovah through a "change of attitude".
Shunning of disfellowshipped or disassociated individuals is also regarded as helping to protect the congregation from unnecessary emotional distress.
Individuals who disassociate and resign are described in Watch Tower Society literature as wicked and thus are also shunned.
Disfellowshipped or disassociated individuals may be reinstated if deemed repentant.
Some serious sins committed by formerly dedicated Witnesses which do not merit disfellowshipping are kept confidential.
Reproof is a step less severe than disfellowshipping; it is typically imposed for a repentant Witness guilty of a serious sin.
The repentant sinner may be required to relinquish any appointed position in the congregation and the individual is denied certain other privileges such as the ability to offer prayer at meetings.

Nonetheless, spiritually and socially the reproved individual is not shunned and can continue to interact normally with their colleagues and, with the exception of their lost privileges, fully able to sail within the congregation.
Marking differs from reproof; It is a disciplinary measure in which non-necessary social interactions are curtailed but spiritual fellowship is maintained.
Marking can be used in cases when, amongst a congregation a member persistently engages in behavior that violates Biblical principles, though falls short of a serious sin.
In 1969, the Cubs, led by first baseman Ernie Banks, seemed destined to win when Durocher's squad took a commanding lead in the newly created National League Eastern Division by mid-August.

Ken Holtzman pitched a no hitter, defeating the Atlanta Braves 3-0 on August 19, to increase the Cubs' lead to an insurmountable 8 games over the second place St. Louis Cardinals and 9[1]12 over the third place New York Mets.
Two weeks later on September 2, the Cubs' record was 84-52 with the Mets in second place at 77-55.

Then, a Cubs' losing streak converged with a Mets' winning streak. They lost the final two of a series with Cincinnati, and when they returned to Chicago, the lowly yet recently revitalized Pittsburgh Pirates (who were under .500 at the time, but went 39-23 the rest of the way) came to town (they would later finish 3rd).
The Cubs lost to the Pirates in a series that saw the Cubs blow leads of 5-2 (lost 9-2) and 4-0 (lost 13-4) in the first two games.
Fortunately, they had the lead in the ninth inning of the third game. The Cubs had a chance to stop their three-game skid before the second place Mets came to town for a crucial two-game series.
With a runner on second and two outs in the ninth, two strikes away from a victory, Durocher decided to have the Cubs' top relief pitcher, Phil Regan, pitch to Pirates' superstar Willie Stargell.
Four pitches later, Stargell put that idea to rest, hitting a pitch onto Sheffield Avenue for a two-run game-tying home run, as the Pirates lost 7-5 in ten innings.

The Cubs had now lost four straight, and headed off to Shea Stadium for a brief two-game set with the Mets, in which they lost both games to the surging Mets, bringing their record to an impressive 84-58, but now just 12 game ahead, instead of the 8 game lead they enjoyed before the streak.
But the horror was not over, as the Cubs headed to Philadelphia for a two-game set with the fourth place Phillies.
The Phillies took both games from the stunned Cubs, who had lost 8 consecutive games.
In the September 11 game, with the score tied and a Phillie on first base, Cub pitcher Dick Selma threw to third baseman Ron Santo on a pickoff play.
Santo, apparently not expecting a throw from the unpredictable Selma, and standing a good 15 feet from the bag anyway, did not catch the ball.

The runner advanced, leading to a run-scoring rally by the Phillies. After the loss, the Cubs stood at 84-60, while the Mets were now 85-57 (they would never relinquish control of first place), and the Cubs never recovered.

The Cubs broke the losing streak in St. Louis, but by this time, the "Amazing" Mets were in the midst of a 10 game winning streak, and the Cubs, with a worn out pitching staff, faded in all aspects of the game.
The Mets, who had lost a major league record 120 games just seven years earlier, ended the season by stunningly capturing the World Series title.
The Cubs finished with a record of 92-70, miraculously 17 games behind the Mets in just the final quarter of the 1969 season.
The name "house music" is derived from the Warehouse club in Chicago, where DJ Frankie Knuckles, a.k.a.
"the Godfather of House", played his sets from 1977 to 1982. After the Warehouse closed in 1983, the crowds went to Knuckles's new club, the Power Plant.
The music style became known as house. Producer Chip E.'s recording "It's House" may also have helped to make the term more popular.

In the Channel 4 documentary Pump Up The Volume, Knuckles remarks that the first time he heard of "house" as referring to a style of music was when he saw a sign that said "we play house music" in the window of a bar on Chicago's South Side.
In an interview, Knuckles joked that the new style of music he was playing was being referred to as "house" after the club, as in the line "let's go to the Warehouse and hear house music."

Later, people from Chicago who traveled to New York City and told club-goers w here they were from often experienced their counterparts response as "So, you’re from House," which eventually became "house music."

A 1986 article in the Chicago Tribune by journalist Lewis D. Segal claims that the term "house" came from "one of the early club-style DJ's, Leonard 'Remix' Roy" who put up signs at gatherings reading "We play house music."
According to author Richie Unterberger, the first use of the word "house" in regard to a musical genre was in a 1984 article by Michael Freedberg.
In the early days of house music the music was soul and disco influenced from "The Warehouse".
Later on in the history of house music, the genre became influenced by club culture.
Identity has become the term to be used in various traditions when researchers examine particular phenomenon.
The role of identity and its formation in occupational contexts is one means by which identity is emerging as a relevant construct in research.
It is even more of a struggle to have a positive identity in the workplace in stigmatized or dirty work (Hughes, 1951).

People are attracted to or repulsed by certain professions and jobs based, in part, on their perceptions of whether they will be able to enact a desired organizational self Trich and Trethewey 2005, p. 1697.

Work contexts themselves have varying stigmas and levels of prestige. For example, Tracy highlight a case for correctional officers on the ways the job is stigmatized as glorified maid (Trich and Trethewey 2005).
The ways in which people justify and attach value to their work has implications for their subsequent satisfaction and quality of life Tracy and Scott 2006, p. 338.
People who engage in jobs which may be considered types of dirty work must figure out ways to form an identity they can live with.
The opportunity to construct a positive sense of self at work is more difficult to realize if one's occupational work is seen as dirty in a broader societal context Tracy and Scott 2006, p. 79.
Dirt management does not mean simply that an employee may feel better about his or her work.

Employees who contend with society's questioning of the dignity of their work and have difficulties in defining their work as meritorious may be more likely to engage in client blame as a means of maintaining their identity Tracy and Scott 2006, p. 338.
With this acquisition Lutyens started considering other places. The Delhi Town Planning Committee was formally created in 1912 having George Swinton as a chairman, J.

A. Brodie and Edwin Lutyens as members and, after Lutyens started considering other locations for the site, they sent him to India in early 1912, meanwhile they drew up and submitted plans for both the north and the south sites, however, the Viceroy while preferring the north site declined the plans owing to the cost of acquiring the necessary properties therein.

The central axis of New Delhi was initially meant to be a north-south processional way (initially called the King's Way), intended to begin at a location on the northern edge of Delhi, at the junction of the Queen's Way, and would parade past the great All-India War Memorial Arch (now called the India Gate) and terminate at the Viceroy's Palace (now Rashtrapati Bhavan).

All-India War Memorial Arch, now called the India Gate Rajpath, Fireworks on Republic Day Designed in 1914 by Sir Edwin Lutyens to commemorate the Indian and British soldiers who died in World War I and the Afghan Wars The original plan called for this processional way to follow a straight line and thus pass through the Purana Quila, which would site the National Archives of India and across the Yamuna River.
During earlier days, tourists commended that it is a gateway of Earth and Heaven.

Then with the space it limited and with much heritage sites on the North side, the committee decided to shift the site to the South, where the Raisina Hill, formerly Raisina Village, used to be located.
The hill was levelled to make way for the Rashtrapati Bhawan, which was initially known as the Viceroy's House.
This would place the city atop Raisina Hill adjacent to Shahjahanabad (old city), while the line will now run a distance up to 6 miles and was mainly due south of the India Gate.

The reason for moving the city is that the land of the site originally proposed was too expensive to acquire and that the new site atop the hill in the south was thought to be of strategic importance.
Situated opposite to the hill, was the Lal Kot citadel, which was afterwards known as Dhillika.
The hill was located next to Dinapanah citadel, which was also believed to occupy the site of Indraprastha, at the time the legendary ancient nucleus of Delhi.

The foundation stone of New Delhi was moved from the site of New Delhi durbar of 1911–1912, the Coronation Pillar, and buried in plain view of the Viceroy's Staff, in the forecourt walls of the Secretariat.
The Rajpath, formerly called King's Way stretches from India Gate straight westward to Rashtrapati Bhawan.

Secretariat Building North Block, Secretariat Building, which houses Indian Defence Ministry, designed by Herbert Baker Rashtrapati Bhawan, formerly called Viceroy's House, is the official residence of the President of India.
The Secretariat building was designed by Herbert Baker, during the British reign, these two blocks housed the Council of State, the Central Legislative Assembly and the Chamber of Princes.
The two blocks are symmetrical. Parliament House was designed by Herbert Baker, which stands at Sansad Marg, which is parallel to the Rajpath.[40]

Copper, in the form of a natural alloy with gold called electrum, and perhaps already, by 9000 BC, in the Middle East; a copper pendant discovered in what is now northern Iraq has been dated to about 8700 BC; discovery of copper metallurgy is dated as early as 9000 BC in the Middle East[11].
It is the oldest known metal and was the first metal to be used by humans and is still one of the most widely used metals.
Before the use of copper, gold (used in varieties of jewelry) and iron from meteors (used for tools and weapons) were the only metals known to humans.
Commonly cited sequence of copper technology development: 1) cold working, 2) annealing, 3) smelting, 4) lost wax casting.
In southeastern Anatolia, all four of these techniques appear more or less simultaneously, at the beginning of the Neolithic circa 7500 BC.

[13] Like agriculture, copper smelting independently invented in several parts of the world: China before 2800 BC, Central America around 600 AD, West Africa around 9th or 10th century AD Investment casting, 4500–4000 BC in Southeast Asia; carbon dating has established mining at Alderley Edge in Cheshire, UK, at 2280 to 1890 BC Ötzi the Iceman (3300–3200 BC) was found with an axe with a 99.7% pure copper head[7]; high levels of arsenic in his hair suggest copper smelting experience with copper would contribute to the discovery of iron smelting; the Bronson theories on independent copper/bronze age in the Old Copper Complex in Michigan and Wisconsin from 6,000 to 3,000 BC natural bronze (an alloy with a high arsenic content) from ores rich in silicon, arsenic, and (rarely) tin, used widely in the Balkans around 5500 BC[17][citation needed]
But sleep does not affect the formation or retrieval of memories in the waking condition; it mostly affects consolidation.
Neuronal connections in the brain are strengthened during sleep; more sleep strengthens more connections and thence helps our brain stabilize and retain our memories.
Sleep enhances the retention of memory, possibly as storage occurs during consolidation, and transfer between the hippocampal and cortical systems of our brain.
During the period which we sleep, there is reactivation of memories during the SWS, and in that not all reactivated memories produce positive results.
Rather, there is qualitative change of memories taking place prior to the transfer to long-term memory.

When you're asleep, the hippocampus is busy replaying the day's events for your consideration and the neocortex is asking it to be quiet so it could fully digest those memories and move them to long-term storage.
Not sleeping enough weakens the connections between the brain cells associated with retaining what you studied.
Thus, lack of sleep not only leaves us unfocused so we don't learn efficiently; but even if the brain does manage to learn something new while sleepless, it won't be able to keep it.
Also some false memories can be transferred instead, if we don't sleep adequately. Therefore, enough sleep is a must for the memory to function its best.
One of the proposed functions for sleep is to improve consolidation of information as recent studies have shown that memory performance depends on getting enough sleep between training and test.

Also, neuroimaging studies show activity in the brains of human subjects during sleep that seem to correlate to activity which was recorded during the learning of new tasks, hinting that new memories may be solidified through such rehearsal.
T. Gilmartin, a Professor of History at Maynooth in 1890, wrote in Church History, Vol.
1, Ch XVII: The Arians wished to support the weight of an Ecumenical Council on their side.
This they hoped to accomplish by holding two Councils. Constantius ordered the prelates of the East to meet at Seleucia in Isauria, and those of the West at Rimini in Italy.
The Arians having previously held a Synod at Sirmium, to agree on a formula of faith, accepted the Homoeon, or declaration that the Son was like the Father.
The Councils met in the autumn of 359. At Seleucia there were 150 bishops, of whom 105 were semi-Arians.
These, faithful to their Homoiousion, (see: Homoiousian) would take nothing more or less.
Thus there was nothing agreed; and the Prefect of the pretended Council dissolved it.

Meantime Acacius, chief of the 'Homoean' party, went to Constantinople; there, in his own way, the Synod of Sirmium was confirmed by the 'Home Synod', that is, the lay-bishops who happened to be at Court; and a sentence was passed against the chiefs of the semi-Arian party.

At Rimini over 400 bishops met, 80 of whom were Arians and the rest orthodox. The orthodox fathers would admit of nothing but the Nicene creed, and the others insisted on the Sirmian creed In the end both parties sent deputies to the Emperor, to state to him that no agreement was probable, and to ask him that the bishops might return to their churches.
Constantius kept the deputies, and delayed for several months giving them any answer; thus he wearied out the orthodox bishops, and eventually got them to accept the Sirmian creed.
Of this Council St. Jerome said: The whole world groaned in astonishment to find itself Arian.

Initial reception of the series was also mixed. Ken Tucker of Entertainment Weekly deemed American Idol to be "the best and worst series at the same time – the best because it's the most telling snapshot of American pop culture at this very moment, and the worst because ... well, there's a long list of reasons, but let's use this succinct summation: it's bad for aspiring musicians, and thus bad for music.
"[166] He thought the show as a television was a consistently excellent show however thought it was as music a non-event.
Others however were wowed by the talent the show had managed to unearth. It has been called "sadistic musical bake-off"[167] as well as "a romp in humiliation.

"[168] A number of elements in the show received criticisms. Product placement for various products and services from the sponsors of the show appeared throughout the series – these were described as "idol' tawdry ton of commercialism meets the tawdry ton of patriotism".

[169] Karla Peterson of The San Diego Union-Tribune thought American Idol is a "conniving multimedia monster" and that "our TV shows now reflect our nation's nefarious compulsions until they have served up the Seven Deadly Sins plus a scoop of Eight Is Not Enough.
Like its mercenary ilk, the perky beast takes all that is good and sacred about our country and turns it into a lump of reconstituted evil.
"[170] The sending of the 2nd-season winner to the first anniversary of the September 11 attacks in 2002 to sing the national anthem at the Lincoln Memorial was also not well received.

Lisa de Moraes of The Washington Post quipped, "The terrorists have won," and also wrote: "And by that, we mean millions of young" American Idol fans "and a few fanatic speed-dialers who, despite Fox’s assurances to the contrary, are said to have influenced the outcome, had decided to turn this important site into just another cog in the 'Great American Idol Marketing Mandala'."[171]
After Vietnam, there have been many reasons cited for Yale's prominence in U. S. elections.
Many publications cite the campus activism culture fostered at Yale since the 1960s, and Reverend William Sloane Coffin's intellectual influence on future candidates.
Yale President Richard Levin thinks the university's dedication to developing "a laboratory for future leaders" is to blame for the phenomenon.
Levin has made this a priority since his inauguration, yet the professional emphasis has been in effect at Yale since Presidents Alfred Whitney Griswold and Kingman Brewster's reign.
Richard H. Brodhead, former dean of Yale College and current president of Duke University thinks, "We're [Yale] community-oriented in admissions, and there's some kind of volunteer tradition at Yale.

Gaddis Smith, professor emeritus of history at Yale, believes there's been "an ethos of organized activity" at Yale in the 20th century, hence John Kerry's leadership of Yale Political Union's Liberal Party, George Pataki's leadership of the Conservative Party, and Joseph Lieberman's management of the Yale Daily News.
Professor Camille Paglia believes the operative factor is a tradition of elitism via networking, "It [Yale] is a web of friendship and affiliations that you build in school.
CNN underlines that George W. Bush directly benefited from privileged admissions as "the son and grandson of alumni.

. . a member of a politically influential family. Still other reports, like those by writer Elizabeth Bumiller of The New York Times and senior Atlantic Monthly editor James Fallows, believe we can attribute Yale's prominence to the culture of community and cooperation between students, faculty, and administration, which eliminates egotism and cultivates allegiance to other people.
Once Link obtains the Master Sword, the curse placed on him by Zant is lifted and he is able to transform between wolf and human at will by using the Shadow Crystal he obtains.
Midna then leads Link to the Gerudo Desert where the Mirror of Twilight is located, the only known entrance to the Twilight Realm from Hyrule.
At the Arbiter's Grounds, the mirror is discovered broken, and the Sages inform the pair that Zant attempted to destroy it.
The Mirror of Twilight can only be completely destroyed by someone with royal blood, a blessing passed down to each ruler of the Twili, and Zant only succeeded in breaking the mirror into fragments.

The King of Thieves who attempted to steal the Triforce was named Ganondorf, and he live a hundred years prior, yet after failing to execute him, the Sages used the Mirror of Twilight to banish the leader of the Gerudo to the Twilight Realm.
With the assistance of a resistant force in Castle Town, Link and Midna recover the pieces of the mirror, fighting entities that have taken control of the mirror fragments.
They discover that Zant's magic has been allowing him to rule the Twilight Realm, and that Midna is the Twilight Princess.
Link and Midna enter the Twilight Realm using the restored Mirror of Twilight and they confront Zant.
Zant reveals that he received his power through his "god", Ganondorf, who aided Zant in his usurpation of the Twilight Realm and curse over the Twili as part of his plan to take over Hyrule.
After defeating Zant, Midna recovers the Fused Shadows and blasts Zant with one of them.
Midna soon discovers that Zelda sacrificed herself to save her and that only Ganondorf's death will result in her curse being lifted.

The two return to Hyrule and link confronts Ganondorf in Hyrule Castle. While a lifeless body of Zelda is suspended from the ceiling, Link strikes down Ganondorf, who possesses the body of Zelda to fight Link.
Eventually, Ganondorf takes the form of beast, yet Link successfully defeats Ganondorf. Midna recovers the body of Zelda and brings the princess back to life.
The legal themes in TKAM, particularly those events and scenes occurring outside of the courtroom, have aroused the interest of legal scholars.
Claudia Durst Johnson points out that lawyers have written more articles about it for law reviews than literary scholars have written for their journals.
The epigraph, for instance, by the nineteenth-century essayist Charles Lamb, reads, Lawyers, I suppose, were children once.

Johnson notes that even in captivity, Scout and Jem negotiate, sign pacts by spitting in their palms and shaking hands, and consult Atticus on laws — should Bob Ewell be allowed to hunt and trap out of season?

They go on trial, or rather people contravene social norms in informal courts: Mr. Dolphus Raymond is shunned for having a black mistress and half-breed children; Mayella Ewell is beaten for kissing Tom Robinson; Boo is given solitary confinement, a punishment worse than the judge could hand down.
In her own life, Scout contravenes social codes — and on some levels, laws — and is punished for them.

She won't submit to pretty clothes, jars for grades 1-3,' and Aunt Alexandra's fanatical attempt…to consolidate Cunninghams and Finches is imprisoning her in a pink cotton penitentiary preserved for long ago little girls.

Johnson notes that the novel…is about Jem's and Scout's developing consciousness of social codes and the way that people's relationships (defined by those codes) both fail and support the citizens of Maycomb and their little world.
The Qing dynasty treated its outer non-Chinese possessions as part of its imperial patrimony, with the emperor as Great Khan of the Mongols, patron of Tibetan Buddhism, and protector of Muslims.

This changed with the creation of Xinjiang province in 1884. In the setting of The Great Game, Yaqub Beg attacked the weak Qing dynasty Chinese forces during the Dungan revolt with British Empire support and conquered Xinjiang, declaring himself its Emir.
The Qing dynasty defeated Yaqub Beg and reconquered Xinjiang in the 1870sand then introduced the same political institutions as in China proper.

The Kumul Khanate, which joined the Qing empire as a vassal after assisting the defeat of the Zunghars in 1757, kept its status despite Qing Dynasty turned Xinjiang into a province in 1884 to late of the dynasty and even till 1930.
In Tibet, the British Empire launched an expedition of 1902–04, occupied Lhasa, and forced the Tibetans to sign an agreement.

The Qing court asserted Chinese sovereignty in response and in the Anglo-Chinese Convention of 1906, the British "agreed not to annex Tibetan territory or to interfere in the administration of Tibet, while China engaged not to permit any other foreign state to interfere with the territory or internal administration of Tibet."

Similarly, Qing authorities turned Manchuria into the "three northeast provinces" and set up the post of Viceroy of the Three Northeast Provinces to oversee these provinces, putting the total number of viceroys at nine in late Qing.
A theme associated with his movies is that parent-child relationships are not ideal, but involve reluctant, absent, or ignorant parents, especially fathers.
In Hook, Banning/ Pan is initially work-obsessed, but finally earns his children's respect.
A very famous instance of the absent-father device is that Elliot's father's absence in E.T.

In Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade, Indiana has a difficult relationship with his medieval literature professor father, who appears to have been more concerned with his Holy Grail research than with his own son; Professor Jones has the misguided idea that he taught "self-reliance" to Indiana by his distant parenting, a feeling Indy does not seem to share.
In Schindler's List, Oskar Schindler refuses to start a family. In Munich, Avner has a wife and baby daughter from whom he is separated.

There are exceptions to this too. Brody in Jaws is a dedicated family man, and John Anderton in Minority Report is tortured by the mysterious disappearance of his son a couple of years before the film begins.
Spielberg's own parents divorced when Steven was young, which had a great impact on the young Spielberg and was probably responsible for this theme in his films.

Many of Spielberg's characters come from or become broken families. Spielberg has said, "I come from a broken family, and I have a good part of my life been drawn to stories about strong families, or about weak families that will become strong through the course of the movie."

In E.T: The Extra-Terrestrial, Elliott's mother is a divorcée and his father is absent; Catch Me If You Can reveals very early on in the film that Frank Abagnale's parents were divorced; more obscurely, Jurassic Park contains a marked reference to Tim's parent's divorce.
More commonly, divided families among Spielberg's protagonists are unified by the end.
There is also a theme of reluctant father figures in Spielberg's films; Tim from Jurassic Park regards Dr. Alan Grant as a father figure.
Grant is initially reluctant, but soon overcomes this and the film ends with both children's heads resting on his shoulders.

John attempted to relieve Château Gaillard, again in an effort to protect the eastern flank of Normandy, counter-attacking at the Battle of Mirebeau: Philip had laid siege to the fort, and it was feared that the loss of Château Gaillard might result in the collapse of John's Norman defences.

[78] John planned a synchronised land and naval attack which proved to be, in the views of modern historians Warren Hollister and Clemence van Heinst, highly original and unusual for the time, but also, in Richard's evaluation, "a well-laid, sophisticated plan" that was well beyond the capabilities of the forces involved at the time.
[79] In any event, Philip prevented John's relief force from arriving and Chateau Gaillard later fell to Philip in March 1204.

[80] John attempted to distract Philip further south, bringing in allies to draw Philip's attention to the Breton front, and using the new Welsh loophole crossbows both to equip his forces, and as gifts to encourage potential allies.
[81] His campaign was hampered, however, by the effective defences of eastern Brittany and by John's lack of siege equipment.
John was probably successful in devastating much of Brittany, but did not deflect Philip's main thrust into the east of Normandy.
[81] Historians remain divided about the nature of John's military skills during the campaign, with most concluding that they were at best adequate.

John's situation worsened steadily. Philip and his predecessors had been carefully developing the relatively undeveloped eastern Normandy over several years;[82] John, by contrast, in taking over southern Normandy, had derived very little financial or political benefit from the region.
Richard had sold off the key castles in the area in order to raise money for his Crusade some years before, and the local barons were not inclined to support John.

[83] John's use of routier mercenaries in the region turned many against him.[84] Many of those facing John saw him as a "tyrant", and compared his behaviour to that of his immediate predecessors unfavourably.

[85] Consequently, following the fall of Château Gaillard that year John retreated south to safer territory, providing a basis for Philip to begin the campaign of attrition against John that would result in the collapse of Angevin power on the continent.
[86] John had either returned to England by December, and stripped his castle defences west of Château Gaillard in an attempt to create a new defensive line along the Seine.

Matters became worse when John's mother Eleanor died in April 1204. This removed a prominent and respected Angevin leader from the south of France, increasing the pressure on John's southern defences.

John was optimistic that he would be able to recapture the Duchy, but by 1204 that was seen as unlikely: Philip attacked southwards, taking Normandy and then targeting the Angoumois and Poitou regions.
[87] With John's main strongholds occupied or under siege by Philip, his position was becoming untenable, and John made no attempt to resist Philip's successful conquest of Normandy.
John remained blessed with significant naval resources, however, and proved relatively capable as a military commander in the surrounding areas of Poitou, which remained safe for him.
[88] In August 1204 Philip marched south again, taking Anjou and Poitou, leaving the Duchy of Aquitaine as John's last major possession on the continent.[89]
The Nintendo Entertainment System went through several venue changes for the full North American release: the "Deluxe Set", the "Control Deck", the "Action Set", and the "Power Set".
The Deluxe Set was the original US release in 1985 which retailed at US$199.99 ($475 in 2016).
[79] It included R.O.B., a light gun called the NES Zapper, two game controllers, as well as a pack-in multicart featuring both Gyromite and Duck Hunt.
The Control Deck[80] was first released in 1985 as a lower-cost alternative without the R.O.B.

accessory or the NES Zapper. Then in 1987 it was repackaged as the Control Deck bundle, retailing at US$89.99 with no pack-in game, and US$99.99 bundled with "Super Mario Bros."[79] The NES Action Set was launched in November 1988 for US$149.99 and it included the control deck, two game controllers, an NES Zapper, and a dual game pack containing Super Mario Bros. and Duck Hunt.

[81] The Power Set was launched in 1989 and it included the console, two game controllers, a NES Zapper, a Power Pad, and a triple game pack containing Super Mario Bros., Duck Hunt, and World Class Track Meet.
The console was also bundled with an NES Satellite four-player multitap for the 1990 "Sports Set".
It came with four controllers and a multicart containing Super Spike V'Ball and Nintendo World Cup.
Several additional bundle packages were available later, using the original model NES console.
The "Challenge Set" was released in 1992 for US$89.99 and it came with the console, two controllers, and a Super Mario Bros. 3-in-one cartridge.

[79] The "Basic Set"[82] was released in 1987 for US$89.99[79] without a game. Then in 1992 it was repackaged with a user's manual for the console and the 1992 Official Nintendo Player's Guide, a book featuring detailed information for every NES game released up to that point in time.[83]
The School of Communication has also produced many notable actors, actresses, playwrights, screenwriters and directors, in particular for film, television and theater.

Notable alumni from the School of Communication include: Ann-Margret, Warren Beatty, Jodie Markell, Paul Lynde, David Schwimmer, Anne Dudek, Zach Braff, Zooey Deschanel, Marg Helgenberger, Julia Louis-Dreyfus, Jerry Orbach, Jennifer Jones, Megan Mullally, John Cameron Mitchell, Dermot Mulroney, Charlton Heston, Richard Kind, Ana Gasteyer, Brad Hall, Shelley Long, William Daniels, Cloris Leachman, Bonnie Bartlett, Paula Prentiss, Richard Benjamin, Laura Innes, Charles Busch, Stephanie March, Tony Roberts, Jeri Ryan, Kimberly Williams-Paisley, McLean Stevenson, Tony Randall, Charlotte Rae, Patricia Neal, Nancy Dussault, Robert Reed, Mara Brock Akil, Greg Berlanti, Bill Nuss, Dusty Kay, Dan Shor, Seth Meyers, Frank DeCaro, Zach Gilford, Nicole Sullivan, Stephen Colbert, Sandra Seacat, and Garry Marshall.
Film and theater directors Gerald Freedman, Stuart Hagmann, Marshall W. Mason, and Mary Zimmerman are also graduates.

Former Chicago talk show host Lee Phillip Bell (1952–86) co-created the Daytime Emmy Award-winning TV soap operas The Young and the Restless (1973) and The Bold and the Beautiful (1987) with her husband William J.
Bell. Broadway theatre notable alumni include Sheldon Harnick, Stephanie D'Abruzzo, Heather Headley, Kristen Schaal, Lily Rabe, Walter Kerr and designer Bob Mackie.
The co-founders of the Chicago-based theater companies Steppenwolf Theatre Company and Lookingglass Theatre Company are NU alumni as well as the founder of Broadway in Chicago, Arny Granat.
Melville Shavelson served as President of the Writers Guild of America [West]. The founder and former director of the American Theatre Company in Chicago, Stuart Oken, is an NU alumnus.

Northwestern alumni also formed the company that creates the popular series of educational software, JumpStart.

The school is well known for its top-notch Radio-TV-Film and Theater graduates.

In New York, Los Angeles, and Chicago theater circles, especially, Northwestern has a significant influence in the theater and commercial acting scene, leading some to and the not-uncommon reference in some circles to a "Northwestern mafia."
The biological or social marker that is recognized as leading to adult sexuality varies across cultures.

Yet, menarche (menstruation for girls) and semenarche (first ejaculation in boys) are commonly used markers within many societies to further define a transition stage, either implicitly or explicitly.
Furthermore, the recognition and freedom given to an adolescent in their sexual development is highly based on culture.
For example, some cultures are restrictive, in where sexual activity among the unmarried and the adolescents is not accepted.
In fact, there is a separation of girls and boys as they go through adolescence within these cultures.

If violated, public shaming and physical punishment may be enacted. Contrary, less restrictive cultures allow for boys and girls to have free sexual expression and contact with each other in public and in private.

It is important to note that a less restrictive culture may still disapprove of teenage pregnancy, where another culture may view procreation within the teenage years as successful, but only after adolescent marriage has taken place.
Additionally, some cultures may be highly permissive, where open sexual activities among unmarried teens are tolerated and at times actively encouraged.
Despite the stance a culture takes on the sexual attitudes of its adolescents, a difference is often set for the role of sexual expression of the male and female.
This social construct can be enforced through laws or instilled as the social norm.
In addition, lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgendered youths can experience homophobia and bullying, and disclosure of their sexual orientation may be stressful.
Thus, the latitude a culture establishes regarding sexual attitudes influences the beliefs and lifestyle of its adolescents, and even how they are viewed.
Queen formed in 1970 following the demise of the band Smile, of which May and Taylor were members.
Mercury was a fan of Smile and encouraged them to experiment with more elaborate stage and recording techniques.
He joined in 1970, suggested the name "Queen", and adopted his familiar stage name.
Deacon was recruited in February 1971, before the band released their eponymous debut album in 1973. Queen first charted in the UK with their second album, Queen II, in 1974.
Sheer Heart Attack later that year and A Night at the Opera in 1975 brought them international success.
The latter featured "Bohemian Rhapsody", which stayed at number one in the UK for nine weeks and helped popularise the music video format.
The band's 1977 album News of the World contained "We Will Rock You" and "We Are the Champions", which became anthems at sporting events.
By the early 1980s, Queen were one of the biggest stadium rock bands in the world.

"Another One Bites the Dust" (1980) became their best-selling single, while their 1981 compilation album Greatest Hits was the best-selling album in the UK and is certified eight times platinum in the US.

Their performance at the 1985 Live Aid concert has been ranked among the greatest in rock history by various music publications. In 2005, an industry poll ranked it as the best live performance in history.
Mercury died in 1991 of bronchopneumonia, a complication of AIDS, and Deacon retired in 1997.
Since then, May and Taylor have performed under the Queen name with vocalists Paul Rodgers and Adam Lambert.
In November 2014, Queen released a new album Queen Forever. The album features tracks that include vocals from original band members Freddie Mercury.
The Empire is named after its capital city of Vijayanagara, whose ruins surround present day Hampi, now a World Heritage Site in Karnataka, India.
The writings of medieval European and Persian travellers, and the literature in local languages provide crucial information about its history.
Today, the ruins of the empire constitute one of the most important archaeological sites in India.
Vijayanagara Empire's legacy includes the monuments spread over South India, the best known of which is Hampi.
Different temple building traditions in South and central India came together in Vijayanagara Architecture style.
South Indian mathematics flourished under the protection of the Vijayanagara Empire in Kerala.
In the 14th century, the mathematician Madhava of Sangama Grama founded the well-known Kerala School of Astronomy and Mathematics.
Over the next three centuries, this school that employed numerous distinguished mathematicians further expanded Madhava's works.
The most famous among them were Parameshvara, Nilakantha Somayaji and Jyeṣṭhadeva.
Efficient administration and vigorous overseas trade brought new technologies such as water management systems for irrigation.
The empire's patronage enabled fine arts and literature to reach new heights in Kannada, Telugu, Tamil, and Sanskrit, and Carnatic music evolved into its current form.

The Vijayanagara Empire created an epoch in Southern India in emphatically defending Hinduism against the onset of Islam, and preserving Hindu dharma, which enabled the distinctive culture of South India to flourish.
The Empire reached its peak during the rule of Sri Krishnadevaraya, when Vijayanagara armies were consistently victorious.

The empire annexed regions formerly under the Sultanates in the northern Deccan and the territories in the eastern Deccan, including Kalinga, while maintaining its influence over the south of the India subcontinent.
Many important monuments were either completed or commissioned during the time of Krishna Deva Raya.
Vijayanagara went into decline after the defeat in 1565 at the battle of Talikota.
The empire was founded in 1336 by Harihara I and Bukka Raya I of the Sangama Dynasty.
The empire rose to prominence as a culmination of attempts by the southern powers to ward off Islamic invasions by the end of the 13th century.
Vijayanagara failed to produce a viable successor after the defeat at the battle of Talikota and subsequently collapsed.

The National Football League preseason is highly structured in comparison to Major League Baseball, with the 32 teams each playing 4 games, 2 each home and away, with two of the teams each playing a fifth game, the Pro Football Hall of Fame Game.
The games are contested in August, with the training camp in the 4–5 weeks before that, to determine the rosters for the regular season.
Each team is allowed to have 90 players on its roster at the start of training camp.
By the end of preseason, teams must reduce their rosters to 53 players for the regular season.

Though the games' lack of local or national relevance lends some latitude in scheduling, there remain many longstanding restrictions and traditions concerning when, where and against whom a given team will play.

Unlike professional baseball and basketball, where teams regularly play exhibition games against non-league teams (and in the case of baseball, allow outside teams to host the major league team as part of a larger event), non-league games in the NFL are exceptionally rare; since a last-ever game against an independent team in 1972, the last non-NFL opposition of any kind came in 1976, and the last time an NFL team was ever the guest even was in 1974 (all but one such case have come in the preseason).

Also, unlike baseball and basketball games (but similar to professional hockey), teams will not use split squad games to try out more players, instead the entire team being limited in the number of exhibition games they may play.

[3] Games have been played in locations such as Europe, Japan, and Canada as an effort to promote the league worldwide, as well as Mexico and Australia; China was once proposed (and a game was scheduled), but a prospective game there eventually was canceled due to financial and logistical difficulties.
Since the debut of the International Series, all games in the series have been regular-season games.
Playing time in the preseason is allotted more equally to allow coaches to evaluate the entire roster, especially the second- and third-string players.

Star and veteran players typically play sparingly if at all in preseason games, while rookies may play most of the game and typically see more playing time during the preseason than they would in the regular season.

Many fans object to exhibition games, as players have suffered injuries in them and season ticket holders are required to purchase them as part of their ticket package, while under most circumstances, fans who buy individual tickets to those games are required to pay the full regular-season price.
[4] Numerous lawsuits have been filed against the NFL over the matter, but to date, none have been successful.
Alongside preseason exhibition, another exhibition game of sorts is the Pro Bowl.

Since 1970 the Pro Bowl has been played at the conclusion of the season (now referred to as an "exhibition game" though the league awarded a now-meaningless "conference championship" to the winning team through the 2009 Pro Bowl). Since 2011, the Pro Bowl has been played the week prior to the Super Bowl.
The palace, measuring 108 by 120 metres (354 by 390 feet) and 24 metres (79 ft)[10] high, contains over 77,000 m2 (830,000 sq ft) of floorspace.

[11] Smaller than the Royal Palace of Madrid, the Papal Palace in Rome, the Louvre in Paris, the Hofburg Palace in Vienna, or the Forbidden City ,[12] the Royal Palace of Stockholm, the Winter Palace in Saint Petersburg, or the Apostolic Palace, it is, however, larger than the White House in Washington, D.C.[13][14] The building is in the Belle Époque style of neoclassicism; having a garden-facing façade that, by design, resembles that of Neoclassical French architect Ange-Jacques Gabriel, as exhibited on his famous work, the Petit Trianon at Versailles.
[10] The palace is a rectangle, not including the central quadrangle, of 108 metres (354 ft) by 120 metres (390 ft).

[11] The façade measuring 108 metres (354 ft) across, known as the corps de logis, is the principal façade, containing the balcony known as the "centre room", with its famous central wrought iron and gilt railing, which is copied from that of Buckingham Palace, a château built near Chantilly for a Duke of Buckingham in 1830.
The palace is decorated with a flag, known as the Royal Standard, when the monarch is in residence at the palace.
In total, the palace has 775 rooms.[15] The principal rooms are contained on the piano nobile behind the west-facing garden façade at the rear of the building.
The centre of this ornate suite of state rooms is the Music Room, its large bow the dominant feature of the façade.[16] Flanking the Music Room are the Blue and the White Drawing rooms.

[17] At the centre of the suite, serving as a corridor to link the state rooms, is the Picture Gallery, long and lit from above, it is hung with numerous works including some by Rembrandt, van Dyck, Rubens and Vermeer; other rooms leading from the Picture Gallery are the Throne Room and the Green Drawing Room.
[18] The Green Drawing Room serves as a massive anteroom to the Throne Room, and is part of the ceremonial route to the throne from the Guard Room at the top of the Grand Staircase.
The Guard Room contains white marble statues of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert in Roman costume, set in a tribune lined with tapestries.
These very formal rooms are used only for ceremonial and official entertaining but are open to the public every summer.[17]

Madrasas were institutions of higher learning in much of the Islamic world, legally designated as waqf (charitable institutions built on designated property), a status that permitted donors and their descendants to retain control.
In the middle east, where madrasas were most common, this led to a proliferation of established madrasas in the 11th and 12th centuries.
In the West, however, madrasas were much less common due to the proscription of the donors' control over the waqf, under the Maliki school of fikh.
As for the madrasa of al-Qarawīyīn, one of the two madrasas to outdate the oldest medieval university, the University of suri lachapelle ,has only been considered a university since 1947.

The other, that of al-Azhar, did not include secular sciences in its curriculum like economics, engineering, medicine, and agriculture until reforms in the 19th and 20th century, and only included their teaching into its religiously oriented curriculum in 1961.
The fact is that many medieval universities spent hundreds of years as Christian cathedral schools and monastic schools before becoming independent universitas scholarium.
While they became more numerous about the same time as the first madrasas, their historical roots run even deeper, back to the 6th century AD, centuries before the first madrasas.

Unlike the medieval universities, which were corporations established independently from Catholic sects, the waqf that established the madrasas often excluded the teaching of non-orthodox religious sciences, like philosophy and natural sciences.

They signed Henry Rodriguez (people call him H‑Rod) to clean up the batting order and protect Sammy Sosa; therefore he go on to smash 31 home runs in his first Chicago season.
Kevin Tapani lead the squad with a career‑high 19 wins. Therefore the team felt a boost.
Rod Beck was the core of the bullpen. Moreover Mark Grace pulled off one of his best seasons.
*1998 the Cubs got swamped by the media: Sosa led the buzz and rookie wonder Kerry Wood was new eye‑catcher.
* Can you believe Wood's standout moment was his one‑hit game versus the Houston Astros, he tied the major‑league record of 20 strikeouts in just nine innings?
Because he piled up strikeouts, people started calling him “Kid K”; that same year he snagged the 1998 NL Rookie of the Year award.
In June, Sosa suddenly got hot; therefore, he smashed twenty homers, a new month record.
