Although attempts have been made to create Hebrew as the natural language of the Jewish people, the majority of Jews do not speak it as a primary language and the lingua franca of the Jewish diaspora is in fact English.

While in the past significant numbers of Jews have either been to speak Hebrew to a level where classical texts can be studied or spoken other Jewish languages such as Yiddish or Ladino as a first language into the early 20th century (for Yiddish), nowadays Hebrew is generally not known and languages like Ladino, almost extinct, and English has replaced Yiddish to a large extent.
Nowadays the three largest languages for Jews are Hebrew, English and Russian. Two other languages spoken by significant Jewish populations are French and Spanish.

Although the Jewish language spoken by the most Jews historically is Yiddish. Yiddish speakers declined a great deal with the Holocaust and with the conversion of Yiddish to modern Hebrew in the Zionist movement and Israel.
In a few countries, the language spoken by the Jewish community is different from the language spoken by the majority of the population.
In Quebec, for example, the Ashkenazic majority speaks English, while the Sephardic minority speaks French as its primary language.

Likewise, in South Africa, Jews speak English rather than Afrikaans. In the Russian case, both the Czardom and the Soviet Union changed the language of Jews by switching it from Yiddish to Russian and some of the other former Soviet countries followed this trend.
Nowadays Russian is the most common language of Jewish communities in Ukraine, Uzbekistan and among Ashkenazic Jews in Azerbaijan, Georgia, and Tajikistan.

North African Jewish communities, small and declining, have switched from multi-lingualism to French as a primary language in Algeria, Morocco, and Tunis, when most others retained Arabic as their mother tongue.
Terry Eastland in Ending Affirmative Action: The Case for Colorblind Justice, covers two main arguments for AA (rectifying historical discrimination and diversity).

She contends, however, that this was not the intended form of AA, The architects of affirmative action did not realize that its benefits would flow chiefly to precisely those individuals who did not need them-the middle-class minority.
She also maintains that AA affixes a label of stigma, entitlement and self-doubt for these minorities.
Eastland concludes with her belief that AA has posed significant risks with occasional rewards, She implies that if AA is ended, competition will become fairer.
The libertarian economist Thomas Sowell has suggested another potential harm within AA in his book, Affirmative Action Around the World: An Empirical Study.
Sowell argues that AA has prompted non-preferred groups (like whites and Asians) to self-identify as preferred groups and that the latter is the most beneficial from AA.

He also argues that due to privilege gained by AA, this policy has succeeded in benefiting the most privileged (upper and middle-classed blacks) of the preferred group whereas the non-preferred group (poor whites or Asians) has not had this luxury.

Sowell continues with the impact of AA and its impacted groups. He believes that AA has minimized the motives to succeed for both groups: the former because they don't need to and the latter because they feel that there is no point.
These combined effects minimized the possible gains of society and causes resentment of preferred groups.

Van Praag says that the Ming court formed official relations with Tibet for getting horses Van Praag (1965: 96), while Wang and Nyima reject that there were any missions between states at all, conjointly asserting that Tibetan areas were under Ming suzerainty because Tibetan religious leaders were Ming officials, yielding horses as a “corvée” tax, and thus the Tibetans were managing internal not external affairs Wang, Nyima (1994).

Sperling observes that the Chinese were at the same time buying horses in Kham, fighting the Tibetans in Amdo, and receiving embassies from Tibet in Nanjing, where he says the “Tibetan lamas who visited the Ming court did so primarily for the sake of facilitating commercial intercourse between the lamas’ wealthy entourages and Ming merchants and officials.” Sperling (2003: 275).

Kolmaš writes that “Ming emperors adopted a policy of laissez-faire as far as Tibet was concerned” and “due to the reduced numbers of their entourages, the influence of Tibetan retinues was rather limited” Kolmaš (1967: 79, 66).

He also writes that “from the Tibetan side, nevertheless, the idea of keeping up the tributary relationship with the friendly empire of the Ming continued to be attractive because the patronage of the emperor brought riches and influence.” Kolmaš (1967: 58).

Laird shows that the Tibetans “positively welcomed invitations to attend court because the value of gifts which the emperor presented to them when they brought tribute far outweighed that which they presented as tribute.” Laird (2002: 115).

Discussing the sending of silverware and Buddha relics, temple utensils and monks’ robes “by the thousand” as gifts to the Tibetan and Nepalese vassals of the Yongle Emperor, Tsai writes that “in his efforts to bring countries in the neighborhood of Ming China into his arms so that he could assume the glory, Yongle was willing to pay a small price.” Tsai (2001: 124).

6 The State Council Information Office of the PRC lists Tibetan oxen, horses, camels, sheep, fur products, medicinal herbs, Tibetan incenses, thangkas (painted scrolls) and handicrafts as tribute, for which the Ming reciprocated with gold and silver as well as satin and brocade, bolts of cloth, grains, and tea leaves.
Ming silk factories were producing silk apparel and household items “decorated with motifs associated with” Tibetan Buddhism SOCO, PRC (2015). 7

In 2012, two white women, LSU undergrad Abigail Fisher and Southern Methodist University law student Rachel Multer Michalewicz, sued the University of Texas over its "race-conscious" admissions policy, which is designed to comply with state law.
(Students who graduate in the top 10 percent of their high school classes are guaranteed spots at any public college or university in Texas under what's known as the "Top Ten Percent Law.")
Fisher alleged that the University of Texas denied her admission on the basis of race, infringing upon her 14th Amendment constitutional right to equal protection under the law.

The Supreme Court heard the case, academically dubbed Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin, on Oct. 10, 2012, and handed down a nebulous decision on June 24, 2013, postponing judgment and kicking the case back down to the lower court, asking the University to demonstrate that a suitably diverse student body could not be assembled without the use of racial classification.

The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled in July 2014 that the University of Texas could proceed with its "holistic" affirmative action program, and on Feb. 10, 2015, Fisher's lawyers again petitioned the Supreme Court, arguing that the Fifth Circuit erred again.
In June 2015, the Supreme Court agreed to rehear the case and is expected to rule by the end of its term in June 2016.
Unlike the Spanish milled dollar the U.S. dollar is based upon a decimal system of values.

The Coinage Act introduced the mill ($0.001), the cent ($0.01), the dime ($0.10) and the eagle ($10) as subdivisions of the dollar, with prescribed weights and composition of gold, silver, or copper for each.

The value of the coin has not been changed. However, only cents are in everyday use as divisions of the dollar; "dime" is used solely as the name of the 10¢ coin; "eagle" and "mill" are largely unknown to the general public, though mills are sometimes used in matters of tax levies , and gasoline prices are usually in the form of a decimal number of dollars per gallon, e.g.
$3.599, as of June 2024, is a typical gas price in the United States. When written, the price is usually written as $3.599/10, because there is no unicode symbol for the mill.
In the United States, the dime is a coin, the dollar is a coin or bill, and amounts of money under one dollar are written as ¢/c (not ¤/¤) or as a decimal part of the U.S. dollar.
1853 US Assay Office $20 gold coin Until 1857 an ordinary English-style d was used, but $ was widely used and ultimately prevented d becoming widespread in the United States.
The decimal point is used with money, and is called the "decimal point" or "point" (period) - never "dot".
(This is different from many parts of the world, where a middle dot or comma is used for the decimal, and a full stop or space is used as a thousands separator.)
Division by thousand is written as, usually in taxes: $3.65 6¾ mills or: $3.65.6 mills or: $3.65⅔ or: . Any coin or bill equal to or less than a dollar is a U.S.

Coin, while any bill above a dollar is in principle a Federal Reserve note, although gold, silver, and platinum coins valued up to $100 as a legal tender are produced, but have value in bullion far in excess of their monetary value.
Minting of a $100 coin has been authorized, but not produced. Both one-dollar coins and notes are produced today, although the note form is significantly more common.
Notes above $100 have been discontinued, and are therefore exceedingly rare, although notes as high as $10, 000 were at one time produced.
At one time "paper money" was produced in denominations of 50c, 25c, and so forth.
Gold coinage was produced and circulated in the form of at least $10, $20, and $100 coins, and exempted from some forms of currency regulation; this was discontinued, however, in the 1930s.
The Coinage Act of 1792, Section 9, defined "eagle" to mean a denomination of ten dollars, and subsequently came to be used to mean a gold coin of such denomination.
"Shinplasters" is a derogatory term that came to be associated with fractional currency.
In 1854, Secretary of the Treasury, James Guthrie, proposed a $100 gold coin, which he called a Union.
Additionally, he proposed a $50 coin, which he called a Half Union, and a $25 coin, which he called a Quarter Union. Thus 1 Union = $100.
The three dynasties that contested for control of northern India from the 8th to the 10th century were the Gurjara Pratiharas of Malwa, the Palas of Bengal, and Rashtrakutas of the Deccan.
The Pala Empire was eventually assimilated by the Sena dynasty, while the Gurjara Pratiharas fragmented into various Rajput states.
The Rajput kingdoms, Saptarishi, that arose in Rajasthan in the sixth century led to the formation of various small kingdoms in Northern India.
Some of those Rajput kingdoms are Chauhans of Ajmer, Paramaras of Malwa, Chandelas of Bundelkhand, Solankis of Gujarat.
A Gurjar Rajput, Chauhan Prithvi Raj Chauhan, was known for bloody resistance from revolutionary Turk Sultanates.
The Chola empire eventually declined in the 13th century, but it is regarded as the most significant Hindu empire to exist in contemporary history.
The Chola dynasty reached its peak under the rule of Raja Raja Chola I and Rajendra Chola I in the 11th century.
Rajendra Chola I successfully invaded parts of Southeast Asia and Sri Lanka. Lalitaditya Muktapida (r. 724 –760 CE) was an emperor of Kashmir belonging to the region's Karkoṭa dynasty.

The Karkoṭa Empire was a powerful Hindu empire, referenced in Kalhana's Rajatarangini and other chronicles that once dominated over south and central Asia from 625 to 1003 or 1101 CE, and at its height encompassed much of South and Central Asia.
It was the precursor to the Lohara dynasty. Lalitaditya (Muktapida) is remembered as the conqueror of both Muslims and Tibetans, who were trying to expand into the regions controlled by Kashmir.
The Kashmirian historian Kalhana, author of the Rajatarangini, describes him as the ruler of all of Northern India and Central Asia, and as far as Eastern Iran.

He marched through the Uttarapatha into Eastern Afghanistan, subjected the Kambojas, Tukharas (Turks of Turkistan or Turkmens of Badakhshan: the Tukhara of Swat–Gilgit–Dardistan and the Tukhara of Badakshan), the Bhauttas (Tibetians of Baltistan, Ladakh, Purang, Guge, Tsaparang and Tibet) and Daradas (Dards of the Chilas, Gurez & the Hunzas, Gilgit, Puian, etc.).
Then he marched north to subjugate the kingdoms of Pragjyotisha, Strirajya (Kamarupa) and Uttarakuru.

The Shahi (Devanagari: शाही), Sahi, also called Shahiya (Devanagari: शाहीय), dynasties ruled portions of the Kabul Valley (eastern Afghanistan), Gandhara (modern-day Pakistan), and present-day northwestern India (from the mid-7th century to the early 11th century).

Athanasius was a Christian theologian, a leader of the fourth century. In a letter to Epictetus of Corinth,[49] he relates how he derived support from the Martyrs who fell under Maximian in the Great (tenth) and last persecution , that of Christians by the gentiles.
He accompanied his uncle, the martyr, to synaxes, a term which refers to both Christian or philosophical gatherings.

The Synaxes of the God-Fearers, or Phobou Theou, were assemblies of Christians and Pious Polytheist Philosophers, suggesting that Athanasius may have received some of his education from such syncretistic philosophers.
[50] It was reported that he spoke with the martyrs before their deaths, and even the last words of the 98-year-old virgin martyr, Flora, during the first years of the tenth persecution.
[citation needed] The tenth and last persecution of Christians by the pagan Romàn was sporadic but more violently lasted in the East, especially in Egypt and Palestine (Euseb.
Martyr. Pal. Hieron. Epist). Alexandria, in which Peter of Alexandria, the 17th archbishop of Alexandria, was martyred in 311, during the late period of that persecution.

He is among the people Athanasius mentions as his educators. Peter's successor as Bishop of Alexandria was also among his teachers: Alexander of Alexandria (312–328) was an Origenist and is the first known mentor of Athanasius.

[51] Sozomen reports that "Saint Anthony [the Great] delivered him (Athanasius) to Alexander, bishop of Alexandria, and that the latter cherished him as a son, and taught him the doctrines and mysterious truths of the Christian religion.
It is likely that he had not yet accepted baptism. He subsequently became a priest, and was bestowed with the care of the church".
[52] Bishop Alexander "attends the council of Nicaea subject of Athanasisus and tells about the initiation of Athanasius as his book-holder".
Historian Sozomen writes: "Alexandros, the archbishop assembled everyone besides him and he ordered the children to act without leaving anything out.
Athanasius acted out the bishop and those who were with him the clerics of the church".

[53] In his first work as a young cleric, Against the Heathen – On the Incarnation (before 319), he used many references to Plato and Aristotle's Organon, which is characteristic of Origenist Alexandrine thought (like Origen he had small anterior knowledge of Aristotle).
[54] In his later writings he ceases these characteristic Platonic Orthodox references,[55][56] as he recognized, adopting the Aristotelian Dios, The Proparizomenos Theos, as his dialytic organ.
[57] He had knowledge of Letter V[58] (albeit more as later [Pseudo-] Plato), and we recognize some echoes of Aristotle's De Interpretatione.
Like Origen, and Theodore of Mopsuestia, his writing style is Socratic. He also was knowledgeable about other philosophical movements such as Neo-Platonism.
[59] In general, he modified the School of Alexandria's position in philosophy from an allegorist Philosopher type, like those of the past, such as Philo, Clement of Alexandria, Plotinus, and Origen.
On Homer's epic poems as Plato on his dialogues, both are on a level with the Hellē رتia.
In his later texts he was also using Homer (Hist. Ar. 68, Orat. iv. 29),[60] as quoted during his defence to emperor Constantius, he used a clarity of the study of Demosthenis (De Corona).

Evita was released to positive reviews from critics; Zach Conner from Time described it as a "glorious, sensuous, [and] fantastic" film and wrote, "You can forget about Madonna the self-important celebrity, because to our surprise, she's a talented, affecting actress.
And, what's equally surprising, Evita is a pretty good movie...In short, it is a relief to report that Evita is something to see, something to laud.
It has boldness, great casting and memorable songs. Once again Madonna confounds expectations.
She plays Evita with a poignancy to match her power, and finally proves herself an actress.
She makes Evita alive, desperately alive, full of ambitions, hope, audacity, and as the years pass, something scars.
Madonna offers a brittle, soft-spoken Evita, with flashing eyes, hesitant with fury...Yes, Madonna finally knows how to work on screen.
She has developed enough technique that we see the rage behind the fading smile.
'She had her moments,' sings the grieving Che, 'She had some style.' Madonna has it too.
Love her or hate her, she has focus, vision, and unmistakable star quality. Everybody wants Madonna-Eva, and everyone is watching.
"[110] Madonna was presented with her ninth Golden Globe Award, for Best Actress in Motion Picture Musical or Comedy, for her portrayal of Eva Perón.

She released three singles from the Evita soundtrack album, including "You Must Love Me" (which won the Best Original Song Oscar), "Don't Cry for Me Argentina", and "Another Suitcase in Another Hall".
At the 1996 Billboard Music Awards, she received the Artist Achievement Award, presented to her by Tony Bennett.

[111] On October 14, 1996, she gave birth to her daughter, Lourdes Maria Ciccone Leon, fathered by her personal trainer Carlos Leon,[112] Biographer Mary Cross writes that although Madonna often worried that her pregnancy would harm Evita by postponing its filming, she reached some important personal goals the year the film was released, becoming a mother and finally starring in a film for which she could earn critical acclaim.
"Now 38 years old, Madonna had at last triumphed on the screen. She had at last claimed her daughter, and she had at last become a competent actress.

In the same year she carried both accomplishments off with homages to Eva Perón (adopting an Argentina baby, mimicking her appearance in style and fashion, and testing the acting skills to portray her character in a movie and musical).
She had already reached another, perhaps more significant, turning point in her career: her relationship with Carlos Leon.
She had reinvented herself and her image in the public eye with the public acknowledgment of her second successful relationship and the birth of her new daughter.
Life imitated art. Art imitated life."[113] Madonna and Carlos later ended their relationship; she declared that they were "better off as best friends.
"[114] Following the birth of Lourdes, Madonna became more engaged in Eastern mysticism and Kabbalah, as she was introduced to Jewish mysticism in 1997 by actress Sandra Bernhard.[115]

Nevertheless, the Luftwaffe kept coming. With the Germans occupying Western Europe, the British expected an air onslaught and a renewed submarine offensive against shipping to cripple the British economy.
Both the Germans and the British realised the war would be won or lost through the production of material.
Liverpool and its port became the main targets for raids on Britain, receiving 68 raids in the war.
The heaviest losses were felt by the merchants. An estimated 39,126 long tons (39,754 t) of shipping was sunk with a further 111,601 long tons (113,392 t) damaged.
[91] MORI, the Ministry of Home Security, suspected a collapse in morale. It reported that civilians criticised firemen's efforts and wild rumours were widespread.
Some 500 people had to be rescued from collapsed buildings. One report read "Indiscriminate action against offenders unlikely.
Morale on the whole unimpaired and everybody busy but Emergency Service Personnel and nucleus of Hostels Staff near breaking point.
Serious delay in ambulance attendance owing to roads blocked. Large scale temporary emigration."
Half the 144 cargo berths were made unserviceable; 75 per cent of cargo space was also unavailable and several major junctions of the railways were forced to close.
[92] London, the principal port, and Hull, on the east coast and a conduit to the Atlantic convoys, were also attacked.

Of the 57 ships damaged, sunk or destroyed during the Blitz 80,000 long tons (81,000 t) was lost; 66,000 houses were destroyed and 77,000 people made homeless, 1,900 dead and 1,450 seriously hurt on one night alone.
[93] Attacks against London up to May 1941 made it clear that the morale, material and food crisis could impact the British war effort. In the northeast, the Hull Blitz devastated the city.
Some 92 raids fell soon after. People of Humber became "trekkers", arriving in towns each evening.
They came and left each morning. Striking railway workers complained that "trent trekkers" were emergent.
Targeted because of its ports and industries, the percentage of destroyed houses soared from 5 per cent to 15 per cent; three-times worse than London.

Panic spread in the capital, but despite the port being a major element in the supply chain (it handled one third of overseas trade), the attacks failed to disrupt rail, road and port facilities for long.[94]
The onset of adolescents engaging in romantic relationships occurs throughout teenage years.
When adolescents reach age of fifteen, 53% become involved in longer term relationships (more than one month) during an 18month period.
According to a survey conducted in 2008 by YouGov for Channel4 (UK) 20% teenagers aged 14–17 had sex prior to the age of 13. This might include experiences such as non-penetrative sexual activities.
The average age of first intercourse is 17. 0 for male and 17. 3 for female respondents (aged 15–44) according to a 2002 American study.

Longer term relationships also become longer as adolescences grow older, which might be due to not only the sexual maturation, but also the maturation of cognitive capacity to establish a romantic relationship.
For instance, it requires the cognitive capacities to establish a stable relationship component such as giving care to others, or being attached to an individual to stabilize the relationship.

However, these capacities do not crystalize until late-teen years. Establishing long-lasting romantic relationships would benefit leading adolescences having competencies for high quality relationship in future relationship, or establishing positive self-identity.
Overall, these suggest that healthy romantic relationship experiences during adolescents will contribute to positive outcomes in future.
Individuals who experienced high quality romantic relationships during adolescence will have increased commitment during early adulthood.
Romantic relationships increase not only self-esteem and self-confidence but also perceived social aspects.

For instance, romantically involved adolescence having positive self-confidence tend to have higher role conceptions such as a good partner; whereas, a negative experience in engaging in romantic relationships could be felt as low confidence.

Adolescents tend to form romantic relationships with people who are similar to them or within their demography usage of phrase unclearin terms of race, ethnicity, popularity, and physical appearance; however, some adolescents may have a trait to value diversity, which is more likely to be encouraged by girls.
Furthermore, adolescents who dated for first or second time are more likely to find a partner of same age.
Also, boys tend to date to same age or younger, while girls tend to date to same age or older.
The purported territories of the Ouyue, considered the predecessor of the kingdom of Yue, are shown in green.
In the second millennium BC, the area of modern-day Zhejiang was described as being within the sphere of influence of the mostly contemporaneous Erligang and later Shang civilizations.
The records of the Shang and early Zhou dynasties' histories are based on transmitted texts compiled many centuries later.
The area of what is now southern Zhejiang was inhabited by peoples collectively known as the Hundred Yue (Baiyue), such as the Dongyue (東越), Ouyue (歐越), and the Shan Yue.
The kingdom of Yue began to appear in Chinese historic records during the Spring and Autumn Period, and these sources placed Yue within the northern part of modern Zhejiang.
The "Song of the Yue Boatman" records an ancient Yue language The exact origin of the kingdom of Yue is unclear but the Yues are believed to have descended from the ancient Baiyue.
The founders of Yue had surnames (Si and later Ying), different from the royal family of Chu in the west, suggesting a possible, albeit distant, relationship between the two.
According to the Zuo Zhuan, Yue was a relatively insignificant state before its rise in the late 6th century BC, and was originally a vassal state of Chu.
Shiji claims that the rulers of Yue were descended from the mythical Yu the Great of Xia dynasty.
However, the Yue were first recorded to have fought in wars in northern China during the Spring and Autumn period.
From various historiographical evidence in ancient China, the Baiyue, and the Ouyue kingdom, appear to have been very different from other cultures in early and classical Chinese history.
Their level of leadership and martial advancement in comparison to the Wu is unclear.
One of the most significant, and perhaps the only known evidences, was The Song of the Yue Boatman (Chinese: 越人歌; pinyin: Yuèréngē; lit.
'Song of the Man of Yue') that was transcribed phonetically into Chinese, apparently sometime around 528 BC by people from the region of Hebei and Henan.
The "song" indicates a language that is otherwise unintelligible to not only speakers of Chinese, but also today's students of Chinese philology.
Other than Yue's language, it is also believed that the Yue possessed their own script.

As the Yue prepared to invade Wu, King Goujian's sword, one of the few artifacts that have survived from the period, was apparently made close or within Wucheng, with bird-worm seal script inscriptions that include scripts introduced to the Wu as well.
A number of notable personal names in Chinese history were associated with the Yue before its annexation by Chu and then by Qin.

Among them were Yuenü (Chinese: 越女; pinyin: Yuènǚ; lit. 'the Lady of Yue'), a famous swordswoman who taught the art of the sword, including a special brand of fencing that originated from the Yue. King Goujian of Yue was also famous for his perseverance during hard times.
If the contents of Yugong in the Book of Documents and Rites of Zhou can be taken to be factual, Dong'ou would be part of Yu province and Yue would be part of Yang province.

To check the rise of the kingdom of Wu, Chu helped strengthen the Yue. Under King Goujian, Yue fully recovered from its previous humiliation and annexed the lands of Wu (except for the two small states of Zhongwu and Zhou) in 473 BC.
Afterward, the Yue moved their capital to the former Wu capital in present-day Suzhou.
However, after Wu was eliminated, Yue didn't have any competitors in the south anymore.
Chu no longer needed Yue as an ally and relations between two states deteriorated.
Eventually, Chu destroyed Yue in 333 BC. After the fall of Yue, its ruling clan moved south and created the Minyue kingdom in Fujian.
The Yue territories would eventually be known as Kuaiji Commandery under the Qin dynasty.
Another kingdom made up of the Baiyue, known as Nanyue, was established in Guangdong early in the Han dynasty.
The destruction of Yue was documented in Chinese history in Shiji, and the Yue ethnic group were gradually merged into the Han Chinese or displaced.
Later on, the people of Wu and Yue became the ancestral ethnic group of modern Hangzhou and Shanghai.
In 222 BC, former Yue lands were annexed by the Qin Empire and its people would be included in Kuaiji Commandery in modern Zhejiang, initially with its headquarters in Wu in modern Jiangsu.
Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. The northernmost point is at Bargen, Schaffhausen, south to Chiasso.
The easternmost point is at Martina, Grisons, west to Chancy, and the westernmost point is at Chancy, in Geneva.
The southernmost point is located in Pedrinate. It contains three basic topographical areas: the Swiss Alps, the Swiss Plateau or "middle land", and the Jura.
The Alps are a high mountain range running across the central-south of the country, constituting about 60% of the country's total area.
The majority of the Swiss population live in the Swiss Plateau. Among the high valleys of the Swiss Alps many glaciers are found, totaling an area of 1063 square kilometres (410 sq mi).
From these originate the headwaters of several major European rivers such as the Rhine, the Inn, the Ticino, and the Rhône, which flow in the four cardinal directions into the whole of Europe.

The hydrographic network includes several of the largest bodies of freshwater in Central and Western Europe, among which also Lake Geneva (called "Lac Léman" in French), Lake Constance (named Bodensee in German) and Lake Maggiore.
Switzerland has more than 1500 lakes and contains 6% of Europe's stock of fresh water.

Lakes and glaciers cover about 6% of the national territory. The largest lake is Lake Geneva, in western Switzerland shared with France; it is followed by Lake Constance on the eastern border with Germany and Austria.

While the Rhône flows into the Mediterranean Sea at the french Camargue region and the Rhine flows into the North Sea at Rotterdam, Netherlands, both springs are only about 22 kilometres (14 mi) apart from each other in the Swiss Alps.
At the airport there is an army of ground crew to service the plane. It is guided into place by a tow tractor to one of the airbridges.
The plane is plugged into a ground power unit to keep its electrical systems running while its engines are off.

In the air sthey run off the power generated from the engines. Airbridge carries people out of the plane while the ground crew use mobile stairs. A plane is cleaned up after arrival by an airplane cleaning service.
Flight catering brings the food and drinks for the flight. The toilet waste truck plugs in to flush out the tanks on the plane and a water truck hooks up to fill the water tanks on the plane.
A fuel transfer vehicle brings aviation fuel from an underground tank to the plane.
A tractor with dollies shuffles the luggage between the terminal and the plane.
When unloading, luggage is passed off the belt onto a dolly for transport to the terminal.
Hi-loaders lift heavy luggage containers up to the cargo hold gate where the ground crew pushes them in.
After landing, containers are loaded into a hi-loader that lowers them down to ground level then loads them onto a dolly.
Conveyor truck carries an irregularly shaped or last minute luggage. Airbridge is used again by the new passengers when boarding the flight.

The plane is taken away form the terminal by tow tractor to a taxi way. The entire process is targeted at getting the plane out in 90 minutes. The airport bills the airline for the time the plane spends in the airport.

Beyoncé and Jay Z were married on April 4, 2008. She revealed their marriage in a video montage at the listening party for her third studio album, I Am… Sasha Fierce, in Manhattan's Sony Club on October 22, 2008.
I Am… Sasha Fierce was released on November 18, 2008, in the United States. The album introduces Beyoncé's alter ego Sasha Fierce, conceived during the making of her 2003 hit single "Crazy in Love".
It debuted at number one on the Billboard 200, giving Beyoncé her third consecutive number-one album in the US.
The album sold 482,000 copies in its first week, and produced the number-one song "Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)", and the top-five songs "If I Were a Boy" and "Halo".
Achieving the longest run on the Hot 100 of her career, "Halo"‘s success in the US helped Beyoncé attain more top 10 singles on the list than any other woman during the 2000s.
It also included the successful "Sweet Dreams", and singles "Diva", "Ego", "Broken-Hearted Girl" and "Video Phone".
The music video for "Single Ladies" has been parodied and imitated around the world, spawning the "first major dance craze" of the Internet age according to the Toronto Star.
The video has won several awards, including Video of the Year at the 2009 MTV Video Music Awards.
At the 2009 MTV Video Music Awards, Beyoncé won three awards including Video of the Year for "Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)".

Her other nominations included Best Female Video for "Single Ladies". The video for "Single Ladies" was the subject of the controversy during the ceremony when rapper Kanye West interrupted Taylor Swift's acceptance speech for Best Female Video to proclaim that hers was inferior to Beyoncé's.
When Beyoncé won the award for Video of the Year later in the show, she called Swift onstage to allow her to finish her speech.
In March 2009, Beyoncé embarked on the I Am... World Tour, her second worldwide concert tour, consisting of 108 shows, and grossed $119.5 million.
Presbyterian churches typically do not have statues of saints, nor the ornate altar more typical of churches of the Roman Catholic Church, but some Presbyterian churches will have a simple altar.

Normally the pulpit and/or lectern will be found on one side of the sanctuary and on the other side the communion table and baptismal font will be found. The Presbyterian church does not require any specific area for worship.
Most Presbyterian churches will not have a crucifix but rather a plain cross, or empty cross, as a sign that the cross was emptied by and for the risen Christ.

Church architecture is not mandated in Presbyterian polity. A "communion table", serving an analogous function to the altar in the Roman Catholic Church, is placed at the same level of the congregation. This table may sit in front of the "Chancel".

This area may be left open and is called the Chancel which might have a number of items such as a decorative altar-like table (sometimes called a credence table), choir loft, choir stalls, lectern and area for the clergy to sit.
Often a Presbyterian church will have an altar cross or a cross on the communion table or on a table in the Chancel.
The term "empty" cross is used by some Presbyterian parties to emphasize the resurrection, and that Christ is no longer dead, but risen, obtaining everlasting life.
In some Presbyterian churches, you may see a cross that has a circle at the center.
This is known as the Celtic cross, and is very common in Presbyterian churches.

The circle on the cross symbolises the resurrection of Christ and eternal life, while the Celtic cross itself is a symbol of Scottish heritage, coming to Ireland and Scotland with the Celtic migrations. The first use of the Celtic cross was not in Ireland or Scotland, but in Gaul.
A baptismal font will be located either at the entrance or near the Chancel area.
Presbyterian architecture is also illustrated by the use of symbolism. You may find decorative stained glass windows with pictures of biblical scenes.
These may also be found in other areas of the church for instance, in the doors, or on the exterior of the church.
You might also find ornate statues of Christ or other elaborate symbols of God.
For example, in some Presbyterian churches there may be a Last Supper located behind the Chancel.
St. Giles Cathedral is the Mother Church of Presbyterians. It holds a crucifix next to one of the pulpits.
This crucifix is not even a depiction of a crucifix but rather a modern designed cross that is very faint.
Hidalgo is venerated as the Father of the Nation even though it was Agustin de Iturbide who brought about Mexican Independence in 1821.

After independence, the question of which day to mark independence was debated between the day the war started, on 16 September, and the day it ended, on 27 September, when Iturbide entered Mexico City.
Political movements of the 19th century tended to prefer the Hidalgo revolt and have credited him with leading to the eventual independence of Mexico.
In the end, political forces chose to emphasize the liberal, anti-Spanish Hidalgo and not the conservative, pro Spanish Iturbide.
[54] Ultimately the day on which Hidalgo declared the end of bad government, 16 September 1810, was chosen, and the day is now celebrated as Mexican Independence Day.
Hidalgo has become iconized in Mexico's history to the point where he has become more of a symbol than a person.
Some of these icons are designed to portray Hidalgo as a martyr of injustice since his approach to Mexican independence was as one who did not like the way his people were treated.
Modern-day Mexico's image of Hidalgo is of a powerful symbol who was responsible for ending Spanish rule in Mexico.
He is viewed as the "precursor and creator of the rest of the heroes of the country.
"[54] Hidalgo's state in Mexico and the city of Dolores Hidalgo are both named after him.

His name and image can be seen extensively in Mexican politics and culture. Half a dozen of Diego Rivera's murals, Hidalgo's image in a flaming torch of liberty done by José Clemente Orozco, a mural by David Alfaro Siqueiros were commissioned by San Nicolas University in Morelia to honor Hidalgo.
In his own hometown of Dolores (Hidalgo), the town name was changed to Dolores Hidalgo in his honor. In 1869, the new state of Hidalgo was created.
He has appeared on Mexican currency, and the largest denomination bill, the 1000 peso note, issued in 2008, bears Hidalgo's image.

[55][56][57][58][59] Every year, at midnight on 15–16 September, the president of Mexico re-enacts the Grito from the balcony of the National Palace in Mexico City, with the ringing of the same bell Hidalgo used in 1810.
This scene, known as El Grito de Dolores, is repeated in cities and towns all over Mexico.
[6] Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla`s remains, with those of three other insurgents, José María Morelos, Vicente Guerrero, and Ignacio Allende, rest in the Angel of Independence column in Mexico City.
There is also a lamp lit to honor the murdered priests and sacrificed people who gave their lives for Mexican Independence.[60]

Initial torch bearer Sir Steve Redgrave, one of 80 bearers in London, told the press that he had received emails calling on him to boycott the relay, but added "I do sympathise with the people that are protesting and bringing it to the world's attention.

"[28] Francesca Martinez and Richard Vaughan withdrew from carrying the torch.[29] Konnie Huq chose to run and make her criticism of China.[30] Pro-Tibetan MP Norman Baker called on all bearers to boycott the relay.
[31] PM Gordon Brown was caught between protesters and the China lobby, and greeted the torch at 10 Downing Street but did not carry or touch it.
[32] In London, the BBC reported, the torch "has received blanket protection with a mobile protective ring surrounding it.
"[33] Demonstrations started from the time torch bearer Steve Redgrave began this leg of the event, at least thirty-five people were arrested.
In Ladbroke Grove one protestor got hold of Huq for a moment in an attempt to grab the torch but was quickly removed by the police and a fire extinguisher was set off.

[34][35][36][37] The Chinese ambassador carried the torch through Chinatown.[38] Relay organisers had kept the Chinatown route secret, at first claiming security issues and then revealing it on the day.
[39] The torch was put on a bus along Fleet Street to evade protesters, for security reasons, and was rerouted.

[38] In response to the pro-Tibet protests, more than 2,000 Chinese supporters lined the path of the torch relay, with placards, banners, and Communist Chinese flags in support of the 2008 Beijing Olympics; many Chinese supporters assembled in Trafalgar Square and held up Olympic Games slogan of One World, One Dream placards.[40]
The album also featured the hit single "Bohemian Rhapsody", which became the band's first UK number one.
It held the top position in the UK for nine weeks, and is Britain's third-best-selling single of all time, surpassed only by Band Aid's "Do They Know It's Christmas?"
and Elton John's "Candle in the Wind 1997", and is the biggest selling commercial single in UK history.

It also reached number nine in the US in 1976, while a re-release in 1992, following its use in the film Wayne's World, hit number two on the Billboard Hot 100 (and number one on the Modern Rock Tracks chart).
The band decided to make a video to go with the song; directed by Bruce Gowers, it was based on their Queen II album cover.

The B-side of "Bohemian Rhapsody" was "I'm in Love with My Car" and these two songs, together with "Death on Two Legs" and "You're My Best Friend" from the same album, all are featured in the 2018 film, Bohemian Rhapsody.
Bohemian Rhapsody is the only song in history ever to have sold a million copies (from their Greatest Hits album) on two separate occasions[97] and became their most recognisable hit.

This, coupled with the A Night at the Opera track "Love of My Life", led to the song and album often being hailed as Queen's finest work; "Bohemian Rhapsody" has been voted, several times, as the greatest song of all time.
[98] The band embarked on the worldwide A Night at the Opera Tour in November 1975, which covered Europe, the United States, Japan, and Australia.
Mercury's best friend and advisor, Capital London radio DJ Kenny Everett, played a huge part in giving the single and the band publicity by teasing fans with airs of the song before its release.

[99] They hired one of the best and most expensive studios of that era, Trilion, which updated their equipment and technology just to keep up with the state-of-the-art equipment Queen demanded for the video.

[100] They hired Trilion, which they were familiar with because it was a subsidiary of their ex-management company Trident,[101] who were, coincidentally, also creative and financial influences in helping Bohemian Rhapsody become popular.
[99][100] Although other bands had 'made videos' before, to air on specific TV shows,[102] Queen were the first band to create an accompanying 'promotional video' of a song for an album release.
[103] Rolling Stone stated: "Its influence cannot be overstated, practically inventing the music video seven years before MTV went on the air.
"[104] The second single from the album, John Deacon's "You're My Best Friend", became a Top Ten worldwide hit, peaking at number sixteen in the United States.

This was Deacon's first single. The opening track, "Death on Two Legs", was reportedly written by Mercury about Norman Sheffield, and the ex-management at Trident were also blamed by Mercury for much of the neglect of this period.[ citation needed ]
Cells require oxygen to maintain metabolism and produce energy. But, they can react to produce different, possibly mutagenic compounds.
Collectively these compounds are called free radicals —which most are forms of oxidizers— or compounds that in general react strongly with other compounds by taking their electrons.
It’s necessary to neutralize these radicals with antioxidants to avoid interfering with regular cellular maintenance, development and proliferation.
Basically, you want to avoid oxidizers so your cells can do what they do on a day-to-day basis.
Recently, some researchers came up with a interesting hypothesis on how consuming antioxidants evolved.

Some antioxidants, like glutathione and Vitamin C the body can create on it’s own, while others it needs to get- like with humans and Vitamin C and others like Vitamin A or K. In addition, some antioxidants, like Beta-carotene the body can convert into antioxidants, with Beta-carotene into Vitamin A.
Another example is that Vitamin D, which is created from cholesterol with sunlight.
In addition, the vast majority of antioxidants are phytochemicals and a subclass of phytochemicals, polyphenols.

These are collectively all the known antioxidants (about 4,000). Antioxidants create a synergistic network to combat free radicals, with some antioxidants taking free radical containing compounds, like glutathione or Vitamin E, and then reactivate them by taking the free radical, itself.

All the antioxidants vary on how well they take on different types of free radicals, they can’t possibly take on every radical, and how they function within certain environments (Vitamin A targets fatty regions, because it’s a fat-soluble antioxidant, while Vitamin C targets aqueous regions, being a water soluble antioxidant).

These antioxidants can neutralize free radicals, but can then carry new radical compounds that can be comparatively less or more dangerous than the original, but having all these antioxidants means they can make use of the new byproducts, preventing, or limit, the domino effect free radicals do.
Microbiological culture is a primary diagnostic method of infectious diseases. It consists of growing a specific microorganism in a special medium designed for it.
A sample taken from potentially diseased tissue or fluid is then grown in this medium which is then tested for the presence of the grown microorganisms.
Most pathogenic bacteria for example will grow in blood agar, which is a solid medium which provides nutrients necessary for bacterial growth.
Single bacteria grow into colonies that can be distinguished from each other by their aspect.
The characteristics of the colonies (size, color, shape, etc.) is usually characteristic of the bacterial species, its specific genetic strain, or both.
The growth of bacterial cultures is necessary to perform bacteriological antibiotic sensitivity testing for specific pathogens.
Microbial culturing is also required in order to determine the presence of viruses in virology, and eukaryotic microorganisms in parasitology .
Zhejiang manufacturing is concentrated in electromechanical industries, textiles, chemical industries, food, and construction materials.

Zhejiang has followed an export-oriented development path and has pioneered the establishment of the "Zhejiang model," characterized as "encouraging entrepreneurship, moving from small to bigger and better, responding quickly to changes in the market, prioritizing infrastructure, and producing in bulk at low cost both for the domestic and international markets".
As a result, Zhejiang has grown into one of the relatively wealthy regions in China and has the reputation of a province with the strongest private economy in China.

The "Zhejiang spirit" is celebrated throughout China. However, some economists (particularly those in China) worry that the "Zhejiang model" is not sustainable, since it is not efficient and largely dependent on public utilities like raw materials and energy, and the plethora of small businesses producing similar products have limited potential in moving into more advanced industries.
The province is increasingly concentrating on the high-tech and service industries.

There is a clear economic shift towards the geographic center of the province, with the economic importance of the north (centered on Hangzhou) gradually declining and that of the southeast (centered on Wenzhou and Taizhou) rapidly rising.
The per capita disposable income of urbanites was 24,611 yuan (US$3,603) and rural residents 10,007 yuan (US$1,465).
The Engel's coefficient was 35.8% and 38.4%, respectively. The per capita net income of rural households was 10,007 yuan (US$1,465), a year-on-year real growth of 8.1%.
In 2011, Zhejiang's nominal GDP was 3.20 trillion yuan (US$506 billion) with an annual growth rate of 9.0%.

Per capita GDP reached 44,335 yuan (US$6,490).[8] The primary, secondary and tertiary industries' value-added output was 116.2 billion yuan (US$17 billion), 1.1843 trillion yuan (US$173.4 billion) and 982.7 billion yuan (US$143.9 billion), respectively.

Jehovah's Witnesses believe that the present world order, or "system of things", which comprises non-Witness religions, governments, and businesses, is about to be replaced by God's new order under the messianic Kingdom of God.
[97][98] The current world order is regarded as being under Satan's control, and is characterized by crime, immorality, war, disease, and death.

[99][100] They believe that a final confrontation between the forces of good (as represented by Jehovah's Witnesses) and evil will shortly take place at Armageddon, after which all wickedness and suffering will be eliminated.
This will be followed by Christ's thousand-year reign over the earth, with the arrival of a new earthly society, the earth to be transformed into a paradise similar to the Garden of Eden.
They believe that Jesus Christ began to rule in heaven as king in October [112] 1914, and that Satan was subsequently ousted from heaven to the earth, [113] [114] resulting in "woe" to mankind.

They believe that Satan is the ruler of the current world order,[115][116] that disorder among nations, environmental destruction, bad attitudes of people, the declining morality of society, and the acceleration of violence and war indicate that the current world order is in its final days and will soon be destroyed at Armageddon.

[97][115][117][107] They believe that in 1914, the time of the gentiles or nations has ended and Jesus has been enthroned as king of God's heavenly kingdom, [112] and that the battle of Armageddon, which will end all crime, sickness, and death, as well as establish the ideal living conditions of Adam and Eve before their sin, will begin soon.

[118] Only non-Witnesses destroyed at Armageddon will be the Christian equivalent of those destroyed for their wickedness by the flood of Noah and God will deem only currently active Witnesses to be saved.
[119][120][121][108][109][110][111] _non-primary source needed[123] [124] God's kingdom, or government in heaven, is said to have been the focal point of Jesus' ministry on earth.
[97][102] They believe that the kingdom was foretold in the Hebrew Scriptures and was the means by which God expressed his rulership over the earth, [126] with Jesus as king ruling as God's agent.

[127] They believe the kingdom is the means by which Christ will fully accomplish God's original purpose for the earth, bringing the afflictions caused by human sin and the devil's schemes for this world to an end, after which humans will have the prospect of enjoying perfect living conditions and opportunities for happiness in line with God's original purpose.

They believe that those who desire to live forever must subscribe to their beliefs concerning Jesus, including that he is God's biblical Son, that his life was sacrificed for believing humans and that he is now king of God's heavenly kingdom.
[97][128][129][130] They believe that the kingdom of God will control the entire earth, with its members overseeing its administration on earth.

[102] All non-Witnesses who cannot be compared theologically to innocent children or equivalent to those unjudged, non-ancient, non-Israelite persons raised in the first resurrection, will be destroyed[109][110][111] and that after Armageddon, Christ will accomplish all the promises of paradise that Revelation's Book of Life predicts.

[132][133][134] The kingdom is said to be the means by which humans will be brought to an approved status in the eyes of God so that they no longer need the assistance of a mediator and will be ready for the final test at the end of the millennium.
According to Watchtower teaching, all of God's requirements for perfect obedience will have been met by the end of that time.

[135] Jehovah's Witnesses believe that the present world system of things,[119] or "the entire inhabited earth", [136] entered the last days in 1914,[115] and faces imminent destruction through intervention by God and Jesus Christ, leading to deliverance for those who worship God and hold to him as the only way of salvation.

[97][115][137] They frequently use the term "system of things", a phrase drawn from the New World Translation, as a reference to all or part of what they believe will be eradicated in the near future at Armageddon.
This includes governments, military powers, commerce, religion, and the "selfish" human mindset that directs these elements.

[119][139][140] Jehovah's Witnesses teach that all other present day religions constitute the "great harlot", Babylon the Great, described in the Book of Revelation, and that it will soon be destroyed by the United Nations, which they identify as the "scarlet-colored wild beast" of Revelation.

[143] This will mark the beginning of the "great tribulation". [144] After all other religions are destroyed, Satan will launch a final attack on Jehovah's Witnesses, which will prompt God to begin the battle of Armageddon, in which all earthly governments will be destroyed and all humans not counted as Christ's "sheep", or true followers, will be executed.
