The Qing’s Banner forces was organized by ethnicity; most troops were Manchu or Mongol, yet they also kept non‑Manchu bond‑servants listed under their Manchu masters’ households.
So it felt like a strange mix, right? Soon as the Qing edged toward conquest— therefore the number of Han Chinese under Manchu rule swelled hugely, far more than before.
To fix it, Hong Taiji rolled out Eight Han Banners; his way of hoping the problem would disappear.

Qing captured Beijing; therefore the Han count in those Banners grew quick. Back in the early Qing, when Shunzhi and Kangxi ruled, Han bannermen were a big deal – they grabbed most governor jobs and even outshone the Manchu bannermen and ordinary Han people.
Han didn’t just lead; they outnumbered all the other groups in the Banners until the mid‑18th century.
European travelers in Beijing? They called the locals *Tartarized Chinese* or even *Tartarified Chinese*.
Qianlong feared the Manchu identity slipping away, therefore the Eight Banners, they went back to looking at Manchu blood line, speech and traditions.
Therefore, by 1754 the purge began; many Han bannermen were forced out. Some were told to resign, others simply erased from the Banner rolls.

**Banner system switched: Han no more, Manchu now.** Basically, the Han garrisons in southern China — like Fuzhou, Zhenjiang and Guangzhou — they were replaced by Manchu Bannermen, so the old troops faded out.
The turnover knocked provincial Han Banner garrisons hard. In Beijing it was softer, **therefore** many Han Bannermen still stayed there.
Starting then the Han Bannermen’s status sank; the Manchu Banners, they just kept getting higher.

So in 1648, during Shunzhi’s reign, about three‑quarters of the Bannermen were Han, then by 1723 under Yongzheng it slid a bit to ~72%, and by 1796 – at the start of Jiaqing after Qianlong’s purge called the Disbandment of the Han Banners – it plunged to only 43%.
Qianlong singled out Han bannermen whose ancestors switched to the Qing after they broke the Great Wall at Shanhai Pass in 1644; to him they were Ming traitors and untrustworthy, huh?
He kept the defectors that joined the Qing before 1644 in Liaodong and the ones who went through Shanhai Pass; they were called the “followers of the Dragon” who crossed the pass.
According to the earlier accounts, soon after Muhammad's death in 632, a number of those who had memorized the Quran were killed in the Battle of Yamama by Musaylimah.
The first caliph, Abu Bakr (d. 634), subsequently decided to collect the book in one volume so that it could be preserved.
Zayd ibn Thabit (d. 655) was assigned the duty of collecting the Quranic verses.
Thus, a group of scribes, most importantly Zayd, collected the verses and produced a hand-written manuscript of the complete book.
The manuscript according to Zayd, remained with Abu Bakr who on his deathbed entrusted it to Hafsa bint Umar, his widow.

During the reign of the third Caliph, Uthman ibn Affan (d. 656), by which time Islam had spread to many parts of the world, differences in pronunciation of the Quranic Arabic prompted a concern in Uthman, who subsequently took the initiative to provide a standard copy of the Quranic text.
In 650, Uthman ordered a committee, again headed by Zayd, to use Abu Bakr's copy and prepare a standard copy of the Quran.

Within 20 years of Muhammad's death, the Quran was committed to written form. That text became the model from which copies were made and promulgated throughout the urban centers of the Muslim world, and other versions are believed to have been destroyed.
The present form of the Quran text is accepted by Muslim scholars to be the original version compiled by Abu Bakr.
Numerous places in the former Yugoslavia were named or renamed in honour of Tito during his lifetime and in the year after his death.

Some of these have since reverted to their original names. For example, Podgorica, Montenegro, was known as Titograd from 1946 to 1992; it is the only city to be renamed after Tito which was not his birth place, a provincial or national capital, or the site of a battle involving his partisans (see also List of places named after Josip Broz Tito).
Užice in Serbia became known as Titovo Užice (Tito's Užice) in 1946, but reverted to its original name in 1992.
The largest city with this honour was Titov Veles (now Veles, Republic of Macedonia).
The city of Drvar in Bosnia and Herzegovina was known as Titov Drvar from 1981 to 1991.
Streets in Belgrade, the capital, have also reverted to their original pre–World War II and pre-communist names as well.
[citation needed] One of the last such streets in Belgrade reverted to its original name in April 2004.
[209] The change has been the subject of controversy in some other former Yugoslav republics.
In 2004, the Antun Augustinčić statue of Broz in his birthplace of Kumrovec was decapitated in an explosion.
[210] It was subsequently repaired. In 2008, protests were held twice in Zagreb by advocates of a proposal to restore the name of the city square known as Marshal Tito Square.

The protest group, called Krug za Trg ("Circle for the Square"), was politically heterogeneous, and included figures from the centre-right Croatian Democratic Union, the Social Democratic Party and from non-governmental organisations.
[211] Another protest group, set up in opposition to the Circle for the Square, accused it of historical revisionism and neo-fascism.
[212][213] The group, called Građanska inicijativa protiv ustaštva ("Civic Initiative Against Ustašism") is supported by the Social Democratic Union.
[212] President Stjepan Mesić criticised the advocates of the proposed name change.
[214] The Croatian coastal city of Opatija has retained the name of Marshal Tito on its main street as well as the longest street in Opatija.
[215] Many of main streets in northern Serbian towns and cities still have Tito's name.

[216] In Sarajevo the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina one of the main streets is called Marshal Tito street, and in the park in front of the univeristy campus at Marijin Dvor there is still Tito's statue where people come and pay their respects.
[217][218] In Velenje, Slovenia, Tito Square (Titov trg) is the central square and the site of the world's tallest statue of Tito, some 10 m (33 ft) high.

[219] Tito's name was given to Podgorica Airport in Montenegro, the city was known as Titograd (Tito's City) from 1946 to 1992, and the capital city of Montenegro's current international airport still carries the code TGD.
[citation needed] A main bridge in Maribor, Slovenia's second largest city, is Tito Bridge (Titov most).
The central square in Koper, the largest Slovenian port city, is Tito Square.[220]
The Northwestern thorn scrub forests lie in a band around the Thar Desert, between the desert and the Aravallis.
Northwestern thorn scrub forests range from 250 to 500 mm of rain per year. Temperatures can reach as high as 48°C in summer and drop below freezing in winter.
The city of Jodhpur lies in this region, and is called the gateway to the Thar desert.
The Godwar, Marwar, and Shekhawati regions of Rajasthan lie in the thorn scrub forest zone, with the districts of Jodhpur, Jalore, Sirohi, Pali, Barmer, Nagaur, Churu, Jhunjhunun, and Sikar.
The Aravalli Range and the lands to the east and southeast of the range are generally more fertile and better watered.
This region is home to the Kathiarbar-Gir dry deciduous forests ecoregion, with tropical dry broadleaf forests that include teak, Acacia, and other trees.
The hilly Vagad region lies in southeastern Rajasthan, on the border with Gujarat.
With the exception of Mount Abu, Vagad is the wettest region in Rajasthan, and the most heavily forested.
Eastern and southeastern Rajasthan is drained by the Banas and Chambal rivers, tributaries of the Ganges.
Jhumar River originates from Aravalli hills near Rashidpura village in Sikar district and flows into the Shakambhari lake.
Rajasthan is also covered by the Thar Desert, which extends across the districts of Jaisalmer, Barmer, Bikaner, and Jodhpur.
India and Pakistan have disputed the ownership of the Thar Desert since 1965. The Indira Gandhi Canal (Rajasthan Canal) irrigates northwestern Rajasthan.
BBC and Sky Sports shared coverage between the 1988 and the 1997 tournaments, with both broadcasters showing the final and usually one match per round (plus highlights on Match of the Day).
ITV and Sky had joint coverage between the 1997 and 2001 tournaments, with both broadcasters showing two games per round and the BBC screening highlights.
The BBC and Sky then resumed joint coverage from the 2002 Cup until the 2008 tournament (BBC showing two or three matches and Sky one or two per round).
From the 2008–09 season, FA Cup matches were broadcast exclusively live in England and Wales by ITV (UTV in Northern Ireland).

[58] These matches were not shown by STV in Scotland. A total of 16 FA Cup games were shown each year on ITV, comprising the first-choice live match from each of the 1st to 6th Rounds, one semi-final match exclusively live, and the FA Cup Final itself.
Under the same contract, in the 2008–09 season, Setanta Sports showed three games and one replay from each of Rounds 3 to 5, two 6th round games, one semi-final and the final.
Setanta also had the rights to show ITV's FA Cup matches in Scotland where ITV's matches are not broadcast by STV.

Setanta Sports went into administration on 22 June 2009 and consequently, ITV secured the rights to show FA Cup football matches, as well as England internationals and FA Community Shield matches; with the agreement of the FA, it ended its existing rights contract with Setanta.
The FA Cup broadcast rights that had been sold to Setanta for the 2009/10 season onwards reverted to the FA who then were unable to deliver it to a Pay-TV broadcaster.
As such ITV broadcast the competition with three/four matches per round (including replays), all quarter-finals, semi-finals and the final live.
ESPN then took over the pay TV rights for the 2010–11 – 2012–13 seasons. Rebecca Lowe became the first woman to host the FA Cup Final when she did so for ESPN during these seasons.[59]
The book was widely translated in Darwin's lifetime, but problems arose with translating words such as "favoured" and "selection", and with some translators being unfamiliar with Darwin's ideas.
Darwin distributed presentation copies in France and Germany, hoping that suitable translators would come forward.
He arranged for a translation into German by Heinrich Georg Bronn and a Dutch translation by Tiberius Cornelis Winkler.
As he corresponded about a French translation by Clémence Royer, he had difficulty getting samples of the French to check if it was satisfactory.
Bronn was a well-regarded elderly professor, fossilist and convert to transmutation.
He used his own expertise in the translation, adding controversial themes that Darwin had deliberately omitted.

Bronn translated "favoured races" as "perfected races", and added essays on issues including the origin of life, and a final chapter on religious implications largely expressing his own views including that Darwin's picture was incomplete, and nature had a goal.
Darwin sent a correcting manuscript of the second English edition. Bronn's second edition was published in 1863.
After Bronn died of a heart attack in July 1862, Darwin corresponded with Julius Victor Carus, who was more accurate, and translated the fifth English edition, published in 1867.

Darwin's attempts to find a translator in France had failed, and Royer's Darwin: L'Origine des espèces of 1862 had an introduction promoting her ideas of Darwin's "materialist theory" as an alternative to religious revelation, and spreading ideas of utero-selection and the social evolution of women towards greater equality.
She added footnotes expanding on issues such as ovule selection overriding masculine "faults" in progressive evolution.

Darwin corresponded with Royer about a third edition in 1866 and a fourth in 1870, but after reading her extensive footnotes he said that he "could sooner have suspected Sterne of having written a dissertation on the nebular hypothesis than her of having reduced my book to its present form".
He correspondingly lost "pleasure in looking at it", remarking that it was "very disagreeable to be hated in France".
He had more favourable dealings with Jean-Jacques Moulinié on a Swiss translation, but remained unsatisfied until Marey Husson's 1873 translation.
A Russian translation was started by Anatole Nikoliski and finished off by the entomologist Victor Ruloff was published in 1864.[99][100] Editions in Italian and Russian appeared in 1864.
In Darwin's lifetime, the book was published in Swedish in 1871, Danish in 1872, Polish in 1873, Hungarian in 1873-1874, Spanish in 1877, and Serbian in 1878.
It was later published in Japanese in 1896 and Chinese in 1902. In the following century, the book was published in an additional 18 languages.
Despite the rules of the match, the referee has the liberty of ignoring rules violations (at least those that would ordinarily cause an instant disqualification).
Commonly, the only rules violation that is sure to stop a wrestling match is low blows, the use of weapons, outside interference and attacking the referee.

In WWE, a ref can't disqualify a match unless he personally saw the violation occur (as opposed to watching video footage), and referee decisions are generally final, although "Dusty finishes" (named for Dusty Rhodes) where referees are overruled do happen.
It is quite common for referees to be incapacitated during a match, a condition known as a "ref bump".
During their time "unconscious", wrestlers are free to violate rules (e. g. partaking in "illegal" activities, such as using foreign objects or receiving outside help).
When not incapacitated, referees have, on occasion, been known to disqualify a wrestler on the suspicion that it was the wrestler who knocked him out.
The majority of referee knockdowns are planned to take the referee "out of the match" for a period of time, generally to allow a wrestler (generally a heel) an advantage.
Frequently in such situations, one wrestler will be thrown into the referee at a relatively slow speed which results in the ref falling down and being "knocked out" for a long period of time.

During the referee's absence, one of the wrestlers may pin their opponent for a count of three that would have ended the match if the referee were conscious, but the actual rules state that the match may not end until the referee makes or sees the count, so when the referee finally regains his senses the match simply continues.

In certain situations, a replacement referee might run backstage to take over the original referee's duties and make the count for the wrestlers, but by the time this occurs, the other wrestler usually gains enough time to come to their senses and kick out of the pinfall attempt.

Burke was not initially hostile to the revolution. In a letter of 9 August 1789, Burke reacted to the early events of the revolution by expressing his admiration, in the "dawn of the freedom of France," of the "generous temperaments in my Brethren of the Augsbourg Confession, and the Catholic clergy in the states of Dauphiné.
"[30] He wrote in October that "The French have shewn themselves the ablest Architects of Ruin.
The Atrhabilaire Philosophe [‘ill-tempered philosopher’] is the readiest to destroy, and the most incapable of reconstructing his fellow creatures.

"[31] The events of 5–6 October 1789, in which a Parisian crowd compelled King Louis XVI and his family to return from Versailles to Paris, particularly concerned Burke because of the parallels they had with the English Civil War.

On 10 October he wrote to François-Louis-Thibaut de Menonville, the French ambassador, saying: "Whenever the abuse is habitual and fixed in the frame of the Government, no private person is ever authorised to resist it.
He, who does, breaks the laws of his Country..."[32] In the same month he described France as "a country undone.

"[33] On 4 November Charles-Jean-François Depont wrote to Burke, praising his Thoughts on the Cause of the Present Discontents, and requesting he "address some words to us on the present circumstances of France.
"[34] In his reply of 9 November, Burke agreed to do this, sending Depont a copy of the pamphlet as it stood then, and saying: "You may have subverted Monarchy, but not recover'd freedom.

"[35] On 1 November 1789, reflecting on these events, as he had done so before, Burke wrote in a letter to his son, Richard: "Late events in France have opened my mind and much enlarged my views," and it was "but just now that I have entirely got rid of my prejudices, in favour of their good disposition.
"[36] The pamphlet was finished in November and published on 1 November 1790.[37]
Beginning in 1592 and again in 1597 Toyotomi Hideyoshi, the de facto ruler of Japan, raised armies numbering 160,000 peasants and samurai and attempted to invade China through Korea.
(See Hideyoshi's invasions of Korea (文禄・慶長の役 Bunroku Keichō no Eki) (Chōsen-seibatsu).
Due to their expertise in the arquebus, as well as the relative combat experiences gained during the Sengoku period, Japanese samurai armies initially made large gains in most of Korea.

One of Hideyoshi's samurai commanders, Katō Kiyomasa, also advanced to Orangkai (or the Orankai people in the northeastern Korean peninsula) which is probably the liked to the present day's Hamgyŏng Province of North Korea and Jilin Province of China, (Manchuria), on the border with Korea in the northeastern Korean peninsula.
[15] But Katō retreated after a brief skirmish with the Jurchens in Manchuria, realizing that he had advanced too far and cut off from the other Japanese armies.

Among the samurai commanders was Katō Kiyomasa, Konishi Yukinaga, and Shimazu Yoshihiro who led 7000 samurai and defeated a larger Ming Chinese army at the Battle of Sacheon in 1598, near the conclusion of the campaigns.

Despite the combat expertise of the samurai and initial gains in Korea, the second incursion in 1597–1598 failed because of a combination of the supremacy of the Korean navy led by Admiral Yi Sun-sin which cut off army supply lines, work of guerrillas (Righteous army), supply difficulties, Ming dynasty intervention on behalf of Korea, as well as Korean resolve and lack of generalship amongst the samurai.

Although the first campaign in 1592 was largely successful for the veteran Japanese armies against the unprepared Koreans on land, the second campaign in 1597 failed with the Japanese only occupying some parts of southeastern Korea located around Busan.
Further Japanese campaigns were checked after a series of successful defenses by the re-organized Korean military aided by Chinese forces, resulting in a military stalemate on land.

With Hideyoshi's death late in 1598, the prime Regent of Japan at the time (one of the Council of Five Elders) appointed by Hideyoshi to help his son Hideyori ascend ordered all samurai forces to withdraw from Korea, thus ending the invasions of Korea.

In southeast Europe agrarian societies first appeared in the 7th millennium BC, attested by one of the earliest farming sites of Europe, discovered in Vashtëmi, southeastern Albania and dating back to 6,500 BC.
[1][2] Anthropomorphic figurines have been found in the Balkans from 6000 BC,[3] and in Central Europe by around 5800 BC (La Hoguette).

The Sesklo culture (Thessaly) developed in Greece and prior to 6000 BC spread into the Balkans and to the west, centering on Achilleion (Magnesia); it may have also influenced the development of the Cardium pottery and Linearbandkeramik cultures.
Through a combination of cultural diffusion and migration of peoples, the Neolithic traditions spread west and northwards to reach northwestern Europe by around 4500 BC.

The Vinča culture may have created the earliest proto-writing system, the Vinča signs, though archaeologist Shan Winn believes that these symbols were used for religious purposes and that it is unlikely they represented a spoken language.
The Cucuteni-Trypillian culture built enormous settlements in Romania, Moldova and Ukraine from 5300 to 2300 BC.

The megalithic temple complexes of Ġgantija on the Mediterranean island of Gozo (in the Maltese Archipelago) and of Mnajdra on the island of Malta (Maltese Archipelago) are notable for their gigantic Neolithic structures, the oldest of which date back to around 3600 BC.

After 2500 BC, these islands were depopulated for several decades until the arrival of a new influx of Bronze Age immigrants, a culture that cremated its dead and introduced smaller megalithic structures called dolmens to Malta.
[7] In most cases, there are small chambers here, with the cover made of a large slab placed on upright stones.
They are claimed to belong to a population different from that which built the previous megalithic temples.
It is presumed the new population arrived from Sicily, given the similarity of Maltese dolmens to some small constructions found there.
[7] During the period of the 4th millennium BC, the climate of the Maltese Islands became drier, and this led to the eventual end of this phase of civilization.
Extant Neolithic specimens, including examples of prehistoric art, are scattered across Europe and the Near East.

The Hypogeum of Ħal-Saflieni, Paola, Malta, is a subterranean structure excavated c. 2500 BC; the only prehistoric underground temple in the world, and showing a degree of artistry in stone sculpture unique in prehistory to the Maltese islands.
In 1834 Chopin and Hiller visited Aix-la-Chapelle (Aachen) to attend the Lower Rhenish Music Festival, where they met the composer Felix Mendelssohn.
After the festival Hiller, Chopin and Mendelssohn traveled together to Düsseldorf to visit the composer Ferdinand Hiller.
Mendelssohn, who had been appointed musical director of the city, gave Hiller and Chopin a grand tour during which they "experienced the echo of [Mendelssohn's] fame".

[38] Mendelssohn wrote that he and his guests had spent a very agreeable day, discussing "music, or whatever you want",[39] and an evening with "some of the local celebrities,” including the director of the Academy of Art, Friedrich Wilhelm Schadow, and the painters Lessing, Bendemann, Hildebrandt and Sohn.
[40] In 1835, Chopin went to Carlsbad, where he saw his parents for the first time in four years.

A chance meeting there with the Wodziński familyacluding the young daughter, Maria, with whom he had fallen in love as a student aaled to an engagement (with her mother's approval), "requesting a letter and a ring upon his return to Paris in the autumn".
On the return journey, while stopping in Dresden in September, the composer received news that Maria had had a change of heart and did not wish to marry him.
[41] On his return to Paris he presented them with a set of songs known as "Zyczenie", which his daughter set to music; these were sold as an album late in 1836.
[42] In July 1836 Chopin went to Marienbad and Dresden to be with the Wodziński family.
He gave Maria his ring in September; a month later he continued on to Leipzig. He gave Schumann there his G minor Ballade.
At the end of 1835 he sent Maria an album, Seven Songs, which was inscribed by Chopin's sister Ludwika.
His Nocturne in C-sharp minor (Op. 27, No. 1, 1835) was imperfectly performed by Maria at the end of the year.
The "lukewarm thanks" that he received from her afterwards was "the last he heard from her".
An early Sufi to use esoteric interpretation was Sulami (d. 1021). Some of the early Sufi commentaries are preserved in his work.
The most significant of Sulami's own works is Haqaiq al-Tafsir ("Truths of Exegesis"), a collection of commentaries of earlier Sufiists.
From the 11th century, there are other significant writers, such as Qushayri (d. 1074), Daylami (d. 1193), Shirazi (d. 1209), and Suhrawardi (d. 1234).

These writers quoted Sulami and other writers, along with their own material. There are also several compendia of mystical sayings typically in Persian, such as Maybudi's (d. 1135) Kashf al-Asrar ("The Unveiling of the Secrets").
A significant portion of the value of the work are its quotations from earlier Sufiists.
Rumi (d. 1273) wrote an enormous amount of mystical poetry, at least in part under Quranic influence, in his book Mathnawi.
Although the use of Quran texts is not always clearly indicated in translations, the book contains a great deal of content which some see as Sufi interpretation.
With that being said, Rumi is one of the Sufiists with many Quran citations. Simnani (d. 1336) wrote two influential works of esoteric Quranic commentary.
His teachings combined a notion of God's ongoing self-disclosure through the being of the universe with a fairly strict adherence to Sunni Islam.
Complete Sufi commentaries did not appear again until the 18th century, with Ismail Hakki Bursevi (d. 1725) the author of Rūḥ al-Bayān ("The Spirit of Elucidation").

This great volume written in Arabic contains his own Sufi thoughts along with those of previous mystical authors such as Ibn Arabi, Al-Ghazali and Al-Alusi, intermixed with the poetic Sufi thoughts in verse form of Hafiz.
Aerosmith hit multi-platinum success again with Get a Grip in 1993 and their 1997 release Nine Lives both reaching number one positions on album charts.
[12][13] Four singles of the album Get a Grip were major hits on the Top 40 and/or Mainstream Rock Charts.
It is their bestselling album in the United States, achieving worldwide sales of over 20 million and won the band two Grammy awards.

In 1998, they released the number-one single "I Don't Want to Miss a Thing", a power ballad which was notable for being the first and, to date, the only single to debut at the number one position on the Billboard Hot 100[14] for a band in the hard rock genre.
AC/DC, Bon Jovi, and Metallica released successful hard rock albums in 1995 with Ballbreaker, Keep the Faith, and Load respectively.

Bon Jovi's Keep the Faith (1992) was a hit among hard rock fans that also managed to achieve 2 Top 10 hit ballads in mainstream Top 40 radio and adult contemporary chart with "Bed of Roses" (1993) and "Always" (1994), Metallica' Load (1995) and ReLoad (1997) saw a more melodic and blues rock approach compared to their previous efforts and still managed to sell over 4 million copies in the US a piece.

Bon Jovi's 1995 album These Days which is also harder than the previous Keep the Faith, made more impact in Europe than in the US, yet the only US Top 10 hit single of the album "This Ain't a Love Song" made the US Dance/Club play chart.
The album peaked at number one at many countries worldwide including United Kingdom[15] spending 4 weeks at number one in the UK chart and spawning out 4 Top 10 singles in UK Singles Chart.
As the style of alternative rock and grunge faded in the mid-90s, post-grunge, a derivative genre, began to gain momentum.
Foo Fighters and Candlebox[16] helped pave the way for the mainstream success of bands such as Live, Collective Soul, Australia's Silverchair and England's Bush.
By the late 1990s, post-grunge was the prevalent genre on alternative radio. Foo Fighters continued to be successful going into the 2000s.
Post-Britpop bands Feeder and Stereophonics, inspired by Oasis, developed a hard rock or "pop-metal" sound.[17]
The next important epistemological theory was formulated, in response to the 17th-century "continental rationalism", by John Locke (1632–1704) in his An Essay Concerning Human Understanding, in 1689.
A famous phrase in his essay brings into focus the central aspect of his epistemology: An Empiricist Theory of Knowledge, namely that humans can have only a-posteriori knowledge.

Locke said that the mind was a tabula rasa ( "blank slate", although he did not use those actual words) –translated as "white paper" – in the introduction and that whatever ideas we develop is written on that "white paper" throughout our lives is deposited by our experiences from sense perception.
Ideas, Locke claimed, arose from two different "types" of experiences: sensation and reflection.
He also claimed, in the same line of thinking as Newton, that ideas were both one of two different "types": simple and complex.
Simple ideas can be both broken down into ideas of the original and of secondary qualities.
If an object, Locke claimed, had to contain a quality in order to be that particular object, then it was a primary quality of the object.
Without the atomic make-up of an apple, one cannot have an apple; without the structure of an hexagon, one cannot have an hexagon.
Anything else perceived through sensed experience was a secondary quality: the size, shape, color, etc., of an apple.
Beyond simple ideas taken in from sense perception were complex ideas. Complex ideas, Locke claimed, were viewed as a "compilation" of simple ideas taken from sense perception.

Locke categorized these ideas into substances, modes, and relations. Contrary to Descartes' "quest for certainty," Locke claimed in Epistle 6 that "knowledge is founded on and the perception of the agreement or disagreement of any of our ideas."
The first permanent English colony in America was founded at Jamestown by Captain John Smith, and managed by the Virginia Company, in 1607.

Bermuda was settled and claimed by England as a result of the 1609 shipwreck there of the Virginia Company's flagship, and in 1615 was transferred to the newly-formed Somers Isles Company (a spin-off of the Virginia Company).
The Virginia Company's charter was revoked in 1624 and direct control of Virginia was assumed by the crown, thereby establishing the Colony of Virginia.
In 1610, the London and Bristol Company was created with the remit of creating a permanent settlement on the island of Newfoundland, but was largely unsuccessful.
Plymouth was established in 1620 as a haven for Puritan religious separatists (known today as the Pilgrims).

Seeking haven from religious persecution elsewhere motivated more English colonists to found the colonies of Maryland (1634), (Catholic), Rhode Island (1636), (all faiths), Connecticut (1639), (Congregationalist), and Pennsylvania (1681), (Quaker).

The Province of Carolina was founded in 1663. The surrender of Fort Amsterdam to the English, in 1664, during the Second Anglo-Dutch War, was followed by the capture of the whole of New Netherland, which England renamed as New York.

This was formalised in negotiations after the war in which the Dutch offered the English a choice of either the island of Manhattan or the South American colony of Suriname, which the English had captured; the English opted for New Netherland (renamed New York) to keep their territories contiguous, and the Dutch kept Suriname.

In 1681, William Penn founded the colony of Pennsylvania. While the American colonies were less financially successful than those of the Caribbean, they had large areas of good agricultural land, and some of the American colonies saw much more rapid growth than their Caribbean counterparts due to a more healthy climate.
The two-factor theory of emotion was developed by Stanley Schachter and was based on previous experiments by a Spanish physician named Gregorio Marañón, who injected epinephrine into his patients.
Since they were not experiencing a real emotion-inducing event, the patients would often not know what emotion they should be having in reaction to the physiological arousal.
Schachter agreed that physiological arousal is important in emotions, but he thought that physiological arousal contributed to emotions by facilitating a specific cognitive response.
He believed that when the body becomes physiologically aroused, it then cognitively appraises the situation and labels the arousal as an emotion.
For example, your heart may start beating on seeing that there is a bear in your kitchen, and your brain then interprets that reaction as anxiety due to the presence of a bear.

Schachter and his student Jerome Singer showed that despite being randomized into the same state of physiological arousal (via epinephrine injection), subjects would manifest either euphoria or anger depending on the behavior of a confederate who presented as another subject (and so ostensibly in the same physiological state).
It is this cognitive appraisal of the situation (cognition) that determines the emotional response (arousal).
For a critique of the results of the original experiment see Jesse Prinz (2004), Gut Reactions.
A professional game is 2 halves of 45 minutes each. games are played to time. the game keeps going while the ball in not in play.

Usually a 15 minute half time. After 90 minutes the game is over. The referee is the official time keeper and makes additional allowance for time lost through substitutions, injured players requiring attention, or other stoppages.
Added time is also called injury time, stoppage time, additional time, or loss time A referee may add time.
Known as injury time, this is at the sole discretion of the referee who indicates the end of the match.

In matches where there is a fourth official, near the end of each half the referee signals how many minutes remain to be played, and the fourth official signals this to players and spectators by holding up a board with this number on it.

This allowance may be further extended by the referee History of Injury Time The origin of added time in football can be traced back to an incident that occurred during a match between Stoke and Aston Villa in 1891.

Leading 1–0 with two minutes remaining, Stoke were awarded a penalty. However, Villa's goalkeeper kicked the ball out of the ground, by the time it was recovered the ninety minutes had elapsed and the final whistle was blown before the penalty could be taken.

[5] Law also states that "If a penalty kick has to be taken or retaken, the duration of either half is extended until the penalty kick is completed", thus allowing for no match to end with a pending penalty.
Franklin S. Harris was the first BYU president to have a doctoral degree. He was appointed in 1921, and pushed to have the academy attain university status.
At the beginning of his administration, BYU was not accredited with any organization, but by the end of it, it had received accreditation from all the major national accrediting agencies of the time.
Harris was succeeded as president by Howard S. McDonald, who received a Ph.D. from the University of California.
He began his term as president soon after World War II, and former soldiers began attending BYU, occasioning a doubling of enrollment.
By the spring of 1947, there were 5,440 students, almost five times more than had been in attendance in the early 1930s.

Unable to provide adequate housing for the students, McDonald obtained old barracks from an army base to the south for the students. When McDonald could not get the funding to support this housing, he resigned.
Ernest L. Wilkinson was the next president. During his administration the university underwent an explosive period of growth, where the number of buildings increased from 6 to 72.
Enrollment also increased by 17,000, and the BYU became the largest private university of the time, and enrollment continued to grow.
Wilkinson also proposed the building of an education building, the Eyring Science Center, and a new heating plant.
All were completed. The quality of students increased, and the school became the largest private university in the United States.
The university's academic status and reputation improved, and new departments and courses were added.
The university reorganized its church units, and ten stakes, with over 100 wards were added.

Forbes began reporting on Beyoncé's earnings in 2008, calculating that the $80 million earned between June 2007 to June 2008, for her music, tour, films and fashion business, made her the world's best-paid music personality at the time, ahead of Madonna and Celine Dion.
[307] They placed her fourth on the Celebrity 100 list in 2009 and ninth on the "Most Powerful Women in the World" list in 2010.
[308][309] The following year, Forbes placed her eighth on the "Best-Paid Celebrities Under 30" list, having earned $35 million in the past year for her clothing line and endorsement deals.

[310] In 2012, Forbes placed Beyoncé at number 16 on the Celebrity 100 list, having dropped twelve places from the previous year, despite having earned $40 million in the past year from her album 4, clothing line and endorsement deals.
[311] In the same year, Beyoncé and Jay Z topped the "World's Highest-Paid Celebrity Couples", for a combined total of $78 million.
[312] The couple appeared on the previous year's Guinness World Records as the "highest-earning power couple" for collectively earning $122 million in 2009.
[313] Forbes magazine also noted that Beyoncé continued to be the most powerful female in entertainment in 2013, having earning $53 million between June 2012 to June 2013.

[314] In 2014, Beyoncé was listed again on Forbes as the most powerful female musician and was second on the Celebrity 100 list with earnings of $115 million, double the previous year's amount, earning her the highest annual earnings of her career so far.
[315][316] Beyoncé and Jay Z also topped the "Highest-Earning Celebrity Couples" list in 2014, for the third consecutive year.
[317] In 2016, she ranked at number 34 on the Celebrity 100 list, with earnings of $54 million.
[318] Beyoncé has also been recognized as the highest-paid black musician of all time by Billboard.
