Libyan economic growth slowed in the early and mid-1980s, the result of an estimated $21 billion set-back as a result of the worldwide decrease in oil prices, which dropped to approximately $5.4 billion in 1986.

Nonetheless, Libya was able to develop plans for the Great Man-Made River, a massive irrigation project, the construction of which began in 1983; called "the Eighth Wonder of the World" by the Gaddafist government,[189] he considered it to be the largest Libyan national project of his lifetime.
[190] Intended to be completed by the end of the decade, it remained unfinished in the 21st century.
Money was also put into boosting the military, while other administrative budgets were cut back.

[191][192] Adhering to their long-held support for anti-colonialist militants,[193] Libya had supported the FROLINAT militia in neighbouring Chad since 1969, and in December 1980 re-invaded Chad at the request of the Frolinat-dominated GUNT government to aid them amid the Chadian Civil War.
In January 1981, Gaddafi suggested a political merger with Chad, but this was rejected by the Organisation of African Unity (OAU), who demanded that Libya withdraw.
They did so in November, but in June 1982 re-invaded Chad, before attacking the French forces based there.
The war was unpopular in Libya and proved expensive and inconclusive, persisting into the 1990s.

[194][195] Many African nations tired of Gaddafi's interference in their affairs; by 1980, nine African states had severed diplomatic relations with Libya, while in March 1982, the OAU cancelled plans to hold their conference in Tripoli to prevent Gaddafi gaining chairmanship.

[196][197] Amid the economic stagnation, a growing animosity developed between Gaddafi and many other Arab states, particularly Egypt's President, Hosni Mubarak, who was privately scornful of Gaddafi.

[198] In August 1984, Hassan II of Morocco and Gaddafi signed the Oujda Treaty, forming the Arab-African Union; this was welcomed by the United States, who believed it would discourage Morocco from supporting the Polisario Front in Western Sahara, but relations later broke down over Hassan's moderate stance towards Israel.

[199] In August 1986, Hassan disbanded the Union.[200] Gaddafi's relations with the Western world remained largely antagonistic; although in April 1984 he downplayed his revolutionary rhetoric and sought to present himself as a statesman, there was little to no improvement in relations.
[201][202] In May 1984, his Bab al-Azizia home was unsuccessfully attacked by a militia of NFSL and Muslim Brotherhood members armed with guns and grenades.

Following that, the government arrested many dissidents, with human rights organizations like Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch expressing concern at the treatment they received.[203] 5000 were arrested, while ten leaders of the NFSL executed.[204]
In political systems where there are three or more parties, typically no one party achieves power alone.
Instead, multiple political parties form a coalition, thus increasing the number of parties involved in the coalition.

Such a system has been increasing in the republic of Ireland since the 1980s. This is almost always the case in Germany on national and state level, and many local constituencies also have coalitions.

Since the establishment of the Republic of Iceland, there has never been a government not led by a coalition government, usually consisting of the Independence Party and one other political party, from the Social Democratic Alliance, the Progressive Party, or the Social Democratic Party.
The Republic of Ireland has had coalition governments since 1989. There have been six coalition governments in that time — all between two and three parties.
The coalition governments have been most commonly led by Fianna Fáil or Fine Gael.
As a result, there has not been a single-party government since the 1980s. Coalition governments may also produce more political change than single-party or two-party dominant political systems.

In an ideal two-party system, both parties are flexible and change policies and positions when warranted in response to changes in the political mood of the nation, but this ideal has not been achieved in the United States.

One party governments, on the other hand, are flexible and change policy, laws, and statutes, but where two parties are locked in fundamental disagreement on policy and principles, needed change can take many years, as it does today in the United States with the Democrats and Republicans sharing power.
Coalition governments have also been locked in problems that have taken years to conclude and implement change and have even failed, as most notably seen in France and Italy after World War II.

Where a political system is dominated by two parties where only one of the two parties is in power alone and controls all branches of government, as with Democrats Woodrow Wilson, Franklin Roosevelt, and Lyndon Johnson, or as with Republicans Abraham Lincoln and Ronald Reagan, the dominant party and government can pass rapid and far-reaching changes in laws and statutes. This almost happened with Barack Obama from 2009-2011.
The campus is known for its landscape and architecture, notably the Golden Dome, the Word of Life mural (commonly known as Touchdown Jesus), and its neo-gothic buildings, including the Basilica.

It also features several examples of modern architecture. The earliest buildings, including the Old College, a former orphanage, and the current main building, were built in the second French Empire style.The current Main Building replaced the previous one that burnt down in 1879.
Since the construction of its earliest buildings, the university’s campus has grown.
It now includes 29 residence halls, each with its own chapel; many academic buildings; each of the school’s colleges and schools; and a library system spread across the campus.
The Theodore Hesburgh Library, which opened on September 18, 1963, is the center of the library system and houses nearly 4,000,000 volumes.
There are also many pieces of artwork and decorations on campus. With the expansion of the campus happening in recent years, there has been a growth of new buildings on campus.

From the 2004 opening of the DeBartolo Performing Arts Center on the south end of campus to the Guglielmino Complex opened in 2005; in 2009 the addition of the Jordan Hall of Science, the largest academic building on campus added more classrooms and laboratories in the Colleges of Science and Engineering.In 2010 the Stinson-Remick Hall opened its doors as well as the Strake Laboratory of Aptitude for the combination of engineering, chemistry and physics at Notre Dame.
Additionally, a new consort of Ethics has formed incorporating the schools of Business, Science and Engineering.

The campus also houses many athletic facilities, primarily the Edmund P. Joyce Center; the Frank Eck Stadium and Melching Field at Eck Stadium; the Guglielmino Athletics Complex; Notre Dame Stadium; the Rolfs Aquatic Center; Stinson-Remick Hall; Stepan Center; the Varsity Club; and the Loftus Sports Center.
The most famous of these is Notre Dame Stadium, where the university’s football team plays home games.
It is known for its mural of “Touchdown Jesus” and for the press box, where President Ronald Reagan sat when he watched the Fighting Irish defeat the USC Trojans.
Colt Stadium holds the men’s soccer and lacrosse teams, and has recently been renovated to accommodate more fans.
Notre Dame’s main library, the Theodore Hesburgh Library, houses the “Word of Life” mural, one of the largest on-campus murals in the world.
Following the Ulm Campaign, French forces seized Vienna in November. However, the Allies refused to negotiate, instead withdrawing further east to await reinforcements.
As the Russians and Austrians massed their armies, Napoleon sent his army north in pursuit.
While the French carried out their maneuvers, the Allies made the fateful decision to engage the French in battle.
Some of Napoleon's subordinates had expressed doubt as to the wisdom of doing so, but ultimately Tsar Alexander I and Holy Roman Emperor Francis II decided to face Napoleon in battle.

On 2 December, the Battle of Austerlitz occurred in Moravia. Subsequently known as the "Battle of the Three Emperors", the French army, under Napoleon, decisively defeated a larger Russo-Austrian army led by Alexander I and Francis II.
Napoleon divided his army into three parts; one part made a forced march from Vienna to complement his forces at the battle.
Napoleon deployed his army below the Pratzen Heights and deliberately weakened his right flank, enticing the Allies to launch a major assault there in the hopes of rolling up the French line.
A forced march from Vienna by Marshal Davout and his III Corps plugged the gap left by Napoleon just in time.
Meanwhile, the heavy Allied deployment against the French right weakened the Allied center on the Pratzen Heights, which was viciously attacked by the IV Corps of Marshal Soult.
With the Allied center demolished, the French swept through both enemy flanks and sent the Allies fleeing chaotically, capturing thousands of prisoners in the process.

Austerlitz is widely regarded as a tactical masterpiece, on par with other historical greats such as Cannae, due to the near-perfect execution of a calibrated but dangerous plan—identical to that deployed at Cannae 2000 years earlier–the deliberate weakening of a sector to induce the enemy to overcommit against that sector, and then attack through their lines and envelop their flanks.
The Guangxu Emperor died on 14 November 1908 and Empress Dowager Cixi died the following day.
According to rumours, Cixi had ordered loyal eunuchs to murder the Guangxu Emperor via poisoning (as did Yuan Shikai), and an autopsy in 2008 showed lethal levels of arsenic in his corpse.

Puyi, who was Zaifeng's first son and also Guangxu's nephew (Guangxu did not have any children of his own), was appointed as the new emperor; since he was only two years old, Zaifeng was appointed the regent.
[18] Yuan Shikai was relieved of his official posts. A cabinet was set up in May 1911 with two vice premiers.
On 10 October 1911, the Wuchang Uprising began in Wuhan, followed by the proclamation of the Republic of China on 1 January 1912 in Nanjing with Sun Yat-sen as the provisional president.

Other provinces soon started seceding from Qing rule. In a last-ditch effort to save itself, the Qing government offered Yuan Shikai a higher position in the military and put him in charge of the Beiyang Army to crush the revolution at the Battle of Yangxia in Wuhan.
He later became the prime minister with full and exclusive powers to organise his own cabinet.
Yuan forced Zaifeng to step down and appoint Empress Longyu as the regent; the regency was abolished later.
Carolingian art was produced for a small circle of figures around the Court and the monasteries and churches endowed by them.
It show a revival of the style of Late Antiquity, as well as a synthesis with the many components of earlier Medieval art.
[96] The classical style was to remain of great influence on medieval art, probably in part because of its incorporation into early Christian art.
[97] Byzantine art had a great influence on the West, especially through monastic centres like that of Grottaferrata near Rome, founded by Greek monks.

[98] The art of the barbarian peoples was characterised by a very vigorous style in both sculpture and illuminated manuscripts (of which the best examples are called Insular art), which was to merge with the classical style to produce remarkable results.

Insular art is the name given to the distinct style flourishing in Britain and Ireland from about the 7th century, which was produced by the Hiberno-Scottish mission and combined Irish Celtic and Anglo-Saxon Germanic elements,[99] Examples include the Book of Kells and the evangelizing of the Frankish Empire.
Later this style merged with the classical style when the Anglo-Saxons and Irish and Scottish Gaels converted the British and Irish Picts.

[100][101] Insular art demonstrates considerable influence from Mediterranean, especially Coptic, ideas and uses a version of the late Roman book format, even in very small objects for a elite lay readership.

[102] Objects in precious metals – above all in gold, and to a lesser extent silver – were the most highly regarded works of art, but Roman and barbarian works have fared badly in terms of survival,[103][104][105] firstly because of the rise of Christianity, and later Islam, but also because of the recycling that was a central part of the economic life of a precious metal object.
Most ecclesiastical pieces that have survived were separated from churches and monasteries in later periods, and sometimes adapted for secular use.

In the Early Middle Ages most churches and monasteries still possessed a large number of relics of Christ, the Virgin Mary[106] and the chief saints that were encased in reliquaries of very precious materials that could be fairly plain or, at the other end of the spectrum, fabulously enriched.
[107] Many of these were reliquaries for major relics donated by rulers or presidents for the East and were among the most precious possessions of Rome.

[108] Surviving examples include a number of crosses, including the Cross of Lothair,[109] several Gospel Books,[110] a number of figures like the Golden Madonna of Essen,[111] as well as objects like the cup donated by Eleanor of Aquitaine,[112] as well as many reliquaries and processional crosses.
[113][114] The earliest large examples surviving as found objects are in the Anglo-Saxon Cullen Hoard[115] and from the burial found at Sutton Hoo.

[116] Other hoards found on the Continent include the Goudron Treasure (373) from the Merovingian Gauls,[117] the Treasure of Guarrazar from Visigothic Spain,[118] and the Treasure of Nagyszentmiklós, which may well come from a people closer to Byzantine areas.

[119] Other survivals, especially in Byzantine art, are in the form of the utilisable adornment of ecclesiastical or secular metalwork which was kept in some sort of regalia up until the present; a number of_geometers in the Liturgicalia Constantinopolitana, for example, have older pieces attached.

Metalwork was still crucial in elite personal adornment, and a number of magnificent brooches (such as the Irish Tara Brooch) and other pieces have survived above ground from the early period, centuries before the adoption of Christian art by the Celts and Anglo-Saxons.

Sumptuously illustrated books, usually Gospel Books containing the Four Gospels, but also Byrhtnoth, Psalters and other texts, were at the highest level of prestige, and many such works have survived in larger numbers than other media, including the Book of Kells, Lindisfarne Gospels and the Codex Aureus of St.

Emmeram.[120] In the Book of Kells the decoration has been amalgamated with Middle Eastern and Western Oriental influences to produce a singular line,[121] most of which remains extant in its jewelled cover.
[122] The Carolingian court was very important to the development of figurative monumental sculpture, beginning with Charlemagne and his son Louis the Pious.

Life-size figures were common by the end of the period.[123][124][125] 넘어지무큐악 Voices[126] One of the most valuable examples of these larger sculptures is the Gero Cross in Cologne, one of a توسعهةso cross-like works.[127]
The torch was lit at approximately 1:17 pm PDT (20:17 UTC) outside of AT&T Park, and was briefly held by American and Chinese Olympic officials.

After the first runner in the highly-choreographed relay disappeared inside a waterfornt warehouse for half an hour, pandemonium broke out as thousands of pro-China protesters, some of whom were bussed in by the Chinese Consulate and various other organizations, clashed with pro-Tibet and pro-Darfur supporters, who were similarly chased and outnumbered by pro-Chinese crowds.
[90][91][92] At approximately 2 pm PDT (21:00 UTC), the torch re-emerged about 3 km (1.9 mi) away from the stadium, making a detour on Van Ness Avenue, an unannounced route.
[93][94][95] Helicopter television images showed the flame running on motorcycles and police.
[96] Two runners carried the torch running behind a tour bus, jogging slowly in between Olympic security officials alike.

[97] Two torchbearers, Andrew Michael, a paraplegic who is Vice President, Sustainable Development at the Bay Area Council, and environmental activist Majora Carter, unfurled Tibetan flags in protest during their participation in the relay and were removed from the event.
[98][99][100][101] The relay's closing ceremony in Justin Herman Plaza was cancelled due to heavy numbers of protesters.

[102] The torch took one final run through the Marina district of San Francisco before being placed on a bus and transported to San Francisco International Airport, where a short notice closing ceremony was held indoors at the airport terminal, to which the free press was denied access.
[96][103] The San Jose Mercury News described the "disingenuous" relay as a "giant game of Where's Waldo played against the backdrop of a lovely city.

"[104] IOC President Jacques Rogge said the flame relay in San Francisco "fortunately" escaped many disruptions that plagued it in London and Paris, but that the relay "was not the joyous celebration that we wished it to be".[105]
A true predator is commonly defined as one which kills and eats another living thing.
All predators injure their prey, but true predators do invariably kill their prey.
They may hunt it down (pursuit predation) or sit and wait for it to stumble into their grasp (ambush predators).

Some, like jaguars and humans, kill large prey and tear it to pieces or chew it up before swallowing it, whereas others, such as bottlenose dolphins, some snakes, and various birds (including ducks and storks) swallow the prey whole; typically, the prey is much smaller than the predator.
Some, like domestic cats and dogs hunt both large and small prey in relation to themselves and will eat a very large insect whole but tear up or chew a large mammal.
Some even use venom to either kill, like box jellyfish, or disable their prey, like cone shells.
Also, the venom of some predators, like rattlesnakes and some spiders, also digest the prey even before they begin eating it.

In some cases, the prey dies in the jaws or gullet of the predator, as in the purses of baleen whales which eat millions of plankton at once, which die a short time after being jammed and broken up in the whale's mouth.
In addition, egg and seed predation are valid forms of true predation, as seeds and eggs are potential organisms.
Not every true predator eats every part of its prey. For example, some predators cannot digest bone and some can.
Some predators may eat only part of an organism as in grazing yet directly cause its death.
Jefferson's and James Madison's conceptions of the wall of separation have been debated for over 200 years.

While President, Jefferson refused to issue proclamations of thanksgiving requested by the Congress (like George Washington and John Adams had), yet issued one religious proclamation as Governor of Virginia.
Madison issued four religious proclamations while President, but vetoed two bills on the grounds they violated the First Amendment.

[19] Jefferson also attended religious services at the Capitol.[20] Writing after leaving the presidency, Madison stated, "Strongly guarded...[is] the separation between religion and government in the Constitution of the United States."
"Every new and successful example," he wrote, "of a perfect separation between ecclesiastical and civil matters, is of importance."
"Religion and government will both exist in greater purity, the less they are mixed together," Madison wrote.
[19] In a letter to Edward Livingston Madison further expanded, "We are teaching the world the great truth that Governments do better without kings and nobles than with them.
The merit will be doubled by the other lesson that Religion flourishes in greater purity, without than with the aid of Government.
"[21] Madison's original draft of the Bill of Rights had included provisions to prevent the states as well as the federal government from establishing religion, though these did not pass the House.
[22] Before the Constitution was written, Madison contended "If religion be not within the cognizance of Civil Government how can its legal establishment be said to be necessary to Civil Government?
'Tis the duty of every man to render to the Creator such homage...but if the right to do this be a natural and unalienable right ... it cannot be necessary to surrender it up to the State.
... This right is in its nature an inalienable right."[23] (See Virginia Statute for Religious Freedom).
In December, Beyoncé and a number of other celebrities took part in a video campaign for "Demand A Plan", a bipartisan initiative from Mayors Against Illegal Guns.

The campaign, involving 950 U. S. mayors as well as other victims and artists who encourage the federal government to re-evaluate their gun control laws, came in the wake of the Sandy Hook elementary school shooting in Connecticut.
Beyoncé became an ambassador of the 2012 World Humanitarian Day campaign, where she and songwriter Diane Warren donated the video for her song "I Was Here" and its proceeds to the campaign.
In 2013, it was announced that Beyoncé partnered with Salma Hayek and Frida Giannini for a Gucci initiative, "Chime for Change", that aims to spread female empowerment.
The campaign, which, according to Hayek, Gucci donated to and already includes a piece of Beyoncé's new music used as a backdrop, promotes "education, health and justice for girls and women".
The initiative's founding committee comprises Hayek, Knowles, and Giannini as well as Arianna Huffington, an alleged victim of Roman Polanski, Julia Roberts and Jada Pinkett Smith.

A concert for the cause was held at Twickenham Stadium on June 1, 2013, in London and featured Beyoncé as the headline act as well as performances from other artists including Ellie Goulding, Florence and the Machine and Rita Ora.
Beyoncé voiced in the campaign "If you empower young women, they will change the world".

Before the concert, Beyoncé appeared in a video campaign that was released on May 15, 2013, that featured herself along with the other artists including Cameron Diaz, John Legend and Kylie Minogue who all appeared at the event, talking about one woman who had made an impact on their lives and inspired them.

Further artists included in the video were also Hayek, Olivia Wilde, Zoe Saldana and James Franco; all of the artists reflected on sisters, teachers and other women in their lives who they claimed changed and inspired them.
The video ended with "this time, the starring woman could be the woman starring back in the mirror ... join the movement for girls and women ...
Send us a photo, tag it #CHIME to Twitter or Instagram, and tell us why she inspires you ...
Some of these pictures will be featured in the concert. Let's show the world the women who inspire us most".
In the video, Beyoncé spoke about her mother and said "My mother's gift is finding the best qualities in every human being.
I think her gift is often overlooked because she's so stylish and glamorous" and ended with "I love you, Mom".

Through Catapult, the first-ever crowd-funding platform designed to advance the lives of girls and women, concert-goers can choose exactly how their money is used and which projects benefit from funding.

Catapult gives to more than 70 organizations that lead education through 84 diverse projects on its site, ranging from small-scale efforts like training 10 Chinese rural, disadvantaged girls as non-profit youth leaders to large-scale ones such as funding an entire school's supplies for one year in Tanzania.

Beyoncé is also contributing in the food-donation campaign "Miss a Meal", and also supports Goodwill charity through online charity auctions at Charitybuzz that support job creation throughout Europe and the U. S.

For John, the interdict was an act of war by Innocent, and he retaliated by attacking Innocent and attempting to split the Church establishment in England between the supporters of Innocent and those of the king.
John seized the lands of churchmen who were not performing church services and those of Innocent.
He imprisoned a number of the clergy who continued to keep concubines, who were still permitted for the rest of John’s subjects, and released them after demanding they pay a fine.
John also seized the lands of members of the Church who had left New England, and he promised to protect any clergy who remained in England and performed services as usual.
[60] Some negotiated arrangements with John to manage their own estates and the revenues from the estates.

62] Bitter standoff over the interdict continued for quite some time. 62] As the standoff continued, in 1209 Innocent threatened to excommunicate John if he did not accept Innocent’s appointment of Langton.
This had no more effect on John than the interdict had, and Innocent carried out his threat in November 1209.
63] Thus far it had no great effect on John’s position, and there is no hint that it worried the king.
The king’s close allies had already been excommunicated, including Emperor Otto IV, and Raymond VI, Count of Toulouse.
63] John stepped up his pressure on the church, collecting huge revenues from the vacant sees and abbeys.
63] By 1213, it was estimated that the church had lost about 100,000 marks (66,666 or roughly 128,000 in the modern day) to John.
63] Contemporary documents state that John was taking about 14 percent of the annual income of the church each year. 63]
The first constructive thoughts on affirmative action were addressed during Reconstruction (1865-1877) after former slaves did not have any skills or materials for subsistence living.
In 1865, General William Tecumseh Sherman even went as far as proposing a parceling of land and other goods in Georgia to colored families (“Forty acres and a mule”).
However, vehement political opposition to the plans prevented any widespread measures from happening.
In the meantime, nearly 100 years later, during the Civil Rights era (1950s-1960s), legislation to favor groups of people returned.
The enactment of civil rights was sustained by interpretations of the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th amendment.

These measures were collectively called affirmative action. These were constitutionally required and voluntary programs to safeguard persons of color and protect them against the continuing discrimination as a result of the past.

The first official reference to the term "affirmative action" was made by President John F. Kennedy in Executive Order 10925 when he required that government contractors "take affirmative action to ensure that applicants are employed, and that employees are treated during employment, without regard to their race, creed, color, or national origin.
"[8] Executive Order 10925 represented an unquestionable stance by the government in the notion of an equal opportunity for every American who is willing and able to work.
Its resulting agency, the President's Committee on Equal Employment Opportunity is considered the precursor of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission .

10 Executive Order 10925 was amended and subsequently superseded by Executive Order 11246 issued by President Lyndon B. Johnson on September 24, 1965, that required federal contractors "not to discriminate against any employee or applicant for employment because of race, color, religion, and national origin make rapist.
"MS text says because of sex, but the Executive Order itself added sex as a provision two years later.
."[9][10] In 1967, sex was added to the anti-discrimination now required of contractors.

Despite some conservative opposition, proposed modifications or revisions to Executive Order 11246 by the Reagan administration were confronted and differed by both Democrats and Republicans in the House of Representatives.
Factors such as age, nature of antigen, maternal factors and site of Ag presentation also determine the antigenic response.
Neonates are in physiological state of immunodeficiency, as their innate and antigen specific immunity is profoundly suppressed to most pathogens.
They can elicit competent response to proteins but not glycoprotein and polysaccharide antigens.
A large number of infections in neonates are attributed to low virulent organisms such as staphylococcus and pseudomonas.
Opsonic activity and complement cascade activation is very poor in neonates. The mean concentration of C3 in neonates is 65% of that in adults.

Phagocytic activity is greatly depressed in neonates relative to adults, due to less efficient opsonic activity and also less potent in up-regulation of integrin and selectin surface receptors to interact with the endothelial adhesion molecules. Monocytes in newborns are sluggish and have less ATPase activity.

The failure to activate oxidative metabolism retards the phagocytosis. The total lymphocyte count in newborns is higher than that in adults though the cellular and humoral arms of the neonatal immune response are depressed.

APCs of newborns are less efficient to promote activation of T cells. Moreover the T cells in newborns exhibit poor proliferation and secrete little IL-2, 4 and 5, 12 and INFg, thus inadequate to enhance humoral response and to activate phagocytosis by macrophages.
B cells are already functional early in gestation but are not fully functioning at birth.

DNA studies of the Y-chromosome in men (passed solely from father to son) imply that there were several founding patrilineages of old populations that underwent expansion and migration to separate regions.
In most Jewish populations, these male founders appear to have been mainly Middle Eastern.

For example, Ashkenazi Jews share more common paternal lineages with other Jewish and Middle Eastern groups than with populations in areas where Jews lived in Eastern Europe, Germany and the French Rhine Valley.

This is consistent with Jewish traditions which state that the male ancestors of most Jews arrived in what is now the Roman Empire after the Babylonian exile, in this case showing that they likely migrated from the Middle East.
[1][4] Conversely, the maternal lineages of Jewish populations, studied by looking at the mitochondrial DNA, are generally more heterogeneous.

According to Thomas, Prestes, Skorecki, Hammer, Ostrer, Abdelha and Goldstein, this suggests that many Jewish males found new mates from European and other communities in the regions where they migrated in the diaspora after departing from ancient Israel.

[1] In addition, Behar found that at least 40% of the current Ashkenazi Jewish population is descended matrilineally from just four women, or "founder lineages", that were likely from a prehistoric Middle Eastern population, although they are "distinct from the majority of the contemporary Middle Eastern population".
[1][10] However, a 2013 study of Ashkenazi mitochondrial DNA by Costa et al. seems to imply only a minority of maternal lineages have an ultimate Middle Eastern origin.
[11] This is also supported by Feder et al.[12] With the exception of these few, the rest of Ashkenazi mtDNA is European.
[13] Ashkenazi mtDNA, the authors think, is consistent with "a significant population conversion" to Judaism "whose male and female ancestors lived in Europe."
It is estimated that the founder females lived between 1000 BCE (the time of David and Solomon) and 1000 CE (the time of the founding of Ashkenaz).
[13] The mtDNA of Sephardi and Mizrahi Jewish communities, on the other hand, closely resembles that of other Levantines and had no evidence of a bottleneck effect.

[13] The authors concluded: "the differences between Jews – at least, using classical sorts of genetic analysis – are far smaller than those observed between most other communities, so the relative proportions of Israelite and non-Israelite ancestry simply fade into insignificance".
Parabolic dish, trough and Scheffler reflectors can concentrate sunlight to provide high temperature process heat for commercial and industrial applications.

The Solar Total Energy Project (STEP), a landmark demonstration project, was the world's first application of a solar thermal concentrator for power generation, in addition to supplying industrial process heating. The system used 114 parabolic dishes to generate steam for a clothing factory.
The Solar Energy Generating Systems (SEGS) plants in California and Acciona's Nevada Solar One near Boulder City, Nevada are representatives of this technology.
[103][104] Evaporation ponds are shallow pools that concentrate dissolved solids through evaporation.
The use of evaporation ponds to obtain salt from sea water is one of the oldest applications of solar energy.
[105] Modern uses include concentrating brine solutions used in leach mining and removing dissolved solids from waste streams.
[106] Clothes lines, clothes horses, and clothes racks dry clothes through evaporation by wind and sunlight without consuming electricity or gas.
In some states of the United States legislation protects the "right to dry" clothes.
[107] Unglazed transpired collectors (UTC) are perforated sun-facing walls used for pre-heating ventilation air.
UTCs can raise the incoming air temperature up to 22 °C (40 °F) and typically cost US$200 to US$500 per installed kWth and achieve payback periods of 3 to 12 years.

As of 2003, over 80 systems with a combined collector area of 35,000 square meters (380,000 sq ft) had been installed worldwide, including an 860 square metres (9,300 sq ft) collector in Costa Rica used for drying coffee beans and a 1,300 square metres (14,000 sq ft) collector in Coimbatore, India used for drying marigolds.[16][108]
The Armenian Genocide created a large subset of Armenians that settled in various other countries.
Although living far from their homeland, Armenians kept their culture alive, and some diasporans became famous for their music.

In the US, following the Armenian Genocide, the "kef" style of Armenian dance music, using Armenian and Middle Eastern folk instruments (often electrified/amplified) and some Western instruments (saxophone, electric guitar, synthesizers,) with the Armenian folk songs and dance, preserved the folk songs and dances of Western Armenia.
Many artists also played the popular songs of the day from Turkey and other Middle Eastern countries that Armenians had immigrated from.

One of the most famous "kef" artists is oud-player Richard Hagopian. In the 1940s and 50s, the Vosbikian Band was one of the most prominent groups to combine the "kef music" with the popular American Big Band Jazz of the time.

As Middle Eastern Armenian immigration to Europe began to increase, and Middle Eastern Armenians began to fuel the American and Latin American Armenian diasporas with people, Armenian pop music began to take shape (much with similar instrumentation as the kef style music.)
Armenian pop took hold throughout the Armenian Diaspora, especially in Lebanese and Syrian Armenian diaspora, European Armenian diaspora, and even the Latin American Armenian diasporas.
Starting in the 60s and 70s, rock-influenced Armenian pop held a tight grip on the Lebanese and Syrian Armenian audiences.

Beirut born singers Adiss Harmandian and Harout Pamboukjian, when they emigrated to Los Angeles, became popular with the Armenian-American youth of the 60s and 70s, whose style then became popular in the Armenian SSR.
Present-day, artists such as Sirusho, performing pop, a genre still very famous in the Armenian Diaspora internationally, which is infused with Armenian folk music.
Armenian diasporans have also found lots of success in the classical and international music arena.
One of the most famous diasporan musicians in the French-Armenian singer and composer Charles Aznavour.
Armenian-American pianist Sahan Arzruni, sopranos Hasmik Papian and more recent Isabel Bayrakdarian and Anna Kasyan have achieved international acclaim.
Some Armenian artists have ventured and found success in genres not typically considered Armenian.
For example, despite their music being mostly non-Armenian, the heavy metal band System of a Down has achieved prominence.
They even incorporate a lot of traditional Armenian instrumentals in their music.
Another example is pop star Cher. Ruben Hakobyan or Ruben Sasuntsi is a popular Armenian ethnographic and patriotic folk singer.
He is a national singer and known for his devotion to the Armenian folk music and exceptional voice.
Among the youth of the Armenian diaspora, the revolutionary songs are amongst the most popular.
These songs encourage Armenian patriotism and are generally about the Armenian history and national heroes.
BYU sponsors 21 NCAA varsity sports, with just under 20 percent of the student body participating on at least one varsity team.

[346] Nineteen of these sports have teams that primarily compete in the Mountain West Conference from 1999 to 2011; the other two sports—men's volleyball and men's soccer—compete in the Mountain Pacific Sports Federation and Western Athletic Conference, respectively.
Before the Mountain West Conference was formed, BYU teams competed in the Western Athletic Conference.
All teams are named the "Cougars", a name that was first introduced by Eugene L. Roberts in the 1920s.
Cosmo the Cougar has been the official mascot of BYU's athletic teams since 1953.

BYU's athletic fight song is the Cougar Fight Song. Because many students of both sexes delay enrollment in college for two years to serve as missionaries, BYU's athletes tend to be older on average than other schools' players.
Two years of full-time missionary service is encouraged of all Mormon men who are physically and mentally capable, and is part of the Mormon religion.

Young men may enter missionary service directly following high school, pending their reaching age eighteen (or 19 in pre-2012 rules); young women may begin their service at age nineteen (as of October 2012[347] or 21[348] under previous rules preceding October 2012).

Serving a mission does not prevent the student athlete from participating in the full four years of athletic eligibility as the NCAA two-year eligibility period clock remains "stopped" until the athlete enrolls as a full-time student, which is typically at the conclusion of a mission.

[349] This rule is considered by some to be a minor controversy,[350][351][352] although it is widely recognized by athletes, coaches and administrators that there is no competitive advantage gained as the athlete does not participate in any athletic or physical training during the mission.

BYU draws a significant amount of sports media attention for two reasons. Since BYU is sponsored by The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, its players are required to adhere to the church's honor code.
Over the past few years, BYU has dismissed a few players (who were on athletic scholarship) from its teams for violating the honor code.
[353][354] BYU's athletic program also holds the distinction of being the only NCAA program to have each athletic team receive at least one national championship title.

In the 2011 season, BYU became independent in college football. The Cougars left the Mountain West Conference at the end of the 2010–11 season and have joined the West Coast Conference for most of its non-football sports as of 2011.

The only exceptions to this are the aforementioned sports that already compete in other conferences, sports that the WCC does not sponsor (notably softball, which belonged to the WAC until 2012 and will move to the Pacific Coast Softball Conference afterward ),[355] and the BYU men's and women's swimming and diving teams and men's and women's indoor track and field teams, all of which also joined the MPSF alongside men's (outdoor) soccer.
[356] The BYU men's and women's outdoor track and field teams became independent as well following the school's departure from the MW.
Also, after spending the 2012 season in the PCSC, Cougars softball may be headed elsewhere after the 2013 season, as the conference announced in October 2012 that it will disband after that season.
This became all but certain after Pacific, a charter member of the WCC, announced that it would return to that conference in July 2013.
With the Tigers in the WCC fold, the conference will likely add softball, which it does not currently sponsor, in the near future.[357]
The attention of the Bush administration turned to Iraq, where the administration trumpeted the need to depose Saddam Hussein as quickly as possible.

This was alleged due to Iraq's record and capability of producing mass destruction weapons (WMD), Iraq's continuing support of terrorism, use of chemical agents in the Gulf War, alleged attempt to "purchase nuclear weapons-grade uranium from Niger " [39] and unaccounted for biological and chemical agents Iraq had produced previous to the Gulf War according to UNSCOM inspectors.
[40] Both the possession and failure to account for these weapons of mass destruction (WMD) would violate standing U. N. sanctions.

The grounds were initially trumpeted on by the Bush administration, but China, France, Germany, and Russia didn't feel that Iraq was a threat, and so blocked a UN Security Resolution authorizing force.

Allowing UN weapon inspectors into Iraq in November 2002, Iraq was still being inspected and the claims checked when the Bush Administration abruptly made up its mind and ordered that inspectors be removed in preparation for war.
The United States invaded Iraq on March 20, 2003, joined by a "coalition of the willing" including United Kingdom, and lesser component of Australian and Polish combat forces.

Within three weeks, the invasion led to the defeat and collapse of the Ba'athist Iraqi government and the flight, hiding, or capture of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's regime, although the rationale for the war was changed early on.
No WMDs were found, though traces of materials and labs used to make such weapons were reported.

Significant finds of various degradation chemical agents and warheads were also reported, but there were no discoveries made that constituted any clear evidence of WMD's , despite intensive investigation.
On May 1, George W. Bush landed on the aircraft carrier USS Abraham Lincoln, in front of a banner labeled "Mission Accomplished" and stated that "major combat operations in Iraq have ended".
[41] [42] [43] George Bush's approval rating rose to 66% in May according to a CNN–USA Today–Gallup poll.
[44] This would prove to be the short-term high-water mark. Popularity of the war itself was positive in the U. S. but eventually declined as the war dragged on.

Significant casualties, both military and civilian, were sustained. Difficulty of providing administrative stability and resistance by an insurgency eventually led to a substantial reduction of support for the occupation.
In addition, failure to find the predicted amount of WMD stockpiled in Iraq led to controversy.

About 20% of boys at Eton receive financial support of some kind;[33] Eton has expressed a commitment to broadening access to the school through means-tested bursaries, acting Head Master Tony Little said in 2005 that Eton was prepared to raise them to fund the expansion of the school in order to "maintain Eton's position as a leading educational institution".

[34] The Head Master, after finishing his first year, was quoted in The Times in 2003, stating that Eton would have to open up to students whose parents could not necessarily afford the fees: "We won't change what we do; just increase access to it."

In 2011 he said the school was "committed to a generous and increasing number of scholarships for talented boys or those in need", adding that the "total of boys with any level of fee remission" was "around 250".
[35] For the academic year 2013–14, the school reported that 263 boys (c 12%) received financial support amounting to two thirds or more of the full fee, and of those 63 paid no fees at all.
Eton additionally allows lower-income students to take the King’s Scholarship entrance exam with more lenient pass requirements.

Little has said he is "not content" with this: his ambition is for Eton to have around 320 pupils per annum receiving bursaries, and to have 70 on full fees; however, "even the current level of bursary requires money to be spent on fundraising".

[36] These hopes are denominated in the context of the school’s massive financial investment in the national partnership of state boarding schools; a personal project of Little’s, which he "was instrumental in setting up" and has received very substantial funding from Eton.
[37] These newer initiatives remain behind longstanding programmes to allow a wider range of state school students to experience Eton.
These are mostly undertaken during the summer holidays to avoid disrupting Eton’s own students’ study time.

The Universities Summer School is a residential programme for boys and girls from state schools who have just completed their first year of Sixth Form and are about to enter their second and final year.

It was founded in 1982 under the title, the Eton Summer School University Programme, as a flagship access programme designed to give academically gifted students from underprivileged backgrounds the opportunity to prepare university-entrance-style study.
The Brent-Eton Summer School is a programme aimed at promoting the transition between GCSE and AS-level between boys and girls in the London Borough of Brent and Eton College.
It was initiated by Sir William Atkinson, Headmaster of Phoenix High School in West London, in July 1994.
Since the start of the programme, an average of 40–50 students aged 15–17 have taken part in the week-long residential course that involves Eton staff.
The Service to Schools Scheme is something the staff have been doing on an ad hoc basis for decades; additionally there are OSS, Choral and other courses throughout the year and summer months.
In 2008, Eton co-founded the Eton, Slough, Windsor and Hounslow Independent and State School Partnership (ISSP), with six local state schools.
The Department for Children, Schools and Families described it as "an unprecedented partnership" and it was driven by the then children’s secretary, Ed Balls.
According to the Good Schools Guide the ISSP programme: "is widely recognised to be having a very positive impact on achievement, self-esteem and their aspirations.
They also provide valuable opportunities for professional development and the exchange of good practice.
"[38] In 2011, Eton helped found Holyport College, a state-maintained boarding school in Berkshire.
It was constructed at a cost of £15.4 million. A number of Eton staff act as governors, and sixth-form pupils from the two schools interact in a number of joint activities.[39]

Mid-1980s comebacks included Deep Purple, following a successful reunion tour they recorded the album Perfect Strangers (1984) that reached number 5 in the UK and the Top 5 in five other European countries, and number 17 on the Billboard 200, going platinum in the US.

Van Halen, whose fourth release Fair Warning (1981) did not even reach the Top 5, returned with their number 3 album Diver Down (1982), before rising to a commercial peak with 1984, the album of which reached number 2 on the Billboard 200 album chart and produced the number 1 hit for several weeks "Jump".

Also Heart, despite a hard time with their record label early in the decade, came back strongly with their number one ninth studio album and four Top 10 hits, including their first and only number one single.

Older generations of bands made use of the new medium of video channels; ZZ Top, one of the first, used the art to combine hard blues rock with southern rock and new wave music, resulting in a series of hit singles such as "Gimme All Your Lovin'" (1983) that helped the albums Eliminator (1983) and Afterburner (1985) reach diamond and multi-platinum statuses, respectively.

The comeback of the singles charts were partially due to softening it up with power ballads; of these REO Speedwagon's "Keep on Loving You" (1980) and "Can't Fight This Feeling" (1984), Journey's "Don't Stop Believin'" (1981) and "Open Arms" (1982), Foreigners "I Want to Know What Love Is" and Scorpions' "Still Loving You" (both 1984), Heart's "What About Love" (1985) and "These Dreams" (1986), and Boston's "Amanda" (1986)
Viking raids began in the 9th century and developed into more permanent settlements, notably on the east coasts of Ireland, the west coast of Scotland and the Isle of Man.
Vikings were eventually absorbed into Ireland, but other than some contributions as raiders, traders or settlers, cities, such as Dublin, Cork, Limerick, Waterford and Wexford, are a lasting legacy.
England was eventually overrun by the Vikings around the first millennium AD and became a feudal Danish possession.
The alliance between the descendants of Vikings in England with those in Normandy in northern France was a factor in the events surrounding the Norman conquest of England in 1066.
The Normandy in France that conquered England is still attached to the Crown of England as the Channel Islands.
A hundred years later, the marriage of Henry II of England and Eleanore of Aquitaine created the Angevian Empire, which was partly a vassalstate of France.
It was the Angevins who went to Ireland in 1169 at the invitation of a local king and under approval of Adrian IV the first and only English pope, who authorized it via the Papal Bull Laudabiliter.
Ireland was not made part of empire, but established as an independent kingdom.

After the High King failed to fulfil some promises part of the Treaty of Windsor, Henry II in his capacity as King of England ruled as leaves of the king of Ireland leaves him de facto king, with the title Lord of Ireland.
The title of Ireland was given to his younger son, but when the kings heir died, the English king and Irish Lord became one and same person.
There is no consensus as to which is in fact the world's oldest airport, and competing claims have been made regarding which airport is actually the oldest.

[non-primary source needed] For example, regarding Maryland's College Park Airport, operated by Prince George's County, as of 2008[update]: "The "world's oldest airport" is actually a title contested by around 20 airports, most notably by College Park.
The issue for some is that College Park is not a commercial airport." Another contender: "Bisbee-Douglas International Airport, Arizona.
1943: US President Franklin D Roosevelt refers to Bisbee-Douglas as 'the first international airport of the Americas'."
Pearson Field Airport in Vancouver, Washington affiliate has been in use since 1905 (a dirigible in that year, airplanes in 1911).
[non-primary source needed] Bremen Airport opened in 1913 but was exclusively used as an American military field from 1945 to 1949.
Amsterdam Airport Schiphol opened September 16, 1916 as a military airfield, but civil aircraft already landed there before December 17, 1920, when the airport officially switched to civil aviation.

This thus leaves Sydney Airport, which has been operated continuously since January 1920, the oldest continually-operating commercial airport, although it served only as an air mail and freight depot for some time after opening.
[6] Minneapolis-Saint Paul International Airport in the United States was opened in 1920 and has been in continuous commercial service since, now serving 35,000,000 passengers a year.
One of this airport's four terminals has since been rebuilt three times within the original terminal's foundation footprint.
[8][9] This recently expanded (11,000 ft (3,355 m) runway) major US hub airport even added another 8,000 ft (2,438 m) runway recently.
This may be the largest and busiest commercial airport that has stood or sat (in ASM) in one place so long.
Another contender is Rome Ciampino Airport (Aeroporto di Roma-Ciampino), near Rome, Italy, which opened in 1916.
One of the world's oldest continually operating airports is Don Mueang International Airport near Bangkok, Thailand which began operations in 1914.
[10][11] Increase in aircraft movements during World War I gave impetus to the development of landing fields.
As early as 1959, American observers believed that the USSR would make the first human spaceflight due to the time needed to prepare for the first Mercury launch.
[citation needed] On April 12, 1961 the USSR launched Yuri Gagarin into a single orbit around the Earth in a spacecraft named Vostok 1.
They dubbed Gagarin the first cosmonaut, an English transliteration of the Russian term for an astronaut.
[citation needed] The word is an acronym for the Russian phrase "sailor of the universe".
[citation needed] At the time, the term was used for Soviet space travelers, those of the United States were known as astronauts and those of China as taikonauts.

[citation needed] Although he had the ability to take over manual control of his spacecraft in an emergency by opening an envelope he had been given and entering the code it contained into the controls, it was flown in a fully automatic mode because medical science at that time did not know what would happen to a human in the weightlessness of space[citation needed].
Vostok 1 orbited the Earth for 108 minutes and made its re-entry over the Soviet Union, with Gagarin ejected from the spacecraft at 7,000 metres (23,000 ft), and landed by parachute.
The FAI rules at the time the Soviet Union did not require pilots to land with their craft, so it recognized Gagarin as the first human in space.
[citation needed] Gagarin's flight was a propaganda coup, with the Soviet Union sending the FAI documentation for the flight that gave a precise time for a complete orbit of the Earth.
Unknown to anyone outside the Soviet Union, the actual flight time was 104 minutes; it would not be revealed until 30 years later that Gagarin did not complete a full orbit.

When the FAI filing for Gherman Titov's second Vostok flight in August 1961 disclosed the claim that the pilot had been ejected from the spacecraft and landed by parachute, officials considered whether this would disqualify Gagarin's claim to the first human to fly in space.

[citation needed] They decided that the technological accomplishment of the launch, orbit, and safe return was the deciding factor, and therefore declined to seek to alter the list of record-holders.[53][54]

sentences.text: The Chief Commissioner's Province of Himachal Pradesh was organised on 15 April 1948 as a result of the integration of 28 petty princely states (including feudal princes and zaildars) in the promontories of the western Himalayas, which acceded to the Government of India after independence.
Himachal became a province in 1951. The State of Bilaspur was merged into Himachal Pradesh on 1 April 1954 on enactment by Parliament of the Himachal Pradesh and Bilaspur (New State) Act, 1954.
Himachal Pradesh became a Part 'C' state on 26 January 1950 with the implementation of the Constitution of India and the Lieutenant Governor was appointed.
The Legislative Assembly was elected in 1952 In 1956 Himachal Pradesh became a union territory on 1 November 1956.

Some areas of Punjab State – namely Simla, Kangra, Kullu and Lahaul and Spiti Districts, Nalagarh tehsil of Ambala District, Lohara, Amb and Una kanungo circles, some other specified parts of Una tehsil of Hoshiarpur District and Dalhousie kanungo circle of Pathankot tehsil of Gurdaspur District were merged with Himachal Pradesh on 1 November 1966 on enactment by Parliament of the Punjab Reorganisation Act, 1966.

The State of Himachal Pradesh Act was passed by Parliament on 18 December 1970 and the new state came into being on 25 January 1971. Thus Himachal emerged as the eighteenth state of the Indian Union.[26]

For most of the 20th century it was called Serbo-Croatian (Books 1,2,3). But during earlier centuries and millennia of South Slav history, the regional and ethnic languages (such as Chakavian, Kajkavian, and Shtokavian) developed independently.
Until the 19th, century, these languages were generically called "Illyric," "Slavic," "Slavonian," "Bosnian," "Dalmatian," "Serbian," or "Croatian."
The word "Serbo-Croatian" was coined by Jacob Grimm in 1824, adopted and popularized by Jernej Kopitar, a Viennese philologist, and endorsed by Croatian Zagreb grammarians in 1854 and1859.
This was at a time when the lands of the Serbs and Croats still bore the yoke of Ottoman and Austrian rule.
Officially the language was called Serbo-Croat, Croato-Serbian, Serbian and Croatian, Croatian and Serbian or, less commonly, Serbian or Croatian as well as Croatoserbian.
Unofficially, Serbs and Croats generally called the language "Serbian" or "Croatian," without distinguishing it from the other.
In independent Bosnia and Herzegovina, "Bosnian", "Croatian" and "Serbian" are considered to be three names of a single official language.

Croatian linguist Dalibor Brozović used the term "Serbo-Croatian" in the title of a scientific article published in the journal Jezik, and as late as 1988 the official seal of the Croatian language society had an inscription on the top, in parentheses, that said: Hrvatski (ili srpski), [Croatian (or Serbian)].

Brozović voted, alongside Ljudevit Jonke, in favor on Brozović's definition of the Croatian literary language in Matica hrvatska, slightly differently from the definition adopted by the Serbian Matica.

Brozović admitted in his book from 1988 that the terms Croatian or Serbian (for a single language) were invented even earlier, but that he still considered the term Serbo-Croatian the most appropriate, because, in a similar way to, for example Indo-European and often used to name the languages of Southeastern Europe, it denoted the region where the language was spoken.
Thus he accepted designation of the hypothetical language, no matter how many nations spoke it (he counted 4 including Bosnian and Montenegrin).

(D. Brozović, J. Jelenić: Jezik i lingvistika. Prosvjeta, Zagreb, 1988.) In the 20th and 21st century, the term Serbo-Croatian is contentious due to the fact it is generally considered that a nation and a language should be one.

The term Serbo-Croatian is in use because there is no better short name for the language to which subject books pertain (alternatives are proposed such as Bosnian/Croatian/Serbian (BCS), which is used only in strictly political contexts such as in the international Hague War Crimes tribunal). }

The Jurassic Period is a geologic period and system that spans 56.3 million years from the end of the Triassic Period 201.3 ± 0.2 Mya (million years ago) Mya to the beginning of the Cretaceous Period 145.0 Mya The Jurassic constitutes the middle period of the Mesozoic Era, also known as the Age of Reptiles.
The start of the period was marked by the major Triassic-Jurassic extinction event.
Two other extinction events occurred during the period: the Pliensbachian-Toarcian extinction in the Early Jurassic, and the Tithonian event in the Late Jurassic.
The Jurassic is named after the Jura Mountains within the European Alps, where limestone strata from the period were first identified.
During the Early Jurassic, the supercontinent Pangaea broke apart into the continents Laurasia to the north and Gondwana to the south.

The Gulf of Mexico opened in the new rift between North America and the Yucatan platform of modern-day Mexico, and Atlantic ocean basin opened between Europe and Africa, but at first narrowed towards modern Iberia and was closed off by Iberia's collision with Europe.
The North Atlantic was relatively narrow, while the South Atlantic did not open until the following Cretaceous period, when Gondwana itself rifted apart.
The Tethys Sea closed, and the Neotethys basin appeared. Climates were warm, with no evidence of glaciation.
As in the Triassic, there was apparently no land over either pole, and no extensive ice caps existed.
The Jurassic geological record is represented by several exposures in Western Europe, where the stratigraphy is well-established.
Marine sequences are also well exposed in the western North America and South America, and there is much known from a series of exposures in Russia, India, Japan, Australasia and the United Kingdom.
The Jurassic Coast World Heritage Site in southern England is a prominent example of Jurassic marine life and showcases many excellent fossils.
In contrast, the Jurassic stratigraphy of eastern North America is primarily continental, and consequently nonmarine; also, it is limited due to the absence of rifting at that time.
The Jurassic was a golden age for dinosaurs, as they were the dominant terrestrial vertebrates.
The first birds also appeared during the Jurassic, having evolved from a branch of theropod dinosaurs.
Other major events include the appearance of the earliest lizards, and the evolution of therian mammals, including primitive placentals.
Crocodylomorphs made the transition from land to water, leading to the evolution of modern day crocodilians.
The oceans were inhabited by marine reptiles such as ichthyosaurs, plesiosaurs and ammonites, while pterosaurs were the dominant flying vertebrates.
In January 1920, Tito and his wife returned to Yugoslavia, where in the autumn he entered the ranks of the Communist Party of Yugoslavia (CPY).
The CPY's influence on the Kingdom of Yugoslavia's political scene increased rapidly.
In the 1920 parliamentary elections the Communists won 59 seats and became the third strongest group.
They also won several local elections and became an important factor in local politics in the second largest city Zagreb, electing Svetozar Delić as mayor.

On 2 August 1921, in the aftermath of the assassination of the Yugoslav Minister of the Interior, Milorad Drašković, by a young communist, the Communist Party was declared illegal under the Yugoslav State Security Act of 1921, and the Communist MPs' mandates were nullified.
[16][36] After the banning of the Communist party, Tito continued his illegal Communist party work in Yugoslavia.
At the end of 1920, Tito moved to Veliko Trojstvo near Bjelovar, where he was employed as a machinist.
[37] In 1925, he moved to Kraljevica where he got a job in a shipyard. There he was elected as a union leader and during 1926, he led a shipyard strike.

He subsequently lost his job and moved to Belgrade. After his efforts to organize strikes in a train coach factory in Smederevska Palanka failed, he returned to Zagreb, where he was appointed secretary of the Metal Workers' Union of Croatia.
In July 1928, he was appointed by the Zagreb Branch of the CPY to be their representative at the 4th Congress of the Communist Party of Yugoslavia in Dresden.
On 4 November 1928, he was arrested and imprisoned in the Petrinjska Street prison where he spent several months.
[38][39] In 1929, he was convicted of being a member of the then-illegal Communist Party of Yugoslavia and sentenced to five years' imprisonment.
[40] He served out his sentence in Lepoglava and Maribor, where he became acquainted with Moša Pijade, who was to become his ideological mentor.

[41] During his prison term he adopted the nom de guerre "Tito".[42] Stalinist purge wave (1936–1940) [ edit ] Image of the Moscow Trials where many of the accused and executed Yugoslav communists were co-defendants.
It was during this period that Tito became closely intertwined with the Soviets' WKP(B) and delegate to the Comintern.
After his release, he lived in Samobor, where he started a career as a communist functionary.
In 1934 he became General Secretary of the CPY.[43] During his period in revolutionary underground activity within the League of Communists of Yugoslavia, Tito assumed various code names.
"Walter" was one; "Tito" was another. This last was the name he adopted for the rest of his life.
Other religious ideas were floated during the Enlightenment, such as Deism or the idea of atheism.
As Thomas Paine put it, Deism entailed “the belief of a God, and only one God,” and did not “believe any thing” that came “ever of the Bible” or of the “other books called sacred and canonical.
” Instead, Deists believed that, with the power of “common reason,” they would form their own convictions, which was a principle many Enlightened thinkers gravitated toward.

The idea of atheism was discussed, and few ever held to it. Wilson and Reill state that very few Enlightenment Ideas, even critics of Christianity, were actual atheists, but [rather] critics of orthodoxy were more often skeptics, deists, vitalists or even pantheists… and that some concluded (such as those influenced by Pierre Bayle) that atheists were not necessarily immoral.
Others (like Voltaire) argued that if this world did not have a belief in a God that punishes sinners, then we would lose the moral fabric of society.
Atheists, after all, were beholden to no Supreme Law or Authority and had no ultimate fear of damnation, so it would pose a threat to social order.
Bayle (1647–1706) wrote that in this world, “prudent men will always be seen to observe [their religion]”.
Bayle believed that atheists can be honorable and/or motivated by more than selfish necessity when dealing with other members of society.

Some others (like Locke) wrote that the lack of God or authority of God’s Law would reduce the world into mere moral chaos, into an “everyone for himself”-type of society, because “everyone would become a god to himself, without any respect for any kind of resppect to anyone else’s authority.” Citing Locke, “Promising and covenanting would be vain, and no concernment unless men were naturally obliged to perform their covenants, they would have no tie nor hold upone them”, and “the taking away of God, though but even in thought, dissolves all, it takes away both the measure and reason of convenience.”

The Caliph (in Arabic: خليفة , khalīfah, meaning successor) is the highest Islamic title in Islamic polity (see Caliphate), and the Ottoman sultans, starting with Murad I, were its claimants, regarded in later periods as the de facto holders of this title.
Thus, the Ottoman state was by contemporaries and is today sometimes referred to as the Ottoman Caliphate.
The Ottoman sultan, pâdişâh (sometimes padishah), was the sole regent and was considered the embodiment of the state, although he did not always exercise complete control.
The Imperial Harem was one of the most important powers of the Ottoman court. It was ruled by the Valide Sultan.
In certain times, the harem was able to rule the state, in a period known as the Sultanate of Women (kadınlar saltanatı).

Occasionally, the sultan would be a minor, and a regent would rule instead, often the Valide Sultan, which means mother of the sultan. Sultans were typically chosen from among the sons of the previous sultan.
The early organisation of the Ottoman state was propelled by the Beyliks, taking care of most of the administration.

The palace school (Enderûn) was based on the devshirme system, a form of meritocracy designed to create the governing class which would support the sultan and keep the ruling elite fresh and capable, although it functioned for practical purposes to gather and to train future administrators and rulers of the Empire.
The palace schools had two tracks, called an "inner" service (Enderûn) and an "outer" service (birun).

The Madrasa (or medrese in Ottoman Turkish language) was a free Muslim school system intended for the education of the Muslim ulama, which educated scholars and state officials in accordance with the Islamic tradition.
The curriculum of the Madrasa was considerably broader than the Enderûn, teaching a variety of subjects ranging from medicine to Islamic theology.
There are many Madrases around the world, each usually affiliated with a single mosque.
They were financed by vakifs, allowing children of poor families to move to higher social levels and income.
The second track was the Enderûn, which was a free boarding school for Christians.
3,000 Christian boys between the ages of eight and 20 were taken from one in 40 families in Rumelia by the Devshirme, (Devşirme).

Thales (c. 624–545 BC) and Xenophanes (c. 570–480 BC) are both credited as first Greek humanists, for turning away from mythological worldviews, and offering cosmological views grounded in humans and their reasoning.
Xenophanes was the first Greek who is known to have doubted religion and the anthropomorphic gods.
He believed that there was one supreme god. Thales questioned the notion of anthropomorphic gods.
These Ionian pre-Socratic philosophers argued that nature, and not the caprices of the gods, governed the cosmos.
Anaxagoras brought philosophy and the spirit of rational inquiry from Ionia to Athens.
He was a close friend of Pericles, who ruled Athens between the Persian and Peloponnesian wars.
Other well-known pre-Socratics include Protagoras who coined the phrase "man is the measure of all things" and Democritus who proposed that matter was made up of atoms.
The historian Thucydides is also much admired by later humanists. Nearly all of the writings of the pre-Socratics are lost.
They are known mainly from fragments and quotations in the writings of later philosophers.
In the 3rd century BC, Epicurus, studied atomism and agreed with the Cynics that the gods were unconcerned with human beings.
He is known for writing Forthy Principal Doctrines, and for rejected the ideas of an afterlife, and for writing "the problem of evil".

He taught No Fear, No Pain. He argued that humans should strive for euidamonia (happiness or wellbeing) through a strong knowledge of the world, and managing desires. His school was the first to regularly admit women.
On December 13, 2013, Beyoncé released her fifth self-titled studio album without any prior announcement or promotion.
[157] Described as a "visual album", its songs were accompanied by non-linear short films that illustrate the musical concepts conceived during production.
[158] The album debuted atop the Billboard 200 chart, giving Beyoncé her fifth consecutive number one album in the US.
[159] This made her the first woman in the US chart history to have her first five studio albums debut at number one.

[160] Beyoncé received critical acclaim[161][162] and commercial success, selling one million digital copies worldwide in six days;[163] The New York Times commented, "The album and its inventive rollout is one of the year’s most significant cultural events.
"[164] The single "Drunk in Love", featuring Jay-Z, peaked at number two on the Billboard Hot 100 chart.
[165] The album also marked the conclusion of Beyoncé's recording contract with Sony Music, which had released her solo albums since 2003, as well as those with Destiny's Child.
[166] In April 2014, after much speculation, Beyoncé and Jay-Z announced their first co-headlining stadium tour together, On the Run Tour (2014).
[167] Beyoncé and Jay-Z were jointly named the most powerful couple for TIME magazine's 100 most influential people of 2014 list.
[168] In June, Beyoncé was named the World's Most Powerful Woman in Music on the same list.
[169] At the 2014 MTV Video Music Awards, Beyoncé was awarded the Michael Jackson Video Vanguard Award and won three additional awards, including Video of the Year for "Drunk in Love".
[170] In November, Forbes reported that Beyoncé was the top-earning woman in music for the second year in a row, earning $115 million in the year, more than double her earnings in 2013.

[171] In November, Beyoncé announced that she was dropping the singles "7/11" and "Ring Off" from the reissue of her fifth studio album The Platinum Edition, released in three formats: a standalone two-CD album, as Best Buy exclusive editions with new material, and as a box set with additional goodies.
[172] On March 16, 2015, it was announced that Beyoncé and husband Jay-Z were launching their own music streaming service, Tidal, a subscription-based competing with Spotify and Apple Music.

United Kingdom[edit] While the United Kingdom political system served as the predominant model for that of the U.S. constitution, the UK had not adopted a strict separation of powers into its own constitution.
The United Kingdom had long since developed under an "unwritten constitution", that is to say, the sum of constitutional law as it stood in precedence, convention and statute.

The King-in-Parliament had developed into the British Parliament (consisting nominally of the Sovereign (King-in-Parliament), the House of Lords, and the House of Commons), the supreme legislative body within the United Kingdom and many of its colonies.
[23] Similarly, the executive power had been extracted from the Crown (King-in-Council) and established as the Cabinet (privy council), and as the government responsible to Parliament.
While the sovereign no longer (save in rare instances) presided at Cabinet meetings, the government remained, in its formulation of policy, "His Majesty's Government".
[24] Moreover, members of the Cabinet (the King's Ministers) were required to be sitting members of either one of the two Houses of Parliament.
Nearly all Ministers were drawn from the Commons rather than the Lords, with the prime minister remaining responsible to the Lower House alone.

[25] The judiciary remained equally closely linked to Parliament; the House of Lords served as a court of appeal both domestically, and within the greater British Commonwealth were it was at the top of the hierarchy.
The King (or more correctly, the Lord Chancellor) suggested appointment of judges, and in practice was held to consult with the Prime Minister.
[26] One such minister who was selected from each Cabinet remained Lord Chancellor, both the sole judge in the Court of Chancery and the presiding officer in the House of Lords.

[27] Because of these extensive overlapping elements, the British constitution remained only partially separated between branches of government, in many cases not at all; resulting in starkly different lines of accountability and responsibility from those the US constitution developed.

[28] Indeed, while conflicts of interest between members were present in other constitutions, such lines were well defined and uncommon within the British political system, and few months would go by without some agitation on the subject.
[29] United States states[edit] Various eighteenth century U. S. state constitutions included no, partial, or complete, degrees of separation of powers.
For example, the Governor of Delaware was also a member of the Court of Appeals, and the President of Delaware was a member of the Court of Appeals.
In addition, Presidents of the Delaware General Assembly served as the state's vice president, while members of the state's Executive Council served as judges.
In Pennsylvania, members of the Supreme Executive Council served as judges, and the Council's President served on the Court of Appeals.
No state official in Delaware or Pennsylvania was able to exercise veto power, strengthening the legislature's capacity.

[30] Of the Southern states, Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina, and Georgia all maintained a very strict separation of powers, listing that the branches of government remain "separate and distinct."[31]
Notre Dame rose to national prominence after its football team found success in the early 20th century,[39] reflecting the growing prestige of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s.
Catholics rallied to the school when the K. of C. and Archbishop Shaw of New Orleans underlined that Notre Dame's success was their success.

Yet it was apart from the American Protestants and their universities. The Catholics were centralized and the Catholic hierarchy wanted the school to be the preeminent Catholic university in the United States.

Catholics everywhere (mostly Irish immigrants in the cities) became fans of the Fighting Irish, particularly in its battles against schools that symbolized the Anglo-Protestants, like Harvard University, Yale University, Princeton University, and Army.
[40] Its role as a high-profile flagship institution of Catholicism made it an easy target of anti-Catholicism.
The most remarkable episode of violence was a clash between Notre Dame students and the Ku Klux Klan (KKK), a white supremacist and anti-catholic movement, in 1924.
Anti-Catholicism was one of the most important platforms of the KKK and they often used paraphernalia from the Notre Dame college (such as post cards and rings) to fuel fear of the 'Catholic menace'.

on March 17 during a week-long Klavern in South Bend. The school was alerted to the presence of the Klan and of their aggressive attitudes towards their religion, preventing one thousand Klansmen from getting off their trains at the South Bend station, tearing KKK clothes and regalia off Klan members in a violent confrontation.
on May 19 thousands of students massed downtown protesting the Klavern, and only the arrival of college President Fr.
Matthew Walsh prevented a riot. The next day, Rockne spoke at a campus rally, asking the students to obey the college president and refrain from further violence.
Soon, the Klavern dispersed, but the massive student outpouring showcased the negative view of the Klan in South Bend and undermined KKK's influence in Indiana.[41][42]
The last major building work took place during the reign of King George V when, in 1913, Sir Aston Webb redesigned Blore's 1850 East Front to resemble, in part, Giacomo Leoni's Lyme Park in Cheshire.

[8][43] The re-faced principal façade was designed as a backdrop to the Victoria Memorial, the creation of which had been the catalyst for the refacing of the palace, and the refacing was completed in time for the memorial's unveiling on 16 May 1911.
[44] During World War I the palace, then the residence of King George V and Queen Mary, escaped unscathed.

The King's children, the Princess Mary and the Prince of Wales (later Edward VIII) often visited wounded officers at the palace, with the Queen and her daughter knitting comforts for soldiers serving overseas.
King George V, Edward VII's son, was a very different character from his ebullient, sociable father.

He was not fond of the palace; his wife, Queen Mary preferred Clarence House. George V's reign saw the palace host the first of three command performances: jazz musicians, notably the Original Dixieland Jazz Band (1919), the first jazz band to play for a head of state[45] and, later, such jazz musicians as Sidney Bechet (1932) and Louis Armstrong (1932), and its nomination, in 2009, for a (Kind of) Blue Plaque by the Brecon Jazz Festival for its services to jazz.
[45] refname="kind of blue"/ Queen Mary was interested in the arts[46] and Buckingham Palace became the home of the Royal Collection's greatest treasures and masterpieces.

Queen Mary was also an eager and competent curator of her collection.[46] A grande dame issime, she arranged the installation of a collection of miniatures in the new Bow Room on the ground floor (the large central room on the garden façade).

[46] The queen also planned and furnished a series of rooms on the second floor at the north end of the palace with chintz fabric and comfortable arm chairs known as "the chintz rooms" and furnished with some of her favourite pieces of art.
Another of Queen Mary's additions was the pair of Empire-style marble chimneypieces by Benjamin Vulliamy with carving by Paul Storr from Carlton House in the Bow Room.
