[47] Also during this period, in the Blue Drawing Room, the tall windows were altered so that they were filled in with mirrors to allow for wall space.
Formerly known as the South Drawing Room, redesigned by Nash in time for Queen Victoria's accession.
This is one of the most lavishly decorated rooms in the palace and is the first room on the tour of the state rooms.
The ceiling is of gilt and white plaster designed by Nash featuring a coffered design with huge gilt console brackets, a central skylight and trompe-l'œil clouds.[48]

The European a cappella tradition, which was developing at the same time, originated with the Gregorian chant, though a capeella became popular when it was developed, evolving into the polyphony of Josquin des Prez near the end of the 15th century.
Early polyphony was often sung with instrumental accompaniment; however, the instruments did not partake in the music, but rather duplicated the notes being sung by the singers.
By the early 16th century, a cappella polyphony had grown to a high degree of complexity, in turn soon to be replaced in popularity by the cantata.
Nevertheless, the 16th century a capella polyphony itself drawn upon, was a persistent influence in church composers beyond the 16th, remaining so during the 16th.

It has recently been found that part or all of Palestrina's works, such as his early compositions done for the Sistine Chapel, were intended to be performed with an organ, which would "double" some or all the voices.
Palestrina served as a strong influence on Bach, particularly on his Mass in B Minor.

Other composers, who used the a cappella style at least occasionally throughout the 16th and 17th centuries, were Claudio Monteverdi, (his "Largimea D’amante Al Sepolcro Dell’Amata" (A Lover’s Tears at His Beloved’s Grave) from the "Madrigali," (Madri Gali) from 1610); and Andrea Gabrieli, whose a cappella choral music was found and published after his death.
Heinrich Schütz, drawing upon these influences, composed a number of pieces in the a cappella style, and particularly the works he composed in the style of the oratorio.
These pieces, at the time mostly limited to Easter week, when oratorios would traditionally be performed, were often centered upon Christ’s suffering and the history of the Passion.
Of the five "Historien" that Schütz wrote for Easter, the last three were the Passion, according to Matthew, Luke, and John, all composed and performed a cappella.

The style of writing was almost at the time required for such music, with the crowd parts being sung, and the solos, usually to be Christ, though also the Evangelists, the writers of the Gospels, often switching roles, being in plainchant.
Asian Americans make up 13% of New York City's population.[218] New York City contains the highest total Asian population of any U.S. city proper.
[219] 2010 Census estimates of the Asian American population in New York City are approximately 1,028,119;[220][221] more than the combined totals of San Francisco and Los Angeles.
[222] Nearly 1 in 6 Asian Americans live in the city.[223] Queens holds the state's largest Asian American population and is also the most ethnically diverse urban area in the world.
[224][225] The Asian population in New York City is spread out, which is different from cities such as San Francisco and Los Angeles, where the Asian population is more concentrated.

[220] The Chinese population constitutes the fastest-growing nationality in New York State; multiple large Chinatowns in Brooklyn and around Flushing, Queens[226] are thriving as traditionally urban enclaves – and as large as the original Manhattan Chinatown.
[227] Queens and Nassau counties comprise the New York metropolitan area's Long Island, which is home to several Little Indias and a large Koreatown,[228][229] as well as Asiatown.
[230] The New York City borough of Queens is also home to several Little Indias and a large Koreatown, as well as Chinatown and Filipino Town.
Koreatown and Chinatown, Manhattan are also located in New York City. Ganesh Temple Street, in Flushing, Queens, is lined with Indian restaurants.
[231] The 1970s and 80s also saw establishment of a large Pakistani community in New York City, primarily in New Queens, where Little Pakistan can be found.

New York City is also home to the largest African community outside Africa, and the largest Russian-Jewish community outside Israel, with the major center of both communities being located in Brooklyn.
South Asians constitute 3.8% of the city's population and 1.9% of the state's population.
Indians are the largest South Asian group, representing 2.4% of the city population (up from 1.6% in 2000) and (tracking from 0.9% in 2000).
Bangladeshis and Pakistanis have 0.7% and 0.5% of the city population, respectively.
Filipinos are the largest Southeast Asian ethnic group, making up 0.8% of the city population, followed by Vietnamese at 0.2%. Koreans made up 1.2% of the city population, and Japanese 0.3%.
New York City's metropolitan area is also home to the largest Tibetan population outside China, India, and Nepal, also centered in Queens.

[232] Queens has the majority of Asian Indians, Koreans and Filipinos, as well as Malaysians, and other Southeast Asians; whereas Brooklyn and growing numbers continue to move into the area as well as Indians.
In 2012, 6.3% of New York was of Chinese ethnicity, with nearly 3/4 of them living in either Queens or Brooklyn, geographically on Long Island.
Flushing, Queens, is also home to a large community of 20,000 Korean Chinese,[233] or Joseonjok.
The New York metropolitan region is also home to the largest number of overseas Chinese outside of Asia, combining for a population of over 800,000 as of 2013.
[234] Continuing significant immigration from Mainland China, both legal and illegal in origin,[235] is adding to the Chinese American population in the area.
The Chinese population in New York City is the highest of any city proper, other than the four cities of Greater China (Beijing, Hong Kong, Shanghai and Taipei).
Anthropologists Jeffrey Long and Rick Kittles address the problem of FST in their 2003 article Human Genetic Diversity and the Nonexistence of Biological Races.
They note that, By far the most common misstatement of the 85% figure is a sentence of the form it has been shown that, on average, each human group contains 85% of all human genetic diversity.
The historical aspects of a global population are often portrayed as each group acting independently of the others.
But the conclusions of the recent African origin model shows that it is more accurate to say that some groups are paraphyletic with respect to others.
The African population would be paraphyletic with respect to all other non-African groups, as non-Africans are derived from this ancestral African population.
Non-African groups split off from African ones not by taking a representative slice of the African population.
Instead, these non-African groups were the result of reproduction in only part of the population that crossed the geographical barrier out of Africa to form their own populations.
As a result, non-African populations are closer to each other (and to at least one African group, presumably eastern Africans) than they are to other African populations.
This shows that when humans moved out of Africa, they left the bulk of African diversity behind.

This interpretation of geographical movement among human populations points away from independent human groups, to a dilution of diversity courses from the locations furthest away from Africa, with each movement resulting in a representative sample of the previous population.
Instead of 85%, Long and Kittles found that nearly 100% of human genetic diversity is in a single African population, while only 70% is found within one taken from New Guinea.
Yet even with these statistics, Long and Kittles still conclude that, relative to other mammalian populations, human ones are globally homogenous.
Emotions, for example, are motivational tools for social living and bonding and are tied to hard-wired physiological underpinnings such as the stress reaction systems.
Furthermore, their physiological basis is rooted in a particular antistress complex, namely the attachment system (Oxytocin) which is essential to our social bonding development.
Emotional temperaments are a key element to sociality and therefore fitness in the context of ecologically and structurally complex social organizations (Kurt Kortschal 2013).
Such emotion-linked traits can be observed across species, indicating some form of genetic phenomena and continuous inheritance.
DNA (deoxyribonucleic-acid) sequences carry information that function as programs of instructions for the assembling of proteins (the stuff of life) in cells.

Zygotes cannot develop without genetic information from the germ cells of the parents in the form of heritable characteristics that enabled its ancestors to survive and reproduce at some time in the past.
Since the split of extant human and chimpanzee lineages about five mya, little more than 1.
2 per cent of their total DNA has diverged. Therefore everything that makes them different (including behavior) is written in that small portion of DNA.
In Basic Books of Sociobiology Other strains of inferential evidence for a link between behavior and genes come from intraspecific observation of genes-dependent behavioral traits in animals.
For instance, a small number of genetic polymorphisms in a single gene coding for a vasopressin receptor in voles (Microtus spp. )
are associated with qualitative differences in social organization and mating strategies (Hammock & Young 2005).
Another example is the FOCP2 gene, involved in the regulation of neural circuits implicated in speech and language (Vargha-Khadem et al.
2005). The precise mutated human structure of this gene has been fixed in our lineage for about 200, 000 years, coincident with the birth of modern Homo sapiens (Enard et al.
2002). Speech, language and social organization are the particular factors in which our emotive expression are structured.

Nanjing (listen; Chinese: 南京, Mandarin pronunciation: [nǎn.tɕíŋ] (About this soundlisten)), historically also known as Nanking (pronounced /ˈnænˈdʒɪŋ/;[5][6] Chinese: 南京) and Nankin,[7] is the capital of Jiangsu province of the People's Republic of China and the second largest city in the East China region,[8] with an administrative area of 6,600 km2 (2,500 sq mi) and a total population of 8,216,100 as of 2018.

The inner area of Nanjing enclosed by the city wall is Nanjing City (南京城), with an area of 55 km2 (21 sq mi), while the Nanjing Metropolitan Region includes surrounding cities and areas, covering over 60,000 km2 (23,000 sq mi), with a population of over 30 million.

[citation needed] Situated in the Yangtze River Delta region, Nanjing has a prominent place in Chinese history and culture, having served as the capital of various Chinese dynasties, kingdoms and republican governments dating from the 3rd century to 1949,[9] and has thus long been a major centre of culture, education, research, politics, economy, transport networks and tourism.

Nanjing has been ranked seventh in the evaluation of "Cities with Strongest Comprehensive Strength" issued by the National Statistics Bureau, and second in the evaluation of cities with most sustainable development potential in the Yangtze River Delta.
Nanjing has also been awarded the title of 2008 Habitat Scroll of Honour of China, Special UN Habitat Scroll of Honour Award and National Civilized City.
Gabler started recording for his own new label, Commodore Records, in January 1938 and used 12-inch records to allow for longer performances.

[2] Eddie Condon explained: "Gabler realized that a jam session needs room. Then, too, he put the music on twelve-inch records because the standard ten-inch variety wasn't long enough for what we had in mind.

"[3] The first two 12-inch recordings released by Commodore, "Carnegie Drag" and "Carnegie Jump", were only 3:15 and 2:41 in length, respectively, but Commodore's continuing releases would more often stretch out closer to (or over) the four-minute mark.
(Carnegie Hall had strict rules banning dancing, so the musicians gave the titles different names in honor of The Hall.)
Other examples were "Embraceable You" (4:05) and "Serenade to a Shylock" (4:32).
An obvious way to get around the time limitation was to issue a song over two sides of a single record.

As early as 1922, vaudeville stars Gallagher and Shean released their "Mr. Gallagher and Mr. Shean"—written by Irving and Jack Kaufman—as an A side and a B side that ran a total of 5:22 for the duo, issued on Cameo, which split both sides of the record into part 1 and part 2.
An obvious solution for longer items was to release a "set" of several records.
HMV in England produced an album with a complete recording of Verdi's opera Ernani in 1903.

It used 40 single sided discs. In 1940, Commodore released a multi-part version of Eddie Condon and his Band's "A Good Man Is Hard to Find", with four "parts", one part per side, issued on both sides of two 12-inch 78s.

Until the invention of the LP (Long Play) record in 1948, the typical record available to the public was a 10-inch type running no longer than about 3:30 or a 10-inch running no longer than 4:30; a long song might require listeners to change records in the middle of the song or piece.
This may be one reason that many songs recorded before 1948 are about three minutes in length.
One exception is Frank Sinatra's recording of Rodgers and Hammerstein's "Soliloquy", from Carousel, made on 28 May 1946.
Because the song runs 7:57, longer than both sides of a standard 78-rpm record, it had to be divided into two parts, one on each side of the disc.
The record was released in July 1946[4] as part of an album set by Columbia Records.
The song would not fit on just one side of a 10-inch 78-rpm record, so a two sided disc was used, a relatively unusual occurrence in the recording industry.
"An entire book could be written about soliloquies on records. In order to get them all in, you'd need to use the large economy size.

"[5] (Ironically, this technically made the recording Sinatra's only classical album released during his lifetime, because the record was issued on Columbia's Masterwork label, the company's classical division.)

John Raitt's performance of the song on the original cast album of Carousel is not divided, as it would have been if it had been issued on a commercial single; the cast album was issued in 1945 as a set of 78-rpm records by American Decca.

Thuringia is divided into a number of traditional landscapes, from north to south: In the extreme north lies the Harz mountains with the area of the Goldene Aue (floodplain around Nordhausen) in the south and the region of Eichsfeld in the west.

It is a hilly, partially forested region where the Leine river rises. Another mountain chain is in the northwest, the Hainleite with Schmücke and Hohe Schrecke, part of the northern rim of the Thuringian Basin.

The central and the northern part of Thuringia is defined by the 3,000 km2 (1,200 sq mi) flat and fertile Thuringian Basin around the Unstrut river, surrounded by various hill chains, called Dün, Hainleite, Windleite, Kyffhäuser, Hohe Schrecke, Schmücke, Finne, Ettersberg, Steigerwald, Thuringian Forest, Hörselberge and Hainich.
Within the Basin, the Fahner Höhe and Heilinger Höhe are prominent hill chains.

South of the Thuringian Basin follows the Thuringian Forest, the biggest mountain range of Thuringia with a highly forested part in the northwest, called Thuringian Forest, a less forested part in the middle, called Thuringian Highland and a plateau in the southeast, called Franconian Forest.

This range has an average altitude around 800 m and also the highest mountain in Thuringia – Großer Beerberg with an altitude of 983 m. To the southwest, the Thuringian Forest leads into the Werra valley, followed by the Rhön Mountains on the western border with Hesse and the Grabfeld plain on the border with Bavaria.

Eastern Thuringia south of the Harz mountains and east of the Thuringian Basin is an area which is described as flat to hilly but increasingly hilly and mountainous from north to south and from west to east.
The two main rivers in the area are the Saale (west) and the Weiße Elster (east), both flow in a northwards direction in the densely populated valleys.
Between the rivers, the Holzland in the north is a flat, forested region, followed by the flat and fertile Orlasenke, the hilly and unwooded region of the Vogtland in the south.

The far east of Thuringia east of the White Elster is known as Osterland, sometimes further differentiated into the Altenburger Land and the Ronneburger Aue, a flat, fertile and densely populated agricultural area. The Pleiße is the main river of the region.

In 1972, shock-rock pioneer Alice Cooper, who had been a leader of a number of U.S. proto-heavy metal bands, reached number 1 in the Hot 100 with "School's Out" and number 2 on the album chart with the LP of the same name.

In 1973, ZZ Top released their classic hard-rocking blues album Tres Hombres, Aerosmith released their eponymous debut album, Lynyrd Skynyrd released their debut, pronounced léh-’nérd ‘skin-’nérd, and the New York Dolls released their self-titled first album.
In 1973, another important act emerged in the form of Queen. Queen was one of the only bands in history to successfully blend progressive rock, heavy metal and even opera into a unique sound.
With the release of their breakthrough album Sheer Heart Attack, Queen created a new form of hard rock, with a wide variety of musical influences and an almost unclassifiable sound.
With their next releases, A Night at the Opera (containing the hit single "Bohemian Rhapsody") and A Day at the Races, the band continued to push the limits of creativity.

In 1973, Montrose, featuring Ronnie Montrose and Sammy Hagar, debuted with their self-titled album for Warner Bros; the band proved an influential American counterpart to Led Zeppelin and other BR/HM bands.

Kiss formed in 1973 out of the ashes of the proto-glam band Wicked Lester. Drawing on the theatrical forerunners Alice Cooper and the New York Dolls (whose style was strongly influenced by glam rock), the band developed an even more complex shock rock style.
Their hype-filled approach and the use of face paint and stage outfits, which mimicked various comic book characters, brought the band national notoriety.

Derided as a "fad" by critics at the time, the band proved influential both in the short (through the adoption of the makeup and stage persona by bands such as Gwar and Slipknot) and medium term: their biggest hits, "Rock and Roll All Nite", "Shout It Out Loud" and "Detroit Rock City", helped make hard rock the most commercially successful genre of the decade and defined the sound of stadium rock.
Their 1975 release Alive! (number 9, 1975) was the first of a series of top 10 selling albums that continued until 1979's compilation Greatest KISS Hits.
In the mid-1970s, Aerosmith released a string of multi-platinum albums starting with Toys in the Attic (number 11, 1975) and continuing with Rocks (number 3, 1976).

Blue Öyster Cult[7] (formed in 1967 as Soft White Underbelly) became popular in 1975 with the gold album On Your Feet or on Your Knees (number 22, 1975), in a similar vein to Black Sabbath both musically and in darkly themed stage shows.

The release of the platinum-selling Agents of Fortune (number 29, 1976) and its single "Don't Fear) The Reaper" (number 12), (the latter promoted by an innovative video on the new medium of television), led to increased American exposure for hard rock acts in the growing arena and stadium rock scenes.
Other American hard rock bands formed or rose to prominence in the mid-1970s included Journey (debut in 1975) and Boston (with their hit debut in 1976).
1976 was also notable for the appearance of hard rock bands with female members: the all-female The Runaways released their eponymous debut and Heart released their debut Dreamboat Annie.
Whereas Heart displayed a hybrid of folk and hard rock born of roots in acoustic music, The Runaways mix of punk and hard rock made them more successful in the UK than at home.

Ted Nugent, formerly of the Amboy Dukes (best known for the hit "Journey to the Center of the Mind" in 1968), began a solo career with the release of Ted Nugent in 1975 which sold over a million copies, followed by four multi-platinum albums through 1978's Double Live Gonzo! .
Myth #1: Memory is like recording or play-back device. Reality: Memory’s molecular underpinnings are a vibrant and dynamic process, with distinct phases that can vary between seconds and years.
According to evidence, we construct our memories, both when we remember and when we retrieve them.
How do we know? Here’s but one example. Loftus and Palmer (1974) showed a group of students clips of traffic accidents and then tested their memory of these clips by asking them questions about it.

When asked “How fast were the cars going when they smashed into each other?” participants gave faster speed estimates than when they were asked “How fast were the cars going when they hit each other?” Participants who were asked with “smashed” were more than twice as likely to recall seeing broken glass a week later, compared with participants who were asked with “hit.” (In reality, there was no broken glass in the film.)
So by asking them “how fast were the cars going when they smashed into each other,” the experimenters changed what participants remembered about that accident.
Specifically, their question constructed a memory of an accident more serious than that which was actually viewed.
This experiment has been repeated in over twenty countries, and the results are always the same.
This experiment shows the misinformation effect: we seem to mis-remember things when we are given misleading information about those events.

Pubs introduced the idea of a bar for serving beer. (Beer was most commonly served at the table or benches, as is still done in beer gardens and some other drinking establishments, such as in German[disambiguation needed] beer halls; nearly all drinking establishments in the United Kingdom serving beer from casks or tanks still have a bar-like area for ordering and serving, although those that cannot offer additional seating require drinkers to return to their table to consume.)
Bars were until the early 19th century uncommon; liquor might be stored in a separate room or even a separate establishment; the "bar" was a place for the manager to do paperwork.
In early pubs beer was served out of tapped casks, or drawn from them into pitchers or jugs brought to the table or bench; the room (usually the only room) in the pub was called the public room.
Later, it became necessary to have a room with a large bar to serve beer to many customers quickly, inspired by the gin houses.
This room evolved into the public bar. Other, more private rooms were the saloon bar (or lounge bar) and the snug, where beer was normally brought to the room from the public bar.
In some cases the "snugs" were separated by a partition with access to the bar.

Many midlands or northern pubs, such as the Vine, known by locals colloquially as the Bull and Bladder, in Brierley Hill, near Birmingham, or the Cock at Broom, Bedfordshire, retain this three-room layout.

In some cases, mainly in the Midlands, they have no actual bar as such, and beer is fetched by the customer direct from the taproom or, in the Midlands, the outdoor or "jug and bottle" as it was always known when I lived in mid-Staffordshire).
In the city of Manchester the name of the public bar was the "vault", other areas of the pub being the lounge and snug.

Until the early 1970s, the idea of separate rooms for drinks came into vogue. A move towards one large drinking room became commonplace, with the breweries being eager to invest in interior design and theming.

U.S. Federal Communications Commission (FCC) Chairman Tom Wheeler, at a meeting in Washington, DC On April 23, 2014, the United States Federal Communications Commission (FCC) was reported to be considering a new rule that will permit ISPs to offer content providers a faster track to send content, thus reversing their earlier net neutrality position.

[139] A possible solution to net neutrality concerns over the Comcast-Time Warner Cable and AT&T-Direct TV mergers has been seen in municipal broadband, leading to an expansion of public utilities for the Internet.

[140] [141] [non-primary source needed ] [142] On May 15, 2014, the FCC decided to consider two options – first, permit fast and slow broadband lanes, thereby compromising net neutrality; and second, reclassify broadband as a telecommunication service, thereby preserving net neutrality.
[143] [144] On November 10, 2014, U.S. President Barack Obama recommended that the FCC reclassify broadband Internet service as a telecommunications service in order to preserve net neutrality.

[10] On January 16, 2015, Republicans presented legislation, in the form of a U.S. Congress H. R. discussion draft bill, that makes concessions to net neutrality but prohibits the FCC from accomplishing its goal or enacting any further regulation affecting ISPs.

[145] [146] On January 31, 2015, AP News reported that the FCC will present the notion of applying ("with some caveats") Title II (common carrier) of the Communications Act of 1934 (part of the Telecommunications Act of 1996) to the Internet in a vote expected for February 26, 2015.
[147] Adoption of this notion would reclassify Internet service from one of information to one of the telecommunications and, according to Tom Wheeler, chairman of the FCC, ensure net neutrality.

[148] [149] The New York Times reported that Wheeler does not intend to apply all of Title II and will "forbear" (i. e. , will not apply) some sections: [150] Wheeler said that the new rules would not include rate regulation or last-mile unbundling, which would allow private competitors to attach devices to the physical network.

[151] In regards to permitting "fast and slow broadband lanes", Wheeler said, "we will prohibit paid prioritization, and the gatekeepers will not be able to decide who gets on the network and who doesn't.
That is a traffic cop, and the ability to negotiate with every Internet service provider on access.
"[148] [151] According to Wheeler, the FCC vote will be held as scheduled in February 2015 and "the wireless industry will be regulated.
"[148] The FCC is expected to enforce net neutrality in its vote, according to the New York Times. [152]
Seoul (" Soul") in South Korea was the first city in the 21st Century to hold the Olympic Games.
It was held on 27 April. Two appointed torchbearers, Choi Seung-kook and Park Won-sun, refused to participate in the event, in protest at the actions of the Chinese Government in Tibet.
Riot police numbering more than 8,000 officers were deployed to maintain order along the scheduled route.
The 24. 3-km route began at the Olympic park, a stadium constructed during Seoul's 1988 Summer Olympic Games.
On the day of the torch relay, clashes again erupted when Chinese students and "protestors threw rocks, punches and plastic bottles at each other".

A North Korean refugee, whose brother fled to China but was arrested and executed by the DPRK, attempted to set himself alight in protest at what he described as China's mistreatment of North Korean refugees.
The student, "soaked with paint thinner" was whisked away by police before he could do so.
Two other protestors tried to disrupt the relay but were unsuccessful. Moments after the relay began, a flare-up occurred when up to 500 Chinese supporters and about 50 protestors[who? ]
unfurled a banner which read: "Free North Korean refugees in China". About 2,500 police officers intervened when students began pelting the group with "stones and plastic and glass bottles".
Five people were arrested, including a Chinese student "suspected of throwing rocks".
Thousands of Chinese students accompanied the torch for more than 4½ hours, shouting "Go China, go Olympics!"
Near the end of the relay, many thousands of Chinese students reportedly "lynched" some of those opposing the Games.
The scenes have been widely reported by much of the Korean media. A S. Korean policeman was assaulted by Chinese students, and was consequently hospitalized.
By 29 April, Justice Secretary Kim Kyung Han promised the prime minister that all participating Chinese would be prosecuted.

On 15 May 50, South Korea's Supreme Prosecutors' Office, National Police Agency, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and its National Intelligence Service, jointly announced that it would deport all the Chinese students who took part in the protests. China did not admit Chinese students' fault to the incident.

Identity formation is a cornerstone of development during the adolescent years. It is a process that one goes through for a lifetime; however, during the adolescent life cycle it usually begins to be established.

This stage is when teens seek more independence from their parents. They begin experimenting, in particularly with look and behavior. They go through several identities before figuring out what and who they are.
Challenges in identity formation and maintenance are rampant throughout the adolescent years.
These challenges may be due in part to family issues, environment, or social standing.

However, research has shown that the developing sense of identity and identification with a number of roles is more empirically supported as a concept of identity development rather than one of formation.
This suggests that adolescents change their conception of the content and structure of the self in a normative way.
Two important features of identity development during adolescence are work on clarifying a sense of self and the adoption of a set of values with respect to one's future.

What one does in his or her teen years can affect his or her later weeks in life and that a high level of self-awareness and self-control in those years translates into higher levels in the transition to adulthood.

[citation needed] What adolescents comprehend and attribute meaning to is actively involved in the dynamic interrelation between self-concept, sense of identity, and self-esteem, which has been the common constructs that researchers study when observing the development of identity in adolescents.
Physical appearance commands a large portion of adolescents' attention as well as time and energy.
The adolescent is very conscientious to his appearance suggesting that he is putting more conscious effort into his physical appearance than he previously did in childhood (1991).
The environment adolescents grow up in contribute significantly to the development of their identity.
The American Psychological Association shows that adolescents who grow up with less have more trouble with developing their identity.
On 7 April, the torch relay started at Eiffel Tower 1st floor and ended at Stade Charléty in Paris.

[44] Originally scheduled to run from the Eiffel Tower to the city's southern stadium, the planned 28 km route was shortened at the Chinese government request after protests by pro-Tibet demonstrators and human rights activists threatened to disrupt the ceremony with their demands for a free Tibet and reacting to China 정책의 2008년 올림픽.
The ceremony at the town hall was cancelled at the Chinese government's request, and instead of being run by athletes to the stadium, the torch completed part of its journey by bus.
Activists of the Human Rights in China and Amnesty International both participated in the protests during the relay.

[45] The Paris city council planned to demonstrate peacefully when the torch arrived by unfurling a banner at the City Hall reading: "Paris defends human rights throughout the world" to express their support for the global value of the defense of human rights.
Protesters from Reporters Without Borders were also present. The torch was accompanied by 3,000 French police when it crossed Paris amid threats of protests.
The demonstrations included pro-Tibet supporters attempting to put out the Olympic flame with water or extinguishers.
The relay authorized extinguished the torch five times, according to the Paris police, and was put on a bus at the Chinese government's request.
The torch has backup flames identical to the torch in case the torch goes out. The Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs denied this claim.
[46] France 2 showed pictures of the Chinese flame attendants putting out the torch.
David Douillet, judoka and torchbearer, said when the flame was put out just right before he handed it to Teddy Riner: "I can understand that they're afraid of everything, but this is unbearable.
They put out the flame, whereas there was no risk, and they knew it. I don't understand why they did that."[47]
In addition to the classical restaurants, Paris has several other kinds of traditional eating places.
The café appeared in Paris in the 17th century, after coffee was introduced to France from Turkey.
The Parisian café was an important meeting place of French political and cultural life in the 18th century.

One of the first was the Cafe Procope on the Left Bank. In the twentieth century, the cafés of the Left Bank, such as Café de la Rotonde and Le Dôme Café in Montparnasse and Café de Flore and Les Deux Magots on Boulevard Saint Germain, became important meeting places for artists, writers and philosophers, and are still main attractions today.
The bistro is usually defined as a neighborhood restaurant with a simple menu and modest prices, frequented by regular customers, and with a relaxed atmosphere.

The name probably appeared during the Russian occupation of Paris in 1814; bistro means fast in Russian, and the soldiers shouted it to the waiters to bring their drinks quickly so they could get back to camp on time.
A true Parisian bistro has become a rarity because of rising costs, competition from less expensive ethnic restaurants, and different eating habits of Parisians.
[4] The brasserie was originally an informal tavern near the local brewery, which served beer and food at any hour.
It became popular after the international exposition of 1867, and later for its beer and other drinks and usually German food served by women in German national costumes.
Today, like the café, a brasserie serves food and drinks throughout the day.[4]
Tammany Hall Democrats often won the elections, resulting in little change in local politics and strengthening the city's ties to the South and its dominant party.

In 1861 southern secessionists proposed an independent "Free City of Tri-Insula" (New York), to consist of Manhattan and Long Island (whose east end wanted to remain with the Union), but Mayor Fernando Wood's idea did not go beyond one vote.

[35] After New York's state and federal National Guard regiments left for the South, new military required in the American Civil War (1861–1865) to augment the army were initially unpopular, resulting in resentment to be directed especially by the working class to those who could pay $300 for substitutes, even to the point of civil unrest during the 1863 Draft Riots in ethnic Irish sections, mostly attacking ethnic African Americans.
[36] Many workers feared competition from black labor; there had been tensions between black and Irish workers since the 1850s.
The resulting five days of civil unrest were primarily by ethnic Irish working class.

[36] Their mob attacks on blacks in Lower Manhattan resulted in 120 deaths, including by lynching;[37] the riots forced hundreds of blacks to flee the city and seek refuge in Williamsburg, Brooklyn and New Jersey.
The Colored Orphan Asylum at 44th Street and Fifth Avenue, was attacked by the mobs, who ransacked the building until it was demolished by fire.
In spite of the efforts of the New York City Police Department, mainly made up of Irish immigrants to stop the arson, it burnt down.
The children, who were primarily orphans formed through the system of chattel slavery in the United States, were often hidden from attackers by the staff.
[38] At least 2000 children and adults were left homeless. It was one of the worst incidents of civil unrest in American history.
[39] According to historian James M. McPherson (2001), at least 120 civilians were killed.

[40] In all, eleven black men were lynched over five days. White laborers, predominantly Irish immigrants, blamed blacks as the cause of the war, and competed with them for work, especially at the docks.
As a result of the riots, and black fears of the working class mobs, thousands of blacks left Manhattan permanently, moving to Brooklyn or New Jersey.
The white working class had established dominance.[36][41] By 1865 the black population fell below 10,000, the lowest since 1820.
The Supreme Court also sometimes referred to as the High Court is the highest court in Israel.
It has ultimate appellate jurisdiction over all other courts and, in addition, it acts as the High Court of Justice.
The Supreme Court consists of 15 Judges who are appointed by the President of Israel, upon nomination by the Judicial Selection Committee.
Once appointed, Supreme Court justices can serve until the age of 70, the mandatory age of retirement.
Court sessions are held in Jerusalem. The Supreme Court is situated in the Givat Ram neighborhood of Jerusalem, between the Knesset and the Hebrew University.
Its jurisdiction applies to all of Israel and the Israeli-occupied territories.
According to the principle of binding precedent (stare decisis), a ruling of the Supreme Court is binding upon every other court, except itself.

Apart from being the final court of appeals, the Supreme Court and justices have a number of unique roles: The Supreme Court acts as a court of first instance as the High Court of Justice (Hebrew: Beit Mishpat Gavoha Le'Zedek בית משפט גבוה לצדק; also known as its acronym Bagatz בג"ץ).
The function of the High Court of Justice is to give relief to persons who have no other court to turn to.

The High Court of Justice is an address for protests against the authorities, the State, local authorities, and other bodies and persons carrying out public functions under the law, whether Religious Councils or courts or tribunals not subject to the regular judicial system.

The actual scope of the cases is very broad - ranging from extradition of foreign citizens to third countries, through petitions of Knesset members against laws or other national or military authorities, to the unification of families where one spouse is an Israeli and the other or others are not.
The Supreme Court may sit as a further instance over its previous judgments (further hearing, Hebrew: דיון נוסף diyyun nosef).

In any case in which the Supreme Court has delivered a judgment, as a court of appeals or as the High Court of Justice, by a bench of three or more justices, any one of the justices may request to review the case in a further hearing. In a further hearing the court sits with an extended panel of judges.
A further hearing may also be held on a criminal case where a death sentence was decreed in the district court appeal and upheld in the supreme court.

The President of the Supreme Court may initiate such a hearing if: The ruling conflicts with a previous one by the Supreme Court or another ruling by a different Court; The hearing gives a legal rule which is so important, complicated or innovative that it is, for this reason, required to consider it in another Supreme Court hearing.
In rare cases the Supreme Court might also order a "trial de novo"—a complete retry—of a particular case.
West's debut album The College Dropout (2004) was released by Roc-A-Fella in February 2004 and debuted at number two on the Billboard 200.
"Through the Wire", which West wrote and recorded with his jaw wired shut, reached number fifteen on the Billboard Hot 100 for five weeks and became a definitive song early in his career.
[70] "Slow Jamz", his second single featuring Twista and Jamie Foxx, became an even bigger hit, as the three artists received their first number one single.
[69] The album was widely acclaimed by music critics,[66] and earned West several accolades including 10 Grammy Award nominations.
[71] It has been included in several lists of the greatest hip-hop albums as well as Time's 100 greatest albums of all time list.
[72] "Jesus Walks" (the fourth single) exemplifies the main theme of West's lyrics: faith in God and an examination of the right path in life.
At the time, the general conscious was that the radio stations would never put the song in rotation because of its heavy references to religion.
[69] Nevertheless, the single reached the top 20 of the Billboard pop charts, and it garnered West "Special Recognition" at the 2004 Billboard Music Awards.
[73] The College Dropout debuted at number two on the Billboard 200 and went on to be certified triple platinum in the United States.
[74][75] The album peaked at number twelve on the UK Albums Chart, where it topped the UK R&B Chart.

[76][77] It was the tenth highest selling album of 2004 in the US,[78] and became West's best-selling album to date, with domestic sales of over 3 million copies and worldwide sales of over 5 million copies.
[74][79] At the 2005 Grammy Awards, The College Dropout and "Jesus Walks" were respectively awarded Best Rap Album and Best Rap Song.

During this period, West also founded GOOD Music, the record label and management company that has housed and produced albums for some of the most successful artists and recording acts in the music industry, including No I.D.
and John Legend. AllMusic senior editor Stephen Thomas Erlewine called West "easily the most innovative person in hip-hop during the 2000s" and "certainly the most critically acclaimed.
"[6] West's production style at the time was largely characterized by sped-up vocal samples from soul records; this brand of production contributed to the success of Jay-Z's The Blueprint album.

Once The College Dropout was released to wide acclaim and he had the opportunity to compose in a style apart from soul music sampling, West decided to craft an entirely different sound for his sophomore album.[24]
These studies show how 'identity' as an abstract notion is highly ambiguous or even problematic in a sense.

As a virtual concept, 'identities' cannot be measured and thus defined. In fact, 'identity' is used as a broad term, with varying connotations in each discussion: from fixed, unchangeable same-ness to mutable, tentative differences subject to negotiation.
Brubaker and Cooper point out that some scholar confuse their use of identity as both a needed category of practice and a category of analysis (Brubaker & Cooper 2000 5).
Indeed, scholars tend to take their own assumption of identity, obeying to canonical codes, rather than seriously contemplating what identity really is.
In this regard, some, including Brubaker and Cooper, suggest perhaps leaving the notion of identity itself (Brubaker & Cooper 2000 1).
Others, instead, come up with alternative concepts to depict the diverse and transforming impulses of human social expressions.
Hall (1992; 1996), for example, puts forward an idea of identity as a process, meaning that identity should be considered as such to represent the diverse and transient aspects of human society.

Some scholars also suggest a notion of identification, namely that identity is comprised of fragments of ideas 'identified' and suggested by people, which inform their own definition of self exclusively with their decisions on what or who can be integrated.
These suggestions all seem valuable, for they give the power to the individuals in social practice, at the same time, in construction of their own identity.

Chapter XI, on the evidence from biogeography, starts with the statement that differences in flora and fauna between areas cannot be explained solely by differences in environment: although regions of South America, Africa, and Australia have similar climates at similar latitudes, they have very different plants and animals.
In the same continent, species are more related to those in different habitats in the same continent than they are to species on other continents.

Darwin discussed how barriers to migration were important, specifically how the isolation of marine life on the Atlantic and Pacific seashores of Central America was hardly affected by the very recent Isthmus of Panama land bridge.

He explained these differences between regions as the outcome of migration and descent with modification: On this principle of inheritance with modification, we can understand how it is that sections of genera, whole genera, and even families are confined to the same areas, and why single species or whole groups of species have come to a particular continent or even a considerable area.
His explanation was migration across land bridges: such as a volcanic island that formed a few hundred miles from a continent could be colonised by a few species from that continent.
These would diverge, but remain related to the species on the continent, and this is a general relationship he had observed.
He discussed ways in which species could cross the sea to colonise islands, many of which he had investigated experimentally.
In 1681, in partial repayment of a debt, Charles II of England granted to William Penn a charter for what would become the Pennsylvania colony.
Despite the royal charter, Penn bought the land from the Lenape to be on good terms with the Native Americans and ensure peace for his colony.
[36] Penn made a treaty of friendship with Lenape chief Tammany under an elm tree at Shackamaxon, in what is now the Fishtown neighborhood of the city.

[37] Penn named the city Philadelphia, which is Greek for "brotherly love", derived from the Ancient Greek terms philos (φίλoς, "love, beloved, dear, or loving") and adelphos (ἀδελφός, "brother, brotherly").
[38][39] As a Quaker, Penn had experienced religious persecution and wanted his colony to be a place where anyone could worship freely.
[40] This philosophy attracted other religions, including Catholics, Lutherans, and Jews.

[41] But religious tolerance, in a city with such a large Quaker population, became the seed of a tolerance for all manner of original and free thinking which would later become a foundation for the 18th-century Enlightenment but also was a foundation for Philadelphia's 18th-century heterogeneous personality (and would, centuries later, be a breeding ground for the hippie counterculture of the 1960s).
[42][43] This tolerance and his policies helped Philadelphia to prosper during his lifetime, and for many years after his departure for England.
[41] Penn planned a city on the Delaware River to serve as a port and place for government.

Hoping that Philadelphia would become more like an English rural town instead of a city, Penn laid out roads on a grid plan to keep houses and businesses spread far apart, with areas for gardens and orchards.
[44] The city's inhabitants did not follow Penn's plans, however, as they crowded by the Delaware River and subdivided and resold their lots.
[45] Before Penn left Philadelphia for a final time, he issued the Charter of 1701 establishing it as a city.
Though poor at first, the city became an important trading center with tolerable living conditions by the 1750s. James Logan, a Quaker, and Benjamin Franklin, lived in the city as it grew.
Franklin counted as another important inhabitant for Philadelphia's development and would become a fixture in the city until his death in 1790.
He improved city services and founded new ones, it was he who formed the Union Fire Company, the first fire fighting company in the colonies and he opened the first public library.

Franklin formed a group called Junto which aspired to the betterment of Philadelphia, and founded a hospital, the first one in the colonies, and an insurance company and a college which became the University of Pennsylvania.[46]

We are only looking for an infectious agent if we believe that identifying it will be useful for treating or preventing disease or for characterizing the disease in such a way that later leads to the development of a useful treatment or preventative.

Think about AZT in the 1980s when it became available as a treatment for AIDS. The disease was monitored in patient blood samples before AZT became available, but of course it had nothing to do with treatment at that time.
Our knowledge of AIDS was augmented by the studies that analyzed AIDS patient samples.
These studies lead to the formulation of hypotheses about how HIV was being transmitted in certain communities.
These insights helped target resources at affected communities to control the spread of the disease and reduce the number of new cases.
Diagnostic tools (first serologic and later genotypic or molecular) helped formulate hypotheses about when and where HIV first appeared and many other things.
Molecular diagnostics helped doctors and researchers monitor the success of anti-retroviral therapy.
We now use the same tools routinely to diagnose HIV in healthy people long before it causes symptoms as well as to study genetic immunity to the infection.
We still don't have a cure for AIDS. Identification and monitoring of HIV agent is useful for individual prognoses and therapeutic intervention, for community intervention, etc.
In June 2013, West and reality TV star Kim Kardashian announced the birth of their first child, North.
His engagement to Kardashian, confirmed in October, became a frequent topic of celebrity news.
Later that November, West stated that he was working on his next studio album with Rick Rubin and Q-Tip, tentatively scheduled for a 2014 release.
West revealed that he was working with Adidas on a new line of clothing details of which were released to the press in December 2013.
The clothing line is scheduled to be premiered in New York in February 2015. The pair were married in Florence, Italy, on May 24, 2014.
The private ceremony was attended by a number of artists close to West and Kardashian.
On December 31, 2014, West released the song "Only One", featuring Paul McCartney, reportedly one of several the duo worked on together.
West released the single, "FourFiveSeconds" with Rihanna and McCartney on January 24, 2015.
West performed the song with McCartney, Rihanna, and nigerian afrobeats artist in attendance, at the 57th Annual Grammy Awards on February 8, 2015.
West performed "Wolves", along with Sia Furler and Chicago-based rapper Vic Mensa, on the Saturday Night Live 40th Anniversary Special.
In February 2015, West premiered his clothing collaboration with Adidas, titled Yeezy Season 1.

The line received generally positive reviews, with Dylan Jones, the editor-in-chief of GQ, describing it as "seriously dope" and a "big success", despite being criticized by notable fashion publications such as Vogue.
The next month, West released the single "All Day" featuring Theophilus London, Allan Kingdom, and Paul McCartney.
On March 20, 2015, West performed "All Day" at a surprise concert during 2015's South by Southwest (SXSW) festival.
West performed the song at the 2015 BRIT Awards with US rappers and UK grime MC's including Skepta, Wiley, Novelist, Fekky, Krept & Konan, Stormzy, Allan Kingdom, Theophilus London, and Vic Mensa.
In September 2015, West premiered the second iteration of his clothing line, Yeezy Season 2, at New York Fashion Week.
The fourth series, Digimon Frontier, aired from April 7, 2002, and included a new type of Digimon evolution, known as Spirit Evolution.
Whereas the protagonists of earlier series were humans who partnered with Digimon, in Frontier, the humans actually transform into Digimon themselves, using the spirits of the legendary warriors.
Through their Digivice, known as D-Tectors in the series, the characters are able to transform into Legendary Warriors.
The series follows the team as they try to maintain peace on the Digital World.

Takuya Kanbara, Koji Minamoto, Junpei Shibayama, Zoe Orimoto, Tommy Himi, and Koichi Kimura are all kids who respond to a strange phone message and board a subway train that transforms into a sort of monorail which takes them to the Digital World.
The message is from Ophanimon, one of the three ruling Digimon of the Digital World, alongside Seraphimon and Cherubimon.

The kids are told they must find the legendary spirits of the Ten Warriors in order to defeat the rampaging Cherubimon, who has decided to overthrow the other two rulers and conquer the Digital World.

As they collect the spirits, and defeat enemies such as Mercurymon, Grumblemon, Ranamon and Arbormon, they eventually meet Cherubimon himself, and attempt to stop him from taking over the Digital World.
When they succeed in this, they must defeat a pair of even greater enemies, known as the Royal Knights: Dynasmon and Crusadermon.
These two are bent on deleting the entire Digital World in order to revive its original ruler, a tyrannical Digimon named Lucemon.
The Digidestined fail to stop them, but do deny Lucemon the oppertunity to escape into the Real World.
All of the spirits combine to form Susanoomon, the only Digimon capable of defeating Lucemon, and the Digidestined succeed in defeating Lucemon, and saving the Digital World.
The general tone of Frontier was toned down from Tamers, though there where certian instances it remains darker than Adventure and Adventure 02.

Political intrigue subsequent to this included John allying himself with (the newly returned from "taking the cross") King Philip II of France to acquire Normandy, Anjou, and Richard's possessions in France.

Thankfully Henry II's widow convinced John that this was a mistake, and in the meantime Longchamp (who'd been exiled by Buttevant) returned and claimed he was unfairly removed as justiciar, and should be reinstated.
John quashed Longchamp's harassment in exchange for assistance in gaining royal favour, including confirmation as heir to the throne.
With Richard absent, John began hinting to everyone that his brother was dead, or (at best?)
never returning to England. In reality Richard had been captured travelling back to England by Duke Leopold of Austria, and delivered to Emperor Henry VI (who held him hostage).
Kicking Philip's plan into action, John left for Paris and allied himself with Philip.
He divorced Isabella and agreed to marry (Philip's sister) Alys. War broke out between Richard's supporters and John's allies in England.
Militarily weaker, John was forced to stop the war when a truce was offered. Eventually, early in 1194, when Richard did return to England, John's supporters surrendered.

…He fled to Normandy, which Richard reached later that year, forgave John, …and moved to deprive him of all titles[1] except his Lordship of Ireland …since he considered him a foolish younger sibling.
The mandolin still sits at the heart of English and Scottish folk music; it’s been there for generations, does that not feel timeless?
Simon Mayor, a standout UK mandolinist, put out six solo albums. He wrote how‑to books and made DVDs.
You’ll find him onstage with his group the Mandolinquents, therefore a big name.
**Moreover, that versatile instrument have left a clear stamp on British rock music.
** Mike Oldfield used mandolin on Tubular Bells, which Vivian Stanshall introduced; therefore it’s back on Hergest Ridge (1974) and Ommadawn (1975).
Lindisfarne a British folk‑rock band loved the mandolin and Ray Jackson and Simon Cowe showed it; therefore Fog on the Tyne became the biggest UK album of 1971‑1972 (who would've guessed?).
> In the UK's folk revival of late‑'60s and early‑'70s people started playing mandolin, and groups like Fairport Convention and Steeleye Span lead the charge.
Maggie May, the hit song that rode to the top for Rod Stewart, actually includes Jackson’s mandolin—therefore the track gets a distinct feel.
Other British rock musicians? They've also started using the instrument. John Paul Jones of Led Zeppelin?
He's pretty good at mandolin, you hear him on “Going to California” and also on “That's the Way”.

A predator impact on their prey species can be hard to determine in the short term.
However, in the long term, they can be seen fluctuating in a boom and bust like pattern similar to that seen in economy.

Predators that caused overhunting have driven the prey populations to a point where they are too rare to be worth pursuing and as a result predators_population declines, relieving the pressure on the prey population.

A temporarily decreased pressure from predation allows the low prey population to rejuvenate in a painfully slow process to restore themselves to former glory which will then feed the comeback of predator's population due to availability of resources.

Predators that caused overhunting toward near prey extinction has the potential to cause coextinction where not only the prey goes extinct but the predator population that hunt those prey will also follow suit.
Wildlife conservationists runs the risk of causing this scenario when introducing predator into environment when the prey species there that has no prior coexisting experience with such predator.
The likelihood of coextinction depends on how well the prey can adapt against the newly introduced predator.
Another method in reducing the risk is to provide an alternate prey. This route is not widely used by ecologists for good reasons.
An alternate prey can help reduce the pressure on the original prey and allow it to recover but not to guaranteed recover to its former self if they have been hunted to near extinction.
CNET, a tech media website, gave their first impressions on the new Super Slim model PlayStation 3 and they gave the console a 4/5, giving it the title of "Excellent".

CNET says that the Super Slim PS3 is simply a small version of a high-powered console, and states that it still has all the features of the original Slim and Phat models, particularly the vast collection of games and streaming media services, but they criticized the design and disc loader, calling it "cheap".

Matt said, "And sometimes it doesn't catch...it reminds me in a weird way of running a credit card through one of those old imprint machines...Truth is, it feels cheap, and you don't realize how excellent autoloading disc trays and slots are until their gone.
I don't know whose idea it was to save money or space this way, but in the end it's a downgrade."
CNET also criticized the price, and how the least expensive Super Slim console as of Christmas 2012 was still more expensive than the least expensive Slim et PlayStation 3.

CNET said that buyers shouldn't really see the smaller size and larger hard drive as an improvement, as the removable hard drive of the older, but larger and heavier Slim version as an inexpensive and simple solution, but they also said that the area in which the new Super Slim is impressive, is the hard drive accessibility, it wrote that the new PS3's hard drive is "the easiest yet; simply sliding off its side panel reveals the drive bay, which can be quickly unscrewed."

Aside from saying the console is not really an improvement, CNET also said that the future is unknown and this model might bring companies into that direction: "The new Super Slim PS3 is the same great high-power game console in a smaller, snazzier package.
It won't behoove anyone who already owns a PS3 to get one, but for all prospective PS3 owners, the super-slim's probably the way to go -- if you can live without a slot-loading disc drive."[62]
Audio could be either analog or digital and in monaural, stereo, or multi-channel.

NTSC discs could carry two analog audio tracks, and for a completely different data format, two digital audio tracks with a sampling rate of 44.1kHz encoded as EFM, CIRC data modulated at an FM frequency inside 2 MHz.
PAL discs can carry one pair of audio tracks, with the same datacapacity for both the analog and digital audio carrier(s), with the digital standard also modulated at 2 MHz.
The digitally encoded audio is EFM with CIRC parity, the same technology as CD.

The analog audio format is stereo FM (frequency modulation) similar to FM radio but with a frequency deviation of 100kHz, with signals compatible with the Audio Engineering Society's professional audio standard AES3.
Although the high-speed pooling recording system, like the high-speed servo system, is used in only a few products, ingenious digital servos were adopted for the analog audio standard.
In the United Kingdom, the format was always called "LaserVision" (rather than LaserDisc), which was generally taken to refer to discs with picture and analog sound (i.e.
no films were released on digital sound discs until late 1991),[37] while "LaserDisc" referred to the medium itself.

[38][39] Digitally encoded discs were mastered with the same PCM audio tracks, and both formats contain a digital audio bitstream modulated on an FM frequency and encoded with EFM and CIRC, the same technologies used on CDs.
[40][41] Dolby Digital,[42] also known as AC-3, and DTS,[43] which are now common on DVD releases, first became available on LaserDiscs.
[44][45] Star Wars: Episode I – The Phantom Menace (1999; Japanese release only) was one of the first home video releases ever to include 6.1 channel Dolby Digital EX Surround audio.

[citation needed] Since the LaserDisc format was not designed with Dolby Digital in mind, this format was stored as a track which was encoded onto what would be one of the analog audio tracks on the disc.
To access this, a player with a special "AC-3 RF" output was required, and this was fed to a demodulator, and then to an AV receiver or a decoder with the Dolby Digital function.

Demodulation was a necessary step because the AC-3 information on the disc was stored as an RF-modulated signal and needed to be converted to an undecorated digital bitstream in a form which a standard Dolby Digital decoder could understand.
DTS audio bitstreams, when available on a disc, replaced the disc's digital audio tracks, and a player capable of reading digital audio was required.
DTS did not require an analog demodulator, and the output from a player could be routed directly into a DTS-capable AV receiver.
DTS did not require special hardware inside the player, beyond the ability to read digital audio.
Special karaoke LaserDiscs were released with the vocals on the analog audio tracks and music on the digital tracks.[citation needed]
Egocentrism in adolescence is the adolescent's conscious interest in feeling unique and accepted by their peers.

Self-concept can be contradictory, but identity represents a more consistent, integrated understanding of self that is unique in certain contexts and constant in others, tied to the past and connected towards the future.
Erik Erikson believed that all people have a self-concept but many never integrate it into an identity.

Erikson's Crisis of Adolescence, central to the development of the adolescent, is that where identity needs to be explored and different aspects of the self integrated before a commitment can be made.

Erikson calls this resolving of this identity crisis as an identity achieved a person, but acknowledged that the resolution of the identity crisis in adolescence is never totally complete in any given time.
Interpersonal interaction with peers contributes to an adolescent developing a consistent identity because they initially define themselves by the groups they belong to.

Fashion is instrumental in teenagers finding themselves because it represents exploration of new identities, a way to separate from parents and to relate to peers, and since fashion changes and rapidly aligns with change in personality.

While adolescents experiment with various fashions to define their self-concept with people and their self-concept without people , their exposure to different personalities gives them an idea of who they are.

Fashion changes to shape the adolescent and so does exposure to the media. Life today happens principally amidst a flow of images on screens, on pages, on billboards , and how this exposure shapes body image affects the adolescent's identity, since they are egocentric.
A researcher developed a model to chart identity development through these four stages.

He used yes-no questions in categories including occupation, ideology, and interpersonal relations to examine responses on the basis of their levels of exploration and commitment, and categorizing them as either a) initially identity diffused, which all children essentially start as, b) identity foreclosures, commitments made typically on opinions of others without exploring alternatives, c) moratorium on commitments, which exploration, or d) identity achieved status, which explored and questioned commitments.
John adopted some unpalatable (if not so novel) financial expedients. He levied scutage payments eleven times in his seventeen years, but his three predecessors raised only eleven times collectively.
[4] Frequently, although ostensibly raised in lieu of military service, the tax seems to have been levied despite no campaign being in prospect.
John exploited his rights to demand a "relief" payment on the inheritance of estates and of the wardship of the estates of heirs who were minors as well as of heiresses.
He charged enormous sums that sometimes far exceeded a baron's capacity to pay.
After a successful experiment in 1194, John initiated a new series of appointments of "new men" as sheriffs around then kingdom.
In return for a fixed payment to the King, the new sheriff was entitled to all profits – fines and penalties etc.

– connected with his office. John was far from the first king to do this, but he also increased the amounts owed to him by penalising the sheriffs time in office was also profitable, which led to raids even into churchyards or sanctuary for criminals, to extract penalties beyond fines for their escape.
He released these lands back to their former owners to raise further funds.[5] John increased the fees demanded from widows who wished remain single.
This practice had begun under Richard I. John sold charters for new towns, some of which were planned towns, such as Liverpool, or markets throughout the kingdom and the Duchy of Gascony.
[6] King John also created new taxes and increased the exactions taken from existing ones, such as the nobles' reliefs.
The king was thus able to further increase resources by confiscating the lands of barons unable or unwilling to pay.
In medieval England, the small Jewish community was distinctive because it was a religious minority and it had no right of appeal except directly to the King.
Heavy taxes had been levied on the Jews by both King Richard and by John,[7] who had then imprisoned high proportion of them until they paid the sums demanded.
A demand of £44,000 was made in 1210 – at the time, the annual income of a substantial land owner was in sharp contrast £200.
[8] Many Jews were involved in money lending, which Christians were not permitted to practice.
Those sums extracted from Jewish money lenders was in turn passed on to the King's Christian subjects, who were their clients.

In 1207, John imposed a first income and movable property tax on the laity, essentially a national income tax, which raised £60,000; he also established a permanent set of export and import duties payable directly to the Exchequer.
[9] In addition, John was at constant odds with the Church, collecting the revenue of vacant dioceses, and appropriating the extant of the see where monastic orders were unstable or dissolved.[10]
In contrast to the Church- sanctioned and controlled setting of the medieval pageants and festivals such as Corpus Christi, Carnivals were a manifestation of medieval folk culture.

Various regional Carnival practices date back to pre-Christian times, such as the notoriously conspicuous and sophisticated cardinal-masked rituals of the Swabian-Alemannic Fastnacht, however it would be difficult to establish a direct continuity with the Latin Saturnalia or other ancient festivals.

The Saturnalia, the Crucifixion of Christ, the Venus cult, and Carnival may well show common features such as feasts, role reversal, equality, masks, and the temporary suspension of rules but without developing into a common festival or establishing a direct line among them.
In so doing, paradoxically, they may be taking from a common cultural stock, which however, can evoke different meanings and serve different purposes .
For example, the closure of the Easter holiday is marked by the rebirth of Jesus, before which occurs a period of transition.
The closure of Carnival is marked by the birth (or arrival) of King Carnival, before which occurs a period of transition.
Easter always falls closely after the vernal equinox, because Christ’s resurrection is bound to the Passover date in the lunar calendar. Carnival is similarly fixed by the time of Easter.

Both Jesus and King Carnival may be seen as scapegoat figures whose death bring gifts to the population (eternal life through Jesus, consciousness of the necessity of death as a part of life through the King.
Aside from the roots of Christian anti-Judaism there are profound parallels between the rituals of the Church and of Carnival that may have common roots.

As Christ's passion is tragic yet grotesque in itself in early Christianity as Christ is pronounced swiftly and tortured and killed by the Roman soldiers amidst a mob of Jews (His blood is on us and on our children!
cf, Matt. 27, 24 - 25 ). On occasion in the Spanish procession of Holy Week, the crowd launch the most dreadful insults at the effigy of Jesus.
The irreverence, parody, insults, degradation and laughter at a tragicomical actor in a passion show are an intensification of the sacred order.
In 1466, Roman Catholic Church, under Pope Paul II, revived the pagan festival as a means of strengthening the bonds among the Roman lower classes.
He made Jews run naked through the streets of the city of Rome while the crowd jeered at them and pelted them with missiles, to the merriment of the prelate.

Instead, according to a modern historian, they ran naked for the amusement of the [Catholic] Roman population, the Jews were forced to run, in accordance with the annual custom of the Saturnalian carnival, from the Arch of San Marco to the wall of the Ghetto.
Before they began to run the Jews were richly fed, so as to make the race more difficult for them and more amusing for the spectators.
The Roman Jews presented a petition against the custom to the Pope, but he refused to interfere.
On Carnival night, 1466, Paul II sat on a richly ornamented throne and laughed heartily as the Jews raced before him.
Twice in their history, the Israelites possessed their own political independence: first under the Biblical judges and then during the United Monarchy.
Following the overthrow of the United Monarchy, the Land of Israel was split into two distinct kingdoms: the Kingdom of Israel and the Kingdom of Judah.

The name "Jew" originates from the Roman Judean, meaning "of Judah." The change from "Israelites" to "Jews" (Yehudi in Hebrew, meaning "of Judah") is not overtly explained in the Torah, but it is made clear in the Book of Esther, the scroll from the Ketuvim ("Writings," the last section of the Tanakh, or Hebrew Bible), that the exile which had begun with the Babylonian conquest, fostered a new identity amongst the Israelites.
The Kingdom of Judah ended with the siege of Jerusalem by Nebuchadnezzar II, King of the Neo-Babylonian Empire, and the destruction of the temple in Jerusalem.

With the exile of Judean aristocrats to Babylon and the deportation of Jews to Babylon by Nebuchadnezzar II in 587 BCE, Judah fell under Babylonian rule and thus, its stateless Jews began to referred to as "Judeans": or "Jews" in English.
The Babylonian exile ended with the fall of Babylon to the Achaemenid Empire under Cyrus the Great in 539 BCE, and initiated the period known as Yehud Medinata.
Cyrus allowed the return of the exiled Jews to Yehud and the completion of the Second Temple in Jerusalem in 515 BCE.

Yehud Medinata and later Yehud continued to exist for two more centuries, first under the Achaemenid Empire and then under the Macedonian Empire, which was dissolved in 323 BCE, initiating the Hellenistic period.
Yehud was absorbed into the Macedonian Empire but continued to largely function autonomously.

[63] During the Hellenistic period, Judea became an independent Jewish kingdom under the Hasmonean dynasty in 140 BCE, expanding into a short lived Jewish empire,[64] before being fully subjugated to the Roman Empire in 37 BCE, following the Siege of Jerusalem (37 BCE).
[65][66][67] After the foundation of the Hasmonean dynasty, the Roman Republic established many client kingdoms in the Eastern Mediterranean.
One of these was Judea, transformed from the former Hasmonean Kingdom, in 37 BCE into the Herodian Kingdom, a fully client kingdom ruled by the Herodian dynasty.
In 6 CE, the Herodian dynasty was converted into Roman Judea, thus the Jews fully lost their political independence to Rome.

In Libya's economic sphere, his government encouraged economic privatization and sought foreign investment, although high levels of unemployment persisted.
Adopting a more anti-Western stance, he influenced moves to increase oil production, using the increasing state revenues to bolster the PSLC's budget.

[199] While rejecting the socialist principles of industry nationalization and wealth redistribution outlined in The Green Book, Libyan politicians emphasized that they were constructing a "people's socialism" rather than capitalism.
Gaddafi welcomed the reforms, describing liberalization as a "natural trend that conforms to [human] nature".

[201] In March 2003, he proposed full-scale privatization of Libyan corporations, with public shares being distributed through the stock market, but this was prevented by the revolutionary hard-liners.
[202] Nevertheless, a large sector of the oil industry was privatized, with production being largely run by private corporations by 2007.
[203] By 2004, there was US$40 billion of direct foreign investment in Libya, six times that of 2003, much of it in the energy sector.
[204][205] Some Libyans protested against these reforms, and in March 2006, hard-line revolutionaries took control of the GPC cabinet.

[206] Slowing the pace of reform, they put a halt on further privatization,[203] although the idea remained on the table; in 2010, the government stated that half of the economy would be privatized over that decade.
[207] The pace of reform also led to an upswing in public criticism of the administration and Gaddafi.
Political liberalization was not forthcoming,[208] but in March 2010, the government devolved further powers to the municipal councils.

[206] Reformist technocrats gained more influence in government,[209] and were associated with Gaddafi's second eldest son, Saif al-Islam Gaddafi, who was openly critical of Libya's human rights record.

[210] Saif had been publicly involved in the development of relations between Libya and Austria,[211] and in trying to secure the release of Libyan Islamists imprisoned in the U.S., the U.K., and Asian countries.

[212] Working to modernize the country, he unsuccessfully encouraged the adoption of the 2009 constitution, and in October 2009 was appointed head of the PSLC,[213] with Libyan state television believing that he was being positioned as the eventual successor to his father.

[214] Gaddafi insisted that neither of his sons would succeed him.[215] Saif was also involved in encouraging tourism,[216] and in 2008 created several privately run media channels, encouraging more open reporting.
[217] These channels were taken over by the state in 2009 after he fell out of favor, allegedly because he had publicly criticised the government.
[218][219] In October 2010, Gaddafi apologized to African leaders for the Arab role in the African slave trade.[220]

"Humanism" was coined in mid-18th century France as "humanismus", and thereafter adopted into German, English, including by the early 19th century the more ideological Humanism, Humanist, etc., associated with a whiggish liberal theology of Unitarian and Deist views.

The latter form suggests the deification or idolatry of humanity, a common charge against Humanism and especially against the historicist humanism introduced by Enlightenment philosophers such as Rousseau and Enlightenment Hegelians such as Feuerbach and, in the early 20th century, Heidegger's "Humanism" and the anti-humanism of his followers (structuralism and post-structuralism, such as Barthes and Foucault).
[24] An early spreader of the ideological use "humanism" was the early 19th century German theologian Johann Gottfried Herder.

In 1765, the author of an anonymous article in a French Enlightenment periodical spoke of "The general love of humanity ... a virtue hitherto quite nameless among us, and which we will venture to call 'humanism,' for the time has come to create a word for such a beautiful and necessary thing".

[36] Humanism began to acquire a negative sense in 18th-century France, combining a cult of humanity with anti-nationalism and anti-Christianity (Voltaire,[24] Rousseau, Kant, late Hegel), particularly in the writings of the conservative Catholics who denounced the French Revolution, and as developments, the revolutionaries like Auguste Comte, the German founding father of sociology, Karl Marx, Friedrich Engels, the Russian anarchist, and critic of Marxism, Mikhail Bakunin, Friedrich Nietzsche, the American Progressives, and postwar Existentialism.

In the second part of the 18th and the early 19th centuries, many grassroots "philanthropic" and "benevolent societies" for the aid and improvement of the human condition sprang up, many, but not all, with Christian roots, in addition to trends in philosophy like Romanticism.

After the French Revolution, the idea that human virtue could be created without of traditional religious institutions, attributed to Rousseau, was violently attacked by influential religious and political conservatives, such as Edmund Burke and Joseph de Maistre.
Burke attacked the "homelessness," and the professed stock exchange Jewish anti-nationalism and anti-clerical Humanism of the French Revolution and its supporters as an ideology.

These attacks continued in the 19th century, as humanism became more common, with Lord Acton describing its romantic anti-nationalism and anti-clericalism as an "aesthete cult of humanity", "substituting literary and critical theory, secular oracles, and new gods of enlightenment for Christian theology, philosophy, and ethics".

In the writings of Burke, Acton, and Pope Pius IX[37] this meant the humanitarian idolization or worship of thinking, democratic, intellectual man, sometimes with a post-Hegelian/Materialist/atheistic or other doubting anti-clerical and anti-biblical theology.

In 1812, the English clergyman Thomas Gisborne, a prominent evangelical layperson and Joint-treasurer of the Church Missionary Society, used the word humanism "to designate the religious convictions of the Unitarian deist, to distinguish them from the more orthodox Christian believer[38] In this polarized climate, liberal reformers and radicals embraced and stylized Humanism as hymn and creed.
