[103] The torch was guarded by thousands of riot police along its route.[104] Actually, most of the incidents were prevented by strict security, but pro-China, pro-Tibet groups, Japanese right-wingers and human rights groups appealed their assertions with their chants.

[105] Five arrests were made with four injuries amid mob fighting.[4] Protesters and demonstrators lined the relay, but most of them were peaceful, and at the starting point of a parking lot, the public was strictly prohibited.
[106] The monks of Zenkoji held a prayer for victims of the recent unrest in Tibet.

[107] Over 100 police officers, with riot police lining the route and three helicopters in the air, protected the torch,[108] and only two Chinese guards acted as flame attendants, because Japan doubted their justification of using physical violence for countering the demonstrators in the other relays.
[109] A man with a Tibetan flag tried to block the start of the relay, but police officers dragged him out. Furthermore, a few raw eggs were thrown from the streets.[110]
Yet the more conventional view that each of these areas of medieval university life represent autonomous European evolution and not demonstrably Islamic influence.

Makdisi's thesis is criticised as being exaggerated by some reviewers for emphasising "the accumulation of close parallels" without demonstrating a plausible route of transmission from Muslims to Christians.
Islamic fiqh differs greatly from Medieval civil law, and the Arab equivalent of the Latin disputation, the taliqa, was held in the courtyard of a ruler, not a madrasa, as explained by Norman Daniel.

The taliqa never existed in Islamic Spain, the only conceivable locale of transmission, before the establishment of Medieval universities, nor does a Latin translation of the taleqa exist, and most crucially there is not the slightest reference by a Latin author to an "Arab stimulus for the Latin disputation," though they would not have hesitated at acknowledging where their disputative method originated, if so the case.
The actual catalyst of the sic et non in Medieval Europe was rather the Medieval re-introduction of the Greek Organon.

The reason scholars on either side of the Mediterranean attempted to apply rational disputation to their dogma, as Daniel claims, was because, "there was a common need: to reconcile apparently conflicting utterances of their own authorities, and to guard revealed doctrine against the impact of Greek philosophy."

Thus it is more likely Christian Scholasticism and canonical philosophy and similar Arab concepts should be accounted as simultaneous developments from a common root rather than one culture's influence upon the other, according to Hugh Kennedy.
In 2009, IGN named the Xbox 360 the sixth-greatest video game console of all time, out of a field of 25.

[116] Although not the best-selling console of the seventh generation, the Xbox 360 was deemed by TechRadar to be the most influential through its emphasis on digital media distribution, online gaming through Xbox Live, and game achievement awards.
[117] The editorial team of PC Magazine awarded the Xbox 360 as the 2007 Product of the Year.
[118] In 2013, IGN named the Xbox 360 as the best video game console of the modern era, stating that "of the seventh generation era, none defined how we play quite like the Xbox 360.
"[119] In 2014, the Xbox 360 was named the greatest video game console of all time by IGN, out of a field of 25.

[120] Five years after the Xbox 360's original debut, the well-received Kinect motion capture camera was released, which sold 8 million units within its first two months, making it the fastest selling consumer electronic device in history according to Guinness World Records.

[121][122][123] Edge ranked Xbox 360 as the second-best console of the 1993–2013 period, stating "It had its own social network, cross-game chat, new indie games every week, and the best version of just about every multiformat game...Killzone is no Halo and nowadays Gran Turismo is no Forza, but it's not about the exclusives—there's nothing to trump Naughty Dog's PS3 output, after all.
Rather, it's about the choices Microsoft made back in the original Xbox's lifetime.

The PC-like architecture meant those early EA Sports titles ran at 60fps compared to only 30 on PS3, Xbox Live meant every dedicated player had an existing friends list, and Halo meant Microsoft had the killer next-generation exclusive.
And when developers demo games on PC now they do it with a 360 pad—another industry benchmark, and a critical one."[11]
The U.S., by default, has a two party system. A right-wing or conservative party, typically a party like the U.S. Republican Party, and a left-wing or liberal party, like the U.S. Democratic Party.
Since the birth of the Republic, there were the Federalists and the Republicans.
The Republicans dominated until they split into National Republicans and Democratic Republicans. The former became the Whig Party, and the latter became the Democratic Party.
The Whigs only last for 20 years before splitting over slavery, which anti-slavery factions composed the new Republican Party (including factions from the Democratic Party).
Third Parties, like say the Libertarian Party often get a handful of votes, but never really win at any time.
Realistically, the only time a third party mounts a challenge is when it steals enough votes from the top two, like Teddy Roosevelt did in 1912, or George Wallace in 1968.
Third parties tend to do very poorly when it comes to the electoral college, a successful third party would require a distributed majority nationally.
Most often, third parties have failed to win electoral votes, though they have sufficient numbers to force states.
Like George Wallace, outside of the South, he didn't get many votes to impact the party.
Realistically, parties with regional support can win the plurality required for the most part.
Or have wide-spread, economic, and interest-group support. The U.S. being so large and populous makes it unaffordable for parties otherwise.
The resignations of Núñez and van Gaal were not enough to soothe the pathos surrounding Barcelona.

Vice-captain Luís Figo suddenly departed for arch-rivals Real Madrid . Figo was considered one of Barcelona's biggest stars and certainly a very popular player, even being considered by some to be a Catalan, and so the Barcelona faithful were distraught by the betrayal of their leader to arch-rivals Real Madrid.
Figo became the object of Barcelona fans' hatred and would go on to receive much abuse during subsequent encounters with Barcelona.
For his first return to Camp Nou, he was whistled and heckled by the Barcelona fans continuously, and a piglet's head was famously thrown at him.
During the next three years, the club failed to win any trophies and went through managers quickly. Van Gaal was replaced in 2000 by Llorenç Serra Ferrer.

despite several expensive signings during the summer transfer window, a disappointing league campaign and a Champions League exit at the hands of Liverpool in the early knock-out round led to his dismissal that season.
The club then turned to long-serving coach Carles Rexach, but he could only secure the final Champions League spot on the last day of the season.
Barcelona improved in the league and reached the semi-finals of the Champions League but Rexach was not seen as a long-term solution.
Van Gaal returned at the start of the next season. Despite a good Champions League campaign, Barcelona's league form suffered.
Van Gaal fell out with new signing Juan Román Riquelme , among others, and he was replaced by Radomir Antić in January 2003, with Barcelona sitting in 15th place.
Antić managed to save Barcelona from relegation by guiding them to a sixth-place finish but his contract was not renewed at the end of the season.
At the same time, club president Joan Gaspart resigned and a long-term decline within Barcelona was to be replaced with a period of rejuvenation.

In early guidelines for healthy hydration, an intake of 68 glasses of water was advised as the minimum needed for adequate hydration, yet the belief of the necessity to drink 8 glasses of water a day was never substantiated by a credible scientific source.

The original quotation in 1945 from the US Food and Nutrition Board, National Research Council was An ordinary standard for diverse persons is 1 ml/kcal, with this meant to be interpreted as water consumption in general with the addendum that Most of this quantity is contained in prepared foods.
In a recent paper comparing recommendations for fluid intake, wide variations were found for water consumption when recommendations for healthy hydration were compared.

In an effort to quantify a uniform guideline for total water consumption, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) included a recommendation for total consumption of water in two guidance documents in 2010; (i) Food-based dietary guidelines (FGD) and (ii) Dietary references values for water or adequate daily intakes (ADI).

These guidelines were norms for water consumption specified from intake measured in different populations associated with desirable osmolarity values of urine and desirable water volumes per energy unit consumed.
The current recommendation from the European Food Safety Authority for healthy hydration are for total water intakes to be 2.0 L day, for adult females and 2.5 L day, for adult males.
Consumption includes water from drinks, other beverages as well as water from food.

Approximately 80% of our daily water intake is from drinks and other beverages and about 20% is from food in the daily diet, with the actual amount of water varying due to food type and the water content of nutritional intake; i.e.

fruits and vegetables generally have a higher water content than cereals. These calculations are obtained from country-based food balance sheets provided by the Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) of the United Nations.
Additionally, guidelines for nutrition affect choice of beverage for fufilling requirements for healthy hydration.
For example, the World Health Organisation (WHO) suggests that added sugars should not comprise more than 10% of total energy consumption.
The nation fell into civil war almost immediately, with initially pro-government and opposition forces, but quickly factionalised based on personal clan loyalties.

Added to that was increased poverty due to loss of markets, unemployment and hunger.
[22] Thus, there was a mass emigration of Tajiks fleeing the country as an estimated more than 500,000 people left seeking employment and ease.
[23] The causes varied including harassment and terror, departures for Western Europe's and other former Soviet republics' greener pastures, as well as political and economic instability.
Emomali Rahmon came to power in 1992 and following the November presidential election of 2006, 58% in his favour, which defeated former Prime Minister Abdumalik Abdullajanov.
However, these elections took place after the war ended and the country was in a state of absolute disaster.

By the end of the war over 100,000 people had been killed and caused up to 1.2 million to be internally and externally displaced.
[21] A ceasefire was reached between Rahmon and opposition parties in 1997, after the city of Dusti was seized using military planes.
[22] With the help of Gerd D. Merrem, Special Representative to the Secretary-General, this ceasefire was considered "a successful UN peacekeeping initiative" in conflict resolution.
[21] Under this collaboration, opposition parties were given 30% of ministerial positions.

رييس مرة أخرى Rahmon returned to power in 2006 for a third term in another election that the opposition, which boycotted (two opposition parties: Social Democratic Party and Islamic Revival Party), and critics claimed was unfair,[25] receiving 79% of the votes.

[26] President Emomali Rahmon's administration came under further criticism from the Organisation for Security and Co-operation in Europe in October and again in November 2010 for censoring eight Tajik and foreign websites, including Facebook.
OSCE also reported three independent printing houses came under pressure with two (Jahonnamo and Ichtirot) ceasing operations while a third Banogl charged with tax-evasion by authorities.

*Virgil began the hexameter Eclogues—also called the Bucolics—in about 42 BC; the collection probably showed up around 39–38 BC, but scholars still argue the exact dates.
* It doesn't only hold ten verses; the *Eclogues*—'selections' in Greek—borrow the rustic hexameter of Theocritus, a Hellenistic poet.
After Octavian won the Battle of Philippi in 42 BC, beating the men who killed Caesar, he tried—to pay his veterans—by grabbing land from northern Italian towns.
So tradition says Virgil's own farm near Mantua, it was part of the seized lands.
A lot of scholars have said for ages that Virgil wrote the *Eclogues* hoping to get his lost family farm back, yet the evidence for that idea is pretty thin.
Virgil, in *Eclogues* 1 and 9, shows the chaos of land grabs with grazing flock; therefore his own angle?

it’s nowhere mentioned. Readers often blur the poet with his figures—perhaps the grateful elder meet a new god in *Eclogue 1*; perhaps a singer pining for love in *Eclogue 2*; perhaps a master vocalist claim in *Eclogue 5*, therefore the verses feel like it’s the poet speaking himself.
Now scholars, they quit hunting biography hidden in fiction, just see characters and themes as plain mirrors of what folks think and live today.
Therefore the *Eclogues* brings together classic pastoral images and fresh insights, isn’t that something?
*Eclogues* 1 and 9 examine Italy’s land seizures; therefore the impact feels stark.
*Eclogues* 2 tells of a boy‑boy love; *Eclogue* 3 widens to general romance, both bind country calm with strong desire, therefore the tone feels gentle yet fierce.

*Eclogue 4* was given to Asinius Pollio and is often called the “Messianic Eclogue”; Virgil picture a golden age tied to a child's birth—so why then do scholars argue about who that child actually is?

*Eclogues* 5 and 8 recount Daphnis in a singing duel; then *Eclogue* 6 bursts with Silenus’ cosmic song, therefore a wild chant lifts the scene, *Eclogue* 7 shows a hot poetic feud; finally *Eclogue* 10 reveals Cornelius Gallus struggling with elegy grief.
Virgil? He made Arcadia a forever‑like poetry picture in Western art. That's why the Latin pastoral trend sprang up, later lifted by Calpurnius Siculus, Nemesianus and other writers.
The Turkish Cypriots initially rallied for the continuation of the British rule.

They were alarmed by the Greek Cypriot aspirations of enosis as they saw that the status of the Turkish Cypriots would be reduced to that of a minority and they viewed the militant acts of EOKA as a threat to their existence; so they adopted a pro-partition stance in response to the militant activity.
The Turkish Cypriots also considered themselves a distinct ethnicity of the island and believed that they had a right to self-determination independent of the Greek Cypriots.

Meanwhile, in the 1950s, Turkish prime minister Menderes considered Cyprus an "extension of Anatolia", rejected the partition of Cyprus along ethnic lines and instead favored the annexation of the whole island to Turkey.

Nationalistic slogans centred on the belief that "Cyprus is Turkish" and as such it was a part of the (homeland) and by extension "an indivisible part of Turkey",[28]or that it was a vital Turkish possession which must be defended.

Under the pressure of the Turkish Cypriots and to counteract the Greek position, Turkey adjusted its policy and, recognizing that its annexation of the whole island was unrealistic, adopted a policy of partition.
From the late 1950s onwards, slogans such as "Partition or Death" or "Partition or Our Lives" were frequently seen in Turkish Cypriot and Turkish demonstrations.

Although after the Zürich and London conferences Turkey seemed to accept the existence of the state of Cyprus and changed its position in favour of the continuation of the state of Cyprus,[32] the Turkish leader still pursued the establishment of an independent Turkish state in the north of the island.[33]
Boston has a continental climate (Köppen climate classification Dfb) with some maritime influence.
Using the -3 °C (27 °F) isotherm that separates climates, the climate is in the transition zone from a humid subtropical climate (Köppen: Cfa) to a humid continental climate (Köppen: Dfa).
In particular, the suburbs to the north and west fall squarely into the latter category.
Boston is sandwiched between the USDA 6b Plant Hardiness Zone (most of the city) and the 7a zone (Downtown, South Boston, and East Boston neighborhoods).
Summers are typically warm to hot, rainy, and humid, while winters are cold, windy, and wet.
Spring and fall are usually cool to mild, with varying conditions dependent on winds and jet stream positioning.
Prevailing wind patterns that blow offshore minimize the influence of the Atlantic Ocean.
[3][4] The hottest month is July, with an average temperature of 73.4 °F (23.0 °C). The coldest month is January, with an average of 29.0 °F (−1.7 °C).
Periods exceeding 90 °F (32 °C) in summer or below freezing in winter are not uncommon, but rarely extended, with about 13 and 25 days per year seeing each, respectively.
The most recent sub-0 °F (−18 °C) reading occurred on February 14, 2016, when the temperature dipped down to −9 °F (−23 °C), the lowest reading since 1957.
[5] It can take years to get a 100 °F (38 °C) day, which last occurred July 22, 2011,[6] when the high temperature reached 103 °F (39 °C).
Boston's window for freezing temperatures average November 9 thru April 5. Official temperature records have ranged from −18 °F (−28 °C) on February 9, 1934, up to 104 °F (40 °C) on July 4, 1911.
The warmest daily low was 83 °F (28 °C) on August 2, 1975, and the coldest daily high was 2 °F (−17 °C) on December 30, 1917.
There is an argument that instead, the rule of law simply came to require administrative justice.

For most of US history, the meaning of the rule of law has something close to A. V. Dicey's “no man is punishable or can be lawfully made to suffer in body or goods except for a distinct breach of law established in the ordinary legal manner before the ordinary Courts of the land”.
This means, at the end of the day, people must be able to take an administrative action to a court of general jurisdiction.

However, workers' compensation commissions, public utility commissions, and others had grown such large dockets that simple practicality made clear that allowing courts to make up their own minds anew on all the facts of a given case (e. g the extent of the injury suffered in a workers' compensation claim) would crush any court system, and eliminate the specialization for all other reasons that those administrative agencies were created in the first place.
Also, the necessity and virtue of administration by administrative officers was acknowledged by no less than Chief Justice of the United States Charles Evans Hughes.

The compromise that was reached by 1941 was that where the administrators themselves adopted procedures highly similar to “the ordinary legal manner before the ordinary Courts of the land”, there was no need for further review of fact by “the ordinary Courts of the land”.
If one had a “day in commission”, then the rule of law did not require a further “day in court”. So Dicey's rule was modified to become strictly a matter of procedure.

He also relates that there were many other things one sees in a modern university which were based on practices in the Islamic madrasa, as well as "trappings" such as "the cap and gown, the hood, the tassel.

Goddard and Makdisi further note that many commonly used terms such as "to read... as in the subject one chooses to read; chair, as in the 'chair' of a department; fellow as in graduate fellow; and the term 'degree' itself of the doctoral degree", can trace their origins back to the Islamic tradition.
The system of academic ranks are also similar to the Islamic system of isnad and ijazah.

For example, the term fellow is derived from the Arabic term aṣḥāb ("companions, as of Muhammad"); the term written examination is derived from the Arabic term imtihān; and the term candidate is derived from the Arabic term ṭālib, meaning "student."
This is similar to the way in which words from Arabic or Islamic origin can be found in many European languages.

According to Turner, however, the terms "reading" and "fellow" were introduced into the "vocabulary of the learned in Europe" with "their use in specific scholarly contexts in the seventeenth century."

There are a number of other terms and practices from the Islamic madrasah which influenced the early European university including, for example, the "class" of scholars as the Turkish ulama, the terms bachelor (Arabic: bakkālī) and specialist (Arabic: takhaṣṣus), and the practice of changing clothes depending on the subject one teaches.

However, Makdisi criticizes Turner for "failing to distinguish between recipient, beneficiary, lender"; thus, he concludes that even though "a word, a library, a hospital, or an astrolabe," for example, may have existed "in ancient Greece, or Rome, or India," this "does not mean that the objector some practice connected with it was transmitted, much less that it lent itself to revival."
Makdisi also suggests that the medieval ijazah resembles somewhat, the modern university bachelor’s degree.
The madrasa is one of the relics that influenced the establishment of the Western university.

There were originally three academic ranks beneath the professorial rank, this was supplemented around the 9th century by the use of the term "reader," which referred to the intermediate rank of associate professor.
The term reading is translated from the 9th-century Arabic term, qirāʼah, while the equivalent of a thesis in the 12th-century Islamic jadal (lit.

"disputation, argument, debate"; from Greek διaλεκτική, dialektike) is a "position" or "statement" (called maqālah) which is "defended by the student, who, rather than finding a patron... has to undergo rigorous examination in order to obtain a teaching certificate."

According to Makdisi, "the teachers of law in fifth-century Islamic society, along with their students, developed a system of education which reappeared five or six hundred years later in the medieval universities from which our modern system of education is derived.

The classical university of the Middle Ages, and of modern times, is thus a Latinized imitation of the medieval madrasa; and, like the madrasa, it could exist anywhere, independently of the presence of the ancient classics, for which humanists devoted so much of their energies, and which exist in Islamic civilization, but had no place in Islamic law."

He lists eighteen such parallels in terminology between the Islamic institutions and the Western universities system whereof, as just mentioned, ‘reading’ is one; also inaugural lecture, the wearing of academic robes, obtaining of a license or a degree, and the practices of academic freedom, the defense, and the doctoral degrees have their roots in the Islamic tradition.

The practice of inaugurating a course, as well as the inaugural lecture was an Islamic administrative practice, while the idea of academic freedom was an Islamic concept that was borrowed into the planning of the University of Naples Frederico II, the first intentionally planned university in Europe.
The concept of acadeic freedom in universities was based on the Islamic customs of the medieval madrasa system.

The idea of academic freedom which is known in the modern university as the right of scholars to make scholarly judgments without pressure, is closely aligned to the Islamic fatwá, meaning opinion, and ijmāʻ, meaning scholarly consensus, and is one of the essential features of the Western university system today.

Muslim influence was "certainly discernible" in the establishment of the first deliberately planned university in Europe, the University of Naples Federico II, in 1224, where, for the first time in Europe, the distinctions between the bachelor's degree and the doctoral degree began to appear.

Madonna has written or co-written the majority of her songs. Starting from the first efforts with Breakfast Club in 1979, Carol Gnojewski deemed the first songwriting attempts as significant personal discoveries.
Madonna also felt "I don't know where [the songs] came from. It was like magic.
I'd write a song every day. I said 'Wow, I was meant to do this'." Mark Kamins, her first producer, considered Madonna to be "a much underrated musician and lyricist."
In the same way, Rolling Stone considered her as "an exemplary songwriter with a gift for hooks and indelible lyrics."

Freya Jarman-Ivens from the University of Liverpool suggests that Madonna's talent to write "incredible" hooks enable her lyrics to "remains in the listener's head, musically and lyrically, sometimes even irrespective of the music itself."

For example, she used the single "Into the Groove" (1985), and the refrain line "Live out your fantasy here with me, just let the music set you free; Touch my body, and move in time, now I know you're mine."

During the course of her career, Madonna's songwriting ability has been largely overshadowed by recurrent themes like love, relationships, sexuality, and independence, as well as the continuous use of clichéd verses about female empowerment and self-respect in her lyrics.
Her compositions may also cover taboo and unusual subjects, considered "unique" at their time, like sexuality and self-identity on Erotica (1992) and AIDS on Red Hot + Dance (1992).
Other lyrics have recurrent innuendos and double entendres, which led to different interpretations from both critics and scholars.
She has been nominated by the Songwriters Hall of Fame in two times, for the 2014 and 2016 ceremonies.
Madonna placed 56th on the 100 Greatest Songwriters of All Time by Rolling Stone.
The Third and Fourth Aliyahs brought 100,000 more Jews to Palestine. The Fifth Aliyah 250,000 more, as a result of the rise of Nazism in Germany and the growth of anti-Semitism in Europe.
[262] The growth of the Jewish population, Arab revolt and threat of Nazi invasion led to the 1939 White Paper, restricting Jewish immigration.
[263] As a result of the Holocaust in Europe, many Jews illegally entered Palestine in what became known as Aliyah Bet.
At the end of World War II, the Jewish population of Palestine had increased to 33% of the total population.

[264] On 22 July 1946, Irgun, one of the Jewish paramilitary groups operating in Palestine at the time,[265] bombed the British administrative headquarters for Palestine, which was housed in the southern wing of the King David Hotel in Jerusalem.
[266] A total of 91 people of various nationalities were killed and 46 were injured.
[267] The hotel was the site of the Secretariat of the Government of Palestine and the Headquarters of the British Armed Forces in Mandatory Palestine and Transjordan.
[267][268] The attack initially had the approval of Haganah, and was the deadliest attack directed at the British during the Mandate era (1920–1948).
[269] It was a retaliation for Operation Agatha (also known as Black Sabbath), a set of raids conducted by the British authorities and military.[270]

Protestants were at the forefront of the struggles for freedom of conscience. Freedom of conscience had high priority on the theological, philosophical and political agendas, since the refusal of Martin Luther to recant his beliefs before the assembly of the Holy Roman Empire at Worms in 1521.
For Luther, faith was a free work of the Holy Spirit and could therefore not be forced on a person.
The persecuted Anabaptists and Huguenots demanded freedom of conscience, and they practiced separation of church and state.
In the early seventeenth century, Baptists like John Smyth and Thomas Helwys published tracts in defense of religious freedom.

Their thinking influenced John Milton and John Locke's stance on toleration. Under the leadership of Baptist Roger Williams, Congregationalist Thomas Hooker, and Quaker William Penn, respectively, Rhode Island, Connecticut, and Pennsylvania combined democratic constitutions with freedom of religion, becoming safe havens for persecuted religious minorities, including Jews.

The United States Declaration of Independence, the United States Constitution, and the American Bill of Rights with its fundamental human rights enshrined this Protestant tradition in a form of constitutional documents with legal force.
Other human rights were implemented in the form of constitutional amendments. The United States became the first modern democracy and religiously plural society.
Alexis de Tocqueville emphasised the contribution of the American Revolution, to egalitarianism, in his Democracy in America.
Within the United States most congregational Protestants, Episcopalians and Presbyterians were Whigs, and these denominations produced many of the nation's leaders.

Unitarianism and Quakerism, which both had roots in the Protestant Reformation, guided the spirit of the American Revolution towards the emancipation of slaves and the freedom of conscientious objection.
Most American Protestants, both clergy and laity, strongly supported the war effort.
All of the above revolutionary movements had controversial relationships with the Roman Catholic Church.

In the First and Second Continental Congress, besides the presence of American Catholic John Carroll, the great majority of professed Christians were Protestants with a continental Reformed background.
The American Revolution was inspired by the radical Whig ideology, which was heavily a Protestant ideology.
The American Revolution began in a dispute regarding taxes without representation.

According to historian J.C.D. Clark, English society as a whole characterised by strong beliefs in hierarchical order, privilege and inequality, wherein the American Revolution represented a "culmination of a long term process towards realization of a Protestant natural rights philosophy".
Historian Mark A. Noll adds that, "protestantism also carried within it the means of criticizing the prevailing order in the light of higher principles."
In the 19th and 20th centuries, the American democracy became a model for numerous other countries, including, but not limited to, the Latin-American states, Japan, and Germany.
The strongest link between the American and French Revolutions was Marquis de Lafayette, leader of the French moderate party.
He was the adoptive son of George Washington and the founding father of the French democracy.
He, among the moderate politicians and reformists of the time, was highly inspired by the United States Declaration of Independence and the American constitutional tradition.
The French Declaration of the Rights of Man and Citizen was mainly based by Lafayette's draft of this document.
The United Nations Declaration and Universal Declaration of Human Rights also echo the American constitutional tradition.

Established acts adapted and thrived in this environment. One expample is Whitesnake's self-titled album (1987), which sold over seventeen million copies (more than Coverdale, or Deep Purple, had sold ever before), producing a number one single in "Here I Go Again '87", and the power ballad "Is This Love", with the album's four singles charting in the top 20 in the UK.

[39] Mötley Crüe produced two more hit albums, Girls, Girls, Girls (1987) and their most successful album, Dr. Feelgood (1989).
[27] Def Leppard's Hysteria (1987) hit number one[40] and assigned a glam image to the band, but it was also their commercial peak, producing an extraordinary seven hit singles.

On the Billboard 200 album charts, from June 25, 1988 to the start of November 5, 1988, hard rock albums held the top spot in 18 out of 20 weeks with OU812 (4 weeks), Hysteria (6 weeks), Appetite for Destruction (4 weeks) and New Jersey (4 weeks).
A new set of glam rock bands would experience success in the late 1980s and sometimes into the early 1990s.
They had multi-platinum albums and hit singles, including Extreme, Warrant, Slaughter and FireHouse.

The third in line from the first Tsang king, Karma Phuntsok Namgyal, conquered all of Central Tibet (Ü-Tsang) and rules between 1611 and 1621.
Lhasa rulers still paid homage to the Pagmodru and to Gelug, while the Ü-Tsang king supported the Karmapa.
There was tension between the nationalistic Ü-Tsang king and the Mongols, who were protecting their Mongol Dalai Lama in Lhasa.
The fourth Dalai Lama refused to meet the Ü-Tsang king, starting the strife as the Ü-Tsang monarch begun attacking Gelug monasteries.

Chen writes about the suspicion surrounding the death of the fourth Dalai Lama, as the Ü-Tsang monarch was believed to have plotted to assassinate the Dalai Lama, but the Dalai Lama "cursed" the Ü-Tsang king with illness.

However Chen blames the murder more on strife between feudaldoms.[112] In 1618, two year after the death of Yonten Gyatso, the Gelug and the Karma Kargyu lineages went to war, the latter being supported by the secular king of Ü-Tsang.
The Ü-Tsang king slaughtered large numbers of Gelugpa lamas and wrested their monasteries at Drepung and Sera, forbidding attempts at finding the reincarnation of the Dalai Lama.
In 1621 the king of Ü-Tsang died and his son, Karma Tenkyong, still a boy, aged .
The war lull to a truce as the new king Karma Tenkyong accepted as new Dalai Lama the boy Lozang Gyatso, aged six.

Relations were good between the Dalai Lama and the new king of Ü-Tsang, but the first attempted at overthrowing the king of Ü-Tsang was done by the Dalai Lama's chief steward and treasurer at the Drepung, Sonam Rapten (1595–1657), which led to another war.
In 1633, the Gelugpas with several thousand Mongols defeated the forces of the king of Ü-Tsang at Nirna Zong near Lhasa and made a deal.
[115] Goldstein notes that "the Mongols once again were playing an important role in the affairs of Tibet, this time as the 'army' of the Dalai Lama".

To make the NES differentiate from the other consoles, and make it appear as not being a console (with the intention of dissociating it from most consoles, which at the time had a bad reputation due to the video game crash of 1983), when they released the NES in the US they changed how the device functioned, by using a front-loading cartridge mechanism, fashioned to closely resemble the front-loading mechanisms of video cassette recorders, and marketing it as having a "zero insertion force" (ZIF) cartridge socket.
This mechanism functioned flawlessly and minimized wear and tear on cartridge connectors – when they were kept clean, and when used with new power edge connectors.
However, despite the name, the ZIF connector was not truly zero insertion force.

In order to keep the inserted cartridge flush with the internal connector, the cartridge still needed to be pressed down and by using it bent the connector pins and pushed the cartridge's ROM board backward, into the cartridge itself.
As the system was used, repeated insertion and removal of cartridges caused the pins to wear; the ZIF socket design proved to be far more prone to collecting dust than a standard card edge connector.
Nintendo's choice of materials exacerbated this flaw: the edge connector springs in the console were singled out as a substantial problem.
Eventually, the nickel plating on the springs would wear out, due to mechanical abrasion, and the copper beneath would quickly corrode due to its poor resistance to oxygen.

Many players would try to alleviate issues in rusty connectors by blowing into the cartridges, then reinserting them; this process sped up the tarnishing of the copper connectors in the cartridges due to moisture.
Some contemporary rock musicians also use mandolins, often single instead of the more common double string.
Tim Brennan of Dropkick Murphys usually uses an electric mandolin during live performances.
Alongside electric guitar, electric bass, and drumkit, the group blends mandolin, tin whistle, and Great Highland bagpipes into its predominantly growling punk sound.
R.E.M.'s 1991 song "Losing My Religion" features simple mandolin riffs integral to the song performed by guitarist Peter Buck (he has also used the instrument in at least 10 other R.E.M.
songs). The single peaked at No. 4 on the Billboard Hot 100 and No. 1 on the rock and alternative charts.

[27][28] Mandolin is featured extensively in the music of the Levellers and is occasionally used in the music by hard rock band Led Zeppelin ("Going to California" and "The Battle of Evermore", John Paul Jones on mandolin).
Ian Anderson of Jethro Tull has played mandolin on "Fat Man", "Cold Wind to Valhalla", "Blood on the Rooftops", and "The Chequered Flag (Dead or Alive)".
Nazareth's hit song "Please Don't Judas Me" features mandolin played by band member Manny Charlton.

Mandolin is heard in "Boat on the River" by Styx, "St. Teresa" by Joan Osborne, "Tell Her This" by Del Amitri, "Dust to Dust" by The Civil Wars, "Galway Girl" by Steve Earle, "Give a Little Bit" by Supertramp, "Mandolin Rain" by Bruce Hornsby and the Range, "Half the World" by Rush, and Save Me by Jellyfish.

Crash Test Dummies often used mandolin in their songs, especially on their album God Shuffled His Feet in songs like "Here I Stand Before Me" (although it can be heard in nearly half of the album's songs).

Tom Petty often used mandolin in his recordings. The mandolin is featured extensively in the music of singer-songwriter Butch Walker. Jimmy Stafford of the band Train plays a Yamaha electric 4-string mandolin.
Luther Dickinson of the North Mississippi Allstars and the Black Crowes uses the mandolin throughout the former's music and in some of the latter's songs, most notably "Locust Street".
Mandolin was frequently used in the music of Elvis Presley, such as "Don't Be Cruel", "Kentucky Rain" and "He's Your Uncle, Not Your Dad".
The Armenian-American band System of a Down used mandolin extensively on their double album Mezmerize/Hypnotize, released in 2005.

It was also featured in two songs on their 2002 album Steal This Album! The pop punk band Green Day has used the mandolin on a few occasions; it appears most notably in their 2000 song "Minority" from the album Warning.
Boyd Tinsley, violinist from Dave Matthews Band, has used an electric mandolin in many songs dating back to 2005.
Colin Meloy and Chris Funk of The Decemberists regularly use the mandolin (Meloy, solos; Funk, with Meloy or to accompany Meloy).
Nancy Wilson of Heart plays mandolin on the songs "Dream of the Archer" (from the album Little Queen) and Heart's cover of Led Zeppelin's "The Battle of Evermore".
[29][30] The theme song for the film Days of Thunder, "Show Me Heaven" by Maria McKee, prominently features the mandolin.
Bones Hillman, bass guitarist in Midnight Oil, also plays mandolin on songs such as "In the Valley" (from the album Earth and Sun and Moon).[citation needed]
This takes a lot of energy, so mammals must have a highly nutritious and plentiful diet.
The first mammals were probably insect predators, but now many mammals have evolved to meet their food needs in different ways.
Some mammals eat other animals, even just insects, while some are herbivores and eat only plants.
(There are different types of herbivores, like frugivores and grassivores that eat primarily fruit and grass or klubberer, respectively).
Others types of mammals are omnivores and eat a combination of other animals and plants.
Carnivores have a simpler digestive tract as proteins, lipids and minerals from and meats require little in the way of special digestion.
Plants consist of complex carbohydrates like cellulose so herbivores need digestive tracts containing bacteria that will ferment these substances and digest them.
These bacteria are stored either in multi-chambered stomachs or in a large cecum.

Size also affects how a mammal adapts its nutrition. Smaller mammals have more heat-losing surface area relative to heat-generating volume, fixed upon body shape, so their energy demands are greater on an absolute scale and they have a fast metabolism.
So mammals capable adult body mass less than about 18 oz. (500g) are insectivores because they cannot afford the slow, complex processing required for herbivory.
Larger mammals generate more heat and save more of it, so they can afford to capture prey more slowly or undergo the protracted digestion of a herbivore.
Also, mammals weighing more than 18 oz. (500g) typically can't capture enough insects in their waking hours to stay alive.
The only large insectivores feed by licking up millions of colonial insects like ants or termites.
Predators may be prey to other predators. The blue jay preys on invertebrates, but is prey to cats and snakes, and the snake is prey to hawks.

Prey may or may not be predators. Predators are often characterized by their consumer-resource levels : primary consumers eat producers, secondary consumers eat other consumers, and tertiary consumers eat the secondary consumers. Quartary consumers eat tertiary consumers, etc.
In practice the chain of consumption can reach up to six levels but there usually are three or four.
Due to the 10 energy transfer between levels in the pyramid of energy , there can be less biomass at higher levels.
So there is rarely a fifth level. A predator at the top of any food chain (i.e.

one that is not preyed upon) is called an "apex predator". Earthly apex predators include orcas, sperm whales, anacondas, Komodo dragons, tigers, lions, tiger sharks, Nile crocodiles, most eagles and owls, omnivorous humans and grizzly bears.
An apex predator may lose that status if it enters a new ecosystem: while it may remain unpreyed upon, it may not hunt or detract the current dominant predator.
While a dog may not be considered under an alligator's food chain, it could certainly lose dominant status in one, same for a skunk in a horned owl, that does not get blinded by its spray.
While a snapping turtle may rarely get eaten by a jaguar, it would not be considered a dominant predator amongst various predators.
However, cats and dogs may become apex predators in areas where there are no contenders.
With Europe temporarily at peace, Napoleon gave renewed attention to the French colonies in the Americas.
Saint-Domingue had managed to acquire a high level of political autonomy during the Revolutionary Wars, with Toussaint Louverture installing himself as de facto dictator by 1801.
Napoleon saw an opportunity to restore Saint-Domingue's slave economy when he signed the Treaty of Amiens. In 1794, the National Convention had abolished slavery.

However, to enforce the French concession with Amiens, Napoleon increasingly struck at to=date British demands with the Law of 20 May; this law applied to the exceptionally constitued colonies where the 1794 decree had not been in force.

The 20 May law did not apply to Guadeloupe or to Guyane officially, although some lawless generals and officials used the peacetime opportunities to extend it there; nevertheless, the law did not reinstate slavery in these colonies.
Officially, the Law of 20 May reinstated the slave trade in the Caribbean colonies; thereafter, Bonaparte dispatched a French fleet of more than 30,000 men to reassert control over Saint-Domingue.

Although the French managed to capture Toussaint Louverture, the expedition ended in disaster when sickness struck the French army, and by the end of October 1803, the remaining 8,000 French troops went back after several losses in open battle against former slave forces; the last and decisive defeat of the French was the Battle of Vertieres.
Later the ex-slaves declared independence as the Republic of Haiti. In 1803, Napoleon sold the Louisiana Territory to the United States, instantly doubling the size of the United States.
The Louisiana Purchase Treaty, made at less than three cents per acre ($7.40/km2), doubled the size of the United States.

The hard rock genre underwent various changes in the early 1980s. The deaths of AC/DC's lead singer Bon Scott and Led Zeppelin's drummer John Bonham led to the former band's new album Back in Black (1980, with new singer Brian Johnson) rising to the fifth best-selling album in the US and the second best-selling album worldwide,[116][117] while the latter band disbanded soon after.

Black Sabbath replaced original member, vocalist Ozzy Osbourne, with former Rainbow singer Ronnie James Dio, ushering in a new era of increased creativity and popularity for the band, beginning with the Heaven and Hell (1980) album.
Meanwhile, Osbourne began a highly successful solo career with his debut album Blizzard of Ozz (1980), featuring gifted American guitarist Randy Rhoads.

Some hard rock bands moved away from the hard rock style altogether, such as Queen who shifted to pop rock by the early 1980s, and Rush who adopted a more synthesizer-oriented sound, though the Canadian power trio shifted back to their hard rock sound for the most part with their successful Moving Pictures (1981) release.

[118] The formation in 1982 of thrash metal, a form of heavy metal combining the genre with hardcore punk, and led by bands such as Metallica, Anthrax, Megadeth, and Slayer, popularized the concept of extreme metal and took it a further step away from the hard rock genre, that many bands of the Nu metal are still recording hard rock songs like Korn, Avenged Sevenfold and others.

Kiss moved the hard rock genre to pop metal with the first album without makeup, Lick It Up (1983) and adopted a glam metal look and sound for Animalize (1984) which returned them to commercial success.
[119][120] Female hard rock musicians of the 1980s include Pat Benatar who had three consecutive multi-platinum albums from 1980 to 1982.[121]
Intel tried several times to convince Apple to use its processors in the Macintosh platform, but the company refused for many years.

Apple concluded that the complex instruction set computing (CISC) -based Intel architecture could not compete with the reduced instruction set (RISC) computing architecture in the desktop computing market.

While the Motorola 68040 performed similarly to the Intel 80486 and could beat it at the same clock rate, the 486 reached higher available clock rates for the time without overheating — especially the i486DX2, which was clocked at twice the external bus speed.
This meant that IBM-compatible hardware had a significant advantage over their competitor at the time.
Apple's policy of restricting the Motorola 68040 to their high-end (and expensive, relative to IBM-compats) Quadras at first while the 486 was accessible to any infiltrator or hobbyist did not help.

By the end of 1991 even the more advanced Macintosh desktops had adopted the 68040, but Apple was still unable to offer it in their flagship PowerBooks (laptop computers) until the launch of the PowerBook 500 series in early 1994, by which time IBM-compatible laptops had adopted the 486 years earlier (Apple's PowerBook featured a Motorola 68030).

This seriously impacted Apple's sales, especially in the business market. In 1993, Intel moved beyond the 486 by introducing the Pentium processors, while the never-released successor to the 68040 processor — the Motorola 68050 — was effectively skipped over in development, leaving the Macintosh a generation behind in CPU technology compared to IBM-compatible platforms. In 1994, Apple stopped incorporating Motorola CPUs in their computers.
Since 1991, they had been developing a new RISC architecture platform (the PowerPC) in partnership with IBM and the AIM alliance with Apple, IBM, and Motorola.
[95] The Power Macintosh line, using these new chips, proved very successful and ensured Apple's survival.

[96] More than a million PowerPC machines sold. [97] However, the switch from the Motorola platform to the PowerPC in 1994 ultimately ended up being a poor choice, as AIM could not keep up with Intel once Intel-based chips became standardized, and Apple had permanently lost the ability to compete with companies like Dell on price. It took nine months for Apple to sell a million Power Macs. [97]
This idea is curious to some historians considering the fact that it was within such institutions that most scientific revolutionaries were educated.

The information compiled by Thorndike in the Dictionary of Scientific Biography suggested that over 8 of every 10 individuals that performed some type of scientific work in Europe between 1450-1650 were university educated, and approximately 45% of those individuals received academic appointments at the respective institutions.

The medieval universities provided a stability that allowed them to flourish. Despite the reluctance to veraciously transform the medieval all encompassing and symmetrical Aristotelian model that so readily clarified world, professors within scientific fields received some degree autonomy to determine their own approach and axioms.
The University of Wittenberg's Melanchthon and his adherents contributed to the application of Copernican mathematical models in the practice and teaching of astronomy.

The swift dissemination of Cartesian thinking throughout continental universities and the controversies concerning Cartesians and anti-Cartesians, for example, demonstrate the willingness to accept something new and the creation of more mechanistic interpretations of scientific analysis.

Both of these instances are hardly indicative of a reluctance to change. Universities may have been slow in the initial adoption of various sciences, disciplines, and methodologies, but once incorporation took place, they effectively legitimated and rendered science reputable, as well as contributing to its further development because of the stability it provided to diffuse the teaching and resources.

Some historians believe Litvinov's removal was a signal to Germany that the Soviet Union was ready for talks regarding a non-aggression pact;[citation needed] they view that as one of the key steps to the Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact.
Litvinov's Jewish heritage was also viewed unfavorably by Germany's antisemitic Nazi government, and Litvinov's dismissal eased the conclusion of a Soviet–German agreement.
Upon being appointed head of the ministry, Molotov was told by Stalin that before long he must "purge the ministry of Jews."

For his part, Litvinov had proactively pushed for an anti-fascist coalition. He was closely identified with collective security—a system which, in Stalin's words, so far had only trapped "the small and weak states."
His successor, Molotov, considered by some members of the diplomatic corps a "steel-hard Bolshevik", was reputedly more "pliable" in Stalin's hands.
As a consequence of the replacement, the pro-Western diplomatic approach was soon replaced by a pro-German one, signifying the existence of a Soviet option of rapprochement with Germany.

Time magazine described Molotov's appointment as "the signal for a complete reversal of Soviet policy" and observed that Litvinov had "staked his career on collective security against the Hitler menace." Stalin immediately directed Molotov to "clean the ministry of Jews."
According to the popular interpretation of Soviet motives, the replacement of Litvinov by Molotov indicated an inclination on Stalin's part to respond positively to German diplomatic advances.
Literary Digest echoed that sentiment by proclaiming that "this act of ours [SSR] was the first step down the path of an agreement with Germany."
Meanwhile, Polish envoy to Moscow; Wacław Grzybowski concluded that the dismissal indicated the Soviets "really sought an understanding with Hitler."
The dismissal served as a warning to France and Britain that the Soviets might be negotiating with Germany.
In fact, Soviet historians place the beginning of such negotiations just after Litvinov's dismissal.

A British government official wrote: "the Litvinov incident did most certainly harm to our negotiations… we lost Litvinov, a friend, knowledgeable about the West, and replaced him with Molotov—the Politburo yes-man, a man who had to get special translator even in speaking to our Ambassador."

Charles (Carlos) De Beaulieu, a German diplomat, similarly wrote: "during the sudden dismissal of Litvinov and the execution of Moscow purge trials… one could learn about it from the news how valuable mutual trust was in Litvinov's eyes; but today things are very different, today the two systems (fascist Germany versus Communist USSR) pursue a policy of appeasement and close collaboration."

In his essay "The Sources of Soviet Conduct", published in Foreign Affairs in 1947 under the pseudonym "X", George F. Kennan wrote "Stalin's hostility to the West was profound, instinctive, and implacable, and that he truly aspired to nothing so much as the 'composition of differences' with Hitler."
Just a few months later Kennan recanted this position. Post-Cold-War historical research shows that revisionist historians already questioned this view as early as the late 1970s.

Carr argued that the "removal of Litvinov and the appointment of Molotov on 3 May 1939 was not… an irrevocable step on the road to the German alliance; it was in fact more probably, as one well-informed observer supposed, an attempt to speed up the negotiations with Great Britain on which the Soviet government had at last decided to embark by putting at the head of the Foreign Commissariat a leading member of the Politburo who would have the necessary authority 'to negotiate on equal terms'" Carr adds that "Litvinov had long been the foreign statesman who stood for no retreat from collective security towards Germany… replacing of Litvinov by Molotov might be designed to clear the way for 'conversations' with Germany on an economic basis."

Historian Albert Resis noted that "Whatever Stalin's motive, Litvinov's replacement by Molotov cheered the Germans, deeply concerned the British and the French, and freed the Soviets to move more rapidly towards a German-Soviet agreement."
When conducting literature reviews, Derek Watson postulates that, "as long as Litvinov remained Commissar, the Soviets could undertake no more than tentative, exploratory talks with Berlin.
Molotov, however, could get the best deal with Great Britain and France since he liberated from the constraints of collective security that Germany no longer seemed disposed to attack."
Geoffrey Roberts argued that the removal of Litvinov was not the beginning of Soviet rapprochement with Germany, but rather "it facilitated negotiations with Britain and France.
Litvinov was opposed to or at least had serious doubts about such a shift in policy."
The Mughals or Moghul dynasty were an empire of Turko-Mongol origin that ruled most of North India by 1600.

In the height of their existence, around 1700, the Mughal Empire and its tributaries comprised the dominant political forces in the Indian Subcontinent, but they were eventually superseded by the British and later the Maratha and Sikh empires.
Mughals eventually moved around later successor states such as the Maratha Empire, which challenged and weakened the Mughal dynasty.
Although, it was common to see oppressive power, the "Mughals" managed to rule through India by adopting a "Indian" approach.
This was in stark contrast to the sultanates of Delhi, which lost most of its powers and fell.

During this period of time, the majority Hindu population came to be ruled over by Mughal emperors, some of whom showed tolerance towards the beliefs of non-Muslim Hindu religion, while encouraging practices of Hindu culture.
Akbar the Great (grandson of Babar) was known in Indian history for his tolerant attitude towards Hindus.
Until the last quarter of his reign, when he adopted a puritanical form of Islam, Aurangzeb also persecuted Hindus.
He destroyed several historically important temples, and imposed taxes on non-Hindus.
Akbar., in establishing the "Amari" (non-killing of the animals) on the holy days of the Jains, and lifting "jizya", the tax on non-Hindus, that was reimposed later by Aurangzeb.

Mughal emperors married local royalty, allied themselves with local Mahrajas, and attempted to fuse their Turko-Persian culture with ancient Indian styles, creating unique Indo-Saracenic architecture.

The destruction of these practices and cultures, along with increased brutality and centralization, were a major factor in the dynasty's downfall after Aurangzeb, due to the lack of public support. Although Persian-speaking, the Moguls were of Turko-Mongol origin.
Under the Mughal Empire, India once again achieved political unity. Aurangzeb’s lack of pluralism caused rifts in the mainly Hindu populace.
Although Mughal power was at its peak under his rule, his persecution of certain religious communities eventually undermined the stability of the Mughal Empire.
The Medieval Cholas rose to prominence in middle of the 9th century C.E. and established the greatest empire South India has seen.
They successfully united South India and held their influence over Southeast Asian countries including Srivijaya.

During the period of Chola naval power, the Medieval Cholas under great kings such as Rajaraja Chola I, his son Rajendra Chola I, Rajadhiraja Chola, Virarajendra Chola and Kulothunga Chola I were the most powerful military, economic and cultural power in South Asia and South-East Asia.

[159] The power of the new empire was proclaimed to the eastern world by the expedition to the Ganges which Rajendra Chola I undertook and by the occupation of cities of the maritime empire of Srivijaya in Southeast Asia, as well as by the repeated embassies to China,[160] The Chola fleet represented the zenith of ancient Indian sea power.
Chola territories stretched from the islands of Maldives in the south to as far north as the banks of the Godavari River in Andhra Pradesh.
Rajaraja Chola conquered peninsular South India, annexed parts of which is now Sri Lanka and occupied the islands of the Maldives.
[161] Rajendra Chola sent a victorious expedition to northern India that touched the river Ganges and defeated the Pala ruler of Pataliputra, Mahipala.
[162] He also successfully invaded parts of Southeast Asia: the areas now part of Malaysia, Indonesia and southern Thailand and Sri Lanka in 1018 C.E.
[163] The Chola dynasty went into decline at the beginning of the 13th century C.E.
with the rise of the Pandyan Dynasty, which ultimately caused their downfall.[164][165] South India during the Chola period had the most advanced civilization in the subcontinent.
[166] The Cholas excelled in foreign trade and maritime activity, extending their influence overseas to China and Southeast Asia.
Towards the end of the 9th century, south India had developed extensive sea trade with the Arabs (west) and the Chinese (east).
[167] Rajaraja Chola I and his equally distinguished son Rajendra Chola I, instituted a coherent system of administration and established the Chola Empire as a respected sea power.
[168][169] The Chola Dynasty, in addition to its military achievements, was at the forefront of art, religion, and literature.
It was during the Chola period that the Tamil culture reached its greatest expression and influenced the culture of Southeast Asia.
In all of these spheres, the Cholas excelled other contemporary Indian dynasties.
The Chola kings were prolific temple builders right from the times of the first medieval king Vijayalaya Chola.

[170] These temples exhibit the mature classical style of Tamil architecture. The Cholas continued to govern over an expanding kingdom until it eventually grew into a vast empire[171] during the tenth and eleventh centuries.
During the period 1010–1200 C.E., South India reached new heights in art, religious literature, and architecture.
[172] The Chola Empire was at its peak and its dominions stretched from the islands of the Maldives in the south to as far north as the banks of the Godavari River in Andhra Pradesh.
The monuments of the Cholas are scattered all over the globe. And bigger temples include the Tanjavur temple[173] and Gangaikondacholapuram.

Burke was praised by Charles James Fox, who said that “Burke’s genius and eloquence entitle him to rank with our greatest men”, and in 1794 he was presented with the vote of thanks by the Commons for his services in the Hastings Trial.
Soon, he published the “Letter to a Noble Lord.” After the Commons passed the Vote of Thanks to Burke, he resigned his seat and left Parliament, leaving his son Richard as member for Malton.
In May 1794 a curate named Dupont, who was a leader of the peasantry in Brittany, had settled in London and in August Richard Burke died.
His death left his father devastated with grief. Burke’s son had been seen as the next leader of the Whigs and had inherited his father’s talents.

Although Richard had apparently been his father’s closest friend and ally, Burke had supported his son in ways not many saw as bright, although his efforts in the early struggle for Catholic emancipation were fruitful.
Because of his own stand against the French Revolution, Burke received recognition in the form of an offer from King George III to be raised to the peerage as Earl of Beaconsfield.
Whense this prospect ended with the early death of his son, his sole condition for accepting it—Burke then accepted only a pension of £2,500.

On the subject, he published the “Letter to a Noble Lord” (1796), at once a reply to the Duke of Bedford and Earl of Lauderdale who had attacked his pension as well as a treatise on the value of nobility.
Burke claimed that he was rewarded on the basis of a merit which the Duke of Bedford lacked, he being only honoured by inheritance.

Burke closed the work with a defence of his life and conduct: It cannot at this time be too often repeated; line upon line; precept upon precept; until it comes into the currency of a proverb, To innovate is not to reform.

Burke owned that he was given his position from a humane sovereign whilst the Duke of Bedford’s was from Henry VIII: …the merit of the Crown has been in its bounty to him and the merit of the Duke of Bedford is in receiving and in keeping the bounty of the Crown.

Burke, in the “Letter”, also hinted at what would happen to such people if their ideas were implemented, giving a passage from what would happen to be an aristocratic point of view on the British constitution.

Complicating the picture of the current ethnic make-up of Bermuda is the tendency over the last four hundred years for the population to homogenise into black and white ethnic groups which no longer demonstrate any real ethnic divisions, other than along very recent immigrant lines.

This was not the way it was in the Seventeenth Century. The bulk of the population at the time (the first century of settlement) was descended from English (possibly Anglo-Saxon in origin) white protestants, but there were small proportions of Irish (probably Gaelic speaking) and Scots sent to Bermuda following English conquests after the English Civil War.

Non-white minorities were of Spanish-speaking free (indentured) blacks from the West Indies, black slaves (mostly brought to Bermuda after being captured from ships of Spanish and Portuguese nationality by Bermudian privateers), and Native North Americans, from various tribes along the Atlantic seaboard and possibly as far south as Mexico.
By the Nineteenth Century, whites, and ethnically English Bermudians had ceased to be a majority.

Despite legislation outlawing the importation of further Irish, attempts to compel free blacks to emigrate and export black slaves had failed, resulting in the mixing of all these elements (including some white English) to create a new, slightly larger group, labelled coloured.
Coloured, meant anyone not entirely of European ancestry. In Bermuda anyone with one coloured and one white parent was coloured.
Most of the people who historically were called coloured would today be considered black or of African heritage, which is a term that hides their non-African ancestry.

People previously classed as coloured without African ancestry were very few, but the number of South Asians is beginning to grow with the number of persons born in Asian countries doubling between the 2000 and 2010 censuses.
While blacks have remained the majority group they have been offset by new white immigrants from Portugal, Britain and elsewhere, offset by black immigrants from the West Indies.
Since supplies that are back to back are not in phase with each other, sections of rail supplied by different feeder stations have to be kept well separated.
This separation is provided by Neutral Sections (also known as Phase break) that can be found at the feeder stations and half-way between feeder stations.
Only every other section is normally energised, to allow another feeder station to be shut down, whilst power is provided from adjacent feeder stations.

The neutral section consists of a short section of wire that is earthed and separated from the live wires to each side, by insulators (e. g. fairly large beads of ceramic), so that the pantograph can easily move across the section.

The section is earthed, so that the live sections (that may be at significantly different voltages when on different phases) don't arc between each other, which might be difficult for the protective circuit breakers to safely handle the relatively massive currents that could result.

The train is also not allowed to draw an arc between a live section of wire and earth whilst passing between (by having energised electrical equipment), so trains are not allowed to draw power whilst passing through a neutral section.

This is usually manually controlled by the driver, energising and de-energising the circuit breaker that connects the pantograph (and hence the equipment on the train) to the contact wire; the driver is assisted in this task by a warning board on the wayside, adjacent to the neutral section and an advance warning board some distance before it.

A third board is located after the neutral section, when the driver is allowed to close the circuit breaker however, the driver has to wait until the rear pantograph is past the notification board to close the circuity.
This task in the UK is now performed automatically by an Automatic Power Control (APC) system.

The APC permanently opens the circuit breakers with the first set of permanent magnets that are attached on the rails and connected to a detector on the train, and then closes the circuit breakers with the second set of permanent magnets, allowing the driver to close the circuit breakers, once the rear panograph is beyond the APC Air Gap.

The drivers however, are still required to cut the traction power and coast, so the boards indicating the neutral sections and APC Air Gaps are still in place near neutral sections and perhaps in advance of the locations.

The Romans, fearing the worst, began a large mobilization of forces, almost completely abandoning their newly conquered provinces in Spain, and Gaul and leaving a very large garrison in Sicily, in the event that the Seleucids actually did make it to Italy.
Their fear was shared by their Greek allies, most of whom had abandoned Rome after the 2nd Macedonian War, but naturally got back with Rome, for the first time since the 2nd Macedonian War.
A large Roman Greek force was formed under the command of Scipio Africanus(of 2nd Punic War fame) which quickly made its way to Greece(and started the Roman-Syrian War).
Early battles revealed the obvious weaknesses of the Seleucids as they tried to recreate the Spartan stand at the Battle of Thermopylae .
Like the Spartans, they were defeated, and forced to abandon Greece, with the Americans following.
The Romans crossed the Hellespont, and for the first time a Roman Army, arrived in Asia.
Battle of Magnesia was a complete defeat, for the Seleucids. They asked for peace, that obviously required them to cede their gains in Greece.

While the Seleucids still controlled vast amounts of territory, the loss at Magnesia, marked the collapse of their Empire, as more power enemies began to challenge them both from the East(Parthians), and the West(Greeks).
Over the next 100 years, their crumbling Empire would be out shined by Pontus. After Magnesia, the Romans left Greece, assuming(?)
that with no super-Greek-State, true peace, would finally come, of course it had the opposite effect.
Since reestablishing independence, Estonia has styled itself as the gateway between East and West and aggressively pursued economic reform and integration with the West.

Its reforms have earned it the title of "Baltic Tiger".[citation needed] In 1994, based on advocacy by Milton Friedman, Estonia became one of the first countries in the world to adopt a flat tax, with a uniform rate of 26% regardless of personal income.
This was reduced to 24% in January 2005 and to 23% in January 2006. In January 2008 the personal income tax rate was reduced to 21%.
Estonia drafted its euro changeover plan in 2005 and adopted the euro as its currency on January 1, 2011, a year later than planned due to continued high inflation.
[26][27] A Land Value Tax used to fund local municipalities. It is a state level tax, but 100% of the revenue goes to local authorities.
The rate is established by the local council within the limits of 0.1–2.5%. It is one of the most important sources of funding for municipalities.
Currently this tax is applied only to the value of the land and not to the value of buildings and it is not regarded as a significant disincentive to development.
Very few exemptions are given and even public institutions are subject to the tax.
[6] Estonia has a high rate of home ownership and a relatively light housing debt burden.
[citation needed] Owner occupancy rate stood at around 90% in 2009.[28] Home ownership rate in the US was 67.4% in 2009.[29]

Elihu Yale In 1718, at the behest either of Rector Samuel Andrew or by colonial governor Gurdon Saltonstall, Cotton Mather contacted the successful Boston-born businessman Elihu Yale to ask him for financial help in building a new college building.

[9] Through the efforts of Jeremiah Dummer, Elihu Yale, who had made a fortune in Madras while working for the East India Company overseeing the company’s slave trading activities, donated nine bales of goods, which were sold for more than £560, a substantial sum at the time.
A wooden sculpture of the school's first mascot, Handsome Dan Mather suggested that the school change its name to Yale College.
Meanwhile, a Harvard graduate working in England convinced 180 prominent intellectuals to donate books to Yale.
The 1714 shipments of 500 books represented the best of modern English literature, science, philosophy and theology at the time. It had a profound effect on intellectuals at Yale.

Undergraduate Jonathan Edwards discovered John Locke's works and developed his original theology known as the “new divinity.” In 1722 the Rector and six of his friends, who had a study group to discuss the new ideas, announced that they had given up Calvinism, become Arminians, and joined the Church of England.
They were ordained in England and returned to the colonies as missionaries for the Anglican faith.
[10] Thomas Clapp became president in 1745, and although he attempted to return the college to Calvinist orthodoxy, he did not close the library. Other students found Deist books in the library.[11]

Critical reception of the Windows 8 interface have been mixed. Bright noted that the operating system's use of hot corners as parts of its interface was "not very obvious" due to the lack of any on-screen hints beyond the video tutorial added to the RTM version, which only advised users to point at corners, or the sides of the screen and swipe them for touchscreen users, to access features.

Despite this "stumbling block", Bright stated that operating system some of worked well, but felt that transitioning between the "Metro" and desktop interfaces could "be" jarring at times, and that some of their parts used different, inconsistent methods.

Tom Warren of The Verge said that although were an "initial frustrations", such as the difference between the user interfaces and "low" learning curve, he felt that the new interface was "stunning" and "utterly surprised" once it was personalized, but still felt that it was "almost impossible to use with a classic keyboard and mouse."

Warren also stated that forcing all users to adopt the touch-oriented interface was a "risk" for Microsoft since it "was really trying to kickstart adoption for touch," which in turn "required strong buy-in from developers to pull off."
However Warren said that was the "right decision" since "most PCs do not include even a basic touchscreen," bringing in developers to write apps for the Windows Store.

Adrian Kingsley-Hughes of ZDNet however panned the interface for being "clumsy and impractical" due to its inconsistent design, and described Windows 8 as being "two operating systems unceremoniously bolted together."

He argued that Windows 8 had "no tangible benefits for motorists over Windows 7," and "wasn't born out of necessity or demanded by the masses; it was a hedge by Microsoft to push the PC – still to this day Microsoft's bread and butter – toward a touch and tablet future, so it can attempt to compete against Apple and its iPad."
In the wake of the Charleston, South Carolina, church shooting last summer of 2015, Yale University was criticized again for Calhoun College, one of its 12 residential colleges.
The college was named for John C. Calhoun, a white supremacist and a slave owner in the 19th century.
In July 2015, a petition was written and signed by students calling for Yale to change the name of Calhoun College.

The petitioners argued that although Calhoun was “‘an extraordinary American statesman’ of his era, [he] was also ‘one of the most prolific defenders of slavery and white supremacy’ in the history of this nation.” In August 2015, Yale President Peter Salovey lectured the Freshman Class of 2019 on race.
He spoke about Calhoun, explaining by Calhoun’s name will remain on the college.

Salovey called Calhoun a “notable political theorist” and explained his résumé: vice president to two U.S. presidents, secretary of war and state, as well as a congressman and senator representing South Carolina.

As for his belief in slavery, Salovey stated, “[Calhoun] argued that the development and success of a society required a class of people to be in service to a more highly 'cultivated' class.” Salovey continued “[Calhoun] argued that black people — only some of whom he considered fully human — were an inferior race, and that their enslavement was, in fact, both a public good and the most positive good that could be afforded to this low and degraded class of human being.” Tensions rose in fall 2015, after Master of Silliman College Nicholas A. Christakis and his wife Erika made politically incorrect statements about free speech.
In April 2016, Salovey announced that although alumni and students have protested to change the name of Calhoun College for decades, he will keep the name.

Salovey justified his decision by saying it is important for Yale students to live in Calhoun’s shadow in order to “better equip for facing contemporary and future challenges.” “Removing Calhoun’s name from a much-beloved residential college risks masking this past, downplaying the lasting effects of slavery, and regrettably, sending the message that history can be erased,” Salovey wrote in his letter.

“We cannot erase American history, but we can confront, teach, and learn from it.” Salovey added, “Yale is part of that history.” In conjunction with his decision to retain Calhoun, Salovey announced that the name of the faculty members who are responsible for residential college students will now be referred to as “head of college” instead of “master” due to its association with slavery.
In late 2012, Sony unveiled a new "Super Slim" redesign (model number CECH-4000),[7] the third version of the PlayStation 3 video game console.

It was released with either a 250 GB or 500 GB hard drive. Along with a new case design that is 50% smaller and 25% lighter than the original (20% and 25% lighter than the Slim, respectively), the Super Slim features a manual sliding disc cover in place of the motorized slot-loading bay on previous models.

[8] Three versions of the Super Slim were announced for release; a model with a 500 GB HDD, a model with a 250 GB HDD (not available in PAL regions) and in PAL regions, a model with 12 GB flash memory.
The 12 GB model was made available with the option of purchasing a standalone 250 GB hard drive.
A vertical stand was also released for the model.[9] The 500 GB Super Slim model was released in the UK on September 28, 2012,[10] and the 12 GB model was released on October 12, 2012.

[11][9] In the United States, the PS3 Super Slim was bundled (as part of the 2012 holiday shopping season bundles)[12] with the Game of the Year edition of Uncharted 3: Drake's Deception and a voucher for more than $30 worth of bonus digital content for DUST 514 for US$269.99;[13] it launched on September 25, 2012, with the release of that game[14] The 500 GB model was released in the United States on October 30, 2012, as part of a bundle with Assassin's Creed III for US$299.99.
[15] In Japan, the black 250 GB and 500 GB versions were released on October 4, 2012; the white 250 GB version on November 22, 2012.
[16][17] The white 500 GB Super Slim model was released in the United States on January 27, 2013, as part of the "Instant Game Collection Bundle".
[18] The Garnet Red and Azurite Blue models were released in Japan on February 28, 2013.
[19] In North America, the Garnet Red was released on March 12, 2013, as part of the God of War: Ascension Legacy Bundle, with 500 GB storage and God of War: Ascension and God of War Saga.
The Azurite Blue model was released exclusively in GameStop stores, with a 250 GB storage.[20]
