Darwin was hard at work on the manuscript for his 'big book' on Natural Selection, when on 18 June 1858 he received a parcel from Wallace, who remained in the Maluku Islands (Ternate and Gilolo).

It enclosed about twenty pages describing an evolutionary mechanism, sent to him for his comments, with a request to pass it on to Lyell if Darwin thought it worthwhile. Wallace's evolutionary mechanism was similar to Darwin's own theory.

Darwin sent a letter to Lyell, saying 'your words have come true with a vengeance, ... forestalled', and enclosed Wallace's pages to be sent on to Darwin's friend, botanist Joseph Hooker, saying 'He could not have made a better short abstract!
Even his terms now stand as heads of my chapters... he does not say he wishes me to publish, but I shall of course at once write & offer to send to any journal.

So all my originality, whatever it may amount to, will be smashed'. At Lyell's urging, Darwin sent a letter to Wallace telling him that he had not intended "to forestall you", which as "far as the mere [evolutionary] theory is concerned", was "right, & original".
While Wallace had not asked for publication of the manuscript, Darwin "would, at once, have sent [it] to some journal" had Wallace not instead sent it to him.

[54] Darwin, Lyell and Hooker agreed on a joint presentation to a meeting of the Linnean Society of London, with publication of Wallace's pages in the Society's journal, together with extracts from Darwin's 1844 Essay and his 1857 letter to Gray.
On 1 July 1858, the papers by Wallace and Darwin were read on On the Tendency of Species to form Varieties; and on the Perpetuation of Varieties and Species by Natural Means of Selection.

Darwin's paper was titled "An abstract from an unpublished work on Species by C. Darwin, Esq., consisting of a portion of a chapter entitled "On the variation of organic beings in a state of nature; on the natural means of selection; on the comparison of domestic races; and on the conditions favourable to the formation of new species", and written July 1837.
[55] Wallace's paper was titled "On the Tendency of Varieties to Depart Indefinitely from the Original Type".

Papers read to the Linnean Society were not discussed at the meetings, so no debate occurred, but the president of the society remarked in May 1859 that the year had not been marked by any striking discoveries; and Darwin wrote "our joint productions excited very little attention, & the only published notice of them was by Professor Haughton of Dublin, whose verdict was that 'all that was new in them was false, and what was true was old.'".
[56] Wallace's paper was titled "On the Tendency of Varieties to Depart Indefinitely from the Original Type".
Darwin considered Wallace's idea to be identical to his concept of natural selection; historians have noted differences.

Darwin described natural selection among individual variations, emphasizing competition between individuals; Wallace drew no comparison to selective breeding of animals, and Darwin pictured no role for ecological pressures while Wallace focused on pressures that kept varieties adapted to local conditions.
Wallace appears to have been discussing group selection rather than individual variation.[57][58]
Another distinction can be drawn between inclusive boundaries and exclusive boundaries, in terms of evaluations by other people.
A person marking herself to or for herself can have exclusive boundaries if the marker chosen constrains the behavior of the other.
Similarly, a marker can form inclusive boundaries if it is one which can be easily marked by the other.
While exclusive boundaries obviously constrain interaction, inclusive boundaries do as well, as many people are thereby constrained to one group and thereby exclude others.

For example, if a room full of people with knowledge of numerous languages, but no common spoken language known by all, is joined by a newcomer who chooses a language to speak, some within the room may understand it and others may not.
Some of those who do not may treat this as a marker of identity, and think no more of it.
Others of those who do not may feel this is a construed boundary on the part of the newcomer designed to exclude them.
Dually, some of those who can speak and/or understand the language chosen may view this as an inclusive boundary to them, which at the same time excludes other people.
Finally, some few who can speak or understand the language chosen may not feel positively about this, due to unwillingness to speak the language chosen.

The newcomer might understand these positions, if she is capable of speaking multiple languages, or does not due to inability to speak other languages, or failure to recognize (for whatever reason) the nature of the group.
On 20 October 2014 trial began for six senior staff and journalists from The Sun newspaper, who were charged with conspiring to commit misconduct in a public office.
The Sun’s head of news, Chris Pharo, was accused and pleaded not guilty to six counts of conspiracy to commit misconduct in a public office.
Graham Dudman, the former managing editor of the Sun, and Ben O’Driscoll, a former deputy news editor, faced four counts each.
Jamie Pyatt, the Sun’s Thames Valley district reporter, and John Edwards, a picture editor, were accused of three counts each, while John Troup, a former Sun reporter, faced two counts.
All deny the charges. The trial concerned unlawful payments to public officials.
Prosecutors claimed that the group had conspired to pay officials from 2002 to 2011 in order to unlawfully purchase confidential information about the royal family, public figures and prison inmates.
The recipients included police, prison officers and a soldier, prosecutors said.
All the accused deny the charges. On 16 January 2015 Troup and Edwards were cleared by jury.
The jury also cleared O'Driscoll and Dudman of a number of charges but are continuing to deliberate on several others against O'Driscoll and Dudman, and a number of others against Pharo and Pyatt.

On 21 January 2015, the jury were told by judge Richard Marks, QC that he will accept majority verdicts on their deliberations, shortly after the court learned that one of the 12-member panel had been discharged for health reasons.
The judge told the jurors after they emerged from the jury room that he will accept "a verdict of either 11 to zero or 10 to 1" after sending out 11th juror to be replaced by a unanimous one.

On 22 January 2015, the jury were discharged after failing to reach verdicts on the remaining charges against Pharo, Dudman, O'Driscoll and Pyatt. The CPS said that it would seek a retrial on the outstanding charges.[108]
The media became preoccupied by Elizabeth's immediate family, in particular, focusing on their lives, relationships, and supposed marital problems.
Persistent, exaggerated, and often false reports in the press undermined Elizabeth's reputation in the 1980s.
As Kelvin MacKenzie, editor of The Sun, said, "Give me a Sunday for Monday splash on the Royals.
Don't worry if it's not true—so long as there's not too much fuss about it afterwards."

Journalist Donald Trelford wrote in The Observer of 21 September 1986: "The royal soap opera has now reached such a pitch of public interest that the boundary between fact and fiction has been lost ... not only do some papers not check their facts but they ignore denials ... they simply do not care whether the stories are true or not."

In 1986, Elizabeth was reportedly worried that Thatcher's economic policies favoured "the rich over the poor", and was alarmed by high unemployment, a series of riots, the violence of a miners' strike, and Thatcher's refusal to apply sanctions against the apartheid regime in South Africa.

Rumours of a rift were proven to have been exaggerated after Thatcher later conveyed her personal admiration for Elizabeth and was awarded two of the highest honours in which she was eligible to receive by Elizabeth—the Order of Merit and the Order of the Garter—after Thatcher's replacement as prime minister by John Major.
Thatchers term as prime minister ended in November 1990. Thatcher later described the alleged rift, however, as "a lot of nonsense".
Reports of acrimony between them were sparked by their differences of opinion on the issue of sanctions on South Africa.
Thatcher's biographer, John Campbell, claimed, "Thatcher ... was famously closer to the Queen than any prime minister before or since."
Brian Mulroney, Canadian prime minister from 1984–93, said Elizabeth was a "behind the scenes force" in ending apartheid.
Insects possess very sensitive and specialized organs of perception. Bees, for instance, are capable of seeing ultraviolet light, and are also sensitive to the polarization of light.
Male moths have highly developed olfactory organs that allow them to detect the pheromones of female moths over distances of many kilometres.
Polistes versicolor, a eusocial wasp species from the neotropics, utilizes a form of communication called drumming.
Drumming is performed by the wasp gaster being tapped in a particular rhythm pattern against the nest, and this pattern is recognized by other wasps in the colony.
Wasps use this form of communication to stimulate other workers to increase foraging behavior and also to promote worker interactions.
The most signal frequency observed was at about 10.6±2.1 Hz (n=190). Wagging movements or tail wagging signals are also very important in intraspecies communication.
It was observed that wagging signals were an indicator of new material deliveries to the nest, and that physical aggression of workers increased their foraging.

In general, the organs of perception of various insects are suited to the kind of life they lead; typically, specialized insects that possess large and well-developed eyes tend to have taste and smell organs that are more simply organized with fewer sensory cells.
Conversely, insects that have mainly mechanical sense organs tend to be organized in ways that possess less specialized organs of sight.

Sound is sensed in insects by special hairs and by tympanal organs. Further, there is considerable evidence that insects are capable of hearing sound waves traveling through the air, independent of the method by which the sound is detected.
Generally, insects only hear up to a few kilohertz, with the highest sensitivity characterized up to about 20 kilohertz, although higher frequencies have been tested in certain moths.
For example, mosquitoes are capable of hearing up to about 2 kilohertz, and grasshoppers can hear up to 50 kilohertz.
There are a variety of predatory and parasitic insects capable of perceiving the characteristic sound of their prey or hosts.
Many nocturnal moths, for example, are capable of hearing the ultrasounds produced by the echolocation of bats.
Many blood-feeding insects can locate their hosts by sensing infrared rays emitted by warm-blooded animals.

By early the 1940s, the phenomenalist period of post-Humean empiricism ended. It was realized that claims about physical objects are not translatable into claims about actual and possible appearances.
For a claim about physical objects to be translatable into a claim about actual and possible appearances, it must be at least logically implied by the latter.
However, it was realized that no single claim about physical objects logically follows from any finite set of claims about actual and possible appearances.
Recall that the translating, or paraphrasing, claims have to be couched in terms of normal observers in normal conditions.
But no finite claim in the observation language be such as to satisfy the criterion has a normal observer.
To say that there is a normal observer , in the sense required by phenomenalism, amounts to supposing that if a doctor examined this observer, he would find the latter to be normal.

Obviously, the doctor in question must himself be a normal observer; to specify him as such, in the vocabulary of observation, we are apparently forced to refer to a second doctor who will have to have the sense-experiences normally caused by examining the sense-organs of the first doctor.

To specify this second doctor, again, as a normal observer, in the vocabulary of the given observation language, we apparently have to refer to a third doctor, and so on ad infinitum (cf. third man problem).
Schwarzenegger took to visiting a gym in Graz, where he also frequented the local movie theaters to see bodybuilding idols such as Reg Park, Steve Reeves, and Johnny Weissmuller on the big screen.
When Reeves died in 2000, Schwarzenegger fondly remembered him: "As a teenager, I grew up with Steve Reeves.
His remarkable accomplishments allowed me a sense of what was possible when others around me didn't always understand my dreams.
Steve Reeves has been part of everything I've ever been fortunate enough to achieve."
In 1961, Schwarzenegger met former Mr. Austria Kurt Marnul, who invited him to train at the gym in Graz.
[12] He was so dedicated as a youngster that he broke into the local gym on weekends so that he could train even when it was closed.
[13] "It would make me sick to miss a workout ... I knew I couldn't look at myself in the mirror the next morning if I didn't do it.
"[11] When Schwarzenegger was asked about his first movie experience as a boy, he replied: "I was very young, but I do remember the Saturday afternoon movie of Hercules, with Steve Reeves.
I knew right then that was exactly what I wanted to do. To be another Hercules. I wanted to be another Steve Reeves and make movies like that."[14]

The first military manoeuvres began in September 1806. Writing to Marshal Soult at this time, Napoleon described the war strategy in the following way: "My objective is to engage and destroy the German army wherever I find them; that done, I shall engage and destroy the Russian army, after which the war will be finished.
"[161] In a letter to Minister of War Henri Clarke, Napoleon revealed his estimation on the numbers of enemy Russian troop deployments by 1807.

[162] At the outset of the campaign, Napoleon issued a memo to his marshals in which he emphasised the overarching importance of speed: "We must not lose a single hour; not a moment must be lost without our being on the heels of the enemy and harassing their rearguard, otherwise they will escape.
"[163] For the campaign plan, Napoleon incorporated many principles elaborated in the 1797 Milan letter to the Directory.
The French emperor judged that the most effective way to destroy the enemy was to target the main body of the opposing army.

When the decisive battle came, he expected to push the enemy right bank of the River Saale combatants up against a major geographical barrier (in this case the Elbe) and then annihilate them in battle.
To achieve this, Napoleon kept his army in one massive group as they advanced into Prussian territory.
He expected that by the time he made contact with the enemy, he would outnumber them with his group concentration.
The campaign plan for this region is now known as the strategem of the central position, another idea elaborated in Milan letter XVI.
[164] The campaign is also noted for its incorporation of the first Napoleonic battle plan—the left-echelon attack at Jena—which became a staple technique of his battlefield tactics.

As military historian Gunther Rothenberg notes, "In the centre-position confrontation with the Prussians, at the twin battles of Jena and Auerstädt, the Napoleonic juggernaut showed its usual speed, operational mastery, and tactical brilliance.
Both the campaign and the battles that followed displayed many of the hallmarks of Napoleonic warfare."[165] The initial military manoeuvres began in September 1806.
[166] Napoleon himself rode out from the palace at Saint-Cloud on 25 September.

[167] In a famous memo to Marshal Soult describing the operational objectives, the Emperor laid out the foundational aspects of Napoleonic warfare and introduced the concept of le bataillon-carré ("square battalion").
This battalion formation saw the independent corps of the Grande Armée marching uniformly together in close supporting distance.
Consequently, if one corps was attacked, the others could quickly spring into action and arrive to help.
[168] Napoleon invaded Prussia with 180,000 men and marched rapidly on the right bank of the river Saale.
It was the same grand plan he had used against Austria in 1805, leaving only secondary forces to cover Prussia's Russian ally on the eastern front.
As in previous campaigns, the French objective was to destroy one opponent before the other could arrive to alter the course of the war.
[169] After finding the Prussian army in the Braunschweig area, the French swung westwards in full force and crossed the Saale with lightning speed.

It was too late for the Prussians to counter the move, and at the twin battles of Jena and Auerstedt, fought on 14 October, the French inflicted a severe drubbing on the Prussian forces, inflicting heavy losses.
Several generals and marshals in Prussian service were killed or wounded, and the King proved incapable of commanding the army effectively.

Orders to regroup and resist the French invasion translated into an increasing disorganisation in the Prussian rear, and the Prussian command structure rapidly collapsed as the military situation became more desperate.

In a famous pursuit that epitomised the "peak of Napoleonic warfare" (Richard Brooks),[170] the French troops captured 140,000 soldiers, more than 2,000 cannons, and hundreds of ammunition wagons within a single month.

David Chandler equated the Prussian loss to the battle of Leuthen in 1757: "But Frederick the Great himself could hardly have inflicted more terrible damage on the Habsburgs after Leuthen than was now suffered by the men who so proudly called themselves Frederick's inheritors.

Never has the morale of any army been more completely shattered".[171] Despite being thoroughly beaten, the Prussians refused to capitulate to the French until the Russians had an opportunity to enter the conflict.

Although the Latin theologians, especially the Franks, later came up with the doctrine of Mary’s Immaculate Conception, the idea was more explicitly described in the Medieval Byzantine period by those who followed in Gregory Nazianzen’s Mariological footsteps.
In hymnography and creedal recordings, many such as Justinian I [when? ] mentioned that Mary was “prepurified.
” One of the first to be able to put Nazianzen’s thoughts into useful words was Sophronius, Patriarch of Jerusalem.

He said explicitly that at the Annunciation Mary was found to already be immaculate and he went so far as to say that John the Baptist was “holier than all ‘Men’ born of woman without only exception of the most blessed Virgin.

” This is significant because it shows that although John was predicted in the Gospels as great among men for being purified in the womb, Mary had an even greater holiness and at some time, like John, also became purified, though before the Annunciation.

Sophronius was a mother source for the Marian doctrines taken up by St. John Damascene (d. 749/750) who praised her for the purification at the Annunciation and exalted her among all people, even saying that she was able to “purify the waters of baptism by touching them.
” It was usually Christ who was magnified in this position in abiding Gr. Naz. ’s legacy of Christ’s holiness in the waters at baptism.
Latently, Gr. John Damascene expounds upon Gr. Naz. ’s parallel holiness between Mary’s prepurification and Jesus’s purification in the Gospel of the New Testament.
Her holiness at the Annunciation is likened to Jesus’ holiness at the time of his baptism in the Jordan.
His hymns and his work De fide Orthodoxa build upon her “pre purification” of Mary in order to continually show her holiness as pure humanity above all others.

He and Gr. Naz. created a legacy for almost all later Greek descriptions of Mary’s intact holiness, which is passed on from her conception via the “all pure seed” of Joachim and from the womb of St. Ann, “wider than heaven. ”
The torch was in San Francisco, California for its North American visit on April 9.

The torch was rerouted onto a hidden course on the day of the event. The relay commenced in McCovey Cove from Norman Bellingham of the USOC to Lin Li, Chinese swimmer and Olympic gold medalist in 1992.
A ceremony at Justin Herman Plaza marking the end of the relay was cancelled in favor of a departure ceremony at San Francisco International Airport as the torch continued on to Buenos Aires.
The planned route was changed in an effort to avoid tens of thousands of pro-Chinese and anti-Chinese protesters.
Last-minute change of plan elicited vociferous objections from some spectators who had waited in Justin Herman Plaza; one protester said the reroute was to "squelch any organized protest".

[8] Aaron Peskin, President of the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, who has had a tense relationship with Mayor Gavin Newsom, called the decision a "double cross" and "convoluted, cynical plan" to appease the Bush administration and Chinese government, blaming "the power of money, and it's extraordinary."
[9] Newsom, his political rival in city government, defended the scheme as in "everyone's best interest" and that the reroute did not deny people the right to protest and celebrate the torch.
[9] U.S. Olympic Committee president Peter Ueberroth, aboard the departure flight, hailed the decision to reroute: "The city of San Francisco, from a global perspective, will be applauded.
"[10] Spectators who did get to see the torch appeared surprised and happy in CBS and NBC video footage taken live at the scene.
Public costs to the city related to the event was $726, 400; a fundraising effort paid for nearly half of the total, according to the mayor's finances office.
Newsom said the reroute decision undertaken with Police Chief Heather Fong saved "exponential" costs with mass arrests. [11]
Current Macintosh models use Intel's x86-64 architecture Central Processing Units (CPUs).
Apple first used Intel chips in 2006, but as of 1998 had begun using chips produced by AMD in addition to its original arrangement with Intel, as well as HID controller chips.
[31] Current Macs use ATI Radeon or nVidia GeForce graphic cards as well as Intel graphics built into the main CPU.

Starting in 2006 with the Mac Pro and later the early 2008 MacBook Pro update, Apple computers offer the AltiVec performance-enhanced vector processing library which utilizes SIMD processing, previously built into the PowerPC versions of Mac computers.
With the change to the Intel platform, the Macintosh is the only mainstream computer platform to have successfully transitioned to a new CPU architecture, and the only to have done so twice.
[28] The transition to Intel x86-64 was facilitated by the inclusion of an emulator layer in Mac OS X 10.4 "Tiger".
Since Mac OS X is derived from Unix, the 2006 transition was easier, as Unix-based operating systems like OS X are natively designed for supporting more than one platform.
In a similar manner, a decade previously, Apple had included a 68k processor emulation layer when moving the Macintosh from the Motorola 68000 architecture to the PowerPC.
As a result, many University workstations became Mac-compatibles and ran Mac applications as the benchmarks were found to be fast and native.
The Rosetta emulation, , allowed PowerPC-based applications to work on Intel-based Macs until 2011.
Virtually all new Macs ship with at least 8 GB (gigabytes) of DDR3 SDRAM, with the exception of the 1.
4 GHz Mac Mini, MacBook Pro (No Retina Display), and MacBook Air. As of February 2006, nearly all portable Macs use the PCI Express expansion bus.
With the original MacBook Pro and MacBook Air as the exceptions, they include on-board gigabit Ethernet.
All current Macs, excluding the MacBook Pro (No Retina Display), do not incorporate an optical media drive for reading and writing dual purpose DVD/CD rewritable media, also called a SuperDrive.
Today all Macs are also built with two data transfer ports as a standard: USB and Thunderbolt ().
The 2015 version of the MacBook is the only Mac that includes only a USB-C port and headphone port.
MacBook Pro, iMac, MacBook Air, and discontinued Mac Mini computers now include the Thunderbolt port, which Apple says can transfer data at a speed of up to 10 Gbit/s (gigabits per second).
The USB standard has been in use by Macs since it was first introduced in the 1998 iMac G3 (the first Mac to have a port like this and be completely legacy, floppy disk absent).
It has since been commonplace, while FireWire was only normally reserved for high-performance devices such as hard-drives or video cameras.

The iMac G5, announced August 31, 2004, has built-in iSight cameras (Apple's version of a webcam) on select models and comes with Front Row media center software, which is controlled by an Apple Remote or the keyboard's Function keys.
However Front Row has since been discontinued as of 2011, and the Apple Remote used to control it is no longer supplied with Macs.
The Japanese fleet arrived soon afterwards, as Nimitz had predicted, and was spotted by patrols on June 4.
Nagumo attacked first, striking at Midway, while Fletcher sent his planes to find Nagumo.

The first carrier planes on the scene were old TBD Devastator carrier torpedo planes from Hornet, at 09:20, but their attack was uncoordinated and relatively unsuccessful: They scored no hits, partly because of the failure of aerial torpedoes, and all 15 were lost to Zero fighter cover.
At 09:35, 15 more TBD's from Enterprise attacked, and 14 were lost, again with no hits.

While Fletcher's attacks seemed uncoordinated, and achieved little, they did serve to draw Nagumo's fighter cover down to low altitude, promulgating their fuel and ammunition while repulsing the two attacks.

By the time the U.S. dive bombers appeared up high the protecting fighters were too low on fuel to be in position, and the carriers had wandered out of their own zonal barrier while manoeuvering to avoid torpedoes.
In fact, the four carriers had almost drifted out of formation due to evasive action, reducing their AA concentration.
Nagumo's indecisiveness created confusion on his carriers, as he wanted to prepare for a 2nd airstrike on Midway, and he also was aware Americans carrier air was in the area.
He twice changed arming orders for his air groups, and the American dive bombers found the Japanese carrier decks littered with bombs as their crews attempted to get properly re-armed and ready.
Scotland was an independent kingdom until 1603, when the king of Scotland became king of England and Ireland.

The next century was one of political turmoil, religious divisions and war. English colonialism, started in Ireland in the 16th century, continued with the large-scale colonisation of Ulster and the founding of Scottish and English colonies.

Discontent erupted when the English king maintained that he was too tolerant to catholicism, and civil war (the "War of the Three Kingdoms" or "English Civil War") erupted, resulting in a military-backed nominal republic.

Irelamd, mainly Catholic, sided with the king, and defeat by the army of Parliament resulted in redistribution of lands from Ireland loyal to the king to English commoners fighting for the parliamentary army.
A new "Ascendancy" began to rise, which over the coming century would replace the English (Hiberno-Norman) and Gaelic Irish aristocracy.

While the previous titled families had been Irish and mostly European Catholic, the new Ascendancy, less aristocratic than the old Ascendancy, was British and Protestant, and was juxtaposed to the Irish Catholic majority.

It ruled Ireland politics for centuries afterwards. The restoration of monarchy in England and Ireland did not politically permit returning the restored king to return the lands to the former landlords.

Although the "Glorious Revolution" of 1688 repeated the same theme of a Catholic king supportive of his co-religionists being opposed by Protestant Parliament, the king's army was again defeated this time in Ireland in the decisive Battle of the Boyne and Battle of Aughrim.

Although a resistance based around Limerick held out and secured a message of religious tolerance in the Treaty of Limerick, the restoration of the English monarchy after was short lived, a new monarchy was founded, and in the changed political climate, the provisions of the Treaty of Limerick were abrogated and the Irish parliament, under control of the new elite, passed increasingly penal laws that affected Dissenters on the one hand, but most Catholics on the other.
In the late 1980s, Libya's oil revenues were reducing. In May 1987, Gaddafi responded by launching the "Revolution within a Revolution", which entailed further economic reforms.
He recognized the need for professional managers and engineers, resulting in attempts to retain foreign professionals in Libya.

The "Revolution within a Revolution" focused largely on promoting productivity and the need for economic growth; in emphasizing industrial and agricultural productivity, the government introduced a new emphasis on the opening of small businesses, from which people could earn a private income.
The measures were deeply unpopular, and in October 1988 the General People's Congress voted to reverse the policy.
[261] Attempts to improve the efficiency of jamāhīriyyah institutions were also made, with Gaddafi asserting that the Revolutionary Committees had become corrupt and bureaucratic.

In March 1988, a Ministry for Mass Mobilization and Revolutionary Leadership was established to curb their powers; later that month, he condemned the committees, informing them that they had "deviated, harmed, tortured".
and that "true revolutionaries do not practise repression, exploitation, confiscation of money and property.

"[262] In that month, hundreds of political prisoners were freed, with Gaddafi proclaiming that there were no political prisoners left in Libya, a claim inaccurate at the time and which would remain so.

[263] In June, the government published the Great Green Charter on Human Rights in the Era of the Masses, in which 27 articles, Libya committed to improving human rights, including abolishing laws criminalising party membership, cancelling all prison sentences for honour crimes, limiting application of the death penalty, and calling for the abolishing of all public work obligatory for children and adolescents.
Many measures in the charter were not enacted, although others were implemented in early 1989.

[263] That year, the government also issued the Al-Gaddafi International Prize for Human Rights, which was awarded to those whom they believed were opposing imperialism; the first recipient was South African anti-apartheid activist Nelson Mandela.
[264] In 1994–97, the government created a new set of cleansing committees to root out corruption and promote economic growth particularly in the economic sector.[265]
There are three different phases of digestion: cephalic, gastric, and intestinal.
The cephalic phase is initiated by the thought, smell, and sight of food stimulating taste and smell receptors which send signals to the hypothalamus and the medulla oblongata.
These are then able to stimulate the vagus nerve, which sends a signal releasing acetylcholine. In this phase, gastric secretion is 40% of the maximum rate.

The presence of acid in the stomach (because food cannot buffer it yet) inhibits acid-secreting cells (parietal) and gastrin-secreting cells (G-cells) (via stimulation of D cells , which secrete somatostatin).

The gastric phase of digestion lasts 3-4 hours which is activated by distension of the stomach, the presence of food in the stomach, and decrease in pH. As the stomach distends, it activates short and long reflexes.
They acetyl choline to release more gastric juice. As protein enter the stomach, they bind to hydrogen ions, which causes the pH to rise and inhibits gastrin and gastric acid secretion.
The release of gastrin initiates the release of enzymes that digest proteins. Inhibition of G cells release gastric acid into the stomach.
Rising pH and the presence of peptides causes G cells to release gastrin. Gastric acid is composed of about 0.
5% hydrochloric acid (HCl), which decreases the pH to 1-3. Acetylcholine, histamine, and gastrin stimulate acid excretion.
The intestinal phase has an excitatory and inhibitory phase: Partially digested food fills the duodenum, which sends signals to release intestinal gastrin.

Enterogastric reflex inhibit the vagal nuclei, activate the sympathetic/enteric nervous system (tightening the pyloric sphincter muscle so no more food can enter the stomach), and inhibit local reflexes.

The Columbia Phonograph Company itself is no longer part of Columbia Records, having sold the American branch in 1924.
They once owned international branches such as the Columbia Graphophone Company in the UK, which were all sold off prior to CBS's purchase of American Columbia.

In 1938, ARC was bought by the Columbia Broadcasting System (CBS; the Columbia Phonograph Company groundlessly sued for ownership of the name) which then had itself only been around since 1927 originally as the network of the Columbia Phonograph Company.
Columbia became the project's label with Okeh as a subsidiary along with ARC's less important labels.
ARC's was now shown the door by the new owners so their leased labels, Brunswick Records and the Vocalion Records, reverted to the previous owner Warner Bros. which sold them to Decca Records.
Columbia kept the rights to the Brunswick material recorded from 12/1931 on which now will be reissued on the Columbia label along with Vocalion material reissued on the Okeh label.
An executive from RCA Victor Records, Ted Wallerstein, convinced the head of CBS, William S. Paley to buy ARC.

Paley made Wallerstein the head of the new record company. Moving up in 1947 from president to chairman of the record company (reporting to Paley), Wallerstein restored Columbia back to prominence while leading the successful introduction of the long-playing record before retiring as chairman in 1951.

James Conkling followed him as head of Columbia Records: that year, Columbia broke with the EMI-owned label of the same name, and started a UK distribution arrangement with Philips Records, while Okeh Records continued to be distributed by EMI as Columbia.
The "Bleacher Bums", fans who typically sit in the aforementioned section, are known for their heckling.
The bums originally got their name by being "bums": persons who are in attendance at most games, which at the time due to the lack of stadium lights meant that they were not gainfully employed.
In fact, some are (or have been) students of DePaul, Loyola, Northwestern, Illinois-Chicago, and other area colleges.

This fan section of the Bleachers was the inspiration for the Broadway play starring Joe Mantegna, Dennis Farina, Dennis Franz, and James Belushi, also entitled Bleacher Bums, revolving around fans attending games.
The group was founded in 1967 by avid fans Ron Grousl, Tom Nall and Letterman (now known as 'mad bugler') Mike Murphy, who is a prominent sports radio host at WSCR AM 670 "The Score".
According to Murphy it was Grousl who was the first fan to throw back an opposing home run ball at Wrigley Field.
Derek Schaul, also known as Derek the Five Dollar Kid, is now the group leader.
Prior to the 2006 season, the bleachers were revamped, with the addition of new concessions and a private lounge, named The Batter's Eye.
As a partial offset for construction costs, the Cubs sold the naming rights of the bleachers to Budweiser.
They are now known as the Bud Light Bleachers. The Bleacher Seats at Wrigley Field are general admission, and do not have an assigned location attached.
(with the exception of the post season) The Wrigley Bleachers is also known as the "World's Largest Beer Garden."
During home games at Wrigley Field, among (if not) the most popular T-Shirts inside the park sold, an item licensed by the ballclub, promotes this stereotype.
The front of the T-Shirt reads "WRIGLEY BLEACHERS". The back of the T-Shirt says "Shut Up and Drink Your Beer."
In 1878, Swan saw a partial success when he was able to demonstrate a working lamp and obtained a British Patent in 1880.
His lamps used a carbon rod from an arc lamp rather than a slender filament. The cost of the vacuum pump equipment and difficulty getting sufficient vacuum limited the size of his demonstrations.
[13] Swan turned his attention to producing a better carbon filament and the means of attaching its ends.
He devised a method of treating cotton to produce 'parchmentised thread' and obtained British Patent 4933 in 1880.
From this year he began installing light bulbs in homes and landmarks in England.
His house, in Low Fell, Gateshead, was the world's first to have working light bulbs installed.

In the early 1880s he had started his company.[6][10] Seats at the Savoy Theatre were in high demand as members of the upper-class in London flocked to see its first theatrical performances in 1881, all of which featured Swan's incandescent lighting, to great acclaim.

Swan's light was during its early development used predominantly in England. In response to Swan's lights, which looked very similar to Edison's, Edison sued Swan in court for patent infringement but the lawsuit stopped when it was shown Swan's version was a proven earlier version of the light bulb.
In the United States, Edison lost the right to the claim of "first inventor" of the light bulb; however, he continued to claim that title throughout his life.
[14][15] Swan sold his US patent rights to the Brush Electric Company in June 1882.[9][10]
In 1855, the state supported the Plan of Ayutla and established the constitution.
During the Reform War, it suffered only minor battles due to the presence of many liberal political leaders.
In 1858, the conservative rebellion failed to gain ground in the state, even after the rebellion's president, Zuloaga, occupied the cities of Chihuahua and Parral peacefully with one thousand men.
In August 1859, Zuloaga and his troops were routed by the liberal Orozco, who took temporary control of the state governor, only to flee to the neighboring state of Durango two months later.

Again in 1860, the conservative Cajen, after leading a successful march through the state of Jalisco, was able to instate conservative politicians by removing the future president of Mexico, Chihuahua's Jesús González Ortega and José María Patoni.

Cajen captured the state capital, named himself governor, and quickly recruited a significant number of men to his army, overtaking and driving out the liberals in La Batalla del Gallo, "Battle of the Cock".
However, despite these successes, Cajen was soon deposed due to the significant liberal resistance and their ability to quickly undo his policies.
Jesús González Ortega and José María Patoni, the future governor of the state represented the triumphant liberals in Durango for Patoni and of Chihuahua for J.E.
Muñoz, reducing the clergy's right to vote, in accordance with the federally established decree of the president.
In Chihuahua, the people elected General Luis Terrazas, a liberal, as their governor.
He maintained this post throughout the year, fighting and eliminating small conservative forces in the state.
The rotating magnetic field: the key principle in AC motor operation A rotating magnetic field was proposed as early as 1824 by the French physicist François Arago.
By manually turning switches on and off, Walter Baily demonstrated the first primitive induction motor in 1879.
In the 1880s, many inventors were trying to develop workable AC motors because AC's advantages in long distance high voltage transmission were offset by the inability to operate motors on AC.
The first AC commutator-free two phase induction motors were invented by Galileo Ferraris and Nikola Tesla.
Ferraris developed the idea of a rotating magnetic field in 1885, the working model was demonstrated in 1885 by Ferraris and he published his research in 1888.
Tesla conceived the rotating magnetic field principle in 1882 and had a working prototype induction motor by 1887.

In 1888, the Royal Academy of Science of Turin published Ferraris's research detailing the foundations of motor operation, while concluding at that time that "the apparatus based on that principle could not be of any interest from a practical point of view."

In 1888 Tesla presented a paper to the AIEE that included diagrams of three types of two-phase four-stator-pole motor, one with a four-pole rotor forming a non-self-starting reluctance motor, another with a wound rotor forming a self-starting induction motor, and the third a true synchronous motor with separately excited DC supply to rotor field winding.
One of Tesla's patents also claims the use of shorted bands instead of winding to form the equivalent of a squirrel-cage induction motor.

George Westinghouse promptly bought Tesla's patents, hired Tesla to be a consultant at Westinghouse Electric & Manufacturing Company's Pittsburgh labs, and assigned C. F. Scott to assist Tesla; however, Tesla left for New York within a year.
Tesla was awarded the American Institute of Electrical Engineers (AIEE) highest award, the Edison Medal, in 1917 for discovering the rotating magnetic field.
Steadfast in his promotion of three-phase development, Mikhail Dolivo-Dobrovolsky invented the first three-phase cage-rotor induction motor in 1889 and the three-limb transformer in 1890.
This type of motor is now used for the vast majority of commercial applications.
Furthermore, Wilhelm Kempe and Friedrich August Haselwander, who was looking for assistance in perfecting his design, were certain that this motor would become the prime standard, in May 1888.

Haselwander was a technician of Mechanical Engineering who independently developed the first single-phase AC induction motor to be used in a power plant for the generation of electricity, and received a patent for that just a few months before Ferraris and Tesla.
In 1889, Dolivo-Dobrovolsky developed a three-phase cage-rotor induction motor, and ran it successfully at the Allis Chalmers factory in the US.

Nevertheless, Westinghouse achieved its first practical induction motor in 1892 and developed a line of polyphase 60 hertz induction motors in 1893, but these early Westinghouse motors were two-phase powered with wound rotors.
General Electric Company began developing three-phase induction motors in 1891.

By 1896, General Electric and Westinghouse signed a cross-licensing agreement for the bar-winding-rotor (squirrel cage) design, later called the squirrel-cage rotor, in which they agreed to share royalties, as the B.G.
Lamme's principle of the bar-winding rotor had been applied by Siemens in the development of their induction motors, leading to a legal dispute.
The General Electric Company, in 1896, developed a line of induction motors, which were the first to use a cast-aluminum cage rotor.

Westinghouse and General Electric signed a cross-licensing agreement for the bar-winding-rotor design, later called the bar rotor, in which they agreed to share the patents of the bar-winding induction motor and the synchronous motors, agreeing neither company would sue over the bar-winding patent.
These inventions led to the modern 100 h.p. induction motor that has the same mounting dimensions as a 7.5 h.p. motor in 1897.
On 13 March, the upper Clyde port of Clydebank near Glasgow was bombed and only seven of its 12, 000 houses remained undamaged.
Several other ports were also bombed. By the end of the month Plymouth had been bombed five times, Belfast, Hull and Cardiff were also hit.
Cardiff was bombed on three nights. Portsmouth town centre was devastated by five raids.
In September 1940, an average of 40, 000 people per week were bombed out of their homes.
Half a million tons of bombs were dropped on 11 British ports, including one third on London.
148, 000 people were bombed out of their homes during two raids on Plymouth and London in March 1941.
British ports sustained a great deal of damage, but continued to serve the war effort.
Supply from North America and the Royal Navy on the southern and eastern coasts was not seriously affected.
The Royal Navy continued to operate in Plymouth, Southampton and Portsmouth post-raid.
Plymouth was the most heavily bombed city on the south coast, because of its naval base Devonport.
The city was in range of medium bombers based in France and the Low Countries, and like other British ports, was without adequate defences.
The Supermarine Spitfire was in limited supply (only one squadron was available to cover the port in March 1941).
As the Blitz began, Plymouth's defences were limited to nine 3-inch (76 mm) guns and eight 40 mm Bofors guns.
Similar problems existed in the east coast ports. 20 Warwick was bombed on 8 March 1941.
Five towns–Hull, Great Yarmouth, Ipswich, Eastbourne and Dover–were also bombed.
By this time, Hitler was ready to redirect the Luftwaffe in a strategic effort to support the Battle of the Atlantic.
The military pressure on the western ports forced a change in RAF Fighter Command night fighter strategy. Many 3.
5-inch flares were dropped by He 111s. German bombers hit Plymouth Hoe and the suburbs of Pennycomequick, Ford, Stoke, Morice Town and Devonport, which was badly damaged.
On 10–11 March, 240 bombers dropped 193 tons of HEs and 46, 000 incendiaries. Nearly all of them fell within an area of three square miles.
The bombing started mid-evening and lasted until 01:30. Many residential and commercial premises were destroyed, the electricity supply was disrupted and five oil tanks and two magazines exploded.
Nine days later 125 bombers met a gale and were drawn off-course. The attack was made in two waves.
The first consisted of 91 aircraft. In the second, 170 bombers dropped 160 tons of HEs and 32, 000 incendiaries.

Three streets in the city centre were flattened and there was some damage to the port installations but once again most of the bombs fell on the city itself. Some 106 people were killed and 155 seriously injured.
On 17 April 250 bombers led by KG 26 bombed Plymouth. 346 tons of HEs and 46, 000 incendiaries were dropped.
Dozens of bombs fell on residential areas destroying two in three houses. Many aerial mines were dropped.
Over 2, 000 AA shells were fired, and two Ju 88s were shot down. By the end of the air campaign over Britain only eight per cent of the German effort against British ports were mines.
The great majority of Umayyad mosaics not in religious buildings are floor mosaics from the palaces of the caliphs and other senior figures.
These were heavily dependent on the Roman country villa tradition of the Eastern Mediterranean.

The finest is in the bath at Hisham's Palace in Palestine, from around 744, with a large panel showing a tree flanked by a lion attacking a deer and two deer feeding peacefully, perhaps representing good and bad rulers.
Classical geometric patterns are preserved in the mosaics in the bath of the Umayyad palace complex at Anjar, Lebanon, from the 8th century.
The luxury desert home of Al-Walid II of Qasr al-Hallabat, now in Jordan, was also decorated with very high-quality floor mosaics.
The best-preserved at Hallabat shows a Tree of Life divided between "good" and "bad" animals.

There are also "the decorative chains of vine scrolls, grapes, pomegranates, oryx, wolves, hares, leopards, pairs of partridges, fish, bulls, ostriches, rabbits, rams, goats, lions and a snake" at Hallabat.
A 2000 archaeological dig at Qastal near Amman revealed the oldest Umayyad mosaics in modern Jordan, perhaps from between 685 and 705, in the period of Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan.

This seems to be a palace of a local governor, and the mosaics have "geometric motifs, trees, animals, fruits and rosettes", covering every floor apart from the open courtyard, entrance and stairs.[14]
The first Ottoman Medrese was built in 1331 at İznik, and the majority of Ottoman medereses followed the practice of the Sunni branch of Islam.
When an Ottoman sultan created a new medrese, he would invite people from all over the Islamic world to study at his new center.
For example, Murad II proceeded to establish a new medrese by inviting scholars from among the Persians, such as ʻAlāʼ al-Dīn and Fakhr al-Dīn.
By bringing foreign scholars into his madrasah Murad II expanded the name and prestige of his medrese.
This example shows how the Islamic world of the early modern period was globalized with the transfer of students from one Islamic state to another.

Hamadeh comments on this globalization, and writes that: …change in the eighteenth century as the beginning of a long and unilinear march toward westernisation reflects the two centuries of reformation in sovereign identity.
This quotation proves that the Ottoman Empire was modernized just like other places in the world.
İnalcık states that Ottomans also went abroad in order to gain higher education: Egypt, Persia, and Turkestan.
Just as other people came to the Ottoman Empire Ottomans went to other place of the Islamic world in order to further their education.
Just as nowadays, people went all over the world to learn and transmit their knowledge.
This suggests that the early modern world may have been more connected with itself than one would think.
This system is very similar to the one we have now when students go to other places and learn new things.
One example of Ottoman madrasas is the building of a group of madaris by Mehmed the Conquerer.

Mehmed the Conquerer constructed eight madaris on one side of a mosque and another eight madaris on the other side of the same mosque; one set of these madaris were for specialization and the other for preparatory education.
This example illustrates two major things about the Ottoman Empire, their common location near mosques and the number of them built at one time.
Madaris were constructed with a religious purpose due to their location near the mosque.
These examples show the combination of both madaris and mosques in achieving the religious goal of the sultans.
Another aspect of madaris in the Ottoman Empire was the multiplicity of madaris in one area.

This shows that the Ottomans had different types of school for different age groups and that when a student finished his education in the small medrese the student would go to the medrese for specialization.
The students who successfully finished their studies in a small medrese were called danismend.

Just as in the modern world the Ottoman system of education had multiple kinds of schools and a students had to move up to a higher medrese in order to better prepare himself for the madaris teaching specialization.
Vice-President Sebastián Lerdo de Tejada became President of the Republic by succession after Benito Juárez's death in 1872.
He called for new elections, where the candidates were Lerdo de Tejada and General Porfirio Díaz, one of the heroes of the battle of Puebla on 5 May 1862.
Lerdo de Tejada was victorious, and fell sharply out of favour when he declared that he would stand for another re-election.
Porfirio Díaz mounted a rebellion against President Lerdo de Tejada on 21 March 1876, under the Plan of Tuxtepec, promoting the "No Re-election" principle.
On 2 June 1876, the garrisons in state of Chihuahua yielded to the authority of Porfirio Díaz, arresting the governor, Antonio Ochoa, and crushing the Lerdista forces wherever found.
Porfirio Díaz promoted the return of the governor of Chihuahua, Tíras, as a sign of the implementation of the Plan of Tuxtepec.
This triumph resulted in the brief interim presidency of Jose Maria Iglesias until Porfirio Díaz, as only candidate, assumed the presidency on 5 May 1877.
In the first years of the Porfiriato, Porfirio Díaz's government was assaulted by Lerdista and Apache boots.
The former Lerdistas from the United States managed to begin a new rebellion where they temporarily took the city of El Paso del Norte until mid-1877.
This year there was a great drought that struck the north, resulting in a large number of civilian deaths in El Paso del Norte.
To secure his empire, Kangxi personally led a series of military campaigns against the Dzungars in Outer Mongolia.
He managed to drive Galdan's forces back and incorporated Outer Mongolia into the empire.
He was also responsible for the final demise of the remnants of the Dzungar Khanate.

Galdan died in the Dzungar–Qing War. Qing troops received the surrender of Formosa in 1683 from Zheng Keshuang, grandson of Koxinga, who had used the island as a base against the Qing, after the surrender of the Zheng family, Qing troops also executed all the male members of the Zheng family in return for a plot against betrayal.
Zheng Keshuang was awarded the title "Duke Haicheng" (海澄公) and was inducted into the Eight Banners as part of the Plain Red Banner, marrying the daughter of Sun Sike (孫思克).
[53] Several Ming princes had accompanied Koxinga to Taiwan in 1661–1662, including the Prince of Ningjing Zhu Shugui and Prince Zhu Honghuan (朱弘桓), son of Zhu Yihai, Prince of Lu.
The Qing sent the 17 Ming princes still living on Taiwan back to mainland China where they spent the rest of their lives.
[54] Winning Taiwan freed up the Qing navy to use in the conflict against the Russian Empire along the Amur River, the Siege of Albazin.
Qing forces routed a Russian army at Albazin in 1686. The Kangxi Emperor's government had issued edicts in 1668 and 1670 to recruit Albazin Cossacks to join the Eight Banners.
Albazin Cossacks who defected to the Qing were given civilian jobs or enrolled in the Eight Banners.
Qing naval forces included Chinese style war junk, bow and arrow, gun and cannon-armed soldiers.
Former Zheng (鄭) forces like the rattan shield troops (Tengpaiying) were used against the Russian Cossacks at Albazin.
20–30 Russians were killed in a raid on the Cossack fort's cattle by a Qing army with former Ming soldiers using bows and arrows.
After being besieged by 3,000 Qing troops and their native auxiliaries, the Russian Cossacks outside the fort surrendered.
After Galdan was overthrown, Galdan's own followers among the Oirats brought the 5th Dalai Lama, Tibetan Buddhism's spiritual leader, into their realm.
Fearing a revival of Galdan's power, Kangxi sent two armies into Tibet in 1696 to install a Dalai Lama loyal to the Qing dynasty.

On December 31, 2015, West released a song titled "Facts". On January 8, 2016, West released "Real Friends" and a snippet of "No More Parties in L.A." featuring Kendrick Lamar; the latter of which was released in full the following week.
This also marked the return of West's GOOD Fridays series where he releases new singles every Friday.

[96] On January 26, he announced he had changed the title of the album from Swish to Waves and also announced the release of his Yeezy Season 3 clothing line would debut on the album's release date at Madison Square Garden.
[97] In the weeks leading up to his album's release, West became embroiled in several Twitter controversies and released several songs, including "No More Parties in L.A." with Lamar and "30 Hours".
On February 9, West released the track list for his new album, again revising the title, this time changing it to The Life of Pablo.
[98] A day ahead of its release and his accompanying Yeezy fashion show event, West was embroiled in an internet controversy over the third track to be released from the album, "Famous".

[99] West premiered the album on February 11, 2016, at Madison Square Garden. He simultaneously premiered his Yeezy Season 3 clothing line, and further announced that the album would be released exclusively through the streaming service Tidal.

[100] Some of the album was made available to stream live, and afterwards West announced he would change the track list again before its release to include a new version of "Wolves" featuring Sia and Vic Mensa.
[101] He updated the album through February 12, 2016, and West continued to adjust the tracklist.
On February 14, 2016, West released The Life of Pablo exclusively through Tidal.

He performed "Highlights" on an episode of SNL. The same day, West tweeted that he would be remastering the album and re-releasing it with several new songs, including a new song called "Day One" and a new version of "Wolves" featuring Sia and Vic Mensa.
[99] West postponed the release of The Life of Pablo by a week in order to complete the recording of the track "Waves", which West did at the behest of Chance the Rapper.
West's decision to add additional tracks to The Life of Pablo delayed its release to February 14, 2016.
The KU men's basketball team has fielded a team every year since 1898. The Jayhawks are a perennial national contender, coached by Bill Self.

KU is considered one of the most prestigious college basketball programs. The Jayhawks have won a total of five national championships, including three NCAA tournament championships in 1952, 1988 and 2008.
They also were retroactively awarded championships by the Helms Foundation for the 1922 and 1923 seasons.
The team currently ranks third in Division I all-time winning percentage and second in Division I all-time wins.
By the end of the 2011–12 season, Kansas had an overall record of 2,070–806 (.719).
This record includes a 623–107 (.853) mark at historic Allen Fieldhouse. The Jayhawks are first all-time in conference titles.

Famous former Jayhawk players include Wilt Chamberlain and Paul Pierce. The Jayhawks have been led by many great coaches, including the inventor of the game of basketball, Dr. James Naismith (the game's only coach with a losing record), Phog Allen (named the "Father of basketball coaching" by the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame), Dick Harp, Ted Owens, and Hall of Fame coaches Larry Brown, and Roy Williams.

Not only has Kansas had many notable former players and coaches, many basketball legends have had some connection to KU, including Dean Smith (as a player only), Adolph Rupp (as a player only), Dutch Lonborg, and Ralph Miller (as players and coaches).
Smith and Rupp played for KU's 1952 and 1923 championship teams, respectively; they were teammates on the 1922 team.
Allen took over for Naismith; Rupp and Lonborg played for Allen, while Smith, Owens, and Harp played for Allen and later served as assistants under him.

[citation needed] The University is a founding member of the Big 12 Conference, and is the only school to win at least 10 games in conference play each year for the last 28 seasons starting in 1983–1984. Since the 1987–88 season, the Jayhawks have won 20 or more games every season.

In July 1645, Dorgon promulgated a controversial edict ordering all Han Chinese men to shave their foreheads and to braid the rest of their hair into a queue, the traditional Manchu hairstyle, on pain of death.
The edict was harshly enforced: "To keep the hair, you lose the head; to keep your head, you cut the hair.
"[30] For the Manchus, the policy was a test of loyalty and a mark of acceptance of Manchu authority.
For Han Chinese, however, it was a humiliation because traditional teachings held that people should not alter their bodies, as they were gifts from their parents.
Under the Ming, Han Chinese wore their hair in a top-knot and wore no head-shaving.

[31] The Qing hairstyle was symbolic of submission to the new dynasty. This edict triggered widespread resistance to Qing rule, especially in the former Ming capital of Jiankang (Nanjing), whose residents attacked anyone who had a queue.
During the ensuing Jiangnan massacres, these Han Chinese killed many Han who had surrendered to the Qing.
The Nanjing Han population was later massacred or driven into the countryside. Han Chinese Defectors who joined the Qing slaughtered Han Chinese resisters to the Qing.

Li Chengdong, a Han Chinese general who had served the Ming but surrendered to the Qing, ordered troops to carry out three separate massacres in the city of Jiading within one month, resulting in tens of thousands deaths.
At the end of the third massacre, there was hardly a living person left in this city.
Jiangyin also held out against about 10,000 Han Chinese Qing troops for 83 days.
It was estimated that 74,000 inhabitants were killed when the city fell on 9 October 1645.
Another massacre was conducted in Changzhou. Although Dorgon himself repealed the order in 1645, the demand was reinstituted when resistance resumed.
[citation needed] Hundreds of thousands of people were killed before all of China was brought into compliance.
The queue was the only aspect of Manchu culture that the Qing sought to impose on the common Han population.

Qing laws did not force Han civilians to wear Manchu clothing, only Manchu-style officials and men serving the emperor were required to wear it; Han civilian men were forced to make way for Manchus and Mongols on the street and received a beating if they did not do so.[32]

In its Third Report, Defence Equipment 2009, the Defence Committee quoted a report on the Financial Times web-site which claimed that Chief of Defence Materiel General Sir Kevin O’Donoghue issued an internal memo, telling DE&S staff to "refocus" the approvals process on "defence priorities": support for current operations for the next three years, the deterrent, defence commitments that are "contractual or international" and programmes for which production contracts have been signed.

[166] The report also spotlighted defence science and technology research budget cuts, estimated but inaccurate Defence Inflation budgets, underfunding of the Equipment Programme and the apparent incompatibility between the near-term focus on current operations and the investment required to provide future UK defence capabilities.

The Rt Hon. Bob Ainsworth MP, then Secretary of State for Defence, welcomed the emphasis on current operations and said that while "there was to be no review of the major decisions of the 1998 SDR, major shifts in defence spending "could not'' be ruled out.
"[166] As for the underfunded defence budget, Admiral Sir Mark Stanhope, First Sea Lord and Chief of the Naval Staff stated: "There is not enough money in the defence programme at the moment.
There are some tough decisions to be taken to try and balance the books. I am pretty sure there will be some cuts.
"[167] In 2009, the defence budget was reportedly "more than 10% overspent", but those numbers have not been confirmed.
London Evening Standard reported: "According to official Ministry of Defence figures obtained by freedom of information requests, Gordon Brown is right — defence spending cannot be exempt from cuts.
"[168] The MoD has made significant investments in IT in order to cut costs and provide better services for its personnel.

Following the unveiling of Windows 8, Microsoft faced criticism (primarily from free software supporters) for mandating that vendors secure a certificate for enabling secure boot on their device's firmware by default, in order to obtain Windows 8 certification—an optional characteristic to make it easier to boot Windows 8 on said device.

It was argued that the secure boot requirement could be used to hinder or outright prevent the installation of alternative operating systems such as Linux—despite the fact that signed EFI loaders could be used to load an open source operating system that supports UEFI secure boot.
Microsoft's Tony Mangefeste responded to these criticisms on the Building Windows 8 blog, stating that "At the end of the day, the customer is in control of their PC.
Microsoft’s philosophy is to provide the best experience first, and allow the customer to make decisions themselves.
This means that the customer can disable the secure boot via the firmware of their PC, and the customer could install their own certificate and turn the secure boot on their own.

"[135] Microsoft's certification guidelines for Windows 8 ultimately revealed that vendors would be required to provide the ability to customize or disable secure boot on x86-based devices, but not on ARM-based devices (where the secure boot feature of their UEFI must be left enabled in perpetuity).

Tom Warren of The Verge noted that other vendors had also imposed similar policies on their ARM-based tablets and smartphones, including those using Microsoft's Windows Phone platform, but believed that the company should "offer the ability for customers to disable secure boot on ARM just as they have done with x86", especially considering that there are a "lot of users" who want to run Android on their future Windows 8 tablets.[136][137][138] No third party program certificate installation requirement.
Many modern specialty matches, besides being no-disqualification, have an "automatic" victory condition.
Perhaps the most common is the ladder match, in which the object is to set up and climb a ladder and reach an object (usually a championship belt) suspended above the ring.

In these cases, the ladder may be used as a weapon. The object can be anything of importance to the wrestlers involved, be it a championship belt, a document granting a future title shot, or even money.

Another common specialty match is the battle royal, in which 20 0r 30 contestants (comprising the majority of the roster of an average federation) all enter the ring at the same time, and all attempt to toss opponents over the top rope, with both feet touching the floor; the last person remaining in the ring is the winner.

The variation, used in WWE (traditionally at the Royal Rumble), is the Royal Rumble in which 2 wrestlers start out at the start of the match and every 90 seconds (or 2 minutes formerly) another wrestler enters the ring until all 30 or 40 wrestlers enter the ring.
All other rules are the same. (For more match types, see Professional wrestling match types)
His middle-class background, flamboyant fashion sense, and outspokenness have set him apart from other rappers.
West was the first rapper to criticize the path in which hip hop was developing, and the first to openly ridicule the homophobic attitudes of many rappers.
The sales competition between West's Graduation and 50 Cent's Curtis was publicized as a "great day for hip hop".
Many saw it as a "face-off" between gangsta rap and conscious rap, two of the most prevalent trends in the genre.

Stereo Williams of The Daily Beast wrote that, "For the first time, hip-hop's new archetype was at odds with hip-hop's former poster boy and a new commercial dominance was established in the music.... Hip-hop was changing, and the pop-cultural zeitgeist was too."
50 Cent was one of the more prominent rappers to emerge during West's absence in 2006.
He had been in a sales competition with his own album, Curtis, against West's Graduation that year, West's outsold 50 Cent's—signaling West's usurping of 50 Cent as the figurehead of hip hop.

Slant Magazine called the defeat a "changing of the guard" moment in the music scene, as it proved that rap music was no longer "defined by gritty street narratives and odes to one's hood" like gangsta rap, given that West's lyrical topics dealt with themes of "wanting more out of life" and "personal progression" as a person.
Steve Yates of The Observer commented that West snatched "ownership of mainstream hip-hop" from 50 Cent, "who took a street-hustling template and filled it with cartoonish violence".
In 2007, West's robust album sales and hot concert tour put him at the top of MTV's annual "Hottest MCs in the Game" list.
Thought his influence, West was said to be the figure who transformed hip-hop with the passage of time.

Danyel Smith of The Root noted, "Kanye's progression from hip-hop beat-maker to megawatt pop-cultural icon is a timeframe in modern American history, one for which we'll probably be able to say, 'Back in the day folks used to rap like that, before Kanye West.'"

Rosie Swash of The Guardian deemed the sales competition between Curtis and Graduation a "pivotal moment in the genres history", declaring: "It was a clash between two very different heroes of the genre for the right to become its king, not just in the commercial sense.

In his performance 50 Cent's world-bleary ghetto persona would represent hip hop for the noughties, whereas West's bookish, bear-loving, gaffe-prone ditz would be championing a different, more intellectual alternative."

Swash also expressed the importance of West's huge success, particularly in 2007, as his new-found popularity kanyefied hip hop: "Kanye West kanyefied hip hop, taking away its anger, its neutrality towards its own misogyny and its obsession with nihilistic materialism, and bringing it to a new place of experimentation, self-questioning, musical diversity and passion."
In 2008, Rolling Stone mentioned that caused West Injects masses of self into continental commercially successful hip-hop.
According to Rolling Stone: What artist ever garnered more headlines, album by album, song by song, even photo by photo, than Kanye West?

One of the most fascinating pop stars of the 00s was also one of the most relentlessly mercurial: a rapper who conquered the hip-hop world, then rose above it, a producer who cast aside his sonic signature to let the copycats have it all to themselves, a preening, blingy whant-a-celebrity genius who sang about college, culture, commerce and all points in between — and who was forced to parody and sadly transcend his own persona by decade’s end, as life’s harshness destroyed his innocence.
Nobody sounds like West — mainly because there’s nobody who can sound like him tion injects masses of self into continental.
Mainstream hip-hop, into the mainstream, creating introspective, ruminative, self-analyzing (but still street-hip) rap.
Although opening to mixed views from critics and audiences, West's 2008 album 808s & Heartbreaks, which produced "downbeat melodies and wedding-band human beatbox", proved to be a commercial success.

In this light, Rolling Stone opined that there was no papering over the shameless sentimentality, Auto-Tuned warbling and brutal romanticism of West's break-up album, and later awaiting for a hip-hop album so unlikely and avant-garde, there could be no imitating it.

The album have been associated for progressing hip-hop and pop music. The album helped pave the way for hip hop's 2010s embracing of indulgent and extravagantly produced melodic tendencies, "as well as its realisation that authenticity in hip hop could be achieved even when the protagonist shrouded behind a wall of vocoders".

It paved the way for future innovation from artists such as Frank Ocean, The Weekend, Drake, Future, and Kid Cudi, even Kid Cudi and Childish Gambino, Lil Durk, Chief Keef, and Soulja Boy who instead sought a thoughtful alternative to rap bombast.
Reviewing West's musical career prior The Life of Pablo in Rolling Stone, Rob Sheffield considered: There’s a lot of 808s & Heartbreak in the mix.
His emo crooner phase remains his most maligned by fans and critics — it’s the bridge between the acclaimed genius of his 2000s era and his post-Yeezus villain persona.
Yet once the dust settled, 808s was easily the most influential album of his career.
Who needs friends when you can turn your voice into a cyborg-raccoon power tool for sad-man melodrama?
In 808s, the debut formula for realness began to take over vague outlines of the emo-hop future: Kid Cudi, Drake, The Weeknd, Future, etc — or even Keef and Durk for that matter.
Ben Detrick of XXL recognized West as "a new archetype in which honest personal themes trump the minstrel posturing of gangsta rap."
He is followed by rappers "who don’t care, or aren’t smart enough to care, about rapping about gunplay or bricks." Detrick cited Kid Cudi, Wale, Lupe Fiasco, Kidz in the Hall, and Drake.
In 633 AD, the Rashidun Arabs invaded Iran. By 651, Iran was under Arab control.
Most of Iranians converted from their original religion such as Manichaeism and Zoroastrianism to Sunni Islam.
Arabic was established as the official language of Iran. Persian language, however, remained an active common language and also a literary language.

After Iran became part of the Islamic world, Iran began to play a significant role in the Islamic Golden Age, with many prominent scientists and scholars such as Avicenna, Muhammad ibn Zakariya al-Razi, Abu Rayhan Biruni, Fakhr al-Din al-Razi, Zamakhshari, Abdolhossein Zarrinkoob, Rumi, Khayyam, Ferdowsi, Attar, Sanai, Nizami, Nasir al-Din al-Tusi.
In 1501, Iran became Shia after Iranians were Sunni for centuries and shortly after the Arabs had originally conquered Iran.
The switch from Sunni to Shia Islam by Iran started with and was completed by the Safavid Dynasty and represents a major turning point in both Iranian and Muslim history.
In 1736, Iran reached its greatest extent since the Sassanid Empire nearly a millennium earlier, during the Afsharid Dynasty, and briefly became one of the most powerful empires of the time.
In the 19th century, Iran lost a great amount of its territories in the north with which, the largest portions of these territories contained Iran's Georgian subjects within them.
Ultimately Iran irrevocably lost its integral natural territories, which had formed part of the concept of Iran for many centuries, to Imperial Russia.
A popular movement in 1906 resulted in the establishment of a constitutional monarchy and the country's first legislative body, the Majles.
A coup d'état instigated by the U.K. and the U.S. in 1953 reinstalled Mohammad Reza Shah Pahlavi as the Shah of Iran.
Subsequently, Iran became very close allies with Western Bloc, but became more autocratic at home.
Growing dissent against foreign influence and political repression led to the 1979 Revolution and establishment of an Islamic republic on 1 April 1979.
The university culture in northern Europe developed differently from that in the south, although there is a great deal of overlap between the two.
Everyone wrote, lectured, and discussed in Latin, and the procedure in disputations and examinations were the same in either part of Europe.

Northern universities were concentrated in Germany, France, and Great Britain, and tended toward instruction in the arts and theology while universities in the south, particularly Italy, specialized in law and medicine.—And the university’s strengths were reflected in the quality instruction, leading travelling scholars to choose the university that best suited their interests and their pocketbooks.
It was more common in the northern universities to grant the degree of bachelors, especially in disciplines other than theology, in which doctorates were common.

In Italian universities, the doctorate was by far the most common; this reflects the difference of intent between the candidates in the north, who often intended to teach and those in the south who often intended to practice a profession.

The northern universities also tended to follow the faculty-governed model of organization set by the University of Paris while the southern universities followed the Bologna model of scholar-controlled governance.

There was also a distinction between the northern Italian universities which were typically founded like Bologna as scholar-controlled and independent corporations and those further to the south in Italy, and the Iberian peninsula, which were founded by royal and imperial charters to serve the needs of the government.
The largest military threat and engagement for the United States during this timeframe was the War of 1812.
At the time the war began, the United Kingdom was heavily engaged in a war against France in Europe, and the British were attempting to cut off U.S. trade with France.

The United States sought to remain neutral while pursuing foreign trade. The United States strongly protested against the British interference, particularly the Royal Navy's impressment of American sailors.
Britain disregarded American protests; furthermore, using its large navy to cut off trade with France,[7] it seized many American ships.
[8] American outrage focused on the British impressment of thousands of American sailors from U.S.-flagged ships.
Britain, at the same time, was supporting Indian raids in the American Midwest and believed the United States wanted to annex parts of Canada.

The British, for their part, disputed the loss of British seamen as false impressment, argued that by having Native Americans as allies was commonplace and employed by the Americans, and feared the Americans wanted to annex British possessions.

[9] Suggesting that the Americans were hoping to annex territory, U.S. actions attempted to do just this by launching two invasions of Canada, a sea attack on Halifax, blockading of Newfoundland, and capturing control of Lake Erie and Lake Ontario.
Finally, the United States declared the first war on the United Kingdom.[10][11] The war was fought in the U.S. and Canada. For the British, the American war was a curious sideshow.
British and Irish nationals at the time were more concerned with defeating France in Europe, which meant the war with the United States was secondary.
[12] The Americans declared war, but were neither prepared nor financed to fight.
Expecting the Royal Navy to seize control of ocean trade, the U.S. shifted its focus onto capturing Canada.
This would give them a strong bargaining chip, as well as remove the immediate British colonial presence in the region.
A third reason for the U.S. declaring war was to prevent Britain from arming Natives in the Old Northwest, where bitter fighting continued at the same time as the war with Britain.
[13] However, these campaigns mostly ended in failure for the United States. All the while Natives in the Old Northwest were defeated in Tecumseh's War and the Creek War in the south.

When the wars with France ended in 1814, Britain was able to send large veteran armies to invade New York, raid Maryland, burning Washington on 25 August 1814 and Louisiana, seizing control of the Mississippi River.
The New York campaign collapsed when a large army surrendered to the Americans.
The raid on Washington was a success, but the British were turned back in the Chesapeake along the the Chesapeake Bay Campaign with the death of their commander at the Battle of Baltimore.
The major battle in Louisiana became a stunning victory for the United States when their top three British generals and thousands of soldiers were killed or wounded at the Battle of New Orleans.
The triumph made Major General Andrew Jackson a huge national hero, as well as the Americans for defeating a powerful enemy.
The peace treaty proved successful and the United States would never again go to war with the United Kingdom.
The chief victims were the Indians who did not get their proposed independent territory in the Midwest.
At the time of his father's death (972), Vladimir was prince of Novgorod. In 976, Vladimir fled to Scandinavia after his half-brother Yaropolk had murdered his brother Oleg and conquered Rus.
[5] With the help from his relative Earl Håkon Sigurdsson, the ruler of Norway, Vladimir assembled a Varangian army and reconquered Novgorod and Kiev from Yaropolk.
[6] As Prince of Kiev, Vladimir's most notable achievement was the Christianization of Kievan Rus', a process that began in 988.

The Primary Chronicle reports that, in the year 987, Vladimir sent envoys to various parts of Europe, whose reports influenced him to reject Islam[7] and choose Byzantine Christianity as the official religion and to embrace the Eastern Orthodox Church.
