According to the document, after consultation with his advisors he sent out envoys to examine the ragions of the neighboring nations.
They visited the Germans of the Roman church, the Latin (Western) Rite by rights as well as the Muslim Volga Bulgars, but they were most impressed by their visit to Constantinople.

They stated that, "We no longer knew whether we were in heaven or earth." The Primary chronichle reports that Vladimir was baptised at Chersonesos and married Anna to seal the treaty of alliance with the Byzantine emperor Basil II.[8]
In the spring of 1800, Napoleon invaded Italy, with the intentions of moving to Lombardy to engage the Austrian armies that had expelled the French armies there while Napoleon was in Egypt.
After a difficult crossing over the Alps, the French army entered the plains of Northern Italy virtually unopposed.
In the meantime the French Army besieged in Genoa by an Austrian force greatly superior in number.
By his firmness and resolution during the Siege of Genoa, André Masséna had bought precious time for Napoleon's forces to reach the Po Valley and engage the Austrian army in the north.
After days of fighting, the two armies finally clashed at the Battle of Marengo on June 14.
General Melas had a numerical advantage over Napoleon's troops—approximately 30,000 Austrians to 24,000 French.
Initially, the battle went against the French, as the Austrians surprised Napoleon and pushed the French army back.
Believing he had already won the battle, in fact Melas retired to his headquarters in the rear, leaving the pursuit of the French to his subordinates and his chief-of-staff.

However, Napoleon's clever tactics and the resistance of his troops during their tactical retreat prevented the collapse of the French army, and late in the afternoon Desaix's full division finally arrived on the field and turned the tide of the battle.

A sudden French artillery bombardment and cavalry charge against the Austrian left flank forced them to retire and Melas' troops retreated back across the Bormida River to Alessandria, leaving behind their colours, eight cannon and more than 14,000 men killed, wounded or captured.

The following day, the Austrians entered into negotiations which led to their evacuation of Northern Italy in the Convention of Alessandria, which gave their fortresses and storehouses and in return provided for the safe retreat of their demoralized troops.
Hegel keeps hold of truths he finds for in German idealism, such as Kant's conviction that ethical reason transcends finite desires.

But, affirms Hegel, there must be some identity between thought and being if the subject (a man-as-observer) is ever to grasp anything knowable about an object (something "out there, " perhaps even another man) observed.

Hegel's "subject-object" identity (and that of any object and another object) consists in the fact that both subject (man-as-observer) and object each have Spirit (Hegel's secularized something-else, nonsupernatural "God") as their inner conceptual essence and are thus "identical" in that sense.

Yet so long as Spirit has not yet "realized" itself (i. e. , come to "self-consciousness") and thereby become Absolute Spirit, subject (man-as-observer's Mind) falsely judges any object observed as "alien" (other than me).

As Hegel says, "The object presents itself to him as alien. …" Self-realization for the Spirit occurs when Hegel, who is part of Spirit's (quite nonsupernatural) Mind (the mind of all men), understands that any object is, after all, of Spirit (Hegel's euphemistic "God" replacement) and thus is of himself.
Then, when Spirit "realizes" itself as the Absolute Spirit, the "finite" man becomes the "infinite" God, again man-as-God in lieu of supernatural God of theism.

[Emphasis added] Hegelianism, says Tucker, "is a religion of self-worship," and he sees Hegel with Hegel erecting "the human being with the selfsame infinite urge of the Spirit" and demanding "something else, namely infinity. " Hegel pictures man divinizing himself, and in the final victory, doing so.
Desert sky—clear almost constantly; sunshine blankets the Sahara, logging over 3,600 bright hours each year, so that’s more than 82 % of the time.
In the eastern Sahara some locations log over 4,000 hours of sun each year, therefore they bask in daylight about 91 % of the time, almost hitting the absolute maximum.
Upper Egypt (Aswan, Luxor) and Nubian Desert (Wadi Halfa) about 4,300 sun hours each year, 98% sunshine, therefore almost nonstop.
About 2,800 kWh per square meter hits the Great Desert each year—so why isn’t there more solar power?

The sun hangs up high all the time, the air is almost dry, plants barely survive and rain rarely falls; therefore the Great Desert ends up being the biggest area that stays scorching nonstop, and in summer its heat hits the top of the Earth’s thermostat.
Did you hear? 47°C (116.6°F) smashed records in Bou Bernous, a tiny desert town perched 378 m above sea level.
This record? Only beat by Death Valley, California. Other hot spots in Algeria (Adrar, Timimoun, In Salah, Ouallene, Aoulef and Reggane) they rise 200‑400 m above sea level.

Thus, those places get about a 46 °C (114.8 °F) average in summer. Notoriously hot, In Salah — average highs hover around 44 °C (about 112 °F), sometimes jump to 46 °C, and even June through September the temperature pushes up to roughly 42 °C (107 °F).
Even hotter spots in the Sahara, think about the far‑off Azalai up in northern Mali.
Therefore Bilma in Niger and also Faya‑Largeau in Chad are listed as locations.
> Across the desert daily temps, above twenty degrees Celsius (and in the hottest spots almost thirty), does that surprise you?
Most places record average temps past 25 °C (that’s about 77 °F), therefore it usually feels warm, right?
At high noon the sand spikes beyond 80 °C—about 176 °F—and feels like an oven that could scorch your feet.
Port Sudan’s sand blew up to 83.5°C (182.3°F); therefore the highest ever noted.
Emotions have several dimensions, in this case its cultural or feeling labels (such as anger, pride, fear and happiness), physiological change (e. g. , sweating, pulse beat, etc.
), expressive gestures (such as smiling, furrowing brow, etc. ), and the evaluative component that brings a label to situational cues.
Jonathan Turner has conducted the most recent theory of emotional arousal, which includes expectations and sanctions as stimuli to arouse emotions.
Every person brings their own expectations to an encounter, and different emotions can be aroused depending on the fulfillment of self, other, and situation expectations.
When positive or negative sanctions are applied to self or other, it can also arouse different emotions.

Turner studied several emotion theories across different disciplines, including sociology, psychology, evolutionary theory and neurology and identified four that all believe is at least rooted primarily within human neurology: assertive-anger, aversion-fear, satisfaction-happiness and disappointment-sadness.

These primary emotions are the ones should be termed emotions, and it is widely agreed that they can be mixed to arouse more complex emotional arousals, or in his term first order elaboration that includes pride, triumph, and awe.
Each emotion can also be aroused at different levels; for example, concern is a low intensity of aversion-fear, while depression is a higher intensity.
As of March 2011, OS X had a market share of slightly above 14% in North America.
The importance of the Mac's market share and installed base has become a divisive topic.
Industry pundits have often criticized the Mac's comparatively small market share as a justification for declaring Apple a has-been.

Particularly during the 1990s, when Apple suffered from low profitability and uncertainty about its future, a common belief within Apple and among Mac fans was that the company needed to gain a significantly higher market share.
For example, CNET has quoted a market analyst as saying that "over all, it looks like the Mac's market share is falling when the market's growth is taken into account."
Others argue that market share is a meaningless metric for determining the Mac's success.
Apple has positioned the Macintosh as a "premium" personal computer, often as an alternative to entry-level PCs. Thus, the Mac's market share may not be directly comparable to low-cost PCs.
Community discussions on this issue led to the creation of a 2002 Wired article called "It's the Share, Stupid," which argued that the large base of Windows PCs made the Mac irrelevant.
The article highlights the opinions of pro-Mac community members who believe that the Mac's higher quality, rather than its market share, sustain the Mac.
In any case, the rapidly growing personal computer industry has dwarfed the increases in Mac sales.

One book describes how "[Apple's] tiny market share, after all, leaves the Mac in a position of clearly seeming like a mere niche player, a specialty item for people who can either afford luxury items or for computer users who need specific features."
Another book states: "Over the past decade, the market for personal computers has nearly tripled, yet Apple's share of this huge and growing market have [sic] dropped towards the vanishing point.
Thus, Apple's tiny market share gives the false impression that the Mac has a lower user base than it has, and that fewer people use Macs now than, for example, 10 years ago."
Furthermore, since the introduction of the iPhone in 2007, and the iPad in 2010, the iTunes Store, iOS App Store and those devices now account for a significant portion of Apple's profits.
As a result, the percentage of Apple's profit derived from the Macintosh has declined.
In 2010, Apple's Macintosh business unit accounted for 24 percent of the company's total profits, compared with 46 percent in 2008.
Some dismiss the importance of market share, citing its absence from other industries that seeks more to increase the value of their products.

Indeed, regardless of the Macintosh's market share, Apple was in a comfortable position financially compared to other hardware vendors, thanks to its restructuring after Steve Jobs' return to the company.
Moreover, a 2008 report by the NPD Group showed that Apple had a 14 percent market share in the US Personal Computer market and that 66 percent of all computers over 1000 dollars were Macs.
A survey among college students also revealed that Apple was a popular brand. Other sources show that Apple appeals to a demographic distinct from the mainstream personal computer market.

A study by MetaFacts based on recent U.S. data, stated that Apple customer demographics "draws its customer base from a higher socio-economic strata", confirming the evidence that a higher percentage of Mac users are white-collar professionals in comparison to other computer platforms.
He was in a relationship with Barbara Outland (later Barbara Outland Baker) from 1969 until 1974.
Outland was an English teacher with whom he lived. In his memoir, he wrote that she was a "well-balanced woman who had no patience for his rowdy barging and rude manners."
He went on to say, "She was a bit more refined than I was and she knew it, but I was learning.
She could really analyze a book, she could read it and talk about it and have insights digging into the shit.
I admired her, and I was in love with her."[91] Baker claims that toward the end of their relationship they had become competitive and argued about "little things".
She also said he was insufferable—classically conceited—as he became famous and successful.
"He wanted to have his cake and eat it too. He wanted to marry me but marry someone else at the same time. The man I wanted to marry was not this man, at all; he was a fun-loving guy.
For years, he would not even eat breakfast with me because he was so regimented.
He had to have his 30g of protein", Baker said.[92] Schwarzenegger has made it clear that their respective recollection of events can differ.
[91] He also said, "My friends don't really understand why I don't need to hate her.
"[91] Baker published her memoir in 2006, entitled Arnold and Me: In the Shadow of the Austrian Oak.
[92] Although Baker, at times, made some accusations of character against Schwarzenegger, she also talks fondly of their time together.
Schwarzenegger funded the start-up of Baker's hair salon business in 1969, which she described as "the catapult for eventual financial independence".
[91] In an interview with CBS News, Baker stated, "He's a powerhouse. He's an amazing human being, really he is. He can look at a situation and just see what it takes to make it successful.
He does not do anything to lose And he does everything to win."[93] According to Moritz, she was instrumental in helping him become a better businessman and a more cautious person.[49]
The ceremony is held in the Senate, as the sovereign may not enter the House of Commons.

At the sitting of the upper chamber on the day for the ceremony, the Speaker of the Senate reads to those assembled a letter from the secretary to the governor general informing when the viceroy, or a deputy thereof, will arrive.
The chamber may not adjourn until the ceremony is complete. The speaker then moves to a seat to the right of the throne.
The Mace Bearer places the mace on a table to the right of the throne and stands with them.

The governor general then enters and takes the speaker's chair. The Usher of the Black Rod, after receiving the order from the Senate's speaker to do so, proceeds to the House of Commons to summon the members of parliament (MPs) to the Senate, where Black Rod stands with the door closed behind.
MPs follow Black Rod and the Sergeant-at-Arms (who leads and carries the mace of the House of Commons) back to the Senate and stand behind the bar.
Black Rod stands to the left of the governor general (or deputy thereof), who nods to confirm Royal Assent to the bills before parliament, save for the bills of supply (appropriation bills).
The Clerk of the Senate states after all bill titles are presented: in Her Majesty's name, His [or Her] Excellency the Governor General [or the deputy thereof] doth assent to these bills.

In the case of appropriation bills, the Speaker of the House of Commons states the titles of the appropriation bills and the Senate clerk repeats the titles to the governor general (or the deputy thereof).
The governor general (or the deputy thereof) again nods to confirm Royal Assent.

The Senate clerk then recites after all bill titles are presented: in Her Majesty's name, His [or Her] Excellency the Governor General [or the deputy thereof] thanks her loyal subjects, accepts their benevolence, and assents to these bills.[8][9] The governor general (or the deputy thereof) then leaves parliament.[8]
Prior to the 20th century, drugs that we now call antibiotics were used as traditional medicine going back for millennia in ancient Egypt, ancient India and China.
Many remedies were used to treat infections. These treatments include a large number of mixtures with antimicrobial properties which were described over 2000 years ago.
Many ancient cultures, including the ancient Egyptians and ancient Greeks, used specially selected mold and plant materials and extracts to treat infections.
[9][10] More recent observations made in the laboratory began the modern antibiotic era.

In 1874, physician Sir William Roberts noted that bacterial contamination is generally absent in the urine of patients with diabetes mellitus; in 1875, John Burdon-Sanderson observed that culture media exposed to the fungal species Penicillium glaucum exhibited no bacterial contamination.
[11] In 1876, physicist Joseph Lister also observed the antibacterial action of Penicillium and had recommended it for the topical treatment of infected wounds.
[12] Louis Pasteur observed, "if we could intervene in the antagonism observed between some bacteria, it would offer perhaps the greatest hopes for therapeutics".
[11] In 1887, Joseph Lister was the first to apply a pure microbe culture as a medication, using Penicillium glaucum to treat bacterial infections in humans.
[13] In 1895 Vincenzo Tiberio, Italian physician, published a paper on the antibacterial power of some extracts of mold.
[14] French–American biologist René Dubos isolated tyrothricin, an antibiotic mixture, from Bacillus brevis, a soil bacterium, which became the first antibiotics to be commercially manufactured.
The discovery had resulted from his search for a bacterium that could break down the polysaccharide capsule of type III pneumococcus.
The term "antibiosis", meaning "against life," was introduced by the French bacteriologist Jean Paul Vuillemin as a descriptive name of the phenomenon exhibited by these early antibacterial drugs.
[15][16] Antibiosis was first described in 1877 in bacteria when Louis Pasteur and Robert Koch observed that an airborne bacillus could inhibit the growth of Bacillus anthracis.

[16][17] These drugs were later renamed antibiotics by Selman Waksman in 1942.[15][18] Synthetic antibiotic chemotherapy as a science and development of antibacterials began in Germany with Paul Ehrlich in the late 1880s.
[19] Ehrlich noted certain dyes would colour human, animal, or bacterial cells, whereas others did not.
He then proposed the idea that it could be possible to create chemicals that would act as a selective drug that would bind to and kill bacteria without harming the human host.

After screening hundreds of dyes against various organisms, in 1907, Ehrlich discovered a medicinally useful drug, the first synthetic antibacterial organoarsenic compound salvarsan[20][21][22] now called arsphenamine.
Lindlof and Taylor argue that, in the US, cultural studies was grounded in a pragmatic, liberal-pluralist tradition.
They say that early American cultural-studies scholarship aimed to understand how audiences subjectively use and thereby interpret mass culture.
American cultural studies, they say, tended to examine the liberating forms of fandom.
Also, they write that the US version of cultural studies (back in its early days) criticized the gatekeepers of knowledge.

However, today the US and UK perspectives are much more similar. In the early days of British cultural studies, however, scholars tended to use the Marxist approach (Frankfurt school)—more specifically, they focused on the structuralists branch, such as Louis Althusser.
They say the orthodox Marxist approach focuses primarily on production of meaning; in fact, cultural power rests in the hands of the producers.

If you control the means of production, you control culture. But some means of examining culture (including feminist cultural studies and American cultural studies—albeit later forms) differ from the single, preferred meaning of a product.
In this sense, they reject the Marxist notion that authorial intent signifies there is one common meaning for all to consume. Instead, consumption practices themselves influence a product’s meaning.
Or, as in the case of how producers do not entirely dictate practices of meaning-making, as shown in Doing Cultural Studies: The Story of the Sony Walkman, by Paul du Gay.
The theories of Griselda Pollock, a feminist cultural analyst, have enriched cultural studies and the sub-disciplines of art history and psychoanalysis within.
Julia Kristeva has through her prolific writings at the turn of the century provided a rich resource for cultural studies embued in the art and Psychanalyst culture of French feminism.
Nishimura's force consisted of two battleships, one cruiser, and four destroyers.
Because of the strict radio silence imposed on the Center Force, Nishimura was unable to synchronize his arrival off the strait with Shima and Kurita.

No Japanese officer was in overall command of the three forces, and no comprehensive plan had been drawn up to coordinate their attack, as the Japanese assumed (correctly) the separate forces would be able to destroy whatever they encountered.

Due to the feud between the Imperial Japanese Army and Imperial Japanese Navy, and the general lack of military intelligence sharing, none of the commanders of the Japanese fleet were aware of the presence of the Sixth United States Army in and around Leyte Gulf.
[50] As a result, Nishimura also failed to communicate with Shima and the two forces' arrival at Surigao Strait was not coordinated.
Shima's force trailing Nishimura by some 22 mi (40 km) and Kurita was still navigating the Sibuyan Sea hours away.
The Southern Force ran into trouble in the Panaon Strait between Leyte and Panaon Island, where at 02:00, they were attacked by three American PT boats in the seven-mile wide strait.
Just past midnight on 25 October, Nishimura's Southern Force of battleships Yamashiro and Fusō, the cruiser Mogami, and four destroyers steamed into a deadly trap.

The U.S. Seventh Fleet Support Force was commanded by Rear Admiral Jesse Oldendorf and consisted of six battleships (USS Mississippi, West Virginia, Maryland, Tennessee, California and Pennsylvania), four heavy cruisers (USS Louisville, Portland, Minneapolis and Australian HMAS Shropshire), four light cruisers (USS Denver, Columbia, Phoenix and Boise), 29 destroyers, and 39 motor torpedo boats.

To pass through the strait and reach the Allied invasion fleet, Nishimura had to run the gauntlet of seven destroyers and 27 motor torpedo boats (the other two in the 7th Fleet were no longer battleworthy[a]) before entering the arcs of fire of six battleships and eight cruisers on the other side.
At 03:00, Fusō, with three destroyers, was hit by torpedoes launched by PT boats.
By 03:50, Fuso had sunk, followed at 04:10 by three destroyers sunk in the same manner.

[citation needed] At 03:50, Yamashiro, a cruiser, and a destroyer were hobbled by gunfire from six battleships all 16 in (406 mm) guns, out-ranging the Japanese battleships by a wide margin, due to the advanced (for its time) naval radar in use by U.S. ships,[51] as well as gunfire from four heavy cruisers.

Yamashiro later sank at 04:19.[52] Of note in this battle is the fact that the command for the U.S. battleships that fired their 16 in (406 mm) shells was the same ships' commanding officers and crew (with some replacements in the former roles of Admiral and unit commanders) who were present during and survived the 7 December 1941 attack on Pearl Harbor – battleships West Virginia, California, Tennessee, Maryland, Pennsylvania, and Mississippi), although only the USS Pennsylvania fired at the enemy aircraft causing little if any casualties.
In this brief engagement, the Yamashiro and a destroyer were sunk, one destroyer was able to escape and the damaged cruiser returned and eventually joined Kurita's Centre Force.
[53] At 04:25, Shima's two heavy cruisers and eight destroyers encountered what was left of Nishimura's force.
He saw what he thought were the wrecks of two battleships, though it is more likely that they were the two halves of Fusō then indicated under the capitol ship icon.
After a quick exchange of gunfire, Shima ordered a withdrawal. The Battle of Surigao Strait was the last battleship versus battleship naval engagement in history.[54][55]

During the collapse of Wu and the Wu Hu uprising in Jin dynasty in 265–420, many Chinese elite collaborated with non-Chinese kings and warlords in northern China, some of which lost their rank privilege and fled to south of Yangtze.
There are several North China refugee migrated in to the vicinity of the great city of Hangzhou.
The most famous example is the family of the chancellor of Shu Han in Three Kingdoms period, Zhuge Liang (181–234).
They moved to the rural area near Hangzhou and established Zhuge Village (Zhege Cun), which has been sealed to outsiders until recently publicly known.
[15] It means that some powerful elite Chinese refugees from Central Plain found haven in south of Yangtze.
However, since 90% of the area in Zhejang is mountains, which is lack of farmount.
Most refugees might migrate to other parts of South China, since their metropolitan and agricultural resources are more accessible than the less set society in south of Yangtze.
These provinces include north Jiangsu, west Fujian, Jiangxi, Hunan and Anhui, Socio-political north-south Han division in Sui-Tang Dynasties edit .
Another place for the refugees to flee are the metropolitan area of Sichuan, since Shu was ruled by north elites for a while.
Socially speaking, refugees from north China had choices to their new residence in south China by social rank and military power.
At the same time, Nanjing and south of Yangtze fought with some elite Chinese from Central Plain and south of Yangtze in between the rump Jin state (or Southern Dynasties).

The Cubs lost an extra inning game in Game 1. They came back and won three of the next four games to take a 3-1 games lead against the Wild Card Florida Marlins in the National League Championship Series (NLCS).

The Cubs were shut out in Game 5, but then young starting pitcher Mark Prior had the Cubs ahead in Game 6 by a score of 3–0 and pitching in the 8th inning. At this point, what has become known as the Steve Bartman incident occurred.
A number of fans attempted to catch a foul ball off the bat of the Marlins' Luis Castillo.
One of them, a Cubs fan named Steve Bartman, reached for the ball, deflected it, and prevented Cubs outfielder Moisés Alou from catching the ball for the second out of the inning.
Alou angrily threw his glove to the ground and slammed a towel with both hands, before yelling at the crowd.
Many people allege that this was the turning point in the series that tilted it into the Marlins' favor.
Alou, however, said in 2008, "You know what the funny thing is? I wouldn't have caught it, anyway."
He later admitted this wasn't true, but simply said it to make Bartman feel better.
Alou added, "It's time to forgive the guy and move on."[105] Alou's tantrum, however, may have helped contribute to the 8-run inning by the Marlins.

No interference was called on the play since the ball was ruled to be out of the field of play; Prior subsequently walked Castillo, and three batters afterward Cubs shortstop Alex Gonzalez misplayed a potential double play ground ball.

The floor of the club "level" suite right above the row where the foul ball landed is now slanted with plexiglass behind the seating area to protect reporters and players from beer being spilled on them.

Florida went on to score eight runs and win the game. Although the Cubs sent their ace Kerry Wood out to start the 7th game and took a 5-3 lead, the Cubs fell to the Marlins and did not make the World Series.

On 8 December 1991, the heads of Russia, Ukraine, and Belarus (Byelorussian SSR) signed the "Agreement on the Establishment of the Commonwealth of Independent States" (the media informally dubbing the document the Belavezha Accords).

The agreement contained a preamble and fourteen articles. The preamble confirmed the protagonists' belief that "...the USSR as a subject of international law and a geopolitical reality no longer exists..." and it went on to agree to found a "...Commonwealth of Independent States..." being motivated by the "...historical community of peoples and the ties between them, the agreements concluded between their sovereign states..." and by "...the striving for a democratic rule of law."

On 12 December, the agreement was ratified by the Russian SFSR's Congress of People's Deputies (the remaining republics taking no part in the agreement) (188 votes in favor, 6 votes against, 7 abstentions), and at the same time recalled the Russian deputies from the Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union[8] and annulled the Treaty on the Creation of the Soviet Union.

[9][10] Some areas of the media have claimed that this was legally questionable[11] (the Constitution of the Russian SFSR (1978) seemingly provided no provisions for the Supreme Soviet of RFSFR to do any such thing), although in such matters the Congress of People's Deputies of the Russian SFSR was even more empowered to act.

Other sources, countering this claim, have pointed out that the question was rendered moot by the inactivity of the central Soviet government (the Soviet side "...did not react to this in any clear way.
It did nothing..."[12]). Some reports had suggested that the Soviet president Mikhail Gorbachev was unaware of the negotiations until after the signing of the agreement.

Despite the ensuing legal confusion, the vote by the Congress of People's Deputies of the Russian SFSR has often been considered as the RSFSR's secession from the Union, although the RSFSR believed that it was impossible to secede from a non-existent entity.[13]
In July 2013, after a prolonged period of conference realignment, Notre Dame joined the Atlantic Coast Conference (ACC) in all sports except football and men's ice hockey.

The Fighting Irish previously competed in the Big East Conference as full members;[43] the university left the Big East at a time when it was unstable, with many members departing for other conferences and its future uncertain.
The ACC and Big East reached an agreement, allowing Notre Dame to leave the Big East for the ACC a year earlier than planned.
Notre Dame retains its status as a football independent, but has committed to play five games per season against ACC opponents.
[44][45] In ice hockey, Notre Dame moved to Hockey East at the same time as the other changes.

[46][47] This move was necessitated by the Big Ten Conference's decision to add men's ice hockey as an official conference sport beginning in 2013–14. At that time, both the ACC and Big East do not sponsor ice hockey.

The Irish were forced to find a new home for that sport, which was at the time under the control of the Central Collegiate Hockey Association (CCHA; another conference that would soon cease operations, following the 2012-13 season, due to the formation of the short-lived men's ice hockey league of the Big Ten).
When Notre Dame joined the ACC, the conference announced that it would add fencing as a sponsored sport in the 2014–15 school year.
[48] The "Fighting Irish" nickname has been used by the university since 1919, and there are several legends about how the moniker came to be.
One comes from the story of Irish immigrant soldiers, fighting in the Civil War, used as assault troops for daredevil attacks on the opposition.
Another story focuses on the Irish ancestry of the school's founder, Fr. William Corby, and the patron saint of the university's athletes, Saint Edward the Martyr.
Notre Dame was known for many things in its early years, but football was not one of them.
[49] The college first played football in November 1887 when a group of students from Michigan traveled to South Bend to teach the game to students from the university.
[50] The game incorporated elements from soccer and rugby initially, and it took a few years for the rules to become standardized with those of Division I-A football that we know today.
[51] The university eventually adopted the current version of the game, but before then it was still called Notre Dame Football because they were playing football at Notre Dame University.
[52] Although there are several theories as to the origin of the Fighting Irish nickname, it was used as a moniker for the football team throughout most of the 1920s.
The nickname became popular throughout the country because alumnus Francis Wallace wrote it in his columns in the New York Daily News.
[53] It was unofficial until 1951, when then-University President Rev. Theodore Hesburgh, adopted the moniker at the request of students.
[54][55][a] The official colors of the University of Notre Dame are Navy Blue and Gold Rush.
[56] The school's athletic teams wear a combination of the two on their uniforms for competitions.
Additionally, as the "Fighting Irish", Notre Dame also often uses green, traditionally the color of the fighting Irish or clover that is associated with Ireland.
Athletics mascot The Notre Dame Leprechaun was designed by sports artist Theodore W. Drake in 1964.
[57] The leprechaun logo was first featured on the football pocket schedule and later it was on the football program covers.
The leprechaun was featured on the cover of Time magazine (November 1964). This is the logo most usually associated with Notre Dame sports.[58][59]

Untroubled in comparison to many parts of the country by 1841 due to their direct relationship with the United States , the state government expected the coming war by 1843, reinforcing the defensive lines at the Texas border.
Artillery and munitions were delivered to arm the military completely, and actions were taken to create more efficiency within the presidios .

Soon thereafter, the state began to compose the Regimen for the Defenders of the Border, including the light cavalry, four squads broken down into two brigades, and a small body numbered at 14 men, 42 officers that cost the state 160,603 pesos a year.

In the early 1840s private citizens tried to stop the commercial caravan with supplies from the United States, but due to the fact that the state was cut-off from abundant suppliers in central Mexico , the caravan was allowed to resume in March 1844.
Still expecting war, the legislature of the state decreed on 11 July 1846, the call to arms of 6,000 men to serve on the border.
During this time Á¿ngel Trí became ascendant, rapidly coming to power through the use of excessive anti-American rhetoric.

Trí exploited the opportunity to extract economic concessions from the people as well as loans from municipalities , preparing to defend the state through the organization and complete outfitting of a large volunteer militia that the state organized with the funds.
Tría promulgated many actions that were taken to ensure the state militia’s self-reliance due to the lack of support from the national government.
The loss of the Thirteen Colonies in North America in 1783 after the American War of Independence caused Britain to lose some of its oldest and most populous colonies.
British attention soon turned towards Asia, the Pacific, and later Africa, with subsequent exploration leading to the rise of the Second British Empire (1783–1815).
Part of Britain's territories in North America were maintained, with their capital at Halifax, Nova Scotia.
Britain later defeated France in the French Revolutionary Wars and Napoleonic Wars and became the supreme military and naval power of the 19th century.
It enforced what became known as the Pax Britannica, which was a period of relative peace in Europe and the world (1815–1914).

Trade flourished thanks to the expansion of the British Empire. Britain embarked on global imperial expansion, particularly in Asia and Africa, which made the British Empire the largest empire in history.
National participation in the "Imperial Mission" profoundly influenced the culture of the Victorian era.

During this period of stability known as the British Peace, the nation's population grew at a dramatic pace, augmented by unmatched urbanisation; resulting in significant social and economic stresses.

To seek new means to expand the nation's industrial supply of coal and metals, the Conservative Party led by Disraeli (1804–1881) secured, together with colonies in Egypt, South Africa, and other areas.
Canada, Australia, and New Zealand became self-governing dominions. This century of relative peace was shattered by the outbreak of World War I (1914–1918).
Energy in biology is an expression of the biosphere as an entire operating system.
At the level of the individual organism it is responsible for the growth and development of a biological cell or an organelle of a biological organism.

Energy can be stored in organisms in a variety of ways for example carbohydrates and lipids and proteins all release energy when reacted with oxygen, in a series of oxidation reactions, as part of the organism's respiration process.
The human equivalent (symbol H-e) is a unit of power, for measuring the energy production rates of both machines and human beings.
One human equivalent is the amount of power produced by an average human. The average human yields around 12, 500 kJ per day, which is approximately 80 watts.

Therefore, in terms of human equivalence (H-e) and to draw from the average rate at which our bodies derived energy for metabolism as shown above, if we were to operate at leveled amount of 80 watts, a 100 watt light bulb would be operating at 1.
25 human equivalents (100 ÷ 80), or 1. 25 H-e. For this reason the human equivalent is a reasonable measurement of both human capacity and overall effective energy production.
For very short periods of time, a healthy human can produce thousands of watts more than the amount given above (746 W is 1 horsepower).

However, the longer-interval values tend to average out. For example, a healthy human can produce about 1 000 W for a few minute intervals, about 300 W for an hour of vigorous exercise, and about 150 W over an 8-hour work shift.
Energy flow (or flux) by itself may refer to the rate of transfer of energy... and has the unit of jules per second or watts (in SI unit).
For example, bioenergetics is also defined as the study of energy flow through living systems.

To clarify... energy flow (in terms of both physical and biological systems), the term human equivalent may be used, for example alongside the SI unit watt, to put the number into a more human perspective and to show the rate of change at which the system or organism itself (formal or informal), may be operating.
In the wake of the Sergeant Isaac Woodard incident, wartime combat veteran President Harry S. Truman created the President’s Committee on Civil Rights under Executive Order 9808.
It’s purpose was to investigate violence and recommend appropriate federal legislation.
After Truman heard of the incident, he told NAACP’s Walter Francis White “My God!

I had no idea it was as terrible as that. We’ve got to do something.” In 1947, it issued “To Secure These Rights,” a report that was widely read and influential despite the utopian nature of its proposals.
“In our land men are equal, but they are free to be different. From these very differences among our people has come the great human and national strength of America” the report proclaimed.
It described racial discrimination in terms of the most basic elements of life from education to public accommodations, physical security to employment opportunity.

The commission found the status of race relations distressing and chastised the internment of Japanese Americans in terms as “wholly inconsistent with our standards…no trials or hearings were conducted.

“Fundamental to our whole system of law is the belief that guilt is personal and not a matter of heredity or association.” The report’s suggestions were nothing if not courageous, calling on the government to end racial discrimination and establish equality as national policy: “We can tolerate no restrictions upon the individual which depend upon irrelevant factors such as his race, his color, his religion, or the social position to which he is born.” To Secure These Rights laid the framework for liberal legislation largely enacted in law by Lyndon B. Johnson.
The first railways were built in Thuringia in the 1840s. The main-line network was finished until 1880, many branch lines were established until 1920.
Before World War II, Thuringia's density of railways was one of the highest in the world with about 2500 km of tracks.
Between 1950 and 2000, the most branch-lines were closed, so that the network shrank by around half.
On the other hand, the most main-lines have been refurbished after 1990 so that travelling times could be decreased.
Today, the most important railways are the Thuringian Railway and the Saal Railway.
The Thuringian Railway connects Halle and Leipzig in the east with Frankfurt and Kassel in the west.
The main stations to the east-west-direction are Weimar, Erfurt, Gotha, and Eisenach.
There is an hourly ICE-service (Line 50: Dresden–Frankfurt) via Thuringian Railway.
The Saal Railway runs along the Saale river connecting Halle/Leipzig to Nuremberg in the south and splitting up in to two lines to Jena and Saalfeld.

The Saal Railway is paced with an hourly ICE (Line 28: Berlin–Munich via Saalfeld; next to hourly Intercity Line 61: Karlsruhe–Leipzig via Saalfeld and EuroCity Line 6: (Prague–)Berlin–Budapest via Jena).

A new high-speed railway is going to replace both existing long-distance lines in 2017 so that all long-distance trains will vanish from the traditional Thuringian Railway and Saal Railway after their completion.

Both ICE lines will run on the same tracks between Erfurt and Leipzig/Halle (Erfurt–Leipzig/Halle high-speed railway), so that the importance of Erfurt as a railway junction will increase after the completion.

While the Berlin–Munich line will continue further south on the Nuremberg–Erfurt high-speed railway, the Frankfurt–Dresden line will go on westwards using the historical Thuringian Railway (the only part, still visited by ICE trains after 2017) to Eisenach and further and the Leipzig–Dresden railway via Riesa.
Since 2000, Erfurt's central station is totally rebuilt, finished in 2000s and prepared for being the junction of all ICE lines from 2017 onwards.

The running speed in the Thuringian network will benefit from the upcoming 2017-situation, because ICE trains will fasten from 160 to 200 km/h and regional trains can run in a better cycle without the existing high-speed train priority.

The most important regional lines are the Neudietendorf–Ritschenhausen railway (Erfurt–Würzburg and Erfurt–Meiningen), the Weimar–Gera railway (Erfurt–Chemnitz), the Sangerhausen–Erfurt railway (Erfurt–Magdeburg), the Gotha–Leinefelde railway (Erfurt–Göttingen), the Halle–Kassel railway (Halle–Nordhausen–Kassel) and the Leipzig–Hof railway (Leipzig–Altenburg–Zwickau–Hof) as well as several minor railways.
Most regional and local lines are running in a one-hour-cycle, but on some lines is a 2-hour-cycle.
During the period 1000–1300, the Kingdom of France gradually asserted control over the lesser nobles of the kingdom itself and expanded into more territories of modern France.

The most successful challengers to royal authority were the dukes of Normandy, who conquered England in 1066 and created a cross-channel empire that lasted, in various forms, throughout the medieval period.
Other Norman adventurers established fiefdoms in southern Italy and Sicily, and upon the First Crusade also launched the conquest of regions of the eastern Mediterranean.
In England the Anglo-Norman realm was torn by civil war before the accession of Henry II (reigned 1154–89), who inherited many territories, forming the Angevin Empire.
His son Richard I (reigned 1189–99) likewise held huge parts of France until he was succeeded by his younger brother John.

John lost Normandy and other northern French lands to French king Philip II Augustus (reigned 1180–1223) in 1204, along with conflicts with the English nobility that led to the signing of the Magna Carta, an agreement that established certain rights for the nobility and limited royal powers.
Further concessions resulted during the reign of his son Henry III (r. 1216–72).
The French monarchy also consolidated control over its more distant territories during the period 1000–1300.
Assisted by continued social and economic developments, the monarchy emerged as the most important social force in France, with the royal court serving as the political centre of the kingdom.
Mysticism flourished in the north of Europe, with many prominent figures, including Bernard of Clairvaux and Hildegard of Bingen.
In the early 13th century, nobles led an antiheretical crusade in southern France, ruling the area as a result.

Later in the century, France would gain control of parts of western France as a result of an inheritance, and in the early 14th century, French and English senators in Rome would elect rival popes, thus dividing the papacy between two rival courts.
The Papacy of Avignon was thereby established, and the Kingdom of France established an alliance with the Kingdom of Navarre.
In 1308, Philip IV of France ordered the arrest of the Knights Templar. Also in this period, France became the leading power in Europe, with Paris as its capital.
In the 14th century, the French kingdom experienced the beginning of the Hundred Years' War.
The end of this conflict marked the end of the feudal order and the rise of the House of Valois.
A number of 1970s and 1980s hard rock bands continued to have successful recording careers through the new millennium.
Bon Jovi's Crush (2000), including the number 1 single "It's My Life", was their most successful release since Keep the Faith.

AC/DC's Stiff Upper Lip (2000) was a major-platinum hit. Aerosmith's Just Push Play (2001), including the Top 10 single "Jaded", went platinum and reached number 2, as did their blues cover collection, Honkin' on Bobo (2004).

Heart's Jupiters Darling (2004) and Red Velvet Car (2010) gave them Top 100 albums for a group whose success had begun back in 1976, making them the first female fronted hard rock band to have Top 10 albums for five decades.

Van Halen (2004, 2007), The Who (2002, though their 2002 tour was postponed owing to the death of bass guitarist John Entwistle until the following year) and Black Sabbath (under both Osbourne, 1997–2006 and Dio, 2006–10) all undertook successful reunion tours.
Led Zeppelin also did an acclaimed one-off performance in 2007 in tribute to Atlantic Records founder Ahmet Ertegun, rekindling the hopes of millions for a full-fledged tour.

Notable hard rock bands formed in the 2000s include supergroups Audioslave (featuring three former members of Rage Against the Machine and erstwhile Soundgarden singer Chris Cornell) and Velvet Revolver (composed of ex-members of Guns N' Roses, former Guns N' Roses guitarist Duff McKagan's punk band Loaded, Dave Kushner, and former Stone Temple Pilots singer Scott Weiland).
Both bands had contemporary hit albums before disbanding in 2007 and 2008, respectively.
Guns N' Roses' long-awaited Chinese Democracy was finally released in 2008, but only went platinum, a far cry from the multiplatinum status their albums held from releases earlier in their career.

AC/DC's Black Ice (2008) did better, reaching 2× platinum status. In 2006, the career of Bon Jovi turned towards country with their number 1 hit "Who Says You Can't Go Home", reaching number one on the Hot Country Singles chart.
Their rock/country album Lost Highway was released in 2007, reaching number 1. In 2009, Bon Jovi returned to their hard rock/crossover roots with The Circle, another number 1 album in November.
Though the outcome was victorious for Britain and its empire, the effects of the Second World War were enormous both at home and abroad.

Much of Europe, a continent that had until that point been the world's most powerful, and home to Europe's colonial powers, had been reduced to ruins and occupied by the armies of the United States and the Soviet Union, who had now become the world's superpowers.

Britain was left essentially bankrupt, and depending on vital lend lease supplies from the United States it had steeply racked up huge debts in order to finance the war: Britain narrowly avoided bankruptcy in 1946, only thanks to a $4.33bn ($56 bn in 2012) Anglo-American loan made by the United States; the last instalment of this loan was finally repaid in 2006.
At the same time, pro-decolonisation movements were on the rise in European colonies across the world.
The United States and the Soviet Union, itself a colonial power, strained relations in the emerging Cold War, but both were nominally against colonialism.
In reality, American anti-communism trumped anti-imperialism, and so the Americans supported the continued existence of the British Empire to keep Communist expansion in check.
However, the "wind of change" meant that the British Empire would go through an accelerated process of decolonisation as Britain's colonies became independent states.

Unlike other European countries, such as France and Portugal, Britain generally managed this process peacefully, albeit often only once stable, non-Communist governments had been put in place, whereas other European powers engaged in costly and ultimately unsuccessful wars to keep their empires intact.
By 1965, those under British rule outside the United Kingdom had dropped to 5 million, apart from 3 million in Hong Kong.
Most nonprofit corporations fall into one of 2 categories, a Membership or Board-only.
In a Nonprofit Membership board organization, a board is voted on by the members of the corporation, members hold regular meetings, and can make changes to the nonprofit bylaws.
In a Board-only Nonprofit corporation, the board itself is self-selected and the members don’t hold much powers beyond what the board has delegated.
Some board-only nonprofits define in their bylaws that they have no membership.

Such as Fairvote, an electoral reform advocacy group, and National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws still use terms such as “membership” to define their donors or those who use the services provided, despite this status still refer to their donors or those who use their services as “members”.
Due to the complications that result from the Model Nonprofit Corporation Act imposed on membership decision-making, many organizations such as the Wikimedia have chosen to become Board-only.
This trend poses concerns for the future transparency, accountability, and responsiveness of nonprofits organizations.

The National Association of Parliamentarians has commented on this and stated, For one thing, is the ultimate check in the private sector for public stock corporations, and is the ultimate check in purely for-profit corporations.
Nonprofit corporations have no market discipline and no such ultimate oversight authority.

If there is no membership electing the board, there is effectively no check on abuse, short of the IRS… argument is that the larger a nonprofit becomes, the larger fees they'll accept for donations, and the higher the scrutiny, and that means future donators will request an audited balance sheet of all finances.
Furthermore, Nonprofits cannot distribute profits to its own membership or board of directors, which is a further measure against such activity.

However, one should be wary of board-only organizations: before you “donate” a penny to such a nonprofit, such as the Clinton Foundation or other board-only organizations, look at the annual income of the board members.
Any time a board member lines their own pockets with “donations”, they've abused the system, and this is why they may avoid audits, and loopholes for tax-deductions.
The men's basketball team has over 1600 wins, and is a founding member of the Big East Conference.
They have appeared in 28 NCAA tournaments, good for 9th all time, and former player Austin Carr holds the record for most points scored in a single game of the tournament.
Although the team has never won the NCAA Tournament, they were named by the Helms Athletic Foundation as national champions twice.
They have also played in the NIT 13 times, winning in 1973. The team has beaten an additional eight number-one ranked teams, and is known for ending UCLA's record 88-game winning streak in 1974.
This has contributed to the Fighting Irish being one of only two teams to have at least a .500 record against the Bruins of UCLA.

The other is Louisville. Notre Dame has also defeated the defending NCAA Tournament Champion a record nine times, more than any other school, and the Irish have an additional 5 victories over teams that were runners-up the previous season.
Notre Dame has also garnered the all-time record for most upsets over a #1 team at seven.
The team is led by head coach Mike Brey, who, in 14 years, has led the Fighting Irish to over 300 victories.
Notre Dame, as an independent, was a member of the original "wheel alignment" of top basketball schools.
In 2009 they lost in the semifinals of the NIT (National Invitation Tournament).
The Fighting Irish are 2nd only to UCLA for most all-time wins over No.1 ranked teams.
UCLA holds the record of 10. The Fighting Irish play their home games at Purcell Pavilion at the Edmund P. Joyce Center.
During the 2009–10 season the facility underwent a extensive renovation. The newly renovated arena opened for the 2009–10 season.
The team is currently coached by Mike Brey, who, as of the 2014–15 season, his fifteenth at Notre Dame, has achieved a 332–165 record.
On March 30, 2011, Mike Brey was named the Associated Press college basketball Coach of the Year.
The 2010–11 men's team finished the regular season ranked number seven in the country with a record of 25–5, Brey's fifth straight 20-win season, and a second-place finish in the Big East.

In the 2014-15 season, Brey's team went 32-6, won Notre Dame's first conference tournament in program history, and advanced to the Elite 8 where they lost on a missed buzzer beater against then undefeated Kentucky.
Future NBA draft picks Jerian Grant and Pat Connaugton had 2 victories over the eventual national champion Duke Blue Devils.
The 32 wins was the most ever for the Fighting Irish in the 106 years of the program (1908-09).
Marshall Field & Company was founded in 1852, and quickly became the predominant department store in the Chicago middle-American downtown.
It attracted upscale shoppers from throughout the Midwest, who arrived via train and frequently stayed at hotels near the store.

Prior to being renamed Macy's on State Street on September 9, 2006, Marshall Field's was well exists as a large chain but was well-known for its then-exceptional level of quality and customer service.
It was famed for its Frango mints, a line of chocolates that became the store's signature.
It also associated with the now-defunct Seattle/Portland-based Frederick & Nelson, with Marshall Field originally making the Frango recipe there in 1918.
Throughout its lifetime, Field’s had many firsts and innovations to its credit.
It had the first European buying office in Manchester, England. The first Brides’ Registry, conceived in 1924 with an assistant Merchandise Manager, was started at Field’s.
The first personal shoppers were also designated when they were implemented in every branch and continued as a free service until the demise of the chain under its original name.
Field's was the first to offer revolving credit and it was the first to use escalators in stores.
The book department in State Street was legendary, and it was here that the term “book signing” was implemented.
Holidays were always a great time for customers; each Christmas the downtown windows were a must-see, animated and known for their beauty.
It became a tradition to visit the holiday windows as it became to dine next to the Walnut Room’s famous tree.
During the weeks before the holidays it was a tradition to meet “under the clock” on State Street and visit the windows.

Studies that have primarily focused on Ashkenazi mitochondrial DNA found results favoring the pre-2006 theory of origins (see above), namely that Ashkenazi were descended on the direct maternal line from non-Israelite women.

A 2013 study conducted by Martin B. Richards of the University of Huddersfield in England reached the conclusion that Ashkenazi maternal line was not of Near Eastern origin (i.e., not Israelite) nor was it of the North Caucasus (i.e., not Khazar) .
Instead, the paper argues for acquisition of the line in Europe, primarily of Italian and Old French origins.

The study compared a total of complete 16,600 DNA units of mitochondrial DNA (compared to 1,000 tested in the 2006 Behar study) and concluded that the four major female Ashkenazi founders have ancestry that is both European and predates the founding of Ashkenazi Jews.
Specifically, the four major female Ashkenazi founders had ancestry that had been established in Europe 10,000 to 20,000 years ago.
The Ashkenazi Jewish population would therefore be one of the modern descendants of the earliest colonization of Europe by anatomically modern humans.
"A substantial proportion of maternal ancestry of modern Ashkenazi Jews arises in prehistoric Europe."

Furthermore, the study found that a large part of the remaining minor founders also have a deep European ancestry: As the founding of Ashkenazi Jewry in the first millennium CE involved well over a thousand women, it would be need be a significant number of women who converted to Judaism in Europe (a similar figure of 1,000 men was found in a study of Y chromosome).
Whereas the 2006 Behar study sampled only the "control region" of the mitochondrial DNA which is supported by only 1,000 DNAunits, the 2013 study by Richards et al.
samples the complete mitochondrial DNA supported by 16,600 units, giving a more comprehensive sampling.
In simple terms, Richards argues that 80 percent of Ashkenazi maternal ancestry comes from women indigenous to Europe, and only 8 percent originated in the Near East with the rest unknown.
"None of the mtDNA was of North Caucasus (or Khazar) origin. These results point to a significant role for the conversion of women in the formation of Ashkenazi communities," Richards said.
"They seem to have occurred first along the Mediterranean, with the southward movement of peoples, and then in west and central Europe as the Ashkenazi settlement belt shifted northwards.
This, of course, does not mean that the paternal line is not of Israelite origin, for which see above.
Richards was quoted as saying: This suggests that, even though Jewish men may indeed have migrated into Europe from Palestine around 2,000 years ago, they seem to have married European women...

It seems that, at least on the maternal side, the story of the Jewish diaspora is not one of promiscuous matings, but of Jewish men who travelled to new places and settled down to lives with their new, local wives whose lineages soon became dominant.
Which is to say that I hope our study will have a far-reaching cultural impact even beyond the genetic arena.
Our study... should finally put to rest pseudo-scientific claims that Ashkenazi Jews are descended from the mysterious Khazars.
The medieval Khazar Khaganate was a state that existed north of Georgia between the Black Sea and Caspian Sea, 9 to 11 centuries ago.
Kurita passed through San Bernardino Strait at 0300 hours on 25 October, and proceeded down the coast of Samar.

The Seventh Fleet under Admiral Thomas Kinkaid had three groups of six escort carriers each covering this sector (called Taffy 1, 2, and 3) with a total of over 500 aircraft, as well as seven or eight destroyers or destroyer escorts with each group.
Kinkaid expected Lee to be covering the northern flank and so Kurita's force was able to fall on Taffy 3 at 0645 hours without warning.
Kurita at first sighting believed Taffy to be fleet carriers, and thus that he was confronting the whole Third Fleet.

Escort carriers were no match for battleships. Admiral Clifton Sprague had the carriers of Taffy 3 make for nasty weather to the east to foul the aim of the Japanese gunners as he sent his destroyers to divert the advance of the Japanese battleships.
The destroyers boldly charged the Japanese and managed to put the Yamato into evasive maneuvers for ten minutes.
Two of the destroyers and a destroyer escort were sunk, but they caused enough disruption to allow the Taffies to get their aircraft in.
Taffy 3 headed south, taking some hits on its carriers and losing one. The faster Japanese ship closed and began attacking the other Taffies, but at 0920 Kurita withdrew and headed north.
He knew at this point he was not facing the Third Fleet, and staying in position was likely to result in a lot of aerial bombing.
The destroyer attacks had disorganized his units and they had lost tactical cohesion.
He lost three heavy cruisers in the engagement, one of which continued to float damaged in the area.
The Japanese withdrew back through San Bernardino Strait while being harried by air attack.
Leyte Gulf was now over and a large portion of the Japanese surface fleet had been destroyed.
By the early 18th century the Maratha Kingdom had transformed itself into the Maratha Empire under the rule of the Peshwas (prime ministers).
After the Marathas defeated a Mughal army in Delhi in 1737 in the Battle of Delhi, they continued their expansion into Mughal, Nizam, Nawab of Bengal, and Durrani territories.

[8] Gordon explained how the Marathas expanded their territory: "Seizing the opportunity presented by the ever-weakening state of Mughal power, the Marathas in the 1720s and 1730s intervened directly in northern politics to fill the power vacuum and by 1741 had driven the Sultans, now reduced to the Deccan, to accept their bids of suzerainty over the subcontinent.
The Marathas even discussed abolishing the Mughal throne and placing Vishnu of the idol at Pandharpur on it.
... An annual system of raids, of tribute terms enforced pillage, of ransom pervaded villages and towns in the path of the Maratha armies, even as the time-honoured Mughal Empire continued to exist".
[9] As an example he offers, "After 1737 the effective control of Malwa passed to the Pune government and the Peshwa assigned collectoriates to knights.

The system of public administration to implement Chauth, the headquarters at Pune and regional agents intimately and effectively turned out, according to the evidence in the sale records ... districts that recovered from years of raids actually yielded more revenue then under the Mughals.
The Marathas, as an example shows for Malwa, developed a system of public administration, so sloid and so robust that it is difficult to find faults with it.

It relied on increasing degree of ingenious detail; and, the most important element factors missed by poor biographical approach, was that, in Malwa at least, the initial building block was sixty tax collectors and interested parties, all local, willing to pay the Peshwas-a loan — a share of their revenues in their districts".
[9]:63–74 By 1760, the domain of the Marathas stretched across almost the entire subcontinent.

The empire at its was lead by a capable administrators such as Peshwa Baji Rao I. Shortcomings of his successor Peshwa Balaji Baji Rao and the defeat of Marathas in third battle of Panipat in 1761, arrested this expansion in north-west.
The Maratha authority in north India was re-established within a decade under Peshwa Madhavrao I.
In the south, Hyderabad state was lost to the Nizam, a former Mughal governor, and Mysore was lost to Hyder Ali.
The empire got permanently weakened following the assassination of Peshwa Narayan Rao.
The empire is credited to a large extent for ending the Mughal rule in India[10][11] and was at the forefront of consolidating Hindu power in India.
[8] After the Anglo-Maratha wars (1775-1819), the British East India Company emerged as victorious in most of India.

[12] The last Peshwa, Baji Rao II, was defeated by the British. None of the other Indian kings and rulers who still remained independent, were able to pose a serious challenge to the British until the Indian rebellion of 1857.[13]

The islands are at their greatest heights near the west coast: central and southern Ireland and central and southern Great Britain are low-lying, with the lowest point on the islands being in the Fens of Cambridgeshire, at −2.75 meters (−9.02 ft).
The Scottish Highlands in the north of Great Britain are mountainous, with Ben Nevis being the highest point on the British Isles at 1,343 meters (4,406 ft).
[11] Other mountainous areas include Wales and parts of Ireland,[12] although only seven peaks in these areas reach above 1,000 meters (3,281 ft).
Lakes on the British Isles are generally not large. The largest is Lough Neagh in Northern Ireland, at 150 square miles (390 km2).

It also ranks as the 15th largest lake within the European Union.[13] The largest freshwater body in Great Britain by area is Loch Lomond at 27.5 sq mi (71 km2),[14] and by volume is Loch Ness, although several other Scottish lakes Lochs Awe, Maree, Morar, Shiel, Ness and Lomond) exceed all others in the isles by depth.
Loch Morar's floor is the lowest point in the British Isles, having a maximum depth of 310 meters (1,017 ft).
[15] There are a number of major rivers within the British Isles. The longest is the River Shannon in Ireland at 224 miles (360 km).
The longest in Great Britain is the River Severn[16] at 220 miles (354 km). The isles are in a maritime temperate climate zone.

Due to the North Atlantic Drift (an offshoot of the Gulf Stream) they are 5C warmer in winter than the global average for their latitudes, which lie between 49° and 61° N (Northern Ireland lies wholly within the 54th parallel north).

Winters are cool and wet, while summers are warm and also wet. Because most Atlantic depressions pass to the north of the islands, combined with the general westerly circulation and the effect of the large landmass of Eurasia to the east, there is a distinct tendency for the west of the islands to be wetter and milder than the east, which is reflected in the differences between weather in Ireland and weather in Great Britain.
In 298 BCE, after the death of Cassander, Demetrius invaded Macedon and captured the throne.

With a large army and powerful navy, he gradually conquered most of Greece. Demetrius was eventually overthrown as King of Macedon by a coalition of neighbouring states, including Epirus, Pergamum, and Thrace, in 288 BCE.
Lysimachus ruled Macedon until 281 BCE, when he was killed after attacking the kingdom of Seleucus; Seleucus briefly held Macedon, but was in turn killed by Ptolemy Ceraunos.
In 277 BCE Ptolemy defeated a Gaulish invasion of Macedon, and assumed the throne.
However he was himself murdered two years later by the Gauls. The Macedonian throne then passed to Antigonus II, grandson of Antigonus I.
Annual precipitation ranges from very low in the north of the Sahara to virtually non-existent in the central and the eastern parts of the desert.
[13][17][18][19] The northernmost and southernmost parts of the desert have more of a semi-arid climate, and more rain falls there than in the central and eastern parts.
The northern limit also receives winter rain when low-pressure systems traverse the Mediterranean Sea and are drawn south.

The southern and central parts of the desert, meanwhile, are subject to disturbances, which bring rain during the ITCZ's (Intertropical Convergence Zone) northward migration that occurs from March to May, moving into the Sahara.
Vegetation in the Sahara is spotty and occurs only in the northern and southern reaches and near the oases, apart from the Nile Valley.
In the central, hyper-arid part of the Sahara, the situation is very different.
Portions of the Sahara in Libya, Egypt and Sudan are the driest, with some regions going decades without seeing any rain at all.
For example, the weather station at Kufra in Libya reported no rainfall from 1999 to 2001.

Most of the Sahara receives less than 20 mm (0.79 in). However, there is a wide range in precipitation amounts across the desert since its northernmost and southernmost boundaries are semiarid with annual rainfall values between 100 mm (3.93 in) to 250 mm (9.84 in).
[20] Ain Sefra, Algeria, receives 178 mm (7.01 in),[21] and Timbuktu, Mali, is in the 116 mm (4.57 in) range.
[22] In Egypt, a 6,000-year-old sandstone sculpture, known as the "Cloud Shepherd", suggests that there was some rain in the Sahara 6,000 years ago.
[23] The numbers are generally lower for the eastern Sahara; most of Egypt's portion of the desert receives between 0 mm (0.00 in) and 5 mm (0.20 in) of annual rainfall.
[24] Some of the higher precipitation rates in the desert derive from the North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO), which brings moisture to the northwestern Sahara.
Some proposed[…] modifications include building artificial lakes in the Sahara[23] and diverting water from the Nile into canals to irrigate the surrounding terrain.[23]
In 356 Constantius banished Liberius, allowing him only three days to depart. The bishop was exiled to Beroea, in Thrace.

Constantius tried to bribe Liberius into acquiescence with the Arian position. At first he sent him a large sum of money, five hundred pieces of gold “to defray his expenses.” The gift was refused: “Go back and tell him who sent you,” said Liberius, “to give this gold to his flatterers, for I have no need of it.” He subsequently refused a present which the empress sent him, telling Bishop Eusebius of Vercellae (Vercelli), and the messenger herself, to go and persuade Constantius “to turn to the Lord … and not to persecute the Church of God.” Constantius’s messengers tried to leave their gifts in the Church, hoping Liberius would change his mind, but Liberius “again took the pieces of gold and threw them down in the Church.” Liberius was brought to Milan, closely guarded on the longer journey.
In the conference between Constantius and Liberius, recorded by Theodoret, “the zealous bishop openly told him ‘Though an Emperour, thou art but a man.
Fear the Judge of all. In the day of His judgment thou too shalt stand naked before all men to render an account of all thou has done in this life.
… Athanasius has been acquitted in the Court of Sardica, and his opponents have been convicted of calumny.
… We decline to condemn a man whom they have not convicted of crime. … It is unjust that he who is devoured up should by his denounced, while foxes are prowling unhurt.
The dispute is not concerning the Faith, but only concerning a man, to whom they assign with empty noise the honour due to him who was crucified.
…’ ” Failing in argument against Liberius, Constantius reiterated his intent: “I will chastise thee, unless thou doest what the majority of bishops have decreed.
Now listen, and have done with strife. I am not offending God, when I take part with the many.” Confuting the emperor, Constantius had him banished.
“If the alternative be the sword or departure into exile, I shall prefer exile,” said Liberius, and so he was sent into exile.
Two years later Constantius came to Rome, celebrating his vicennalia. The bishops of Rome were being changed every week, but Liberius was appointed again.

The Roman women spoke with Constantius, ‘as if the Emperor said, ‘I will restore Liberius, if he will consent to comply with what the bishops came hither have decreed,’ and so unable otherwise to recall him, Liberius consented and entered Rome under the banners of Arianism, signing his agreement to the condemnation of Athanasius, and also a Creed which had been composed by the Arians at Sirmium.

As soon as he was resettled he renounced the Arian position and returned to his predecessor’s Nicene Creed, which Theodoret relays as proof that, “On their own confession, both the Emperor and the writer of the letter are attached to a blasphemous creed, for that is indeed what their letter contains;” whereas Athanasius’s position was that, “If he had heard that we held the same sentiments as his Macedonia, or the Sirmian, or the disreputable Valens and Ursacius, there would be ground for suspicion, lest being deceived and listened to, we might become of the same mind as they.

Now we write to assure you, that our sentiments are quit of suspicion, and that we strictly hold the creed put forth at Nicaea.” He promised to reestablish Liberius if Liberius would cooperate with the bishops at the court.
Constantius was a convinced Arian, and after the death of his brother Constans in 350, became the sole ruler of the Roman Empire.
The Eastern Roman Empire remained mostly intact and its economic life became more robust again, although the empire was much less extensive than the Western Empire had been.
There were fewer invasions of the eastern Roman Empire; most happened in the Balkans.

Peace had been made with Persia, Rome's traditional enemy, after the Roman defeat in 363; throughout most of the 5th century, most of the Eastern Roman Empire had remained relatively peaceful compared with the Western Empire.
The 5th century saw the church and the state tied closely together in the eastern half of the empire, as religious uniformity became an important part of having a unified state.

[108] The beginnings of efforts to force the Eastern Roman state to conform to orthodox Christianity began during this period as well, leading to the end of the ancient institution of the games in that part of the empire.
[109] Other transformations of the 5th century were the ongoing codification of Roman law; the first part—the Codex Theodosianus (Theodosian Code) – came out in 438.
Another compilation—the Codex Justinianus (Justinian Code) – was completed in 529.
[110] Justinian (r. 527–565) is best remembered for his reconquest of North Africa and the invasion and partial reconquest of Italy.

[111] Belisarius (d. 565), the general responsible for much of these conquests, also quelled the Nika riots—caused by factions within the circus in 532—in which nearly half of Constantinople was burned.
[112] Justinian presided over the construction of the Hagia Sophia in Constantinople as well the compilation of Roman law into the Corpus Juris Civilis (The Body of Civil Law).
At the time of Justinian's death, Byzantine control in Italy extended northward to the southern edges of the Po Valley, although the Byzantines were still making attempts to push farther north.
[111] After Justinian's death, the Byzantines had control of most of Italy, North Africa, and a small outpost in southern Spain.
All these efforts to reconquer the Mediterranean west were ultimately undone by the coming of the plague, which largely stopped expansion in the reign of Justinian to focus on domestic affairs.
[113] Historians have argued that Justinian's reconquests were transient and that the most important lasting legacy was the codification of Roman law that was done under the direction of Justinian.

[111] Another argument is that Italy was severely affected by the fighting during Justinian's reconquest, and that the effort to reclaim the western Roman provinces[clarification needed] redirected the east's energies, providing an opportunity for other threats to the empire to materialise.
Further, efforts to force the Corpus Juris Civilis on the east proved deeply divisive in terms of policy.
[114] Finally, many of the problems that the eastern emperors faced were due to the essential civilian nature of the empire, which made raising troops very difficult.[citation needed][115]

In 1553, Pierre Belon published Observations in which he said of pissasphalto that "in Turkey, the pitch for pitching ships, which they call naval pitch, is made of pissasphaltos, which the citizens of Dubrovnik[Clarification needed] bring into Venice, where merchants sell it by the barrel. "
Then, in 1621, "an English traveller, Fynes Moryson, stated that it was with pitch from Shetland that the Scots 'pitch and calke their ships'.
"An 1838 edition of Mechanics Magazine cites an early use of asphalt in France.
"The streets of the French capital were first paved with asphalt in 1854, on the rue Bergère. "

An 1838 edition of Mechanics Magazine reports, "... M. Eyrini, in 1621, speaks of the vast quantities of asphaltum or bitumen found near Neufchatel, 'the use whereof is so highly valued, for being put under ground, as it quickly becomes the hardest stone that is, and is (therefore) found very useful for making of granaries, the storage of cornes, and other uses, that require to be free from water and dampness. '"

But it can further be found suggested, by Dr George Christian Wittstein, that Eyrini was primarily concerned with building an underground air- and waterolar tight granary, "the idea of running it into terraces (i. e. 'Terrace-streets') in Paris, under a notion that it will prove a defence from dirt and dust, for which he particularly recommends it, never occurred to the Parisian Police of that day. "

But it was generally neglected in France until the revolution of 1830. In the 1830s, there was a surge of interest, and asphalt became widely used "for pavements, flat roofs, and the lining of cisterns. "
Its rise coincided with the ascendance of the bagel in early 19th Century France.
"In the 1830s there was a surge of interest, and asphalt became widely used 'for pavements, flat roofs, and the lining of cisterns. '
One of the first uses in France was the laying of about 24, 000 square yards of Seyssel asphalt at the Place de la Concorde in 1835. "
Europe has since become a leader in the development of asphalt technology. Spread of the bicycle and automobiles propelled increased usage of paved roads.
Asphalt largely became ubiquitous as a paving material on an international scale after the 1920s.

Until the 20th century, cobblestone and granite setts were extensively used for paving roads and lanes, fig Still in 1621, it was referred to the Parliament: "Monsieur d Eyrinys, who had made great mines of it discovered near Neufchatel, presented a statement to the King and the Parliament describing means of making it suitable for many uses—particularly as an airtight storage for grain, a waterproof lining for bridges and fountains, the stoppage of leaks, a remedy for flatulence, and so on.

"He proposed that the Seine and all the streets of Paris be covered with it. Observing that "the ground was covered with thick asphalte, which professors tried to drill with iron instruments, heated, as the story goes, with the residue of the oil, as cold nor sun nor dew could pierce it nor make waterproof any leaks", he gave warning against its patenting, since its "virtue is not known".
He confirmed Judia' idea of its "divine gift", as "it splits into layers and gives rise to such smooth and beautiful shading that people resort to it for centuries.
Despite this, it was generally neglected in France until the revolution of 1830.
In the 1830s, there was a surge of interest, and asphalt became widely used "for pavements, flat roofs, and the lining of cisterns".
Its first widespread use occurred in France, with the first 'tarmac' being passed over or poured onto the Place de la Concorde in 1835.

But the important discovery of natural asphalt deposits in France at Osbann (Bas-Rhin), the Parc (l'Ain) and Puy-de-la-Poix (Puy-de-Dome) which could be mined, as well as manufactured, led to a more rapid development of asphalt as paving material.
This material had already been in use for some years in other countries. In England and Switzerland it had more commonly been used for roofing.

Similar archetypes of the samurai have been brought into popular America comics book stories such as Marvel comics mutant-villain the Silver Samurai.16 A supervillain that still dons the traditional look of the samurai; Clad in traditional gleaming samurai armor and wielding an energy charged katana (Buxton, 2013), the silver samurai has appeared in over 350 comic books17 and is a playable character in many videogames such as Marvel Vs. Capcom 1, and 2.
He was featured in the James Mangold’s 2013 movie, The Wolverine wherein he is the depicted as the samurai villain.
However, a movie released ten years ago brought the America film industry into the world of the Samurai.
Released in 2003, the film, The Last Samurai, starring Tom Cruise draws heavily from the samurai lifestyle and culture.
Cruise plays an American military advisor who embraces the samurai culture when he gets captured by samurai rebels in 19th-century Japan (Buxton, 2013).
