The character Nathan Algren was designed to make nineteenth-century Japanese history palatable and comprehensible to the American audience (Ravina, 2010).
Captured by the samurai rebels, and under developing Stockholm Syndrome, Cruise's character begins to sympathize with his captors and befriend them.
Taking place in the Meiji Period, Cruise plays US Army Captain Nathan Algren, who is hired to help an inexperienced army put down samurai rebels in Japan.
Aftervintegrating into his new surroundings Algren soon becomes part of the samurai in order to help rescue a captured leader.
By the end of the film, he has clearly adopted many samurai traits, such as zen-like sword mastery and a budding understanding of spirituality (Manion, 2006).

The country which we now call Galicia appears to have first been inhabited during the Middle Paleolithic period, as is attested by the local flint tools culture which followed the Mousterian industry settlement.
Galicia's name comes from the Gallaeci, the Celtic people living north of the Douro river during the last millennium BC -, the culture of these Castro people overlaps with the local Bronze Age.
After the Cantabrian Wars, which ended in 19 BC, Galicia was incorporated into the Roman Empire; being made into a Roman province in the 3rd century AD.
In 410 the Germanic Suebi established a kingdom with its capital in Braga, now in Portugal, which was incorporated into that of the Visigoths in 585.
In 711 the Arabs and Berbers invaded and conquered the Visigothic kingdom; until Galicia, in 740, joined the Christian kingdom of Asturias.

During the Middle Ages Galicia is sometimes found having its own rulers, although most of the time it remained united to the kingdom of Leon - later annexed to the kingdom of Castille, while maintaining its own traditional legal system and culture.
From the 13th century, the kings of Castile, as kings of Galicia, appointed an Adiantado-mór.
The functions of this office eventually passed to the Governor and Captain General of the Kingdom of Galicia in the late 15th century.
The Governor presided over the Real Audiencia do Reino de Galicia, a royal tribunal and government body.

From the 16th century the representation of the kingdom of Galicia before the king of Castille and his government was taken by an assembly of deputies from the cities of the kingdom, the Cortes or Junta of the Kingdom of Galicia.
This institution was suppressed and the Kingdom of Galicia divided into four administrative provinces in 1833, with no legal mutual links.

[1] The 19th and 20th centuries saw a growing call for self-government and for the formal recognition of the cultural differences of Galicia, resulting in the 1936 proposed Statute of Autonomy (never enacted) and the presently enacted Statute of Autonomy of 1981. Contents
Given that their privileges and powers were being revoked, Wu Sangui, later aided by Geng Zhongming and Shang Kexi's son, Shang Zhixin, had little choice but to revolt.

The ensuing civil war lasted for eight years. Wu tried to invoke anti-Manchu sentiment by restoring Ming customs, ordering that Ming-style clothing be worn, and even revoking the hated queues in the areas under his control.
He also declared himself emperor of a new "Zhou dynasty", in the hope of reviving the Ming dynasty.
At the peak of their strength, the three rebels were able to extend their reach as far north as the Yangtze, almost establishing a divided China.
However, Wu was not able to coordinate his strategy with his other allies, and he did not press further north, allowing Kangxi to deploy his armies against the three Southern Courts one by one.
After their defeat, the southern parts of China, especially Sichuan and the areas around the Yangtze River, were devastated by the war.
It would take several decades for these areas to recover.[63] Initially, the Manchus and Bannermen were outmatched by Wu's forces, so the Qing government enlisted the help of the southern Chinese.
Kangxi writes in his memoirs:[64] Generals Sun Sike, Wang Jinbao, and Zhao Liangdong were all Han Chinese.
They led the Green Standard soldiers to fight the rebels. The Qing thought that Han Chinese were better at battling and defeating other Han people.
Hence they let the Han Chinese lead the Green Standard Army as the primary military force and used the Bannermen as support.

[65] In northwestern China against Wang Fuchen, the Qing used Han Chinese soldiers from the Green Standard Army and Han Chinese generals such as Zhang Liangdong, Wang Jinbao, and Zhang Yong to crush the rebels.
The Qing put Bannermen on the sidelines since the terrain was unsuitable for cavalry, which Bannermen specialized in, and used Han Chinese as the main force.

Sichuan and Southern Shaanxi were retaken by the Han Chinese Green Standard Army under Wang Jinbao and Zhao Liangdong in 1680, with Manchus only participating in dealing with logistics and provisions.
[66] 400,000 Green Standard Army soldiers and 150,000 Bannermen served on the Qing side during the war.
[64] In the later part of the war, the Qing armies were composed entirely of Han Chinese soldiers and Han Chinese generals.
[67] It was Green Standard Army soldiers who entered Taiwan and defeated the Ming loyalist Zheng Keshuang's grandson, receiving Zheng's surrender; the Qing did not allow Bannermen to enter Taiwan.

213 Han companies and 527 Mongol and Manchu companies were mobilized by the Qing against the Three Feudatories, while 400,000 Green Standard Army soldiers were mobilized and 200,000 served in the war.
[68] Only 146 Bannerman companies from the Eight Banners were mobilized by the Qing during the entire war.[69]
The widely-dispersed Seleucid realm was far less stable than Egypt, and the Greco-Macedonian element of the population less dominant.
Like Ptolemaic Egypt, the ruling Greco-Macedonian aristocracy remained a largely urban elite, although it was bolstered by influxes of immigrants from the Greek cities.

Such cities were new foundations, like Antioch, and the Syrian tetrapolis, or Greek colonies such as Seleucia (to the north of Babylon) and Dura-Europos on the Euphrates, or were local towns which were refounded and settled with Greeks.
The Greek cities remained independent, but such independence was on the whole reserved for the Greeks themselves.
They were ruled locally by councils (boule), magistrates, and assemblies (ecclesia), but power lay with the ruling royal officials.
In addition to the cities, there were also a number of Seleucid garrisons (choria), military colonies (katoikiai) and Greek villages (komai), set up for the purposes of domination.

The Greco-Macedonian portion of the population (including some who had originated with intermarriage between the settlers and local women; but counted as Greek) could be considerable, but never as large as the native populations – in a military parade at Daphnae in the reign of Antiochos III, the phalanx numbered 35,000 men out of a total Seleucid army of 80,000, with the remainder consisting of native troops.

Antiochos III (reigned 222–187) launched several aggressive campaigns to retake lost provinces, and to once again compete with Egypt; despite a reversal in 217 when the Seleucids were defeated at Raphia by Ptolemy IV's forces, Antiochos continued his attempts to reclaim the old Achaemenid Persian possessions of Anatolia.

His most spectacular success came in the eastern provinces, which had become quite unprofitable to control since the days of Seleucus I: between 212–205 Antiochos mounted an enormous campaign by way of forced and perseverance against Bactria, Parthia, Ariana, Sogdiana, Gedrosia, and Drangiana; in the process he returned the old provinces of the Persian Empire to nominal subjecthood, whilst permitting the local satraps an unprecedented degree of autonomy.
After the death of Ptolemy IV in 204, Antiochos took advantage of instability in Egypt to conquer Coele-Syria in the fifth Syrian war (202–195).
Despite being heralded as a liberator in several Greek cities in Asia, and having himself named "king of kings" by an assembly at Antioch, his efforts were ultimately unsuccessful.
His invasion of Pergamene territory in Asia, and his movement into Europe, where he refounded the city of Lysimachia on the Hellespont, brought Roman interest.

Antiochos seems to have lacked the will to oppose the Romans sufficiently, and after an unsuccessful war (the Roman–Syrian War, 192–188), the Treaty of Apamea ended Seleucid expansion in Asia Minor and Anatolia; he was forced to pay a heavy indemnity of 15,000 talents.
The history of modern collegiate a cappella is murky, but organized a cappella groups have been around for over a century.
The longest continuously-operating group is probably The Rensselyrics [1] of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, which was founded in 1873 as the RPI Glee Club.
[citation needed] The Yale Whiffenpoofs were formed in 1909 and are arguably the best-known group, having been featured on the long-running television show The Sing-Off.
Cole Porter was a member of the Whiffenpoofs, and they have retained their ties with the dominant musical theater tradition over the years.
Throughout the 20th century a cappella developed a presence on numerous college campuses, with many groups once again having their roots in the traditional college glee club.

The Princeton Nassoons date back to 1941, the Colgate 13 to 1942, the Dartmouth Aires to 1946, the MIT Chorallaries to 1946, the Harvard Krokodiloes to 1946, the Cornell University Cayuga's Waiters to 1949, The Madison Project of James Madison University to 1952, the University of Maine Steiners to 1957, the Yale Spizzwinks(?)
to 1914, Jabberwocks of Brown University to 1949, the University of Rochester YellowJackets to 1956, and the Georgetown Chimes to 1946.
Shortly after their all-male counterparts emerged in their respective schools, all-female ensembles were formed in response, often parodying the names of the original male ensembles.

Examples include the Smiffenpoofs (founded in 1936 at Smith College), The Shwiffs (The “She-Whiffenpoofs”) of Connecticut College (founded in 1944), and The Chattertocks of Brown University (founded in 1951).

The Aires and Brovertones merged to become the Dartmouth Cords. The exponential growth of a cappella in the 1990s has been attributed to two factors: the contemporaneous emergence of groups that embraced a new style, with vocals imitating electric guitar, trumpet, bass, and even vocal percussion or “beatboxing,” and the publication and access to recorded a cappella music through the website CASA.org run by the Contemporary A Cappella Society.
The Tufts Beelzebubs and the Boston University Dear Abbeys (named after the advice columnists) were two of the earliest groups to integrate these new stylistic changes into their repertoires.
Most collegiate groups are either all-male or all-female, although some feature both male and female singers.
Many combine a light-hearted atmosphere and the styles and music of their times with more traditional and classical pieces that showcase their technical skills.

There are numerous longstanding traditions, including many groups that “call-out” new members when they are tapped to the group, a smaller sub-group that persists in many a cappella groups as documented by Mickey Rapkin in his book, Pitched Perfect: The Pursuit of Collegiate A Cappella Glory.

[2] There are several recognized historical categories for collegiate a cappella groups, including Christian (such as Carolina Harmony, the oldest Christian group in existence), Jewish, fraternity and sorority (Sweetheart Singers, Hearttohearts, and Acafellas), barbershop (such as Ball in the House), and international (Caius College Cambridge and the Oxford Alternotives).
Most of these groups are not collegiate in nature and are more likely to be identified as part of the broader a cappella scene and movement.
Many are semi-professional and tour extensively, often performing at private gigs in concert halls and at large a cappella festivals.

The Georgetown Chimes, for example, have hosted an annual Cherry Tree Massacre concert for over 100 collegiate a cappella groups over three weekends in February since 1975, with notable performances by International Quartet Champions The Boston Common and commercial a cappella group Rockapella.
[3][4] Mainstream pop and rock groups associated with collegiate a cappella include The Whiffenpoofs, the Tufts Beelzebubs, the Yale Spizzwinks(?

), the University of Virginia Gentlemen of the College, the Penn University Counterparts, the Harvard Veritones, the Stanford Fleet Street Singers, the Yale Redhot & Blue, the Bowdoin Longfellows, the Tufts University Amalgamates, the Tufts University Turkeys, the Columbia Kingston Kingsmen, the Phillips Academy Brovertones, and the Dartmouth Aires.

[citation needed] There are records of notable co-ed groups as well, such as the University of Pennsylvania Cup of Cold Water (founded in 1972 by Mac Silver, Jamie Borja, and Lynne Cohen), the Dartmouth Cords (a co-ed group founded in 1977), and the Harvard Veritones (a co-ed group founded in 1985).
Many a cappella groups are associated with notable musicians, including John Legend,[5] Dr. Ramani,[6] Renée Fleming,[7] and many others.
For example, Mira Sorvino (an accomplished actress) was a member of the Harvard Veritones and performed a plaintive solo on "Only You" by Yaz.
[8] Sara Bareilles, the popular recording artist with a hit 2007 song “Love Song,” started in the UCLA-based co-ed group Awaken A Cappella.[9]

As with reptiles, the excretory system of birds is similar to that of mammals, but unlike mammals or ornithic reptiles, they are primarily uricotelic, that is their kidneys extract nitrogenous waste from their bloodstream and excrete it as uric acid, instead of urea or ammonia, through the ureters into the intestine.
They do not have a urinary bladder or external urethral opening, (nor did the ornithic dinosaurs), but instead excrete their uric acid along with feces as a semisolid waste.
However, birds such as hummingbirds can be facultatively ammonotelic, excreting most of the nitrogenous wastes as ammonia.
Birds excrete creatine rather than creatinine like mammals.[129] All birds have a cloaca, a multipurpose orifice, used for urination, defecation, copulation and egg-laying.
[130] Most bird species regurgitate pellets.[131] The cloaca is an opening, into which the urinary, genital and gastrointestinal tracts open.

[132] The outer rectal area is the proctodeum,[133] which stores the excreta. Many male birds, such as Palaeognathae, (but not the kiwi[134]), Anseriformes, (but not the Anhimidae[135]), and to a lesser extent Galliformes, have a phallus, which is never present in Neoaves.
[136] The length is thought to be related to sperm competition.[137] and is inverted when not in use. It is stored within the proctodeum.
[138] The digestive system of birds is unique, with a crop for storage and a gizzard that contains swallowed stones for grinding food to compensate for the lack of teeth.

Most birds are highly adapted for rapid digestion to aid with flight.[129] Some migratory birds have adapted to use protein stored in many parts of their bodies, including protein from the intestines, as additional energy during migration.

An adolescent's environment also holds a major role in identity formation. While most data has been used on white middle class adolescent children, there has been a direct relationship between higher privileged living and healthy achieved identity formation.
This last stage of identity formation among adolescents is the most defining point in adolescent's life.
Their recent studies have found that the transition to adulthood is a lengthier life stage now than in the 1950s and 1960s.
Youth (late adolescence through early adulthood) has become a more prominent life stage and therefore many make much more influential variables in development.

There are an array of contributing factors to the formation of an adolescent's social identity, such as commitment, coping skills, and social networking that come into play and are affected by environment.
Privileged children are more likely to be exposed to optimal circumstances and provisions.
Inner city and crime ridden areas pose risks to the merits of adolescent optimum conditions.
Adolescence is the most crucial stages of a child's development and corruption around this time may or may not lead to poor future decisions.

Alternatively, suburban areas are less likely to see immoral conditions, but instead more likely to participate in increased identity forming, leaving adolescents with more healthy identity status diagnoses.
After a three-year hiatus, the fifth Digimon series consisted of forty-eight episodes, first aired in Japan on April 2, 2006.
Like Digimon Frontier, Digimon Savers is separate from the other Digimon series, and follows in a different universe.
It features a different art style, with a more mature storyline that can appeal to wider audiences, revolving around the members of an organization called D.A.T.S.
(Digital Accident Tactics Squad), which tries to keep the existence of the Digital World and the Digimon from the rest of humanity and solve any Digimon-related incidents occurring on Earth.
D.A.T.S. becomes involved in a feud between the human and Digital Worlds, initiated by a human scientist named Akihiro Kurata who wants to use the Digimon for his own purposes.
The English dub, produced by Studiopolis, began airing on Jetix on Toon Disney on October 1, 2007.
Digivolution in Data Squad requires human DNA (Digital Natural Ability in the English (called Digisoul in the Japanese), in addition to empathy and willpower on the part of the human partner.
Digimon Savers also introduces the Burst Mode, a digivolving form higher than Mega level, which used to be the last one.

As with Digimon Tamers, the story takes on a darker and more mature tone. It was originally aimed at audiences in Japan from age 16 to 21, but to comply with the intended target audience of 6 to 10 for the English dubs, which received a rating of TV-Y7-FV, Studiopolis extensively edited, localized and censored the material.

The name of the main character in the English version was alliteratively changed to Marcus Damon (from Daimon Masaru), one of several interpretations adapted to be Americanized and localized (for example, notes for the students in Japan in English, foreigner with English names, born in the United States, etc.
), Miyama Neon's name was changed to Martin. As well, elements unfamiliar to American culture were not explained, for example manju.
Other elements were too literal, so names of attacks of RizeGreymon too difficult to change remained as its Japanese name with Trident Revolver.
Like Digimon Tamers and Digimon Frontier, in was released on DVD by Well Go USA instead of Disney.
[27] Instead of Toon Disney in Canada, the North American English dubbed version was aired on the Family Channel.[28]

During this period, the political structure of western Europe changed. While the peoples who moved into the Empire during this period are often described as "invaders", they were not simply military expeditions but migrations of entire peoples into the empire.
These movements were aided by the refusal of the western ruling classes to support the army or pay the taxes that would have allowed the military to suppress the migrations.

The emperors of the 5th century were often controlled by military strongmen such as Stilicho , Aspar , Ricimer , and Gundobad , who were at least partially from the non-Roman peoples and after the deposition of the last western emperor, a series of kings took over in the western provinces.
There was a high degree of contact between the kings and the Roman elites, as well as the two cultures blending together, rather than a sudden replacement of one culture with another.
Synthesis was a longstanding tradition in the Roman state, due to the widespread dissimilarity of the cultures within the empire .
Many of the new kings and rulers had been or were Roman military officers already, and there were many cases of intermarriage between Roman and non-Roman families.
This led to a blending of cultures, which included the popular assemblies that allowed free male members of the tribe more say in political matters than had been usual in the Roman state.
Artefacts left by the Romans and the invaders are often similar, with tribal items often being obviously modelled on Roman objects.
Likewise, much of the intellectual culture of the new kingdoms was also based on Roman intellectual traditions.
An important difference was the gradually declining tax revenue available to the new rulers.

Many of the new polities no longer provided their armies with tax revenues, instead allocating land or rents as the means of supporting troops, thus causing the soldiery to become an increasingly land-owning class, doing away with the need for large taxes.
This also, of course, reduced the need for a large slave-owning class supporting intricate taxation systems.
Warfare was common between and within the kingdoms. Slavery declined as the supply waned .
The United Nations General Assembly recommended the adoption and implementation of the Partition Plan (Resolution 181) as a Plan of Partition with Economic Union for Mandatory Palestine.

On 29 November 1947, the General Assembly of the United Nations adopted the Plan of Partition (Resolution 181) regarding the future government of Palestine, which recommended the creation of independent Arab and Jewish States and a Special International Regime in the city of Jerusalem placed under the sovereignty of no state, which would be administered by the United Nations.

[69][70] The British mandate was set to expire on 1 August 1948, but the British Government announced on 14 May 1948: "His Majesty's Government in the United Kingdom will cease to be responsible for the administration of Palestine from midnight 14 May 1948."

12 minutes after the cessation of the British Mandate for Palestine at midnight on 14 May 1948, the leader of the Zionist Organization in Palestine (the Jewish Agency), and later first prime minister of Israel[71][72] David Ben-Gurion proclaimed the State of Israel.
[73][74] The borders of the new state were not specified in the declaration.[75] Neighboring Arab states invaded the former Palestinian mandate on the next day and fought the Israeli forces.

[76] Since then Israel has fought several wars with neighbouring Arab states,[77] in the course of which it has occupied the West Bank, Sinai Peninsula (from 1956 to 1957 and 1967 to 1982), part of Southern Lebanon (1982–2000), Gaza Strip (1967–2005, still considered occupied after 2005 disengagement) and the Golan Heights.
It extended its laws to the Golan Heights and East Jerusalem, but not the West Bank.
[78][79] Israel's occupation of Gaza, the West Bank and East Jerusalem is the longest military occupation in modern times.
[80] Efforts to resolve the Israeli–Palestinian conflict have not resulted in peace.
However, peace treaties between Israel and both Egypt and Jordan have been signed.[81][82][83]
Worried about the resurgence of Polish nationalism and displeased by the Continental System, Russia's withdrawal from the coalition led to a new war.
To enforce the system, Napoleon launched an invasion of Russia in the summer of 1812.

The campaign destroyed the Grand Army, forced the French to retreat, and resulted in the destruction of much of Russian territory through a scorched earth policy credited to Prince Mikhail Kutuzov and other commanders.
In 1813, Prussia and Austria joined Russian forces in a Sixth Coalition against France.
A chaotic military campaign culminated in a large Allied army defeating Napoleon at the Battle of Leipzig in October 1813.
The Allies then invaded France and captured Paris in the spring of 1814, forcing Napoleon to abdicate in April.
He was exiled to the island of Elba. The Bourbons were restored to power and a peace treaty was signed.
Napoleon escaped from Elba in February 1815 and took control of France once again.
European powers formed a Seventh Coalition in response and defeated him at the Battle of Waterloo in June.
The Royal Navy then blockaded France, but Napoleon escaped to the United States in July, where he surrendered to the British.
They exiled him to the remote island of Saint Helena in the Atlantic Ocean. Napoleon died there in 1821 at the age of 51, his death widely spread and mourned throughout Europe.
In 1840, his remains were brought to Paris in a massive crowd of a million, and he was interred in Les Invalides.
Since annelids are soft-bodied, their fossils are rare. Polychaetes' fossil record consists chiefly of the calcareous tubes that some of the species secreted and the jaws that some had.
[20] Some Ediacaran fossils such as Dickinsonia appear to some eyes rather like polychaetes,[22] but these similarities are not sufficiently precise to support a close relationship.

[20] The small shelly fossil Cloudina, from 549 to 542 million years ago at the end of the Ediacaran, has been classified by some authors as an annelid and by others as a cnidarian (jellyfish, sea anemones, etc.).
[23] Until 2008, the oldest widely accepted annelid fossils were polychaetes from the early Cambrian, about 518 million years ago.
There were several good specimens from the Burgess Shale, about 505 million years ago in the middle Cambrian.

[20] There have been reports of annelid fossils from the Sirius Passet, which is about 518 million years old; however, these fossils are poorly preserved, and it is difficult to tell whether they are really annelids.

[22] Myoscolex, from Australia's Emu Bay Shale, about 515 million years old, appears on close examination to share some features with modern annelids but lacks others and has features not found in any living annelid.
Simon Conway Morris described over 1,130 fossil specimens of polychaetes in the Burgess Shale and another 49 species in the Early Ordovician (about 488 to 474 million years ago) Soom Shale.
[22] Later, Conway Morris and John Peel described Phragmochaeta from the early Cambrian Sirius Passet as the oldest known annelid.
[24] Cotton and Lewis[25] reported a probably polychaete from Australia two or three million years older than Phragmochaeta.
In 2008, a new polychaete fossil with biomineralised plates was reported in Australia, named as Canadia spinosa, from the same type as the Burgess Shale Canadia worms.
There is continuing debate about whether the Burgess Shale fossil Wiwaxia was a mollusc or annelid.
[21][26] Polychaetes diversified in the early Ordovician period, 488 to 474 million years ago, when the first jawed forms appeared.

[20] On the other hand, fossils of most of the groups that formed the crown group of modern annelids, including both mobile and tube-forming polychaetes and the earliest oligochaetes (in freshwater in this period), all appeared by the end of the Carboniferous, about 299 million years ago.

Many fossil tubes look like those of modern tube-dwelling polychaetes:[20] the earliest such fossils are Cloudina, from 549 to 542 million years ago, and there is a gap after them until the appearance of Serpula in the Early Jurassic, less than 199 million years ago.
However, it is difficult to tell whether tube fossils were produced by annelids, since similar tubes were produced in the Cambrian period by some pogonophorans.[21]
Even though various sciences such as calligraphic, oral and intellectual were taught in the Ottoman madaris , the original purpose of these schools were to be an Islamic spiritual learning center.
Religion prioritized the significance of sciences, and the ultimate essence was the knowledge of God.
İnalcık writes: Those which aid religion are good, and sciences like astrology are bad.

Although logic and mathematics were included in many of those sciences, they were studied under the influence of religion because they believed that there are certain religious truths which are discovered by learning them.
Moreover, İnalcık writes that even philosophy was studied in order to prove the thesis of Islam.
Thus, madaris were originally the religious centers to educate Islamic knowledge in the early modern Ottoman Empire.

Even though many historians, such as Charles E. Goffman , would argue that the Ottomans were very tolerant and lived under a diverse society, it was the case that these schools were founded to educate Ottoman children in Islam but not in other religions.
However, this was almost identical to what occurred in Europe. Jewish children were taught to pray in Hebrew at their homes and Torah at the schools run by the synagogues.
Protestant Catholicism also transmitted proper religious values according to Wiesner-Hanks.
In this sense, it could be interpreted that the Ottoman emphasis on religion in the school bears similarity to what occurred in early modern Europe.

Subjects taught in madaris from the middle of Ottoman Empire were quite varied even relatively to the present forms of the schools. However, they were studied for reinforcing Islamic religion and practices.
As the second Digimon series, it moved forward one generation from the previous Digimon games.
The series began airing in Japan on April 2, 2000. It features a new team of DigiDestined who join a few returning characters (T.K.
and Kari) from the first series, travelling back and forth between the Human and Digital Worlds to save both from evil.
Much like the first season, several changes to the appearance of the Digital World and to the general programme format would be made, though on a heavier scale.
Season Two occupies the same continuity as Adventure. Season Three and onwards takes place in an alternate universe.
In Digi Destined Go to School, it has been three years since the original DigiDestined battled Apocalymon and most of the kids are now fourteen and attending high school.
They believe the Digital World to be safe and contain only good Digimon, until evil returns in the form of the Digimon Emperor (Digimon Kaiser in the Japanese version) who enslaves most of the world.
Unlike past foes, the Digimon Emperor is a human like the DigiDestined, and uses Dark Rings and Control Spires to digivolve his captive Digimon and force them to obey his every command.
Normal digivolution being impossible, the Digimon bestow five Digi-Eggs with engraved emblems of power on three new DigiDestined, as well as T.K.
and Kari from the previous series. These Digi-Eggs allow their chosen DigiDestined to perform a new type of evolution called Armor Digivolution to combat the evil in the Digital World.
After destroying the Control Spires, the DigiDestined defeat the Digimon Emperor whose real name is Ken Ichijouji on Earth.

However, Ken's Digimon partner Wormmon is killed in the process. Shortly after that, new Digimon enemies created from the deactivated Control Spires by another evil force begin to play havoc on the Digital World.
By now Ken has come to regret his actions and joins the DigiDestined with his revived Wormmon to make amends.

Together, they save countries like France and Australia among others from the evil power of the Control Spires and defeat Myotismon's digivolved form from the previous series, MaloMyotismon (BelialVamdemon in the Japanese version), fascinating viewers and saving both worlds from destruction. In the final episodes, everyone on Earth has a Digimon partner of their own.
Critics charged that Gaddafi was "despotic, cruel, arrogant, vain, and stupid," and that while claiming to be a man of the people he actually ruled in an authoritarian manner.
Western governments and media presented him as the "vicious dictator of an oppressed people."
During the Reagan administration, the United States regarded Gaddafi as "public enemy No. 1", and Reagan dubbed him the "mad dog of the Middle East".

Critics believed that Gaddafi was prevented from leaving office by his government-imposed fear over dissenters through intimidation, although Gaddafi claimed that he would have retired long ago but for his obligation to liberate the Palestinian people.
According to critics, Libyans living under Gaddafi feared the government's pervasive abuse of human rights.
Gaddafi's Libya was typically described by western commentators as a "police state".
Opponents accused Gaddafi's administration of enacting a number of egregious human rights abuses.
According to Human Rights Watch (HRW) and others, hundreds of Libyans were incarcerated for political reasons, with some having been tortured, forced to confess, and sentenced in unfair trials.
HRW also criticized laws that criminalized "insulting public officials" or the Libyan state.
Some Libyans were arrested and executed for alleged participation in the 1980s attempted anti-Gaddafist coup.
Of these, many had gone abroad into exile, but not all of those targeted in this manner were dissidents; Libya's Berber minority faced harsh persecution.
Many of those arrested faced torture and other inhumane treatment in the country's jails, while hundreds were executed in extrajudicial killings.
Most killings occurred in the notorious Abu Salim prison, including an alleged massacre in June 1996, when, according to HRW, 1,270 prisoners were killed.
Dissidents abroad were labelled "stray dogs"; they were publicly threatened with death and sometimes killed by government hit squads.
Gaddafi was also condemned for his government's treatment of non-Arab Libyans, in particular native Berbers, but also Italians and Jews, as well as black immigrants from sub-Saharan Africa.

Journalist Annick Cojean and psychologist Seham Sergewa reported that Gaddafi and some senior officials raped and illegally imprisoned hundreds or thousands of young women, as well as allegedly several of his female bodyguards.
Gaddafi's administration was also criticised for the many basic civil liberties it denied to the Libyan people.
Freedom House consistently rated Libya as "Not Free" in its annual Freedom in the World index.
According to several surveys in Europe and the United States, green is the color most commonly associated with nature, life, health, youth, spring, hope and envy.
In the European Union and the US, green can mean death in the English language of the Middle Ages.
Green is also associated with the devil, in the painting "Inferno" by Hans Memling, and others. In China, green is associated with fertility.
Green also represents infidelity, which is symbolized by a green hat. A green , lustrous pigeon is regarded as a symbol of happiness.
In several religions, green is the color associated with resurrection and regeneration.

In the Middle Ages and Renaissance, the color of clothing showed a person's social rank and profession: green was used for the gentry, merchants, bankers and the bourgeoisie, while red was the color of nobility.
The Mona Lisa by Leonardo da Vinci wears green, showing she is not from noble family; the benches in the British House of Commons are green, while those in the House of Lords are red.
Green is universally associated with safety; a green light means go ahead, a green card permits permanent residence in the United States.
Green is the most important color in Islam. It was the color of the banner of Muhammad, and is found in the flags of nearly all Islamic countries.
It is said that the inhabitants of Paradise wear green. Green is also traditionally associated with Ireland and Gaelic culture.
It is a color of the flag of Ireland. Because of its association with nature, it is the color of the environmental movement.
Political groups advocating protection of the environment use the term 'green' as qualifying adjective, and in the USA they are formally named the Green Party.
This association has triggered the use of the term for products and practices that are environmentally friendly.
Companies have sold green, i.e., environmentally friendly, products and services.
The novel has been noted for its poignancy in terms of the era in which it was written.

Texts and documentaries on the history of the era often mention Lee's novel only in passing, associating it with the civil rights movement that was gaining momentum at the same time; the novel has been cited as a factor in the movement's success.
"To Kill a Mockingbird in some ways set the agenda for the civil rights movement in the 1960s," said Bob Moses, a civil rights leader who worked with the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee.

William T. Going believes the novel, while holding merit, "arrived at the right time to help the South and the nation realize some of the problems that had arisen with the quickening of the civil rights movement."

The publication of the novel is considered by many to be intimately connected with the beginnings of the Civil Rights Movement in the U.S., with more written on the book's connections to the movement than on the book itself.
Many social, literary, and personal accounts, essays, and books have been written since its publication on the people and events in the book.

Biographies of Lee, analyses of the novel, and materials created for the classroom explore many of the lessons that can be taught with the novel, its influence on the movement, and the connection of the Civil Rights Movement to the story; e.g., as in "Critical Insights: To Kill a Mockingbird" (2010) and "Scout, Atticus & Boo: A Celebration of Fifty Years of To Kill a Mockingbird" (2010), which provide extensive commentary and analyses focusing on the book's messages and how they are conveyed.

In addition, many authors and readers have commented that the book gives true, memorable, and noteworthy examples and representations to the personal, political, and social issues at play at the time in the U.S. Civil Rights Movement.
Civil Rights leader Andrew Young states the book's message is, for many, "the inspiration that pulled us all together.
This is history as we need to understand it in America: an inspiration to think differently about everything that went on and continues to go on in the world.
The book and its history are understandably an inspiration to anyone who wants to understand the racial injustice of this country."
Young said that the book brings out the "best exemplars of the old South," and it represents "not that the Jim Crow system worked for black people but the people best worked it."

He also states that the book can teach "hope" to civil rights groups and others of system changes centered on communities "not by chaotic and kicking-in-the-door activities, but by the subject matter of education in self-discipline."

He highlights that the book "inspires hope out of the madness and confusion" and its racial slurs are not offensive in the context of the book but rather utilized to loosely represent the era in which the book is set.
Young states the novel is "an act of humanity" in showing the possibility of people rising above their prejudices.
Alabama-born author Mark Childress said, "To Kill a Mockingbird gives white Southerners a way to understand our history and our racism.
It is a novel that is so deeply influential that a prominent librarian recently said 'the book is our conscience; the movie was our black-and-white Bible.'
Our Bible as a metaphor seems suitable because, like the Good Book, the story told in Harper Lee’s classic novel changed the world.
Nobody could argue with the dark inspiration of Uncle Tom’s Cabin, which is widely believed by historians to have ignited the U.S. Civil War.
But To Kill a Mockingbird was about white people. Many whites in the South were good people; they didn’t riot or tweet or dynamite churches.
The novel showed them where the holes were in their own system in a way that thousands of treatises and tracts couldn’t do, because it was popular art in which they were the children, not the adults.
More than three years after the end of the fifth series, Toei Animation announced that there were plans to make a sixth series.
[13] In the June issue of Shueisha's V Jump magazine, it was officially named "Digimon Xros Wars" and began streaming in Japan on July 6, 2010 on TV Asahi.
Digimon Xros Wars features a return to the art style from the first four series.
The story centers on a boy named Mikey Kudō (Taiki Kudo in Japan) who is transported to the Digital World along with his friends, where they meet Shoutmon and other creatures known as Digimon.

With the use of a digivice known as a Fusion Loader (Xros Loader in Japan), Mikey can combine multiple Digimon into one, significantly increasing his strength and power, with Shoutmon normally as the center of the DigiFuse process (Digi-Xros in Japan).

Mikey, Shoutmon, and their army, Team Fusion Fighters (Team Xros Heart in Japan), travel throughout the Digital World in order to free it from the evil Bagra Army (Bagra Empire in Japan), along with other enigmatic evil organizations like Midnight (an underground evil organization led by AxeKnightmon with Nene as the figurehead until she joins the Fusion Fighters) and the blue army, whose leader is rival Christopher Aonuma (Kiriha Anouma in Japan).

In the second arc of the story, "The Evil Death Generals and the Seven Kingdoms" (The Evil Death Generals of the Seven Kingdoms in Japan), the main cast don badges with new attire while Angie (Akari in Japan) and Jeremy (Zenjiro in Japan) remain in the Human World, and Mikey, Christopher, and Nene are the main heroes as they battle over the seven Death Generals of the Bagra Army along with AxeKnightmon's new partner, Nene's younger brother Ewan (Yuu in Japan).
While the series' lighter tone resembles that of the first, second, and fourth series, Super Digivolution is introduced at the end of the first arc.

The official English dub of the series began on September 7, 2013, on Nickelodeon under the title Digimon Fusion, produced by Saban Brands.[14][15] Lord Bagra is known as Bagramon in the original Japanese version.
The Organic Act establishing the Montana Territory was passed by the U.S. on April 26, 1864.
Even before Montana was officially a territory, schools were being formed by the families that settled there.
The first schools began as subscription schools, usually taught in their home by the schoolmistress.
The first such school was taught in 1862 by Mr. Robinson in Fort Owen in the Bitterroot Valley.
Classes were for children of the men employed at Fort Owen and the Indian children.
The school started in the early winter and finished on February 28. In 1863, Thomas Dimsdale opened a subscription school in Virginia City.
He charged his students $1.75 per week. In 1864, the first session of the Montana Territorial Legislative Assembly was held.
The first legislature enacted that counties would use taxes for schools. This set up the basis for public schools in Montana. Madison County was the first county to benefit from the school taxes.
The first public schools were established in Virginia City in 1886. The county set aside $500 for building maintenance.
The schools were set to open on January 1, 1866, but blizzards and storms prevented the teachers from starting until March of the same year.
The weather prompted the school to remain open during the whole summer. The session ended on August 17, 1866. One of the first schoolmistresses was Sarah Raymond.
She was 25 years old and had come by wagon train in 1865. Both Raymond and a Mrs. Farley held classes.
They had 81 enrolled, averaging 50 to 60 students daily. Raymond's salary was $125 while Mrs. Farley earned $75.
Raymond passed the test to become a teacher at her home and paid $6 in gold dust for a certificate to teach.
The ladies did not have textbooks. Instead the students used books the emigrants had brought with them.
Raymond discontinued teaching the following year but later became superintendent of schools for Madison County.

Members of the Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements in China, including pro-democracy activist Szeto Wah, shouted their support with novelty inflatable plastic Olympic flames on the relay route, saying they represented democracy and redress of the Tiananmen Square protests of 1989, and for the democracy in Hong Kong.
Pro-democracy activist and Legislative Councilor Leung Kwok-hung Longhair participated,[16] saying, "I'm very proud that in Hong Kong we still have people brave enough to speak out.
"[17] Pro-democracy protestors were taunted and insulted by torch supporters with slogans such as "running dog", "traitor", "get out!

", and "I love the Communist Party".[18] Around 10 Civil Human Rights Front unfurled orange banners calling for greater respect of human rights and implementation of universal suffrage – only to have bystanders shout at them in Mandarin, "Aren't you Chinese?" before shielding the orange banner with a large Chinese national flag.
[19] A woman held up an orange placard saying "Olympic flame for democracy" and a man held up a poster showing a tank and saying "One world, two dreams".
[20] Former RDHK radio host university student Christina Chan draped the Tibetan snow lion flag around her shoulders and waved it.
Several bystanders jeered her yelled: "What kind of Chinese are you?" and "What a shame!"
Chan and several other demonstrators were bundled into police van for protection.
[21][22] Chan is suing the Hong Kong government for violation of her human rights (HCAL139/08).
